The only plausible explanation of the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich paid him more than he was bound to pay is that he was not paying under a legal obligation, but for  krysha .   iv)\tIt was difficult to accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was unaware of these issues at the time.  The fact that he initially demanded $30 million a year, and called for the first payments in early 1995, reinforced the point.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky accepted in his oral evidence that, whilst he could not recall having discussed the figure of $30 million, he could not exclude the possibility that he had. On the other hand, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, submitted as follows in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s purposes in 1995:\r   i)\tThere was no reason for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky: "\xc2\x85  not  to enter into a partnership agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich under which they would share ownership of shares acquired in Sibneft, and the profits of ownership and control" [143] . ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s contentions about the agreement between himself and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich were entirely characteristic of the way that the loans-for-shares scheme was known to have operated in other cases, where the individual with the political influence to secure the privatisation and acquisition of the particular company concerned, invariably took an interest in the company;  examples were Mr.\xc2\xa0Khodorkovsky in respect of Yukos and Mr.\xc2\xa0Potanin in respect of Norilsk Nickel and Sidanco.  Whereas Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, on the other hand, postulated that: "\xc2\x85 the acquisition of Sibneft was a unique instance unlike any other loans-for-shares deal, in which control of the company was acquired solely by an individual (Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich) who did not have the political connections to secure the privatisation and acquisition himself, was not either an oligarch or a Red Director of Sibneft, and relied for political support on another individual (Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) who, uniquely, elected to take no interest in the company he was expected to secure.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich also contends that the Sibneft acquisition was unique in that the group which controlled the lender under the loans-for-shares auction (Messrs Abramovich, Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili) did not acquire ownership of those shares when they were sold, but allowed them to pass to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich alone." [144]   iii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Sumption\'s argument that a partnership agreement of the kind alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would not in fact have served Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s purposes, namely to generate cash, because Sibneft itself did not make profits for some years was no more than a "rehash" of the ill-founded pleading point that the partnership alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should be treated as one that limited Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to an entitlement to share in the profits of Sibneft rather than in those "profits generated by the partners thanks to their control of Sibneft, which is what the agreement was really about [145] ". iv)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky knew full well that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had the potential to make money out of Sibneft between 1996 and 2000, wholly separately from (and in excess of) the declared profits of Sibneft.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own evidence was:   "I explained that there was the potential to make a lot of money by consolidating control over these companies and directing their sales through my Trading Companies \xc2\x85.  Although I gathered from our conversation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky knew little about the oil industry, he was clearly excited by the prospect of a business which had excellent potential for the creation of substantial and regular cash flows"  [146] . v)\tThis supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s contention that his purpose was to obtain a partnership interest, not merely in Sibneft dividends, but in the profits generated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s control of, or involvement with, Sibneft.   Conclusions in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s purpose My conclusions in relation to this issue are as follows:  \r   i)\tWhat occurred in relation to other major State-owned industrial businesses included in the loans-for-shares scheme, or which were otherwise privatised at about the same time [147] , is of very little assistance in my determination of this case.  Not only were the facts relating to each case very different, but also it is impossible to predicate, from the limited information available in relation to such transactions, that the terms governing Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s arrangements were, or were likely, to be the same.  It was not possible to draw useful parallels between the three other cases relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, where oligarchs had acquired majority stakes in major industrial businesses;  such comparisons as could be made were wholly inconclusive in relation to the issues which I have had to decide.   ii)\tThere was nothing in the evidence to suggest that, in 1995, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had any commercial interest in acquiring an ownership interest in what had been poorly performing State-owned companies, with large accumulated debts.  He certainly had no interest in participating in any way in the management of Sibneft or in transforming its acquired businesses into profit-making ventures.  On the contrary, on my analysis of the evidence, his interest and purpose in entering into the arrangements with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was to secure a future cash flow stream.  That explains why he was interested in the amount that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies could generate and not in what might ultimately be the profits generated by Sibneft itself.   These findings support Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, and undermine that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.\r   vii)\tThe alleged 1996 Agreement This topic is not strictly a topic of circumstantial evidence, since whether there was an agreement reached in 1996 in the terms alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in paragraph C37 of the Re-re-re-Amended Particulars of Claim is one of the defined issues in the Agreed List of Issues.  However, it is convenient, chronologically and logically, to deal with it at this stage.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case was that between March and June 1996, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made clear to him that he felt very strongly that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should distance himself from Sibneft, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was so involved in politics and that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should be secret partners, without their names appearing on any documents relating to ownership of Sibneft.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky says that he agreed to this on the terms set out in paragraph C37, namely\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would arrange matters so that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, or his companies, was the legal owner of all the Sibneft shares which had been acquired prior to the 1995 Agreement; ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would continue to have the rights and interests which they had acquired pursuant to the 1995 Agreement in the shares that would be held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich; iii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would, upon request, transfer to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili shares equivalent to their interest in Sibneft on the basis of the percentage split referred to above; iv)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would continue to be entitled to dividends and any other payments made by Sibneft to its owners on the basis of the percentage split referred to above; v)\tthereafter any further acquisitions of Sibneft shares would be held on the same basis. Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case was supported not only by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence, but also by the following evidentiary materials:\r   i)\tthe evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, in particular as recorded in the proof of evidence recorded by Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim; ii)\tthe Le Bourget recording; iii)\tthe evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Khodorkovsky, who gave an interview consistent with the approach set out under the alleged 1996 Agreement (recognising Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interest in Sibneft but declining to acknowledge that he owned a stake in it); iv)\tthe numerous public statements denying Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky interests in Sibneft. Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz further submitted that the rationale of the alleged 1996 Agreement strongly supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case because, early in 1996, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s public association with Sibneft presented a real threat to the business.  He submitted that an analysis of the evidence showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was acutely aware of the potential risks of being seen to associate too closely with a person as politically active, and thus politically exposed, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.\r   In support of his arguments that there was a strong rationale for the making of the alleged 1996 Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz referred to the following matters:\r   i)\tthe fact that 1996 was a Presidential election year, a year in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was particularly closely involved in politics; ii)\tthe agreement of the historical experts to the propositions that: a)\tRussian businesses were subject to substantial levels of political risk, both before and after the 1996 Presidential elections, and that the risks included attacks by local and national government agencies on businesses controlled by political rivals; b)\tprominence, while it could bring benefits, could also subject individual businessmen to increased risks; c)\tthe fact that, in the volatile political situation of 1996, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could not be sure whether (even if President Yeltsin were re-elected) Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would end up as a friend or foe of the Kremlin.  For example, President Yeltsin\'s  Midnight Diaries  showed just how realistic these fears were:  they tell of the conflict, between the first and second round of elections, between President Yeltsin\'s two groups of supporters (the FSB supporters led by Mr.\xc2\xa0Korzhakov, and the "analytical group" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky);  Ms.\xc2\xa0Dyachenko protected Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, and President Yeltsin demanded Mr.\xc2\xa0Korzhakov\'s resignation.  But, if this middle of the night stand-off had ended differently, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could have become a political liability for Sibneft, even if President Yeltsin had nonetheless secured re-election. On the other hand, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case was that no distinct agreement had been made in 1996, and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the alleged 1996 Agreement had been devised when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had persuaded himself that shares in Sibneft had originally been acquired and held by NFK (the successful bidder in the loans-for-shares auction, half of which was owned by Consolidated Bank).\r   In support of that contention, Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted that, on that basis, it was necessary for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to explain how the Sibneft shares later came to be held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies in a manner consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky continuing to be interested in them.  The alleged 1996 Agreement was devised to serve as this explanation.  In what were referred to as the "re-drafted Particulars of Claim", as served on 8 January 2008 [148] , Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged that in 1996 there had been an agreement to transfer "his" and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s shares from his own companies to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies, to be held on trust for him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption referred to paragraphs 35-38 of the Particulars of Claim which alleged:\r   "35.\tThis ownership interest in Sibneft was acquired in summary as follows: (1)\tThe original issued share capital of Sibneft was 4,516,396,20 shares. (2)\tBy Decree Number 972 of the Government of the Russian Federation, dated 29 September 1995, the Russian Government approved a privatisation plan whereby 51% of Sibneft\'s shares would be issued and transferred into state ownership for three years, and the remaining 49% of the shares would be sold by commercial tender at auction. (3)\tBy a Decree made on or around 30 October 1995, the Russian Government proposed to auction the right to enter into a \'Loans for Shares\' agreement in respect of the 51% of Sibneft shares retained in state ownership, under which a creditor would loan money to the state and manage the state\'s shareholding, and at the end of a period of three years the share would, if the state failed to repay the loan, be transferred to the lender. (4)\tA company owned and controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Neftyanaya Finansovaya Kompaniya (\'Petroleum Financial Company\') (\'NFK\'), made a bid of $100.3 million in conjunction with Stolichny Savings Bank, and this bid was announced as successful on 28 December 1995. (5)\tThe remaining 49% of the shares were sold by auctions commencing in January 1996.  The majority of these shares were acquired by entities owned or controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich. (6)\tIn May 1997, NFK transferred its rights to manage the shares to Finansovaya Neftyanaya Korporatsiya (\'Financial Petroleum Corporation\') (\'FNK\'), another company owned and controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich. (7)\tIn about October 1998, the State failed to repay the loan, and its 51% shareholding was transferred to FNK as envisaged in the Decree pleaded in subparagraph (3) above. (8)\tOn 16 December 1998, Sibneft issued another 224,093,389 shares to various minority shareholders of Sibneft\'s subsidiary companies. (9)\tAt all material times after December 1998, the share capital of Sibneft was 4,741,229,639 shares.  Approximately 86% of the issued share capital had been acquired by entities on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich." The manner in which the shares were held 36.\tInitially, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili legally owned or controlled companies which controlled and legally owned their proportions of the Sibneft shares.  However, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky became more heavily involved in politics, and while Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili continued to manage the largest and most influential TV channel, ORT, it was decided and agreed between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would be distanced from the Sibneft business.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich proposed that all shares held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should be  transferred  legally to him or to entities under his ownership or control. 37.\tIt was orally agreed between the three by 1996 that: (1)\tsuch a  transfer  would take place; (2)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would continue to beneficially own the shares so transferred, which would be held  on trust for them  by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich; (3)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would continue to be entitled to receive dividends and to any other payments made by Sibneft to its  beneficial  owners on the basis of the percentage split referred to above. (4)\tthereafter any further acquisitions of Sibneft shares would be hold on the same basis. 38.\tBy about August 1997, this agreement had been implemented and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s shareholding  had been transferred  to and was legally owned or controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or by companies owned or controlled by him, the beneficial ownership of that shareholding held on trust by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the agreed proportions set out at paragraph 34 above." [emphasis supplied]" Accordingly, Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted, the assertion in the first sentence of paragraph 36 was inaccurate, because:\r   i)\tThe Sibneft shares which were acquired through the cash auctions of the 49% of the company\'s share capital, and in the default auction relating to the 51%, had always been controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies, and had never been legally owned by NFK. ii)\tThis remained Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case until shortly before the strike-out application, in July 2009, by which time it had become clear: a)\tthat any alleged trust-type agreement would be governed by Russian law;  and b)\tthat Russian law did not recognise the concept of a trust or a beneficial interest. iii)\tIn fact, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky accepted, no shares in Sibneft were ever held by companies controlled by him or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  With this discovery, the alleged 1996 Agreement lost its entire commercial rationale, and became redundant.  There was no need for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to be "distanced" from Sibneft by having their shares held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies, because all the shares that by 1996 had been sold (apart from a small number sold to other purchasers in the first private auction) had been held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies from the outset. iv)\tIn response to the summary judgment application, Dr.\xc2\xa0Rachkov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Russian law expert, came to his aid by suggesting that the representative capacity in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was said to have held the shares under the alleged 1995 Agreement could be derived, notwithstanding the absence of any concept of trust in Russian law, from the terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement, by classifying the latter as a "joint activity" agreement, or a  sui generis  agreement in Russian law.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky then amended his account of the alleged 1996 Agreement, to remove any suggestion of original ownership or control on his part, and then transfer of, any shares.  The difficulty for him was that, on the case currently pleaded, the alleged 1996 Agreement made no difference to the parties\' relationship, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written opening expressly acknowledged [149] .  The only possible conclusion, submitted Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had invented it in order to meet an imaginary difficulty, and persisted with it for the sole purpose of salvaging his credibility. v)\tEven on the footing that the alleged 1996 Agreement changed something, the alleged rationale for the change made no sense, given the political circumstances prevailing in Russia in early 1996, and the fact that, even after the alleged 1996 Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not distanced from Sibneft.  On the contrary, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich sought publicly to associate Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky with the company. Conclusion on the alleged 1996 Agreement I have little or no hesitation in rejecting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on the alleged 1996 Agreement.  My reasons can be summarised as follows:\r   i)\tThe evidence which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky gave in cross-examination in relation to the change of his pleaded case in relation to the alleged 1996 Agreement and the "transfer" of Sibneft shares legally "controlled and legally owned" by companies legally owned or controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was highly unsatisfactory.  For example, the suggestion that it was his lawyers "\xc2\x85 who change[d] the position", but that he "\xc2\x85 never change[d] the facts" [150]  was wholly unconvincing in circumstances where one of the original alleged terms of the alleged 1996 Agreement was an agreement to transfer specified shares, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was resiling from that allegation.  Nor was his assertion that everything was left to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to "structurise", an adequate explanation for the changes to his pleaded case. ii)\tHaving heard the evidence, and reviewed the history of the various amendments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, it appears to me highly likely that the original pleading in relation to the alleged 1996 Agreement was indeed based on the mistaken assumption as to NFK\'s ownership of shares in Sibneft, and the subsequent amendments opportunistically crafted to reflect Dr.\xc2\xa0Rachkov\'s Russian law advice. iii)\tIt is difficult to see what rationale (political or otherwise) there might have been in early 1996 for the making of the alleged 1996 Agreement.  If there was going to have been some such agreement along these lines, it is surprising that the point was not raised, or such an agreement reached in the context of the first cash auction, which opened on 1 November 1995 in relation to the privatisation of the first 15% tranche of Sibneft shares.  In that auction, Runicom acquired a 12.2% shareholding.  But, as I have already described, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky took no interest in that auction, nor in how "his" shares were going to be held. iv)\tI accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, as summarised in paragraph 111 of his 3 rd  witness statement that in early 1996, and for some time thereafter, he personally had no concerns about Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s being publicly associated with Sibneft.  The fact that subsequently, in late 2000 and early 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had come to view Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as a political risk, because of the latter\'s publicly made criticisms of Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin\'s governance, is no reason why he should have adopted such a stance earlier. v)\tIn fact, by the time that the alleged 1996 Agreement is supposed to have been made, it was common knowledge that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was publicly associated with Sibneft, as he accepted in his evidence.  Although he had no shareholding, he had taken a very public part in the loans-for-shares auction, on behalf of NFK;  he had given press interviews on the results of the loans-for-shares scheme. vi)\tI was not persuaded by the other "wider" political points made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, based on the expert evidence about political risk in Russia at the time.  Whilst, no doubt, prominence or high profile of the type enjoyed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or other oligarchs might have exposed them to increased risk of attack from government, that was not, of itself, any reason in the circumstances for the making of the alleged 1996 Agreement. vii)\tNor was I impressed by the argument that there was a need to distance Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky because of the risk that the Communists might win the next election.  If that eventuality happened, it would have made little difference whether or not Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was publicly associated with Sibneft. viii)\tThe fact that, after the alleged 1996 Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not, in fact, distanced from Sibneft was also wholly inconsistent with his case.  As I have already described, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made arrangements to have Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky publicly associated with PK-Trast in advance of the second cash auction in September 1996;  in the same month, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was appointed to the board of Sibneft (resigning in December 1996, upon his appointment to the Security Council);  in June 1997, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili became a director of Sibneft, remaining on the board until 1999.  I was not impressed with the suggestion in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s appointment to the Sibneft board was designed to divert attention from his alleged shareholding.  The appointment appeared to have the opposite effect, so far as contemporary press reports were concerned.  Subsequently, in August 1997, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s close association with the management of Sibneft was expressly referred to in the Saloman Brothers Eurobond circular for Sibneft, as described in greater detail below.  In January 1998, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appeared at the very public ceremony at the LogoVAZ Club, where the merger "heads of terms" between Sibneft and Yukos were signed, a fact which was also widely reported in the press. ix)\tWhilst what is stated in paragraph 25 of Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim\'s proof of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s evidence dated 7 December 2007 offers  prima facie  support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the alleged 1996 Agreement, I attach little weight to such evidence, for the reasons set out below. x)\tLikewise, I do not consider I am assisted by the Le Bourget transcript, or the various public statements denying Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interests in Sibneft, or by the interview given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Khordorkovsky. xi)\tThe critical issue here is whether an oral agreement in the terms alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was made in early 1996.  Ultimately, that depends on my assessment of the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich about the matter, and their general credibility, albeit evaluated in context.  I have no hesitation in preferring the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on this point.  Even if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz sought to argue [151] , the alleged 1996 Agreement did affect the position of the parties, because they thereby agreed that the shares should be held in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s name, and such agreement therefore had some real, albeit limited, commercial function, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence in relation to the alleged 1996 Agreement was unimpressive. It follows that I decide Agreed Issue 3 in the negative.  There was no such agreement as alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.\r   (viii) \tThe conduct of the parties between 1995 and 2000 (b):  whether any payments were made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili prior to 1996 (ix)\tThe conduct of the parties between 1995 and 2000 (c):  the nature of the payments of the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili between 1995 and 2000  and whether they were referable to 50% of (a) Sibneft\'s profits or (b) Sibneft\'s profits and profits generated indirectly through Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies as a result of his acquisition of control of, or involvement with, Sibneft I take these two topics together as, to a certain extent the relevant evidence is common to both.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s pleaded case is that it was agreed that he would "\xc2\x85 be entitled to dividends and to any other payments made by Sibneft to its owners" [152] .  As I have already explained, and contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission [153] , there was no pleaded case that one of the  express  terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement was to the effect that profits earned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich through other corporate entities, as a result of the latter\'s trading with Sibneft, or as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich having acquired control of, or involvement with, Sibneft, should be split 50:50.  Likewise, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s 4th witness statement did not suggest that there had been any agreement to share profits made by other corporate entities.  \r   Again, as I have already explained, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s oral evidence, however, was that it was  expressly  agreed that he (and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili) would be entitled to all profits "in respect of our share of Sibneft", whether generated directly by Sibneft or indirectly through, or as the result of any trading connection between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies and, Sibneft.  This was the way in which the case was formulated in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written and oral closing submissions:  for example at paragraph 401 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing, his evidence was summarised as follows:\r   "Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky made it clear that it was his understanding that his entitlement to Sibneft profits extended to profits derived from owning Sibneft, however and by whatever corporate vehicle Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich caused them to be earned." Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, in closing [154] , submitted that there was nothing adverse to be inferred by the absence of any pleading of such an express term, since such a term would in any event be implied as a term of any Russian partnership agreement.  I disagree.  If indeed such a term was the subject of an express oral agreement under the terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement, I would have expected it to have been pleaded, or at the least referred to, in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s principal witness statement for trial.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky admitted in his oral evidence that he did not "know at all" what relation his payments bore to Sibneft\'s profits, or indeed the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  The evidence showed that he never did know, and took no steps to find out;  he said that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili who informed him.  He suggested that there were regular meetings between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, but then admitted that he did not know what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did to ascertain the profits of Sibneft.  He said that he was "[d]efinitely not" interested in knowing how large Sibneft\'s profits were.  \r   The dispute between the parties in relation to payments made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich principally focused on:  \r   i)\twhether any payments were made prior to 1996;   ii)\twhether the payments were referable to Sibneft\'s profits or to profits generated indirectly through Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies as a result of his control or involvement with Sibneft;  and iii)\twhether the fact that payments were made to both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky submitted that:\r   i)\tthat there was no credible evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made any  krysha  payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in 1995;  the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s team to the effect that payments were made under the alleged 1995 Agreement before 1996 was "clearly untrue" because it was evidence which was: a)\tthe product of collusion between witnesses; b)\treconstructed, following disclosure, from documents without any genuine recollection on the witnesses\' part;   c)\tin parts, demonstrably false.   ii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on the alleged 1995 Agreement (i.e. that it conferred upon him an interest in Sibneft shares or a right to such an interest) found support in:   a)\tthe beneficiary of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s payments - being (according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  and b)\tthe quantum of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s payments - being (according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) correlated with the profits made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his Trading Companies as a result of his influence and control of Sibneft.   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, on the other hand, contended that he paid Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili sums in the region of $ 20-30,000,000 in 1995, and that neither those payments, nor payments made to him and to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili between 1995 and 2000, bore any relation to Sibneft\'s profits or to those profits combined with the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  He submitted that the fact that payments were made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as well as to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, was not consistent only with the partnership relationship alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  on the contrary, that fact was also consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s  krysha  allegation.  \r   General evidence about the payments made from 1995-2000 The evidence in relation to these two topics, to the extent to which it was (largely) un-controversial, can be summarised as follows:  \r   i)\tThe amounts paid to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili actually came from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, not from Sibneft itself.   ii)\tThe amounts involved could not be precisely calculated, except for the year 2000, because of the absence of records.  In the case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, that was variously because the businesses whose records would be relevant had been liquidated or were no longer under his control, or hard copies of records no longer existed as a result of explicable routine destruction or loss.  I reject the allegation made on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky [155]  that the absence at trial of documents pre-dating 2000 in relation to the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was the result of a "deliberate policy of document destruction" on the part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich "in order to impede investigations into his dealings".  There was a considerable body of evidence to show that this was not the case.  I find there to have been nothing sinister in the absence of such records on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s part.   iii)\tIn the case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, the absence of documentation (although some records relating to payment were produced by him) was largely explained by the fact that he had lost many documents in his flight from Russia, and because other records have been impounded by judicial authorities in the course of various money-laundering investigations.   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky accepted that substantial payments were made to him and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili between 1996 and 2000;  he did not put forward a positive case as to the ballpark figures but was reluctant to accept that the sums put forward in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence were the sums which had been paid, although the figures for 1996-8 were presented by him as accurate to the French investigating judge in evidence given in June 2011 in the context of a judicial investigation into alleged money-laundering [156] .  \r   The evidence put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his witnesses showed the following profits or losses for Sibneft and the following payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili for the relevant years:\r   All figures in $ millions All figures in $ millions All figures in $ millions \xc2\xa0 Sibneft BB/AP \xc2\xa0 Profits (Losses) Receipts 1995 (206) 20-30 [157] 1996 (2.3) 80-85 1997 68 70 1998 36 50 1999 315 50 2000 675 490 The figures given in the table for Sibneft profits were derived from the audited annual group financial statements.  In cross examination Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asserted that the audited financial statements did not reflect the true profits of Sibneft, on the grounds that the trial of Mr.\xc2\xa0Khodorkovsky in 2003 showed that Russian oil companies generally transferred profits to connected entities by way of artificial transfer pricing, apparently in order to reduce their taxable profits [158] .  I deal with this assertion below.  \r   The figures given in the table for the years 1995-1999 were based upon estimates provided by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova of sums which she handled on his behalf.  For 1997, the table added to Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova\'s estimates a further 96.5 million French Francs and $4.35 million, approximating $20 million in total, which was paid by Runicom SA in that year for expenses associated with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s property at Cap d\'Antibes.  These payments were not handled by Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova.  The quantum of the French expenses paid in 1997 were confirmed by Hans-Peter Jenni ("Mr.\xc2\xa0Jenni"), a Swiss lawyer, who acted as legal and business adviser to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky from about 1991 and to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from about the same date to February 2008, and whose firm dealt with some of the administrative arrangements.  For the year 2000, the figures were derived from an extant spreadsheet (the "Bolshoi Balance"), prepared under the supervision of Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko on the instructions of Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler [159] .  This spreadsheet gave a detailed breakdown by categories of payee and by month.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko explained that the total payments made to Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili or their companies in 2000 were contained in a table described as "the FOM table".\r   Except for the payments allegedly made in 1995, these estimates were not seriously disputed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  His case as to what he was in fact paid was unclear.  According to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, "Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky does not in fact assert a case as to what precisely he was paid in these years".  It appeared to be that he did "no[t] dispute at all that the sums were paid", but:\r   "do[es] not accept \xc2\x85 that those particular sums that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich asserts were paid were in fact the sums that were paid" [160] . He did not put forward a positive case even as to a ballpark figure which he accepted he received. Conclusion as to whether any payments were made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili prior to 1996 The only real issue on the figures related to whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had received any payments in 1995.  He denied receiving anything in that year pursuant to his version of the alleged 1995 Agreement.  Such denial was consistent with his case that the payments represented Sibneft profits, or related to profits derived from the acquisition or control of Sibneft, since Sibneft was not formed until October 1995 and management control of the company was not acquired until the following year.  But since he claimed to have no precise recollection of dates or figures, and said that he did not concern himself with the details of payments which he received, because this was left to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, his own evidence was not of much assistance on this issue.  He was unable to give any satisfactory explanation in cross-examination for payments which certain documents showed had been made to him or LogoVAZ in 1995, including a sum of $4 million paid in September 1995.  His suggestion that payments were made to LogoVAZ because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies had bought cars for its employees was unconvincing, and was, I find, rebutted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in his oral evidence.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova gave evidence about the 1995 payments.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich recalled an initial payment of $8 million in early 1995.  He recalled a further payment of $10 million in the autumn, $4 million of which was paid directly to LogoVAZ.  In cross-examination he also referred to a cash payment of $16,000 made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to enable him to pay off a debt to a Mr.\xc2\xa0Denisov and a payment made a couple of months later of a further $50,000.  \r   Ms Goncharova recalled dealing with payments from early 1995 until late 2000 [161] .  She said that she was instructed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to make a payment to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky of around $5 million in cash in early 1995.  In her oral evidence, she gave a graphic and wholly credible account of personally delivering approximately $5 million of US dollars in banknotes in a holdall to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at the LogoVAZ Club between February and March 1995 in instalments of $1 million and $500,000.  She was able to pinpoint early 1995 as the relevant date, because it was around the time that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s staff had just moved into their new office premises.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova\'s recollection as to the timing was also consistent with the evidence that ORT was in desperate need of money in 1995.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler also gave evidence about a payment of $1 million paid by Runicom SA to Atrium Consolidated Limited on 6 December 1995.  There was no dispute that such a payment was made, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky disclosed a document showing that it had been.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence was that Atrium was connected to Mr.\xc2\xa0Aven, to whom Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky allegedly owed a debt.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s team asserting that payments were made under the 1995 Agreement before 1996 was:  \r   "\xc2\x85 clearly untrue.  It was evidence which was (1) the product of collusion between witnesses;  (2) reconstructed, following disclosure, from documents without any genuine recollection;  and (3) in parts, demonstrably false." In particular he submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had changed his case about the basis on which payments were made, because reference was made in the Defence, and the evidence served in support of the summary judgment application, only to payments in respect of ORT and that the specific payments which were:\r   "\xc2\x85 now alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to have been made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, or at their direction, prior to 1995, were not ORT payments". Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested that this posed a problem for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, because in evidence served in support of his strike-out application, by Paul Mitchard, a partner at Skadden, there was no reference to any payments unconnected with ORT.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that, on the contrary, the statement made clear that only ORT-related payments were alleged;  that was despite all of the major witnesses to payments - Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova, Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk - having been interviewed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Mitchard.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz sought to point the contrast between the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s witnesses at the summary judgment stage and that given in their written witness statements, claiming that payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were  krysha  payments to cover Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s "personal expenses", and not limited to ORT-related payments.  He said that this was as the consequence of collusion between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s witnesses.  The various witnesses were cross-examined by him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Gillis to this effect.  \r   I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s attack on the veracity of the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s witnesses in this respect.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case had always been that the agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky arose  in the context of  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky needing to meet the cash flow requirements of ORT, so that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could use his control over the TV station to maintain his political power and influence.  As both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler said in their written and oral evidence, the great majority of the funds constituting $30 million paid in the first year did in fact go to ORT, but the scope of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s demands expanded over time, so that there was a gradual increase in the proportion of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s personal expenditure that was being funded by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  It was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence that, by 1997, his entire personal expenditure was in fact being funded by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not involved in ORT and had no particular reason to be concerned about whether or not the money was strictly being applied for ORT purposes.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky has never alleged that it was a term of the alleged 1995 Agreement that the money paid to him had to be applied for ORT purposes.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s concern was with the amounts, not with what the purpose to which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky applied the funds.  \r   In his written evidence [162] , Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler described the changing position as follows:  \r   "129.\tHowever, before long, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky began to widen the scope even further and there was a sense of \'ORT Project\' or rather \'Project Boris\' i.e. we were expected to meet all the expenses that went along with elevating and maintaining Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s position as a powerful and wealthy man.  This was supposed to be our \'insurance policy\' to make sure that we retained our control of Sibneft.  We paid for his house in the South of France as part of Project Boris.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told me at the time that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had asked for money for a house in the South of France, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had said he needed for entertaining consistent with being the controller of a major TV company.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would regularly send us invoices related to other businesses or for personal items, on the basis that it was necessary to enhance his standing." And, in cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler said:   "I think whatever Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky says was ORT was ORT". I have no doubt that this was the case.   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s arguments, in my judgment, placed undue semantic emphasis on what was said by Mr.\xc2\xa0Mitchard (who was not involved in the actual events) at the pre-disclosure, summary judgment stage.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his witnesses gave credible oral explanations as to how their evidence came to be summarised by Mr.\xc2\xa0Mitchard at that early stage.  As I have said earlier in this judgment, this was a case where the evidence given by witnesses in oral cross-examination and re-examination was on the whole more reliable - in the sense of more nearly approximating the truth - than what was said in closely crafted witness statements on earlier interlocutory occasions.  \r   I also reject the suggestion, put to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova in cross-examination, that the 1995 payments were a recent invention or emerged as a result of collusion.  These payments were not required to be specifically pleaded, and were mentioned on the first occasion on which evidence on the merits was served on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s behalf.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Mitchard\'s third witness statement (served for the summary judgment application) states on the basis of information provided by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that the payments began "\xc2\x85 in the first half of 1995 before Sibneft had even been established", and that Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova had confirmed that "\xc2\x85 she was responsible for payments to ORT from about the beginning of 1995".  Nor do I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s criticisms of the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler in this context [163] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was very careful in his evidence to differentiate between what he could actually remember or "recollect", and that which he had reconstructed from documents shown to him.  Likewise I accept Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence in relation to the 1995 payments.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova\'s oral account of struggling with a heavy holdall, laden with dollars, to the LogoVAZ club, was particularly convincing, as was her dating of this trip by reference to the move to the new offices.  Nor do I find anything surprising about the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich consulted Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova, amongst other sources, about these payments, as he frankly admitted in cross-examination.  Since she was the person in charge of handling the payments, it was the obvious thing for him to do.  \r   As an example of this type of criticism, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, in his written closing submissions [164] , referred to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s cross-examination about his evidence recalling a demand in Autumn 1995 by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky for $10 million, of which $4 million was paid by Runicom SA to LogoVAZ.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz criticised Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for claiming "a mixture of recollection and reconstruction" and for the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was allegedly "unable to give an explanation" for the narrative on a Debit Advice from Runicom SA\'s bank, United Overseas Bank, Geneva, to Runicom SA showing a payment of $4 million to LogoVAZ.  The narrative read:  "Payment under Settlement Agreement".  That criticism was not justified.  The cross-examination was as follows:  \r   "Q.\tThis document does indeed show a payment from Runicom SA to LogoVAZ in September 1995 but it refers, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, to payment under a settlement agreement.  Are you suggesting that Runicom SA was issuing false invoices that misrepresented what the payments were being made for? And my question to you, if you\'re suggesting that this was not a payment being made under a settlement agreement, is whether your suggestion is that Runicom SA were issuing false invoices that misrepresented what the payments were being made for? A.\tNow, if I understand you correctly, this settlement agreement - or that name, it\'s a very broad term, and I\'m sure that that document was executed at that time because otherwise the bank, the paying bank, would not have accepted this payment and would not have made the payment.  So there is nothing false about it. Q.\tSo is your evidence now that this payment was made as a result of some agreement called the settlement agreement between Runicom SA and LogoVAZ? A.\tI can only speculate.  It\'s been a long time and it\'s very hard for me to recall.  But if it says what it is, then this is what it is.  But I can comment why that money was needed. Q.\tWhat I\'m interested in is why it was paid, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, because if you say there was a settlement agreement and it was paid as a result of a settlement agreement, then I suggest to you that is not consistent with this being paid as  krysha . A.\tIf I recall correctly, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky demanded that that payment be made and he needed this in order to pass it on to Mr.\xc2\xa0K[h]orzakhov [165]  later on.  Part of it was paid in hard cash and part of it was in non-hard cash, i.e. bank transfer." Thus Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich not only gave an explanation of the narrative on the debit note, but also gave one which was wholly consistent with the payment being of a  krysha  nature.  Indeed, vague, broad-brush wording, such as "Settlement Agreement", is just the type of wording one might expect a payer to use to describe a payment destined to secure political influence, in circumstances where, on the one hand, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described, the payer needed to convince the bank that the payment was legitimate so that it would effect payment, and, on the other, might wish to conceal from the bank the true nature of the payment.  Whilst such description is one that might justifiably be open to criticism in a Western accounting context, as providing a false explanation, its use was understandable in the circumstances.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky speculated in his evidence that this payment might have been for motor cars purchased by Runicom SA from LogoVAZ, but that suggestion was rebutted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, which on this point I accept.  \r   In his written closing submissions [166] , Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also suggested that Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova\'s evidence "had been exposed as untrue";  because, it was said, she had referred to an assistant of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s called Ivan;  and because, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, following this evidence:\r   "\xc2\x85 had been able to locate the employment records for \'Ivan\' - Ivan Surov - who worked at the LogoVAZ club." The assertion was made that: "Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov was first employed on 4 December 1996, very much later than the time when Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova claims to have interacted with him there" and accordingly "her recollection was false".  However the documents produced by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not in fact demonstrate that Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov was employed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (or entities associated with him) only as from December 1996.  On the contrary, what the documents produced by him and other documents suggested was:   i)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov was first employed by an entity called Novokuznetskaya Street House CJSC as from December 1996;   ii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov had previously been employed by a company called JSC Engineering [167] , which appears to have been associated with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and to have been a subsidiary of LogoVAZ;   iii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov had been employed in the same job as an administrator from September 1988 [168] . This evidence was not put to Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova and no application was made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz to have her recalled or to adduce further evidence relating to the date when Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov first started working as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assistant.  Nor do I accept the other criticisms made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz as to, for example, the late emergence of this evidence, the alleged inconsistencies in her evidence, and the absence of any cross-examination of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s witnesses in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Surov [169] .  This was precisely the sort of detail which one might expect to emerge in cross-examination.  I accept Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova\'s evidence in this respect.  \r   Accordingly, I conclude on the evidence that sums in the region of $20-30 million were indeed paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, or to his order, in the year 1995.  Whilst these payments could have been characterised as being consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, on the grounds, for example, that they were effectively payments on account of an entitlement to 50% of future or anticipated profits to be earned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies as a result of the acquisition of control of Sibneft, that was not the way in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky chose to address the issue.  As I have said, he simply denied that payments had been made in 1995.  In those circumstances, I conclude that the evidence in relation to the 1995 payments does indeed undermine Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the alleged 1995 Agreement.\r   Conclusion on whether the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili between 1995 and 2000 were referable to 50% of Sibneft\'s profits or the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted [170]  that the evidence suggested that the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili  were , consistently with the alleged 1995 Agreement,  actually calculated  as 50% of the profits generated from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s influence and control of Sibneft, as a result of his alleged partnership with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  He also submitted [171]  that the quantum of such payments  correlated  with the profits made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich "as a result of his control of Sibneft".  In support of these contentions, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted as follows:  \r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own case was that in 1995 he expected to make about $60 million from his influence gained over the companies to be placed into Sibneft, by increasing his profits from $40 million to $100 million, and expected to pay about $30 million to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  although it was controversial whether any such payments were actually made, the expectation that he would pay 50% of his generated profits to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was plainly consistent with the 1995 Agreement.   ii)\tThe evidence of the Le Bourget transcript and the Bolshoi Balance demonstrated that in 2000 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich paid Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky approximately 50% of the sum which he had told them had been generated from his oil trading using Sibneft. iii)\tIt was clear, therefore, that, whatever was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s pleaded case, the focus of his argument at trial was based on an alleged correlation between what he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were paid on the one hand, and not only the profits of Sibneft (when they finally came to be earned as from 1997), but also the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies derived from their trading with, or the latter\'s "involvement with, Sibneft" [172] , on the other hand.  In essence this involved an allegation that such profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies should be treated as Sibneft profits and/or that the 50:50 profit share expressly agreed under the terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement extended to a share of the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies that were derived from his "involvement with Sibneft".   My conclusions on calculation and correlation Contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission, I conclude that the evidence did not demonstrate that the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were " actually calculated  as 50% of the profits generated from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s influence and control of Sibneft".  Nor did such evidence establish that there was in fact any  correlation  as between such payments and the profits made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a result of his control of Sibneft.  Accordingly I do not accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the alleged 1995 Agreement finds support from the evidence relating to the payments.  My reasons for this conclusion are set out below.\r   No correlation to Sibneft\'s profits First, none of the payments which were made in the period 1995-1999 were referable to Sibneft profits, as shown in its annual audited group financial statements.  Indeed this was accepted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz referred to this point as "a red herring".  However it was one that was in issue between the parties, at least at some stage during the trial, and was a point prayed in aid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  The fact that the payments were not referable to Sibneft\'s profits was shown by the following:  \r   i)\tAs I have found, the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, or his order, began in February 1995.  In that year, $20-30 million was paid before any management interest or shareholding interest in Sibneft had been acquired.   ii)\tIn 1996, Sibneft made a loss, but an estimated $50 million was nevertheless paid to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in that year.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s stake in Sibneft did not exceed 47% in 1996.   iii)\tFor 1997 and 1998, the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili exceeded the entire profits of Sibneft for the year.   iv)\t1999 and 2000 were the first years in which Sibneft\'s total profits exceeded the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  In 2000, the payments were considerably more than 50% of Sibneft\'s profits, even on the footing (asserted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky but disputed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich) that $30 million of the payments represented the latter\'s profit share in respect of RusAl.   v)\tThe absence of correlation between Sibneft\'s profits and payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have been even greater if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were right in saying that his share of the cost of acquiring Sibneft shares in the auctions of 1996 and 1997 fell to be set off against his share of profits.   vi)\tNo profits of Sibneft were distributed until the dividend of $50 million declared in November 2000, but nonetheless payments were being made throughout the year to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.   No proof of improper transfer or diversion Second, I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegation that the audited financial statements did not reflect the true profits of Sibneft on the grounds that it had improperly transferred profits to connected entities by way of artificial transfer pricing, whether in order to reduce its taxable profits or to transfer profit to certain shareholders, and that Sibneft\'s profits should therefore be treated as including the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s referred to this process as "tricked"  [173] .  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz sought to stress both during the course of the trial, and in his written closing submissions, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was  not  making any allegations about transfer pricing and sought to disavow any such allegation.  But Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence in response to questions put by Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption in cross-examination clearly suggested that he was indeed alleging that the profits on sales of the oil were improperly not being taken in Sibneft, which he accepted was not profitable, but rather being captured abroad or in one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  The following passages give a characteristic sample of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence on this point:  \r   "Q.\tSibneft didn\'t make a single penny of profits in 1996, did it? A.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, I explain you again and I agree again -- explain to you again:  they use all company, all oil company, the same way.  Company itself was not profitable but they make money trading oil abroad and selling for the other price.  Nothing changed that time. Q.\tYou have no knowledge, do you, of what the trading terms were between Sibneft and those to whom it sold export oil? You have no personal knowledge of that at all, do you? A.\tAbout how they deal -- how the -- what is technology of this deal? Q.\t\tNo.  As I understand it, the last answer that you gave was talking about transfer pricing.  Right? A.\tIt\'s different terminology.  Some use transfer pricing, some use different pricing, but I learned that only after.  I didn\'t know these words before. Q.\tYou still have not got the faintest idea, have you, of what the terms of trading were between Sibneft and those to whom it sold oil? A.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, I am sorry for this example.  When I present my PhD, I try to explain it to my mum -- she doesn\'t have this education like me -- because the sense of the problem I understand well, anyone in the world.  I heard by TV that you have the greatest mind in England, I accept that;  but believe me this is not your level, a little bit less, to understand what means to get profit from abroad when you sell in the country. Q.\tDo you actually know anything about the terms of trade between Sibneft and those to whom it sold oil? A.\tI don\'t know anything about the terms I know how it was done. Q.\tHow do you know how it was done? A.\tBecause it was common knowledge.  Every oil company, they have done the same, and Khodorkovsky is in jail because of that. Q.\tYou don\'t know at all? A.\tIt\'s common knowledge for everybody who knew a little bit.  It\'s known, it\'s common knowledge. Q.\tYou say that other companies engaged in transfer pricing and therefore you assume that Sibneft did, but you don\'t know at all, do you? A.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, I knew that at all.  Excellent.  I knew -- I don\'t knew any details but I knew the construction.  It\'s very simple and you know that [174] . \xc2\x85 Q.\tNow, you have just suggested, in the answer that you last gave, that the profits generated by Sibneft ended up with Runicom.  That\'s what I understood you to suggest. A.\t\'Ended up\'? (Consults interpreter) Sibneft itself that time did not generate the profit.  Sibneft that time generate oil and refinery of oil and sell it to Runicom and then Runicom generate the profit because Sibneft -- it was exactly what happened in Soviet Union when Sibneft was vertical-integrated company:  one company produce oil, the second company refinery oil, the third company sell oil.  The company which produce oil didn\'t get anything because they just produce oil;  that\'s it.  It\'s expensive, it\'s not a profit.  The company that refine it, they also don\'t produce the profit:  they produce the product which is profitable.  And then only on the last stage it was -- the company who sell all that, this company generate the profit.  It\'s happened at the beginning that all oil company tricked.  What does mean \'tricked\'? They sell oil and product which produced refinery company with low price,  then sell this -- produced price, then sell it to another Russian company and companies sold abroad and after that it generated profit.  It\'s what Abramovich has done and all other oil company have done [175] ." It was for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to adduce evidence to support this allegation of improper transfer pricing.  He did not do so.  His own conclusions based on disclosures in court proceedings about the affairs of Yukos, another oil company, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Khodorkovsky, were of no evidential weight.  \r   He produced no evidence to show that Sibneft\'s financial statements, audited by Arthur Andersen, in accordance with US GAAP, subject to any overriding requirements of Russian law, understated Sibneft\'s profits by excluding profits earned as a result of transfer pricing transactions, whether with connected parties or third parties.  Indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not appear to challenge them [176] .  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky acknowledged, Sibneft was one of the first major Russian companies to have its accounts audited in accordance with general accounting standards applicable in the West.  Sibneft\'s financial statements referred to "Related party transactions", (i.e. transactions between the company and its directors, managers or shareholders, or companies in which its directors, managers or shareholders have material interests).  The relevant connected parties in the case of Sibneft were Runicom SA or Runicom Ltd [177] , which were controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Sibneft sold export crude and products to Runicom SA/Runicom Ltd until 2000 when the oil trading operations were consolidated with the Sibneft group.  The accounts in the relevant period dealt specifically with transactions between Sibneft and these companies, stating, for example, the percentage of total sales made to such companies and amounts receivable from such companies.  In 1996 there was a specific statement to the effect that the sales were at market prices, although this statement did not appear in subsequent years.  The auditors would have been obliged to have noted any inappropriate transfer pricing transactions that artificially or improperly reduced Sibneft\'s profits, to the detriment of its shareholders who were not related parties.  No such irregularities were reported.  \r   The course of trading between Sibneft and Runicom SA/Runicom Ltd, which were appointed as Sibneft\'s exclusive export agents from 1995, was also described in a Sibneft Eurobond offering circular of 1997 [178] .  The accuracy of the information in the circular was verified by Salomon Brothers and Cleary Gottlieb.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who was a director of Sibneft at the time, was among those who took responsibility for it.  In summary, export crude oil was sold to Runicom SA or Runicom Ltd at world market prices less a commission of about 2% until March 1997 when the commission discounts ceased.  Products were sold at world market prices throughout.  Both companies, moreover, had other trading operations unconnected to Sibneft.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that, in addition to Sibneft, his Trading Companies obtained significant business from elsewhere, for example as exporters of Rosneft products.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that his Trading Companies did not engage in transfer pricing, and were not in a position to do so because the oil price was highly regulated [179] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler also dealt with the question of alleged "transfer pricing" in his third witness statement.  The use of ZATOs and other internal tax zones and vehicles was described by Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov [180] .  He explained the use that Sibneft made of such entities and the distribution of the amounts earned by the tax efficient companies as between the Trading Companies controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Sibneft, in such a way as to ensure that Sibneft itself was in the same financial position as it would have been if the tax efficient companies had not been used.  \r   Their evidence on these matters was not challenged in cross-examination.  The only evidence that was referred to on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf [181]  which might possibly have supported an allegation of improper transfer pricing was the 2002 Audit Chamber\'s Report (although this was referred to by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz in the different context of the quantum of receipts of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies), but Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz did not seek to rely on such report and, as I have said, expressly disavowed any allegation of improper transfer pricing.  Certainly, if such an allegation had been pursued, I would have expected evidence, expert or otherwise, to show that the Sibneft audited financial statements had either mis-stated the position, or could not be relied on to reveal the fact that the "real" profits from Sibneft\'s oil were being captured by trading counterparties.  Accordingly, I do not accept the suggestion, to the extent that it was made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, that Sibneft\'s funds or profits were improperly diverted or siphoned off to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies or tax vehicles, and therefore that, for that reason, the profits of the Trading Companies should be treated as "Sibneft\'s profits".\r   No actual correlation to 50% of the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies Notwithstanding my conclusions in relation to the transfer pricing allegation, and notwithstanding the inadequacies of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s pleaded case, I approached the matter (in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s favour) on the basis that, if there had been a profit share agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, it would have been wholly logical, from a commercial perspective, for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to have insisted on having a profit entitlement to share not only in Sibneft profits, but also in a wider pool of profits generated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  That was because:\r   i)\tfirst, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself said, one of his stated aims in acquiring control of Sibneft was to increase the profits which his own Trading Companies might generate through trading with the businesses of Noyabrskneftegaz and Omsk Oil;  and ii)\tsecondly, even absent any improper diversion of funds from Sibneft, or legitimate transfer pricing, the evidence showed that there was a substantial amount of re-organisation of the business of the previously State-run subsidiaries that would be required before Sibneft itself would be generating profits. So I have approached my determination of the issue on the basis that, if there had been a profit-sharing agreement between the three men, it was likely that any such agreement would extend to the wider profit pool. I turn, therefore, to consider whether evidence relating to the quantum of the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili supports Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s final version of the alleged 1995 Agreement [182] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument depended upon him showing an actual correlation between what he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were paid in each of the years 1995 - 2000 on the one hand, and, on the other hand, 50% of the profits generated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies that were attributable to trading with Sibneft, or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s control of, or involvement with, Sibneft.  As was pointed out in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions [183] , and accepted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, there was a considerable amount of evidence to show that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies generated very substantial profits as a result of their trading with, and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s control of, or involvement with, Sibneft.  The evidence also showed, as I have already said, that the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili came from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.\r   But my third reason for rejecting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument under this head is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was unable to demonstrate, on the evidence, that  numerically  what he and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were paid bore any, or any real, correlation to 50% of the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies derived from their trading with Sibneft or as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s control of, or involvement with, Sibneft.\r   The allegation that there was such a correlation appeared to be based on three arguments put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz:  \r   i)\tFirst, that because Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption had said in opening, as confirmed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in evidence, that: "\xc2\x85 as Sibneft prospered and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to pay more, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky demanded more" that meant that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich accepted that there was a correlation between Sibneft profits (in the expanded sense used by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) and payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  and ii)\tsecond, that because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own case was that, in 1995, he expected to make about $60 million from his influence gained over the companies to be placed into Sibneft, by increasing his profits from $40 million to $100 million, and expected to pay about $30 million to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (i.e. 50% of $60 million), that demonstrated the relevant correlation;  and although it was controversial whether any such payments were actually made in 1995, the expectation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would pay 50% of his generated profits to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was plainly consistent with the 1995 Agreement.  Indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions asserted [184] : "Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence is also  that it was agreed  that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s reward for performing his side of the bargain  would be 50% of this profit , i.e. in the first year $30 million." [Emphasis supplied] iii)\tThird, that the figures shown in the Bolshoi Balance for the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in 2000 showed the relevant correlation. I am not persuaded by either of the first two arguments.  As to the first, the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky demanded more, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies became richer, and became in a position to pay more, was not indicative of an agreed  entitlement  to participate in 50% of such profits;  nor was it any more consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case than with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case.  As to the second argument, apart from the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not accept that any payments were made to him at all in 1995, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was not " that it was agreed  that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s reward for performing his side of the bargain  would be 50% of this profit ".  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky who indicated that he would require approximately $30 million per year for ORT and his personal expenses, and that he subsequently inquired how much Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could make a year in order to satisfy himself that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could afford to pay his fee.  It was in that latter context that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich indicated that he currently generated around $40 million per year and expected to be able to increase it to around $100 million per year.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained in his witness statement \r   "I am absolutely clear that he did not fix his fee by reference to 50% of my anticipated trading income or otherwise make any reference to sharing profits." Likewise in his oral evidence Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made it clear that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not interested in how Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies would perform;  he was only interested in whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could pay $30 million:\r   "He was interested in the cashflows that I was able to provide. [185] " I accept this evidence.  It was entirely consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s lack of interest in detailed financial matters.  \r   As to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s third argument, I deal with the evidence relating to the figures shown in the Bolshoi Balance for the year 2000 below.\r   Lack of certainty as to which profits Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was entitled My fourth reason for rejecting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegation of correlation (which, indeed, applies more widely in relation to his case as to the alleged profit sharing terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement), is that his evidence was vague and uncertain as to  which  profits he claimed that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a 50% entitlement.  Even leaving to one side the absence of any pleading of this alleged express term, his case as to the relevant profit source was wholly unclear.  Was it to be a share only in the  increased  profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, generated as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich acquiring influence and control of Sibneft (as paragraph 445 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s closing, and its reference to $30 million as 50% of $60 million, would appear to suggest)? If that were so, there would, it is to be supposed, have had to have been a fairly complex annual calculation of what the Trading Companies were making prior to such acquisition (as they were already making profits and trading with Noyabrskneftegaz and Omsk Oil), followed by a calculation which stripped out those profits, as well as those generated by trading with non-Sibneft entities, from the quantification of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s 50% profit share.  On that basis, there would also have had to have been a calculation of the profits earned by Sibneft itself.  Or was the claimed share to include  all  profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, even those generated as a result of trading with non-Sibneft entities? And would a proportionate share of the losses incurred by Sibneft in 1995 and 1996 have fallen to be deducted from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s 50% share?  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence did not attempt to provide the answers to any of these questions.  \r   No attempt to conduct any correlation exercise Fifth, the evidence showed that no attempt was ever made at the time to relate the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili either to the profits of Sibneft, or to the profits made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or his Trading Companies by virtue of their trading with, or his control of, Sibneft.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, which I accept, was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was never interested in the activities of his Trading Companies or Sibneft, and that no one ever sought to audit, or verify the profits, for the purposes of distributing some defined share to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  No information was ever provided to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about Sibneft\'s profits, although they did have access to the information publicly available in the company\'s published financial statements.  Nor was any information given to them about the profits of any of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  The following passages from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s third witness statement explained the position:  \r   "69.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was never interested in the activities of my Trading Companies or Sibneft.  He was concerned only about my ability to pay and he just assumed that I would pay whatever he asked and that, if I had a cashflow problem, I would let Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili know there would be a slight delay in making payment. \xc2\x85 131.  \tFor the larger payments, it was generally Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler who, after discussing them with me, supervised the logistics, often communicating with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to make sure Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky received them.
