Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler sought to protract and delay payments where possible, as well as source them from alternating Trading Companies in such a manner that they would not disrupt their cash flows and activities. 132.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s demands were not tied to any notion of a \'share of profits\' - be it of Sibneft or any other company.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky never asked me to provide to him any official profit and loss position for either Sibneft or any other company under my control. 133.  \tHe only seemed to be interested in whether I had sufficient cash available to afford his demands for payment.  I would sometime refer to limitations in cashflow in different companies as a reason to defer payment or negotiate a proposed amount.  By the end of 2000, he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili seemed to have made their own back of the envelope calculations of what I was earning from my different businesses as a basis upon which to suggest that I had enough cash to pay their demands but again this was all about access to cash and not about profit. 134.  \tFor example, when in 1998 the oil prices hit the all-time-low of about $8 per barrel, and I was losing money in the oil business, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky still expected me to pay his demands, and I had to do so. 135.  \tI never got involved in the details of payments and I do not remember the specifics of the 1997-1999 credit agreements alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky but from the amounts and the currency, these could relate to the French property he asked me to purchase for him.  I have some recollection that the idea for providing Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky loans instead of cash payments might have originated from his desire to avoid French transaction taxes." Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence supported that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  I accept their evidence on this point. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said in his oral evidence that he did not know how much money was paid to him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and that the latter was responsible for checking Sibneft\'s profits [186] :  \r   "Q.\tNow, you say that these payments represented your share of Sibneft\'s profits.  How do you know that? A.\tI don\'t know that at all.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told me that he has obligations to hold my shares and to pay me according of profit which these shares generate finally. Q.\tWhat steps -- A.\tI didn\'t have any idea how much company generate and so.  Again, mainly -- not mainly -- Badri was responsible to cooperate with Abramovich for checking how is everything going and time to time Badri put me that,  \'Boris, everything is going well\'". But Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could not identify any steps taken by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to ascertain the figures [187] .  The following gives an example of his evidence in this respect: "MRS JUSTICE GLOSTER:  My question for you is this:  was there any formal or informal process whereby Badri or you, or staff on your behalf, would audit the profits that were being generated by Sibneft? A.\tI don\'t know anything about formal process.  I just know about regular meetings Badri with Roman and maybe with Shvidler as well, as I understand, when they present him report what happened in the company. And that is as money is concerned. MR.\xc2\xa0SUMPTION:  What steps did you understand that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had taken to ascertain what were the profits of Sibneft? A.\tI don\'t have any idea.  I don\'t have any idea.  I think as we agreed in our agreement as we agreed in \'95, we trust Abramovich and we didn\'t have time to manage the company and to send audit and so.  It\'s not -- already not trust at that time in our understanding." If indeed there had been an express agreement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were to be jointly entitled to a 50% share of the net profits after tax of Sibneft and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, one might have expected that at least some sort of informal audit process would have taken place.  I find the absence of evidence of any such process (other than Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s vague assertions about Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili) surprising, if, indeed, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case were correct.  \r   No correlation in timing, amounts or methods of payment Sixth, the process by which the timing, the amounts and the method of the payments were agreed did not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s theory that such payments related to, or correlated with, any specified proportion of profits made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, whether directly from Sibneft and/or indirectly through Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, as a result of his involvement with, or control of, Sibneft.  The following summary of the evidence in this respect gives a clear flavour of what I find as a fact, was \r   "\xc2\x85 a demand-led system created to satisfy Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s financial whims \xc2\x85 [which] had nothing to do with Sibneft profits [188] ." At about the beginning of each year Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would discuss with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili how much Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could expect to receive in that year for his "expenses".  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described the process as follows [189] :\r   "The stronger Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky became, the more money he required to maintain his position.  Typically, around the beginning of each year, we would discuss with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili the amount that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky expected to receive from me that year given his political expenses, such as the financing of ORT, maintenance of his political image, financing of various mass media, and also his \'expenses\'.  In 1996, I recall that I paid him approximately US$80 million (this large amount was attributable to the elections held that year), though that year was difficult for me as considerable funds were spent on privatisation.  Then in 1997, I paid around $50 million and around the same amount in 1998, despite the shortage of cash caused by the financial crisis.  In 1999, I also paid about US$50 million."  In cross-examination Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich supported this account:  \r   "A.\tIt\'s almost always we had agreed in advance how much would be paid on an annual basis.  Sometimes we were not able to pay the whole amount and then there was a spill-over for the next year. \xc2\x85 A.\tWhat I mean is that we never had an arrangement whereby, for instance, we would let them -- all the $50 million -- let them have the 50 million together.  The arrangement was that they issued requests and then in response to their requests we made the payments." Thereafter payments would be demanded and made in the course of a continuous process of  ad hoc  negotiation, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova described.  Most of the requests were oral.  Sometimes Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would telephone Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich directly;  sometimes Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would telephone him and make the request on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf.  Sometimes the request was for hard cash;  sometimes it was for payment of particular bills or items of expenditure, whether for ORT, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky personally, or otherwise.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would call Ms.\xc2\xa0Goncharova on a daily basis with instructions for payment.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was only concerned about Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s ability to pay and just assumed that he would pay whatever he asked.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky described the process in his oral evidence, as follows:  \r   "I never calculate numbers and my relations was absolutely simple:  I made request directly to Abramovich or Shvidler or indirectly through Badri.  If Abramovich was able to pay,  calculating what is our interest , Badri and me together he paid that.  If he was not able to do, he said \'Boris, we don\'t have money now to spend because we invest if to buy something or because company didn\'t generate this money\' [190] ." "I told Badri, \'Badri, we need that and that, for reason of ORT or for reason of charity or personal reason to buy jewellery for Elena\', and Badri  calculate with Roman what is opportunity to pay or not " [191] .  [emphasis supplied] Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova\'s evidence also emphasised the  ad hoc  nature of the arrangements:  \r   "My understanding is that the way Boris received this money was very ad hoc.  There was no single arrangement by which he would always receive money.  Rather, he would identify some personal asset which needed to be paid for and would inform Badri or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or his team what it was and who the money needed to be paid to, and they would arrange it.  This could, for example, be for jewellery for Elena Gorbunova, for real estate or whatever [192] ."  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky acknowledged this was a partially correct description, but went on to suggest that it did not reflect the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili "calculate[d] the balance all the time".  The cross-examination went as follows:  \r   "Q.\tThat is a correct description, isn\'t it, of how this worked? A.\tThis is partially correct description but it doesn\'t mean -- Q.\tIt\'s not partially correct -- A.\tSorry -- but it doesn\'t mean that it\'s incorrectly what I said before:  that Badri and Roman  calculate the balance all the time .  This is the point, and this is a key point." [emphasis supplied] Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the point that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was making was that, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asked for money, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would only pay it if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were indeed owed that sum "calculating what is our interest." I do not accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion that calculations were made, whether at the time payments were demanded (or at other times), of what, at any given moment in time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were entitled to receive by way of their alleged 50% profit share of Sibneft profits, or of the profits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  There was no evidence (apart from what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said) that any such calculation process occurred.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, as described in his witness statement, that he had meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili for the purpose of discussing Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s likely future financial requirements, not to calculate any profit share entitlement [193] .  I also conclude that it may well have been, in the context of those discussions, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili discussed what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his Trading Companies were able to pay, and that this may well have involved a discussion, in general terms, about what Sibneft and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies were making, since what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could actually afford to pay would necessarily be dependent upon the cash flow of such companies.  But I do not accept that, at any time, there were discussions calculating an agreed 50% profit share of the profits being made by Sibneft and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  I do not accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that "\xc2\x85 the Le Bourget transcript provides important direct contemporaneous evidence of exactly such discussions [194] ".  I address the transcript in greater detail below, but it provided no such confirmation.\r   Further evidence of the  ad hoc  nature of the process of requesting and making payments was found in the evidence relating to payments in connection with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s French properties in December 1996.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had purchased Chateau de la Garoupe at Cap d\'Antibes, France, for FF55 million through a French company controlled by him, Soci\xc3\xa9t\xc3\xa9 d\'Investissements France Immeubles Sari ("SIFI").  The purchase of the Chateau, and subsequently of the antique furniture in it, and its redecoration, had been funded by payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies.  These had been purportedly structured as loans, but it was common ground that there was no intention that such so-called loans should be repaid.  Subsequently, in July 1997, an adjoining property, Clocher de la Garoupe, was also purchased by SIFI, for FF90 million, and was similarly funded.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jenni, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Swiss lawyer, described the "\xc2\x85 rather chaotic system which evolved \xc2\x85" as "\xc2\x85 a result of the constant demand for additional monies" to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s expenses associated with his French properties.  What happened was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s property agent, M.  Bordes, would demand some payment from Mr.\xc2\xa0Jenni or his associate, Mr.\xc2\xa0Stiefel, who would pass the demand on to Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler.  If Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler resisted it, as he sometimes did, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would ring Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili so that he could contact Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and demand that it be paid.  \r   Other evidence showed that payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, through an offshore corporate vehicle, also funded payment of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and his family\'s credit card expenditure between 1998 and 2000.  Pavel Ivlev ("Mr.\xc2\xa0Ivlev"), a Russian lawyer, who worked in Moscow, dealt with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Russian tax affairs from 1997 onwards and fled Russia in November 2004, described the process.  Although he suggested in his written evidence that the payments came from Sibneft, he admitted in cross-examination that he had never made "\xc2\x85 any due diligence or any analysis of the source of funds".  His concern was simply to ensure that the bills were paid [195] .  \r   It was common ground that, at the Dorchester Hotel meeting in March 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to repay a debt that the latter owed him and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky turned round to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and asked him to pay off the debt.  It was duly paid.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed that the funds to pay came out of his profit share entitlement, which was disputed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  What is instructive, however, for the issue presently under consideration, is the manner in which an  ad hoc  demand was made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, and complied with by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich without, it would appear, any discussion as to what at that particular moment in time was either side\'s profit share.  \r   No correlation demonstrated by the Bolshoi Balance Seventh, I do not accept the submission made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz that the figures shown in the Bolshoi Balance for the payments made in 2000 to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili demonstrate a correlation between such payments and the financial performance of Sibneft and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, thereby supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that it was agreed that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should have a 50% profit share in the profits of Sibneft and those generated Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s involvement with, or acquisition of control of, Sibneft.  \r   The FOM table of the Bolshoi Balance recorded the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in 2000.  The Bolshoi Balance also included details of the payments received or made month by month by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies from the whole of his investments, including but not limited to the oil and aluminium businesses.  In his witness statement Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler explained that he was never asked by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at any time to provide them with a summary of Sibneft profits or trading group profits belonging to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, for the purpose of calculating what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should be paid.  He described the function of the Bolshoi Balance in the following terms:  \r   "131.  \tAs I have already explained, one of my key roles was to monitor the cashflow position in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s various businesses.  I needed to know the state of our cash flow online.  I recall that I asked Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko at the end of 1999, to have her team prepare for me a global cashflow balance and have it updated monthly.  I wanted to be able to see at a glance the cash position of all the various projects.  I remember explaining how I wanted the information presented.  This cashflow information was known as the \'Bolshoi Balance\' (literally the \'big\' balance).  I am aware that Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko regarded the presentation of the information in this way as \'accounting heresy\' but it was a management and not an accounting tool.  The Bolshoi Balance was not intended to provide information on profits and losses relating to specific projects but it did enable me to track cash effectively. 132.  \tI understand that in the course of reviewing computers for the purposes of disclosure in this action, the Bolshoi Balance for 2000 plus similar information produced in 2001 and 2002 were located.  As the Bolshoi Balance also contains a complete record of the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in 2000-2002, we have disclosed the entirety of the documents, even though much of the information is unrelated to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  This was not a document prepared for him.  We did, however, extract some of the information on this Bolshoi Balance into a separate table called the Fom table (short for \'Fomichev\', a reference to Mr.\xc2\xa0Ruslan Fomichev) which summarised the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  The Bolshoi Balance does not explain the sources of payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili but shows the availability of funds at a specific point in time within the companies relating to a given project. \xc2\x85 146.  \tIt can be seen from the Fom table that in 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were paid a total of $491 million.  This was a vastly different level of payments to that made in previous years but the year 2000 was different in a number of key respects.  In previous years, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was paid around $50 million each year (although in 1996 it was around $80 million).  In 2000, I recall that the intention was to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky around $50 million but, as matters developed through the year, this amount increased.  To the best of my knowledge, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not fix the annual amounts according to any partnership share or accounting process because I am certain that he would have been asked me to obtain the relevant figures.  I was never asked by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky/Patarkatsishvili at any time to provide them with a summary of Sibneft profits or trading group profits or profit from any other \'situation\', project or group of assets belonging to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for the purpose of calculating what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should be paid.  My understanding was that from 1995 to 1999 all agreements regarding payment totals were made by reference to what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky needed to maintain ORT and his own status. 147.  \tThings were different in 2000.  At the beginning of 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was one of the most powerful men in Russia.  His close friend Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin was the new President.  By June/July 2000, however, I recall that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich indicated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was going to need around $150 million for the year as I was asked to review whether we had available cash.  I was not, however, asked by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or anyone else to \'account\' for profits or provide any financial information for any other company or business owned or controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in agreeing any increase in the figure. 148.  \tAround September/October 2000, things changed again with respect to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s position following his public reaction to the  Kursk  submarine tragedy and I discuss this further below." I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence as set out in these paragraphs.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted [196]  that, in relation to the year 2000, there was clearly a correlation, between the amounts paid to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as shown in the Bolshoi Balance, and an amount of $900 million which (on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s reading of the transcript of the recording of the discussion at the meeting at Le Bourget) was the approximate amount which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili said had been made from Sibneft that year.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that, accordingly, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, the amount paid to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as a consequence should have been 50% of that - in the order of $450 million;  and that the evidence demonstrated that they were paid a figure close to this sum.  He relied upon:  \r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own evidence to the effect that he agreed to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky $305 million plus $160 million in 2000, totalling $465 million [197] ;  a figure which Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted was very close to the amount that would be paid as 50% of about $900 million;   ii)\tpayments of this amount "tagged as being for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as shown in the Bolshoi Balance:  namely the PRB total of $461,367,441, at cell Q19";   a)\tfrom which fell to be deducted "two payments - $7,614,470 labelled  "Bili [Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili] (loan)" and $16,271,042 [198]  labelled "payments (set-off against Al)" as connected to RusAl dealings, leaving a total payment of just under $437.5 million;  and b)\tto which fell to be added the PRBR section referring to cash payments of $3,670,500. This, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted brought the total payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili up to about $441 million, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted, was a figure "remarkably close to half of $900 million."  I deal below with the submissions made in relation to the Le Bourget transcript, but I do not accept the submission made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz that the figures shown in the Bolshoi Balance for the payments made in 2000 to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili demonstrate the correlation for which he contends.  First, wherever Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili obtained the $900 million figure from, it bore no relation either to Sibneft\'s actual profits in 2000 ($675 million), or the net cash flow sums which the Bolshoi Balance records as having been received by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s oil-related businesses including ZATOs in 2000 [199] .  Indeed the commentary at paragraph 56 of the First Schedule to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions specifically made the point that the \r   "\xc2\x85 [gross] receipts from oil trading companies and ZATOs in the year 2000 were just under $1.4536 billion.  Payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili totalling approximated $490 million are less than half of that sum." Second, the FOM table in the Bolshoi Balance shows that the pattern of payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was erratic, in the sense that their timing and quantum bore no relation to the timing and quantum of the sums received by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies.  Third, the figures in the Bolshoi Balance were cashflow figures, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler described.  They were not sufficiently transparent to support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s contention. Accordingly, I do not accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were either actually calculated as 50%, or correlated to 50%, of Sibneft\'s profits and/or those generated indirectly from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s acquisition of influence and control of Sibneft, through his own Trading Companies.  \r   The fact that payments were made to both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili not persuasive as support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case My eighth reason for rejecting Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s arguments under this head is that I do not accept that the fact that payments were made to both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was persuasive support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  It was common ground on the evidence that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili who controlled the payments and generally handled the "commercial side" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s affairs.  It was also common ground that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would make requests for payments and that payments were made to one or other or both of them (whether in cash or otherwise, and whether directly or indirectly to entities or persons associated with them) pursuant to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s arrangements with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  \r   However, on the evidence before the Court, a precise breakdown of the distribution of the payments as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not possible.  This was because payments were generally made to accounts designated on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf, which were either those of nominee companies whose exact beneficial ownership was not apparent, or else those of third party payees who had provided goods or services to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or to ORT.  Even in 2000, when some payments were, possibly, allocated in the Bolshoi Balance to either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (although even this was unclear on the evidence before me), it was possible that amounts were redistributed between the two of them after receipt.  \r   In the circumstances, I am not persuaded by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument that the fact that payments were made to both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili is inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s  krysha  allegation and supports Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s partnership allegation.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence explained Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s role and involvement, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s (limited) understanding of the association between him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili clearly did provide  krysha  type services, not only in relation to RusAL but also in relation to Sibneft - for example "persuading" Mr.\xc2\xa0Ovodenko to withdraw Sameko\'s bid in the loans-for-shares auction.  If there had been any evidence of periodic, or indeed any, calculations as to what was due in respect of "the partners\'" alleged 50% or calculation of what was each of their respective profit shares, the submission might have had more force.  But the reality was that the manner in which monies required by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were demanded, negotiated and paid had all the hallmarks of  krysha  type payments, and not payments of a specific profit share to either man.  \r   x)\tThe Le Bourget transcript Background Unknown to both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili recorded the meeting attended by all three men at Le Bourget on 6 December 2000.  In December 2009 Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky purchased the audio recording from an intermediary, whose identity he was unwilling to disclose on grounds of concern for the physical safety of such person.  Under the terms of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s agreement with the intermediary, the latter stands to make an enormous financial gain in the event that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were to win this litigation;  the deal gives the intermediary 5% of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s winnings.  A transcript of the recording was first disclosed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky on 3 December 2010;  the audio recording was first provided on 5 January 2011.  The original transcript, which was wrongly dated, contained errors of transcription and translation (which have since been corrected).  The recording itself contains gaps and sound distortions.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz criticised Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for not admitting the authenticity of the recording or transcript, or even that the Le Bourget meeting had taken place, until his third statement served on 31 May 2011.  I do not consider that, in the circumstances surrounding the production of the recording, such criticism was well-founded.  \r   The meeting took place over ten years ago and, accordingly, actual recollections of the content of the meeting (and its date) were bound to be limited, as both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich acknowledged in their evidence.  Indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that he did not remember the meeting at all before receiving the recording.  I do not find it surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (or his legal team) considered it necessary to subject the recording to forensic examination and consideration of its contents before accepting it as authentic, nor that it took them five  months to do so.  \r   Before I consider the respective submissions of the parties as to what the Le Bourget transcript shows, it is necessary to say something about the transcript itself and the factual context in which the meeting took place.  A transcript of the recording, in translation, together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s respective commentary on each statement made, was supplied to me [200] .  Necessarily both men\'s commentary was  ex post facto  reconstruction - no doubt with the benefit of assistance from their respective lawyers.  The transcript is difficult to follow.  Much of it is rambling and obscure, and its meaning depends critically on the context.  One cannot construe the discussion in the way that one might construe a series of e-mails or a commercial document.  One suspects that many contemporary nuances of the conversation may well have been lost in translation.  \r   Many of the exchanges are incomprehensible, unless one had an understanding of the previous discussions between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (or in some cases Mr.\xc2\xa0Ruslan Fomichev).  Moreover, as he acknowledged in his cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s understanding of the context of the discussion was very limited at the time, because he left the management of his financial affairs to others (i.e. Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev) and knew little or nothing about recent discussions between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  It was therefore difficult, as he acknowledged, for him to follow what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were talking about [201] .  His assertions as to what particular passages in the transcript meant had therefore to be treated with particular caution.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s comments were also, to a certain extent, reconstructional, as he accepted.  I approached his commentary with similar caution, but he at least was directly involved in the financial discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili both before and during the meeting.  \r   By the time of the Le Bourget meeting, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was an exiled fugitive living in France;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in his turn was to become an exile in April 2001, when he left Russia and went to live in Georgia, although his relations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin in December 2000 were apparently still amicable.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that his relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky changed after the  Kursk  tragedy of August 2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich took the view that the former had taken an overtly hostile and one-sided stance in using the media which he controlled, to exploit a public tragedy of that sort to further his own political agenda against the government.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had made clear to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky what his views were.  As he did not openly disagree with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky very often, this fact had adversely affected their relationship, and thereafter they almost stopped meeting in person and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich increasingly dealt with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky through Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   The principal purpose of the meeting was to discuss the mechanics of how to structure the ORT share sale and the state of the mutual accounting as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on the one hand and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on the other.  Both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were concerned by this stage that the vast sums of money that were required to fund their lifestyles should be received by them out of Russia.  They were concerned, for example, as to whether exchange control would be given to remit the proceeds of the sale of their ORT shares outside Russia.  Previously, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had received an income stream from two non-Russian sources.  One was Andava SA, which from 1996 had taken on the role of a treasury vehicle for Aeroflot.  As I have already described, Andava produced an income stream for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky which was derived from Aeroflot\'s dealings with Andava in Switzerland.  But, by 2000, that income stream had dried up, not least because of the allegations by the Russian public prosecutors that the Andava monies had been misappropriated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky from Aeroflot, and the charges against Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky which had led to his flight from Russia in October 2000.  The other providers of funds to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky outside Russia were the Runicom companies, which had been used to pay most of the sums which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had received from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, including in particular the sums he received for buying and doing up the properties on the Cote d\'Azur.  \r   But, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained at the Le Bourget meeting, the Russian government had announced certain changes to the Russian tax system, as a consequence of which, the oil businesses of his Trading Companies (through which he had previously made most of the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili) were going to be consolidated into Sibneft;  in future, therefore, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s main source of income would be dividends declared by Sibneft.  These could be paid only twice a year and would be subject to Russian tax, making it more difficult for him to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Payments would also be visible to the Russian authorities, a potential problem now that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was a fugitive from Russia [202] .  \r   From the beginning of 2000, and well before Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky left Russia in October 2000, he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been trying to transfer their assets into offshore structures in the West.  As he accepted in his evidence, by December 2000 he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were certainly aware of the money-laundering regulations in force in most Western jurisdictions, and the consequent need to obtain documentary explanation of the origins of any payment in order to satisfy money-laundering enquiries from transferee banks or asset managers.  Indeed the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Ivlev (one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s witnesses) was to the effect that Western financial institutions were, at that time, more than usually sensitive in relation to the transfer of substantial monies from wealthy Russians, because of the scale on which such Russians were attempting to transfer monies out of Russia.  They were particularly so in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Ivlev said:  \r   "I mean, at that time again these issues of suspicion on the side of the foreign banks towards money-laundering operations of Russians was really widespread, so every time we were facing extreme level of control from the banks.  So they had to be really satisfied in order to proceed with the money originated or belonged to wealthy Russians.  And, you know, Berezovsky was an extreme case.  Everybody knew that he is a - he just became an enemy of the state, left the country.  So it was in the air, it was in the media at that time." Thus, it was critical that any future payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (whether, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended, in respect of their interest in Sibneft, or as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich contended, by way of  krysha  payments), should be documented and capable of satisfying the stringent money-laundering enquiries that they knew they would be bound to face from recipient financial institutions.  \r   So any analysis of what the Le Bourget transcript establishes has to be conducted against the fact that, at the time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have been particularly concerned to ensure that the necessary documents were generated to "legalise" (which was the word they used) their receipts of payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies.  Indeed their concern was borne out by the fact that subsequently there were official or judicial enquiries into allegations of money-laundering by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Switzerland, The Netherlands, France and Brazil, in addition to Russia itself.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s submissions Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the Le Bourget transcript was:\r   "\xc2\x85 plainly a key if not the key piece of evidence before the court in relation to a number of issues" including the alleged 1995 Agreement.  He and his team conducted a microanalysis of the transcript and submitted that it provided very valuable assistance in assessing where the truth lay as regards the 1995 and 1996 Agreements and the ownership of Sibneft.  He submitted that the transcript demonstrated:   i)\tthat payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been in the past - and were planned to continue to be in the future - calculated by reference to the profits that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was making from his ownership and control of Sibneft;   ii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich acknowledged Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interest in Sibneft;  and  iii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wished to formalise ("legalise") their interest in Sibneft, but that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was resisting this.   A number of evidential points were relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz.  It is not necessary or feasible for me to deal with them all.  In my judgment the transcript did not provide the support for his case which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended.  \r   References to $30 million coming from "aluminium" - Box 29 and following The beginning of the meeting was spent discussing the sums which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich owed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich came to the meeting with a spreadsheet (which no longer survives) which set out what had been paid, and what was still owing.  In his third witness statement and in his commentary to the transcript, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich gave evidence to the effect that there had previously been an agreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in September or October 2000 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky a sum of $305 million.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that this agreement had been made in October, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s position in Russia was becoming increasingly difficult and his finances were strained.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili asked for a large payment to keep "for a rainy day" [203] .  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz attacked this evidence on the grounds that, in cross-examination, "extraordinarily" Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had admitted that he had no actual recollection of any agreement to pay $305 million and that, in re-examination, he was asked for further details of the proposal and purported to provide them, despite the fact that he said he could not remember.  I do not accept this criticism.  First of all, it was clear from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence and his reference to reconstruction, that his memory had been jogged by what he had read in the Le Bourget transcript.  Second, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence about the amount and the timing was borne out by the Bolshoi Balance, which shows a significance increase in the payments made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky from October 2000.  Although the transcript records Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili initially complaining that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had at that stage received only $100 million out of the $305 million, subsequently the transcript shows that he accepted that in fact only $85 million was outstanding.  Third, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s reference [204]  to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s re-examination was an error;  the passage quoted was dealing with a different matter.  \r   Moreover, in cross-examination [205]  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky accepted that, prior to the Le Bourget meeting, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had "definitely discussed" and agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were going to be paid the sum of $305 million, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not accept that the reason for the breakdown of the figure into $275 million and $30 million was that $275 million was going to be funded from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s oil trading operations and $30 million from his aluminium operations.  He asserted that the two figures represented his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s profit share from the two businesses.  \r   Thus Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended that the references in the Le Bourget transcript to $30 million being described as coming from "aluminium" demonstrated that what was being discussed was his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s entitlement to $30 million of profits from their investment in RusAl and $275 million of profits from their investment in Sibneft, which supported his case.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was cross-examined to that effect.  In support of this contention Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that, whilst it made perfect sense for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to have identified how much money was due from each of the oil and aluminium investments, if the other two men were indeed his partners, it was impossible to see why Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have identified the source of the money, if there was really just an agreement to make a  krysha  payment of $305 million.  \r   I do not agree that the passages relating to this discussion in the Le\xc2\xa0Bourget transcript demonstrate that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was referring to, or recognising, any contractual entitlement of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s part to share in Sibneft\'s or RusAl\'s profits.  The wording in the transcript, neither in itself, nor in context, is sufficiently clear to support such an interpretation.  Moreover, I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, as given in his commentary on the transcript and in cross examination [206] , that, when he had agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili earlier in the year to pay $305 million, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had indicated that it would be difficult to find such a large sum and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had asked where the money was going to be coming from, as he wanted to satisfy himself that the money would indeed be paid.  In the circumstances, such a question was not a surprising one (although Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz described it as a "ludicrous suggestion"), since the sum was far larger than any which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had previously been paid.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that he mentioned the $275 million and $30 million as being respectively sourced from his oil trading businesses and his aluminium businesses, and that the spreadsheet which he had brought to the meeting recorded the internal breakdown as to the source from which the funds derived.  I do not find it in the least surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili might have been interested in the cash flows of the oil and aluminium operations;  in making his demands for  krysha  payments, he might well have been assisted in pitching the demand at the right level, if he knew what quantum of payment the businesses could service.  As indicated above Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz could not demonstrate any correlation between the cash flow figures for the oil and aluminium operations as contained in the Bolshoi Balance and the $305 million as representing 50% of such profits for the year 2000.  \r   Accordingly I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission in this respect.  \r   References to the possibility of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili being registered as shareholders in Sibneft and receiving dividends Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the discussion in the Le Bourget transcript relating to the possibility of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili being registered as shareholders in Sibneft and receiving payment of dividends strongly supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  \r   From Box 450 there was a section of the discussion which addressed a question raised by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about how he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should plan for the next year.  As explained by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the government had announced the withdrawal of certain tax reliefs from oil companies, which would result in additional tax liabilities for his companies.  In consequence, the oil businesses of his Trading Companies (through which he had previously made most of the payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili) were going to be consolidated into Sibneft;  in future, therefore, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s main source of income would be dividends declared by Sibneft.  These could be paid only twice a year and would be subject to Russian tax, making it more difficult for him to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   The passages upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz relied in this context ran from Box 458 and following.  The transcript records the discussion between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as follows:  \r   "Box 458:  \tA.\t So, nevertheless, next year there\'ll be only one way for us to get the money:  legally, through paying taxes, dividends.  We\'ll be able do it twice a year.  During the first six months, and then in the course of the second half of the year.  And all shareholders who are also commercial directors, will receive it.  Nnn...  and all the other, minority shareholders.  Absolutely everyone will receive it, based on the portfolio. Box 459:  \tP:  \t(So shall we legalise our income then?) Box 460:  \tA.\t the idea is that we should legalise this process, that\'s the idea.  To say that this portfolio belongs to so-and-so, this one -- to so and so ...  and if you trust me, I shall do it in such a way so as not to have few visible ...  if you don\'t trust [me], then you need to (get some valuations, some prices).  There can be no official agreements between us.  Well, first of all, it is forbidden.  Secondly, there is no way not to break these agreements.  In other words, the moment you decide you want to break them, you have the right to break them, and legally you ...  all this is (nothing).   Box 461:  \tP:  \tI am trying to ...  nnn.   Box 462:  \tA.\tWell, then everyone will achieve the result for the sake of which all this was done, except for us.  Because the shares ...  nnn.  (wanted to) make your participation that.  nnn. Box 463:  \tB:\tNnn ...  (not like that now).   Box 464:  \tA.\tBorya, what is not like now? Box 465:  \tB:  \tWell, it wasn\'t like that we (used to do it). Box 466:  \tA.\tBorya, yes, exactly like that.  Well, now we shall once again be arguing over ...  nnn. Box 467:  \tB:\tNnn...   Box 468:\tP:\tWe can suggest another, we can suggest another option ...  nnn ...  yes.  Another option, whereby a bank would participate instead of us.  " Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case [207]  was that in 2000 he wished to have his existing interest in Sibneft formalised.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended [208]  that in the above passage Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was talking about how the various portfolios of shares in Sibneft would have to be held in the future, and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was saying that, if they trust him, he will front Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s shares so as not to have them visible as shareholders in Sibneft;  if they do not trust him and insist on becoming visible shareholders, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have to buy him out of Sibneft - since (as he explained later, in Box 496), if their shareholdings in Sibneft were to become visible, Sibneft would be destroyed.  But Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to Sibneft was premised on the assertion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had been "fronting" his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests since 1996;  the suggestion that in this part of the conversation Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was only  now  offering to front their shareholding for them in future [209] , was inconsistent with such a case.  It was put to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that Box 460 showed that he was unwilling to arrange for Messrs.  Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili formally to be shown as shareholders.  But, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained in cross-examination, what he was saying was that only shareholders would be entitled to dividends, and that, because he was a shareholder, he would continue to make the  krysha  payments to them but only out of the dividends which he received.  As he also pointed out in cross-examination, he referred to the fact that their  krysha  relationship was prohibited [210] .  It was also worthy of note that nowhere in the transcript do either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili assert that they had previously agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that he would transfer shares in Sibneft to them upon their request, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged had been agreed in 1996.  \r   In relation to what was a partially inaudible Box 462, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that he was referring to a previous proposal made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev for legalising Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s receipts from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, by transferring Sibneft shares to them, or to a bank acting as their nominee, so that they could have a documented right to receive dividends by way of cover for the payments that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was making to them;  this proposal was unacceptable to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich not only because it would have made them owners of a substantial proportion of Sibneft which, according to him, they had no right to be, but also that, by this date, he had no wish to increase Sibneft\'s association with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, by now a fugitive from Russian justice.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence about the alleged Fomichev proposal was incredible and \r   "\xc2\x85 no more than an attempt to deny the clear evidence to be taken from the Le Bourget transcript:  that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were  already  entitled to 50% of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s stake in Sibneft, and simply wanted to formalise that entitlement." [Emphasis in original] He subjected the evidence to a detailed critique as to the manner in which he alleged that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had changed his case in this respect.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also apparently relied [211] , in this context, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev\'s evidence in what was referred to as the  North Shore  litigation [212] , to the effect that he understood Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have an unregistered interest in Sibneft.  That was, however, a different point, which I address below.  At Le\xc2\xa0Bourget, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was addressing a proposal that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should become registered shareholders of Sibneft.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, not only because he said that he could not rely on him to tell the truth, but also because the judgment debt to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s company owed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev remained outstanding.  \r   I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission on this point and accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence about Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev\'s proposal and the subject matter of the discussion.  But in any event, the passages relied upon in the transcript simply are not clear enough to support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that these passages demonstrate an acceptance or recognition on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s part of an  existing , albeit unregistered, 50% interest, or entitlement to such an interest, in Sibneft vested in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   There then follows from Box 468 onwards various discussions about Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili becoming registered shareholders in Sibneft, whether through the nomineeship of a Western bank or otherwise.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was clearly reluctant for this to occur because of the adverse effect that any public association of the two men as registered shareholders of Sibneft would have on the company.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended that these passages were only consistent with him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili having  existing  interests in Sibneft.  For example, he referred to Box 495, where he said "\xc2\x85 but this does not mean my legalisation, and this is the heart of the problem".  He relied on this as demonstrating that he wanted his existing stake in Sibneft formally recognised.  I am unable to accept this analysis of the transcript.  In so far as anything is clear from what (at least in translation) appears to be a disjointed and incompletely recorded conversation, that is difficult to follow, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s concerns appear to be centred on the "legalisation" of their income stream;  in other words their need to receive future funds from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich legally in Western bank accounts with some plausible and innocent explanation of their origins.  It is in that context that the men were discussing the possibility of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili becoming registered shareholders.  Whilst the transcript shows that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili considered they had an entitlement to receive future payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and every expectation of doing so, the language used goes nowhere near to recognising some existing contractual or beneficial entitlement to a 50% shareholding interest in Sibneft.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz pointed to the various references to dividends in the discussions between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, particularly at Box 519 to 541 and then from Boxes of 587 to 592.  He submitted that these discussions were only consistent with word "dividends" being used in the conventional sense and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s attempt in his commentary on the transcript to characterise Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s use of the word as a reference to  krysha  payments was "utterly implausible." Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the only analysis of the transcript in these passages was that this was a discussion between shareholders as to the dividends that "we" (i.e. the three men) would be entitled to receive, and would be receiving, from Sibneft.  \r   But my reading of the transcript, coupled with the evidence from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, leads me to no such conclusion.  It was not surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was interested in the likely quantum of Sibneft dividends, and in the manner in which they would be paid, given that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had previously explained that the only way of his (i.e. Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich) deriving revenue in 2001, and consequently paying Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili their required income stream, would be out of dividends declared to him by Sibneft.  Nor, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, would it have been at all surprising for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have been keenly interested in how much Sibneft would be declaring by way of dividends, since not only would they have provided the means by which he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would be paid, but also, no doubt, would have determined how much Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could demand and expect Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to agree to pay.  Indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said as much when accepting in cross-examination that, at least to some extent, the amount of Sibneft dividends would determine how much Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would receive in the year;  he said [213] :\r   "\xc2\x85 one could say that they can\'t demand from me more than the company can make.  To some extent, yes, you can make this conclusion \xc2\x85" When reading the transcript one also has to remember that, at various stages, the parties go back to discussing what, at that stage, was only a proposal that the two men might become formally registered as shareholders, as well as other alternative mechanisms for paying monies to them.  The fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili refers, for example, at Box 540 to dividends in the following way:  \r   "\xc2\x85 how will it work out that we will be able to receive dividends?  If we are not shareholders?" is not surprising in the context of the preceding discussions.  Although on one view his reference to "[how]we will be able to receive dividends?" could be read as a reference to a "beneficial" entitlement to dividends, I conclude that in context the language used is equivocal;  it is just as likely that he was simply referring to how he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were going to get their regular  krysha  payments.  Similar comments may be made about other passages relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz.  The whole tenor of the transcript is far too vague to bear the evidential weight which Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz seeks to place upon it, as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.   Likewise, I was not persuaded that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s (or indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s) use of the pronoun "we" in various passages in the transcript went anywhere near demonstrating unequivocal, or indeed any real, support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili mixed up the singular and plural pronouns [214] , and that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili used the pronoun with different meanings [215] .  Even if one can infer from the transcript some sort of proprietorial attitude displayed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to the oil operations, that is not inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted, it is in the nature of the concept of  krysha , that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili might have regarded Sibneft as "theirs" in the sense that the company could not have been created or prospered without the protection that they provided.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption accepted, some of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s statements in the transcript, certainly suggest not only a sense of entitlement on his part to participate in the profits being generated by Sibneft, but also a feeling that the more money Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was making, the more he could be required to pay to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  However, in my judgment, the transcript itself does not in any way reveal whether such apparent feeling of entitlement was based on a  krysha  type relationship, some other deal or arrangement between the three men, or a contractual entitlement to an ownership interest in shares in Sibneft and/or to a participation in its profits or those made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s acquisition of control of Sibneft.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s references to 44% of the Sibneft shares being held "in trust with the management" In the Le Bourget transcript various references were made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to 44% of the Sibneft shares being held "in trust with the management".  Thus for example, at Boxes 468 to 470 there is the following passage, starting with a proposal by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that a bank should become a shareholder in Sibneft as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and his nominee:  \r   "Box 468:  \tP:\tWe can suggest another, we can suggest another option ...  nnn ...  yes.  Another option, whereby a bank would participate instead of us.  " Box 469:  \tB:\tTo which we shall entrust management.  Nnn ...  (a small country)...  (so that) a bank participated ...  nnn ...   Box 470:\tA.\tnow you are willing to say, that...  nnn...  I am saying that...  nnn...  holding...  44 holding, there are 40 percent, which I once talked about (myself), are under my control, but I don\'t own it.  And the other holding there, about 90 percent, it is in trust with management.  Are you happy with such a set up? Then you can...  nnn...   And at Box 540-541, the three men returned to the question how, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were not to become Sibneft shareholders, they might be able to receive money from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in the future, given the changes that the latter had explained earlier:  \r   "Box 540:\tP:\tAnd how will it work out, if at the moment it\'s ...  how will it work out that we\'ll be able to receive dividends? If we\'re not shareholders? Box 541:\tA.\tWhy? We can take these dividends out assigning them to a company, and later we can disperse them very thinly.  Pay taxes...  nnn...  management, 44 per cent is in a management-controlled trust.  [The dividends] are taken out, taxes are paid, after that they [the dividends] are dispersed through different routes. Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that these passages clearly showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was explaining to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that their 44% interest in Sibneft (namely half of the total of 88% of the share capital of Sibneft, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich directly or indirectly held at the time), which they then owned under the terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement and the alleged 1996 Agreement, was held in a trust;  and that the 44% described as being held in trust "in a management-controlled trust" was the half that was being held for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  He submitted that when Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, as recorded in Box 470, even went so far as to ask Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky:  "are you happy with such a setup?", that could only make sense where the manner of how shares were held was relevant to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, which could not have been true of a  krysha  relationship.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich gave misleading evidence to the court, both in his commentary on the Le Bourget transcript and in his cross-examination, for the specific purpose of obscuring the real position relating to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s ownership of their 44% interest.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was cross-examined at considerable length about this matter.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko also gave extensive evidence about the trust structures which (at this time) held, directly or indirectly, effectively 88% of Sibneft, through intermediate holding companies.  The position was confirmed by a statement made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption on instructions, which was not challenged.  There were two successive trusts:  a Liechtenstein foundation operative between 1999 and 2001;  and a Cyprus trust operative from 1 March 2001.  The beneficiaries of the Liechtenstein foundation were Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and, on his death, his children.  The foundation had the power to add Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s relatives to the list of beneficiaries, provided that there was the consent of the protector, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler.  There was also power to alter the regulations governing the foundation to change the beneficiaries, provided Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich consented.  The beneficiaries of the Cypriot trust were Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and, on his death, his children.  The trustees had power to add anybody as a beneficiary provided the protector, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, consented.  The trustees were Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum and a lawyer, Mr.\xc2\xa0Demetris Ioannides.  The trust arrangements covered the whole of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Sibneft holding.  I was not however provided with the relevant trust deeds.  \r   It was clear from the evidence given by both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler that in public statements at the time Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was keen to disguise the fact that (according to him) he was the ultimate sole beneficial owner of 88% of the shares in Sibneft.  In order to do so, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler adopted a standard formula, namely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich controlled half of the 80% shareholding, and that the other half was controlled by "a management trust".  Both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler said that, for security reasons, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich never wanted to say publicly that he owned all the shares in Sibneft;  so he always said that he controlled half, with half being controlled by "the management".  This misleading stance was also adopted in contemporaneous press interviews;  see for example an interview with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler published in Petroleum Intelligence is Weekly in November 2000, where he was quoted as saying \r   "First, I would like to say that Sibneft is a separate oil company not mixed up with the aluminium interests with our shareholders.  As for the list of shareholders, Roman Abramovich controls about a 40% stake, a similar amount is controlled by the company\'s top management, while the rest is in free float." I have no doubt that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s security concerns were genuine.  They were supported by the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, who explained in his evidence that, given the prevailing circumstances in Russia at the time, he too had concerns about publicly disclosing his control of his businesses.  \r   The euphemism about half of the Sibneft stake being controlled by "management" was untrue in the sense that, in reality:\r   i)\tthe entirety of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s indirect share holding in Sibneft was held in trust;   ii)\tthat, as lifetime beneficiary of the relevant trust, he was no doubt in a position to exercise considerable control over the shares (although there was no evidence before me as to what the precise position in respect of control actually was, under Liechtenstein or Cypriot law);  and  iii)\tas lifetime beneficiary, he was no doubt entitled to enjoy the economic interest in the shares (subject, of course, to such, if any, entitlement of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili). In a certain respect, the euphemism could be said to be partially true, in that the protector of the Liechtenstein and Cypriot trusts, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, and two of the trustees of the Cypriot trust, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, were representatives of the management of Sibneft.   Whilst the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler were prepared to misrepresent the position to the Press has some adverse effect on their credibility, I do not, in the circumstances, regard the effect as so serious that I should disregard their evidence in relation to this issue.\r   It is against that background that I have to consider Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s comments in the transcript suggest or support the proposition that 44% of the Sibneft shares, or an interest in 44% of the Sibneft shares, were held, whether in a "management trust", or otherwise, for the benefit of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili pursuant to the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements.  \r   I do not read, in the manner suggested by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz ,what, on any basis, are Delphic comments made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at the meeting.  Having heard the evidence, I do not accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s comments as recorded in the transcript (or indeed his commentary), support the analysis that he was referring to a 44% entitlement being held on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, despite the fact that they are in some respects untrue or misleading as to the precise trust structures.  Thus in my view both Boxes 468 and 541 were referring to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s existing arrangements for ownership of Sibneft shares, and Box 541 was explaining the mechanisms by which payments could continue to be made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Nor does Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s criticism of the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in his commentary at Box 470 take the matter any further.  Whilst the statement was not true, I do not accept that it was being made "to obscure the true position" that he was explaining to the other two men that " their  44% of Sibneft -the half of his holding in which he held for them under the 1995 Agreement and the 1996 Agreement-was held in trust." There is no warrant for such a conclusion;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that at the time he did not recall the details about the trust arrangements, even if he had once known them, and in any event he was perpetuating the myth about the "management trust".  \r   Conclusion on the Le Bourget transcript I do not find that a close analysis of the Le Bourget transcript supports Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case as to the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements relating to Sibneft.  Even if I were to be wrong in this conclusion, such passages as Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggests do support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case are so equivocal when placed in the full evidential context, that on any basis they would carry little weight in my final assessment of where the probabilities lie.\r   xi)\tThe belief of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and others as to his entitlement to an interest in Sibneft ;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s asserted belief;  his public statements and private statements about his connection with Sibneft;  materials showing the belief of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and others in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s entitlement to an interest in Sibneft Introduction In addition to relying upon the Le Bourget transcript, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended that his case was supported, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s shown to be untrue, by what Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz referred to as a substantial body of contemporaneous and near contemporaneous oral and documentary evidence showing that it was the belief of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and a significant number of their friends, employees and associates that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did indeed have a shareholding interest in Sibneft, and not merely an entitlement to indeterminate payments [216] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz pointed to various contemporaneous statements in the press and in books to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was a substantial shareholder in Sibneft;  he submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on the alleged 1995 and 1996 agreements was also supported and corroborated in particular by statements made in the following documents:  the Curtis notes;  the proofs of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  evidence from other proceedings;  the French Documents;  the instructions to Valmet;  evidence from the Sheikh;  affidavits of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay.  He also referred to evidence given by various friends or associates of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  I address the submissions in relation to these materials below.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s belief that they did have an interest in Sibneft was also a powerful indicator:\r   i)\tthat they did have such an interest;  and ii)\tthat the alleged 1995 Agreement was made on the terms that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claims. In this context, he referred to a passage in the speech of Lord Hoffmann, in  Carmichael v National Power plc   [1999] 1 WLR 2042  at 2050-2051: "\xc2\x85 In a case in which the terms of the contract are based upon conduct and conversations as well as letters, most people would find it very hard to understand why the tribunal should have to disregard the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Lovatt and Mrs. Carmichael both agreed that the C.E.G.B.  were under no obligation to provide work and the respondents under no obligation to perform it.  It is, I think, pedantic to describe such evidence as mere subjective belief.   In the case of a contract which is based partly upon oral exchanges and conduct, a party may have a clear understanding of what was agreed without necessarily being able to remember the precise conversation or action which gave rise to that belief .  As the Court of Appeal pointed out, the tribunal did not make any specific findings about what was said at the interviews or on any other occasion.  But the terms of the engagement must have been discussed and these conversations must have played a part in forming the views of the parties about what their respective obligations were. The evidence of a party as to what terms he understood to have been agreed is some evidence tending to show that those terms, in an objective sense, were agreed .  Of course the tribunal may reject such evidence and conclude that the party misunderstood the effect of what was being said and done.  But when both parties are agreed about what they understood their mutual obligations (or lack of them) to be, it is a strong thing to exclude their evidence from consideration.   Evidence of subsequent conduct, which would be inadmissible to construe a purely written contract  (see  Whitworth Street Estates (Manchester) Ltd. v. James Miller and Partners Ltd .  [1970] A.C. 583)  may be relevant on similar grounds, namely that it shows what the parties thought they had agreed .  It may of course also be admissible for the same purposes as it would be if the contract had been in writing, namely to support an argument that the terms have been varied or enlarged or to found an estoppel."  [Emphasis supplied] Relying on this, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that:\r   i)\tsuch an approach would necessarily apply,  a fortiori , in a situation such as this, in which the contract was made entirely orally, and more than 15 years ago, so that, entirely predictably, the memories of the parties to that contract about the exchanges by which it was made have faded; ii)\tthe fact that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, two of the three parties to the alleged 1995 Agreement appear to have concluded that they were Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s partners under that agreement, and that the agreement gave them a 50% interest in Sibneft and an entitlement to participate in 50% of the profits it generated, and conducted themselves on that basis, was a reflection of the true position;  and iii)\tit was common ground that the agreement which the parties made was to be objectively determined from their external conduct [217] .  If Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich conducted himself in such a manner as to allow Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili genuinely to believe that they were entitled to a share in Sibneft, then the objective conduct of the parties would strongly suggest that the agreement which the parties made was to this, and not to some other, effect.  Thus, the Le Bourget transcript showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself considered that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had an interest in Sibneft. Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, on the other hand, submitted that the available materials provided support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s belief and the alleged "concession" by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as to such belief Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also sought to rely [218]  upon what he referred to as a "concession" made in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions [219]  that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili "may have genuinely believed that they had an interest in Sibneft".  He submitted that once it was conceded that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had an "honest recollection" of having an interest in Sibneft, that recollection was evidence which strongly supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.\r   However that in my judgment is not a correct reading of the relevant paragraphs in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions - namely both paragraphs 61 and 62.  I quote them below (without footnotes), to demonstrate what the point was that was there being made:\r   "60.\tIt is fair to say about the Le Bourget transcript that parts of it suggest a sense of entitlement on the part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, which is also apparent from some of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s public and private statements.  These statements raise the question whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky really believed that he had an interest in Sibneft, and whether he could have believed that if it was not true. 61.\tIt is possible that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky may have persuaded himself that in some sense Sibneft was \'his\' company.  If so, the reasons became increasingly clear as he disclosed his mindset in the course of his evidence.  There seem to have been two related factors at work in his mind: (1) \tBy persuading President Yeltsin (through members of his circle) first to create Sibneft, and then to privatise part of the state\'s holding in it and to include the rest in the loans-for-shares scheme, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had made it possible for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to acquire management control in 1996 and almost all of the shares in the course of 1996 and 1997.  It is plain that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appears really to have believed that this was all that really mattered and that all that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich later achieved was due to him.  In keeping with his whole approach to this transaction, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky regarded Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a subordinate, a functionary, whom he had installed as \'his\' manager, generously incentivising him by allowing him to take a proportion of the profits far in excess of the real value of his contribution to the outcome.  It is clear that he had no knowledge or understanding of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s achievement in integrating the two Siberian businesses into one organisation and transforming old-style Soviet state enterprises carrying a billion dollars of accumulated historic debt into a modern and highly profitable capitalist organisation.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence is that he regarded this as straightforward, and that one had only to acquire control for the money to come pouring in.  This presumably explains why he  regarded shares which he had not bought or paid for as \'his\', and payments for krysha which were plainly unrelated to Sibneft\'s profits, as nothing less than his due if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could afford to make them.
