Initially, from the very first discussions, we discussed that I would acquire these shares, I would hold them for a while;  and later, when it all settles down, he\'ll take them back.  However, this option was forgotten very soon." I found that explanation to be credible.  His account was also supported by Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s evidence to the effect that President Putin had not instructed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to purchase the shares.  After the meeting at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had agreed the sale in principle, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich met Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin to discuss the purchase and whether it made sense for him to buy the shares in order to avoid any possible future conflicts between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and the State, in relation to ORT.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that if Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin had indicated he was against the sale, it would not have gone ahead.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s response was that what was important to the government was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not interfere with the channel\'s operation anymore, while the rest was not essential.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s account that he was not involved in any way in the purchase of the ORT shares by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  or involved in, or aware of, any discussions about the price to be paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for them.\r   I find that it is probable that at a subsequent meeting in early November 2000 at Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s office at Sibneft in Moscow, also attended by Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Gorodilov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili reported to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was reluctant to sell but could be persuaded to do so, if the price was increased to $150 million.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to purchase at this price and, at least as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, a commercial deal was struck at this price.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence on these points was corroborated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Gorodilov, who was instructed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in late October to liaise with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev in relation to the detailed arrangements for the deal [345] , and who attended the meeting between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Moscow at which the price was finalised.\r   Thereafter, and possibly even earlier in October, Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Gorodilov liaised with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s financial assistant, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, about the detailed arrangements for the purchase, on the basis that it had been agreed in principle.  I conclude that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev would not have been involved in these negotiations unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had approved of the purchase at least in principle, or, even if he had not actually decided at that stage to sell, at least was content for the time being to go along with the arrangements for the proposed sale.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz challenged Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s changing and vague recollection of the chronology of these events.  However it was not surprising that, after the passage of time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could not be certain about specific dates.  But the precise chronology did not matter.  What was critical was that the evidence showed that, as early as late October/November 2000, and in any event well before the date of the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting on 7-9 December 2000 at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged he was intimidated into agreeing to sell the ORT stake, the transaction was subject to ongoing negotiation and detailed discussions, as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s representatives and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s behalf, about the arrangements (including for payment) which were necessary for the sale to take place.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s travel records and the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Gorodilov showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had travelled to Cap d\'Antibes on 6 November\xc2\xa02000.  The evidence also showed that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were at Cap d\'Antibes on that date.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence on this point fluctuated, but ultimately he denied that there was any meeting on this date.  I accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s recollection, albeit based on his reconstruction from the documents, is likely to be correct and that he did, at the request of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, fly down to Cap d\'Antibes to have a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to discuss the ORT sale on that date.  Whether the $150 million figure was agreed in principle at this meeting, or at the November meeting in Moscow between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, is not material.  \r   Although Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz criticised the discrepancies between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account as contained first in the Re-Amended Defence, and subsequently in the Re-re-Amended defence, and then in his evidence, it is not surprising, given the passage of time, that the precise details of chronology were not recalled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or were incorrectly set out in his statements of case.  Nor do I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion [346]  that this was a dishonest [347]  case which "Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and team therefore came up with":\r   i)\tfollowing their realisation "that the most effective way to deny the threats made by [Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich] at the Cap d\'Antibes meeting would be simply to deny the meeting took place after the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov ...";  and  ii)\tin order to get round the embarrassment that his original Defence "admitted that the meeting in question [i.e. the Cap d\'Antibes meeting] took place in the period between Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest and 25\xc2\xa0December 2000".   I do not accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s original Defence actually did admit the suggested timeframe of such a meeting [348] , but, even if I were wrong on that, and the pleading is to be construed as suggested by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s detailed exegesis, it is not surprising in a case of this sort that further evidentiary investigations made before trial result in the production of further documents, such as travel records, which shed a different light on the timing of events.  That clearly happened in this case.  Moreover given the changes in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case as to the alleged date of the Cap d\'Antibes meeting, it is not in the least surprising that, in preparation for trial, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich focused more intently on the timings of the relevant meetings.  In addition, I find that it would have been wholly consistent with the manner in which the three men did business for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should fly down to the south of France in a private plane to discuss the proposed sale with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  The suggestion put to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in cross-examination that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov travelled to Cap d\'Antibes solely for purposes connected with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s purchase of the Chateau de Cro\xc3\xab was not made out.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself accepted that he knew that discussions were taking place between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in October and November 2000 in relation to the sale of the ORT stake and that he had discussed the negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   There was a considerable amount of documentary evidence to show that, during November 2000, preparations were made not only for the transfer by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of their shares in ORT to a company controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, but also for the transfer of the 11% stake in ORT held by LogoVAZ to another Abramovich-controlled company.  These documents included pre-emption notices, board minutes and transactional documents and showed the involvement of representatives both on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s side and on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev was most unlikely to have been involved in the transaction with Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov without Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s approval.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz challenged some of the documents as being backdated, but although that might have been the case in relation to a few documents, the meta data or other evidence demonstrated that, even where backdating took place, the majority of the critical documents were nonetheless prepared, or in the course of preparation, in November 2000.\r   The Le Bourget meeting Passages in the transcript of the Le Bourget meeting, which took place on 6 December 2000, are also consistent with an agreement having been reached at least in principle as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Moscow in November, with the discussion at the Le Bourget meeting being directed at certain aspects of the structure of the deal which were still outstanding.  These arose mainly from the wish of Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili to receive the funds into their personal bank accounts outside Russia without obtaining Russian exchange control permission or encountering problems with Western money-laundering regulations.  It appears that the Le Bourget meeting of 6 December 2000 was arranged in order, amongst other things, to finalise such matters before Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s imminent trip to Chukotka for the gubernatorial elections.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged in his fourth witness statement that:\r   "\xc2\x85 whilst the initial purpose of the meeting was to discuss mutual business, it quickly became apparent that the main purpose for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was to put pressure on Badri and me to agree to the sale of ORT"  [349] . I do not accept that as a correct analysis of the Le Bourget transcript.  As submitted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in his written closing submissions, the transcript referred at several points to an agreement for the sale of the ORT stake which had already been reached as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was saying he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were ready to sign.  For example: i)\tAt Box 234, it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, rather than Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, who first raised the proposed ORT sale: "Fine ... nnn ...  let\'s now deal with ORT.  Well, Roma, we are absolutely ready (on all) the parameters, including the ... nnn ...  yes.  We had a problem with Borya, and we sorted that out too.  (He) is in England, he is ready, we disclosed the documents, and we are ready to sort it all out officially.  How shall we proceed." ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s response (Box 235) was: "We also have everything ready, as always and like everybody" As Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky acknowledged in cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was saying that they were now ready to go ahead [350] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also admitted that the reference by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in his presence to "our agreement in Moscow" related to the agreement made with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for the sale of the ORT shares [351] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili "tried to play a game" - in other words that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was merely pretending to go along with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s idea of the proposed sale.  But it is impossible to draw that inference from the transcript and it would make no sense in the light of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s comment that the problem with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been "sorted out".  \r   i)\tAt Box 238, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili said:   "No, in fact, when we made our agreement, when we made our agreement in Moscow, yes, you said the following:  that as you are taking it all on your account, I mean, you are the one paying for it, right, so you will not have any problem with transfers, because the payment transfer will originate from the West.  Then we got this scheme ...."  ii)\tThere was then a long discussion, in the course of which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili both spoke to Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov on the telephone, about how the proceeds might be remitted to England in a manner which was tax-efficient and consistent with Russian exchange controls and British money-laundering regulations.  The conversation between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov concluded with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili saying (Box 402): "Therefore we don\'t care where the money comes to London from.  You see, don\'t you? In this case, talk to Roman.  He (will give you his agreement) to this (deal)." iii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich then said, "well, let\'s yes, lets agree" (Box 403), and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili responds (still over the phone) (Box 404): "\xc2\x85 and we are ready, we are ready to carry it out"  iv)\tLater, while Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was talking on the phone to Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a private conversation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili said to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (Box 408):   "Borya, well, we need to finish this off, don\'t you think? So a decision must be taken, one way or another, right? I am absolutely fine with what I am being offered..." Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not demur.  At Box 410 there was a further private conversation about the costs of legalisation of the funds to satisfy money-laundering enquiries.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested both in his commentary on the transcript and in his evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was playing a game and stringing Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich along, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky still had the intention to put the shares into a trust.  But whatever may have been in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s mind at the time, this suggestion was not consistent either with what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was saying, or with the fact that, while Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was still on the telephone to Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was having a private conversation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and during the course of this conversation Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appeared to be perfectly happy with what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili additionally had negotiated [352] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not recorded as saying to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, even in private, that he was not selling, or that he had not yet made up his mind whether he was going to sell. v)\tImmediately after Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had finished speaking to Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov, he said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov was waiting for a document (Box 416).  To this Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili responded (Box 417):   "The document we shall organise today, no problem." vi)\tA little while later, after some discussions about other unrelated sums that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wanted Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to pay, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had the following exchange with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (Box 428-431): "A:\tWe could now close this deal as it is, and later - I promise - we shall always find understanding on this matter P:\tSure, sure\xc2\x85 A:\t(So then) we shall finalise this deal, so that I could report on it without further ado, (that) the deal is done\xc2\x85nnn.. P:\tNo problem\xc2\x85 A:\tSo that he can finish the \xc2\x85 election campaign in peace." Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich recalled that at this point Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not display any negative attitude to finalising the arrangements [353] .  \r   Finally, at Boxes 448-450, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had the following exchange:\r   "P:\tRight, it\'s settled then, no problems.  No problems.  De facto we don\'t lose anything because we are compensating the amount we stand to lose now so that later ...  And as for what we\'d lost already - well, it\'s gone.  In a word, it\'s like this there...  Rom, so we \xc2\x85." A:  \tWhat, then, should we sign then so I could take it to Vladimir Vladimirovich [President Putin], show it to him and say:  here you are, the deal is done, nnn \xc2\x85 P:  \tBut we have signed everything.  Now as soon as the payment goes through, they can already get the shares \xc2\x85 nnn \xc2\x85 we have already signed everything (we have everything signed) [354] ." I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, which is supported by the transcript, that by this stage, so far as he was concerned, the deal had been done in principle, and finalised in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s presence, subject only to documentation [355] .  I accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had the clear understanding at this point that there was nothing else to discuss [356] , and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had given the impression that "he was absolutely fine with it, absolutely agreed"  [357] .  The only matters outstanding, therefore, so far as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was concerned, were the documentation and the arrangements for the transfer of the funds to the West.  What had been agreed at least in principle, so far as the mechanics of payment were concerned, was that $10 million was going to be paid in Russia and the remainder offshore.\r   Nor, contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion does a fair reading of the transcript suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was putting pressure on Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to sign written documents.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained, he did not have any relevant documents for signature with him and in any event the structure of the deal had changed, which would have required revised documentation.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that certain passages of the Le Bourget transcript demonstrated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was acting as President Putin\'s messenger in relation to ORT.  I do not accept that submission.  It was clear from both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had  discussed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s position and his own proposed purchase of the ORT shares with President Putin or Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin, and that he intended to inform President Putin of the sale once it was finalised.  From Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s point of view, the object of the purchase was to relieve pressure on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili after the former\'s public row with President Putin, and to avoid any adverse reputational or other consequences for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself - as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich put it, to take the political heat out of the relations between President Putin and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  In the circumstances it was not surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was proposing, and indeed was keen, to inform President Putin of his acquisition.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that he had not promised President Putin that he would acquire the ORT shares, but only that, if he did buy them, he would inform him [358] .  The transcript suggests that the discussion between the three men was amiable.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also submitted that there was no sufficient explanation as to why, as at the date of the Le Bourget meeting, and prior to the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have been a willing seller of the shares in ORT for $150 million, in circumstances where he had previously refused the sum of $300 million for the same shares and there had been no relevant change in circumstances.  I disagree.  By November 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was a fugitive from Russia;  he had been engaged in a serious and public dispute with President Putin in the media;  he had been summoned to appear before the Deputy Prosecutor on 13 November on fraud charges connected with Aeroflot;  he had issued an open letter in the press which was published on 15 November to the effect that he was not going to return to Russia to face the charges and had alleged that the Aeroflot case had been revived by President Putin as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s criticisms of him;  there was apparently no alternative offer still available from the Russian State to purchase the 49% OIT stake, or, if there was, it was not one that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili considered was going to be honoured;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was regarded as a man whom both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could trust to make the relevant payment;  and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were in need of funds that were available to them outside Russia.  In my judgment all these factors were reasons why Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, and indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, might well have been extremely keen to sell their ORT stake for $150 million by the time of the Le Bourget meeting:  even if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was, as he suggested, keeping his options open at that stage (a proposition which I find difficult to accept) I find that he did not convey that impression to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   It is against the background of my finding that, no later than the Le Bourget meeting on 6 December 2000, and in any event prior to the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had conveyed the impression to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, had agreed, at least in principle, to sell his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s ORT stake to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for the sum of $150 million, that I have to assess the likelihood of a further meeting having taken place between 7-9 December 2000 at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich threatened Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in the manner alleged by the latter.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was arrested because of the former\'s refusal to sign an agreement at Le Bourget In this context it is also necessary to evaluate the evidence relating to an allegation made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich tried to make him sign up to the deal to sell the ORT shares on the spot, and that it was a direct consequence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s refusal to do so, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was arrested on the next day, in order to put pressure on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to sign the agreement.  This allegation was made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in his written commentary on Box 159 of the Le Bourget transcript.  Having referred to a raid by Customs officers on ORT\'s premises on 5\xc2\xa0December, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said:\r   "I felt at the time of this meeting that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin\'s messenger and had been sent to obtain our signatures to the sale of ORT.  The Maski-Show raid the day before our meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was intended to be a warning to us. When Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich returned to Russia without our signatures, Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin realised that he need to increase the pressure to make us sell.  Consequently, the following day, 7 December, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was arrested." I reject this allegation.  First, as I have already said, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not have any contractual documents with him that could have been signed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky there and then.\r   Second, by the time of the Le Bourget meeting, the decision to arrest Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov had already been made;  on 5 December 2000, the Prosecutor\'s office had formally drawn up the charges and made the formal decision to arrest Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov and detain him in custody when he appeared for interview on 7 December 2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s lawyer, Mr.\xc2\xa0Borovkov confirmed this fact in his evidence in support of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s subsequent UK asylum application for asylum.  Moreover it was widely known that it was highly likely, if not inevitable, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be arrested when he attended for interview;  Deputy Prosecutor Kolmogorov had announced on television on 30 October 2000 that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be charged with misfeasance relating to the affairs of Aeroflot (which was the event that provoked Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s flight to France).  On 1 November 2000, after he had left, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was summoned to appear before the Deputy Prosecutor on 13 November 2000.  On about 13 November 2000  Kommersant  announced in the press that the interview was about to happen and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be arrested when they appeared.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov confirmed this with contacts of his in the State administration [359] .  He also said, in his witness statements, both in this action and in his asylum proceedings, that he knew well in advance of 7\xc2\xa0December 2000 that he would be arrested and detained that day [360] .  Following the announcement on 13 November 2000 that he would be arrested when he attended for interrogation, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov gave an interview to  Kommersant  on 23 November 2000 in which he stated that once he attended the General Prosecutor\'s Office for interview "they will hardly let me out".  Mr.\xc2\xa0Goldfarb commented that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s vulnerability as a potential hostage was "obvious" from the moment at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky refused to go to Moscow for questioning on 13 November 2000.  In her witness statement in this action Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova explained that she spent the night before his arrest with Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, it having been known for some time that he could be arrested.  In his commentary on the Le Bourget transcript, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also confirmed that he was aware that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov had been summoned to appear on 7 December 2000 and said that it was common practice to arrest people on the spot following their interrogation [361] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had already advised Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov to leave Russia [362] .  At the time of Le Bourget he had known for five weeks that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was going to be charged and arrested [363] .\r   Notwithstanding this, both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov sought in their oral evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was behind the timing of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, arguing that before the Le Bourget meeting the arrest was only "possible" or "probable" and that it was because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s refusal to sign on the dotted line that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was arrested [364] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky pointed to the question which he had asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as recorded at Box 641 as to whether "you reckon they could arrest [Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov]" and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s answer as recorded at Box 642, where he said "I don\'t think they would".  This was based on a conversation which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had had with a friend of his, Mr.\xc2\xa0Krasnenker, a former Vice President of Aeroflot, who had also been summoned for interrogation to the prosecutor\'s office on the same day and who had been told that there would be no arrest on 7 December.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to suggest in cross-examination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s answer was disingenuous and that:  \r   "\xc2\x85 after Glushkov was arrested, later on, I didn\'t have any doubt that Abramovich played game together with Putin and the Prosecutor Office and so, no doubt at all.  This one of my key -- turn point." I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertions as made in his evidence:  \r   i)\tfirst that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest on 7 December came as a real shock to him:  whatever view Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich might have expressed based on Mr.\xc2\xa0Krasnenker\'s statement, it was obvious to everyone, including Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov himself, that it was highly probable that he would be arrested when he appeared for interview;   ii)\tsecond, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest on 7 December was in any way connected with, or came about as a result of, the fact that no agreement to sell the ORT stake had been signed at the meeting on 6 December: the evidence showed that the prosecutor\'s decision to arrest Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov and to detain him in custody had already been taken on 5\xc2\xa0December 2000;  as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said, and I accept, he had not told President Putin that he was meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on 6 December;  the next time he had any communication with President Putin after the Le Bourget meeting was 9 or 10 December in Moscow, after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov had been arrested;  on that occasion, he believed that he would not have mentioned his meeting, as it would have been more likely that he was discussing the upcoming elections in Chukotka, where Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was running for governor;  he believed he would have only mentioned the meeting to President Putin or Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin in late December 2000 or early January 2001, after the final agreements in relation to ORT had been signed. iii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was playing some sort of devious game behind the scenes to procure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest in the event of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s refusal to agree to the sale of the ORT stake at the Le Bourget meeting. There was no evidential basis to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had access to, or any influence over, the Russian Prosecutor;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that he did not even know the Prosecutor General was not challenged.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin gave clear evidence to the contrary. I conclude that it reflects poorly on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s credibility that he made the allegation that it was the events at Le Bourget that led to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, or that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was somehow involved behind the scenes in the decision to arrest Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in order to put pressure on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to agree to the sale of the ORT stake.\r   The alleged meeting at Cap d\'Antibes between 7 and 9 December 2000 The evidence relating to the alleged meeting at Cap d\'Antibes between 7 and 9 December 2000 was extensive, as was the time and length of submission devoted to its minute analysis.  It is not appropriate that this judgment should do likewise in relation to its treatment of the issue.\r   Conclusion in relation to the alleged meeting on 7-9 December 2000 My conclusion, having heard all the evidence and considered all the detailed submissions, is that no meeting between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky  and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich took place either on the 7, 8 or 9 December 2000 after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, whether at Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s chateau at the Cap d\'Antibes, or elsewhere, at which the alleged threats were made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to intimidate Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky into making his decision to sell his shares in ORT.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s changing case in relation to the date of the alleged meeting Before giving my reasons for this conclusion, I should say something about the manner in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the date of the alleged meeting at Cap d\'Antibes has changed over time.  By his own admission in cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky changed his "recollection" many times about when the meeting took place.  His case was originally that it occurred in late December 2000.  According to the Patarkatsishvili proofing notes, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky told his solicitors in 2007 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich came to France on 17 December 2000 and said that if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili agreed to sell the ORT shares, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be released.  In his oral evidence in support of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s asylum application, he said that he thought it was around 17 or 18 December [365] , although he had also said in paragraph 23 of his witness statement in support of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s asylum application that the meeting was at the end of December.  In his second witness statement served in response to the summary judgment application in these proceedings, he said that the meeting occurred "towards the end of December 2000"  [366] , and in his fourth statement served for trial that it was "a couple of weeks after Nikolay\'s [Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s] arrest, towards the end of December 2000 and a day or two before Christmas"  [367] , or "about two weeks after" the Le Bourget meeting [368] .  However, the passports and other travel records disclosed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky shortly before trial effectively showed that it was not possible for any meeting to have taken place at Cap d\'Antibes with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on any date from and including 10 December to the end of the month.  Thus the records showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky made various short journeys within Europe between 10 and 16 December, before travelling to England on 16 December and from there to the United States on 17 December 2000.  He attended various press conferences in Washington on the following day, 18 December 2000, and then went skiing at Aspen, Colorado, together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Voronoff.  He returned via Luton on 27 December 2000, before leaving again for Spain on 31 December.  In addition, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who is also alleged to have been present at the meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in Cap d\'Antibes, can be shown from his travel records to have been in Georgia between 16 December and 25 December 2000.\r   Shortly before the trial, after the appearance of the material summarised above, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky served his sixth witness statement suggesting that it was now:\r   "\xc2\x85 far more likely that the meeting at Cap d\'Antibes took place on or in the few days after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest on 7 December 2000" [369] . At this stage, however, he was still not willing to rule out the possibility that it might have been later in December.  It was finally conceded, on 23 September 2011, that the meeting could not have taken place on or after 17 December 2000 and, on 28 October 2011, that it did not happen after 10 December 2000.  In his oral evidence, having first suggested the date could have been 7 or 8 December [370] , he asserted that it was on 7 December itself, and added some circumstantial detail, said to be based on recollection, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had come down from Paris with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the latter\'s aircraft, landed at Marseille and arrived at the house shortly after Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili [371] .  He did not appear to be suggesting that the 9 December was a possible candidate for the alleged meeting.  He said:\r   "\xc2\x85 I still have a little bit of doubts about the 8th.  And it means that my recollection almost - not 100% first of all, but almost 100%, that has happened on the 7th." As I have already said, in a case of this sort, involving events which occurred many years ago and which are not necessarily evidenced by documents, it is often not unusual that the recollection of parties or witnesses may change both before and during the trial as to what they believe to be the correct chronology of events.  That is particularly so in a case such as the present where the parties\' focus intensifies in the final preparations for trial.  However, even making every allowance for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in this respect, I found it nonetheless surprising that his recollection of the date of the alleged meeting changed so frequently over time and that the precise date was not fixed in his mind.  If the meeting did indeed take the course which he alleged, and threats were made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s ORT stake would be expropriated and Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s detention in jail would continue, unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky agreed to sell his ORT shares, one might with some justification have expected that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have remembered the date upon which somebody whom, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, he considered as a friend, behaved in such an appalling way.\r   Whilst such change of case is not by any means determinative, and if I had otherwise been prepared to accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on the evidence, I would have disregarded it, the change is nonetheless relevant to my evaluation of the nature and weight of his evidence and that of his witnesses who also spoke to the date of the meeting.\r   Reasons for reaching the conclusion that no meeting took place on   7-9 December 2000 My reasons for reaching the conclusion that no such meeting as alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky took place on 7-9 December 2000 may be summarised as follows.\r   First, in my judgment the evidence, both in the form of documentary records, such as passport stamps and other flight records, as well as that given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his witnesses, established that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich left Le\xc2\xa0Bourget immediately after the meeting on 6 December and flew back to Moscow;  that he remained in Moscow from 7-9 December 2000;  that he left Moscow for Chukotka on 10 December 2000 where he was campaigning for the gubernatorial election fixed for 24 December 2000;  and that he did not leave Russia during the period 7 - 9 December 2000.  I refer to some of this evidence by way of example:\r   i)\tThere were no Russian exit or entry stamps for any date in December after the 6 December 2000 in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s passports;  the first stamp in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s passport showing his departure from Russia was an exit stamp on 2 January 2001, when he left Russia to go skiing in France.  That evidence was supported, to a limited extent, by hearsay statements from the Border Guard Service of the FSB.   ii)\tThere were no records of any flight from Moscow to France having been booked on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s behalf in the period 7-10 December with the private jet company, Global Jet, which, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained, was the service which he personally used.  Although he accepted it was not impossible that he would have used a private jet provided by another company, he said that it was not very likely.  Records existed from Global Jet for each of the journeys from Russia taken by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich which (on his evidence) involved a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in the period October 2000 to May 2001 [372] . iii)\tRosaviation, the Russian Federal Agency of Air Transport, apparently maintained complete records of private charter flights leaving from and arriving in Moscow in the December 2000 period.  Their records showed very few private flights in the period 7-10 December 2000 between Moscow and Nice or Marseille.  There was none on 7\xc2\xa0December, and the timings of the two flights on 8 and 9 December 2000 did not fit Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  The flight records also indicated that there were only two private aircraft flights from Moscow to Paris on 7\xc2\xa0and 8 December 2000, both of which were operated by Global Jet.  Global Jet confirmed that the flight on 7 December 2000 was not booked by or on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  and the flight on 8 December 2000 had on board only Messrs Shvidler and Tenenbaum.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence on this point was not challenged. iv)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich provided a detailed account of his movements and meetings on each of 7, 8 and 9 December 2000 in his sixth witness statement, and in his oral evidence.  In his earlier witness statements, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was still addressing Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that the meeting took place a few days before Christmas, and it was therefore unsurprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich only considered the period 7-9\xc2\xa0December in detail in his sixth witness statement served on 26 September 2011, shortly after Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s change of case.  His evidence as to his movements in this period was corroborated to a certain extent by the evidence given a trial by Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin, and by Mr.\xc2\xa0Sergei Kapkov, who helped Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich organise his gubernatorial campaign in 2000 given at trial, and was subsequently his assistant at the State Duma.   v)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s evidence was that he was visited at his house in Moscow by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, by prior appointment, during the evening of 7\xc2\xa0December, in the company of Mr.\xc2\xa0Krasnenker, who was worried that he too, like Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, was going to be imminently arrested.   vi)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Kapkov\'s evidence was that, having spoken on the telephone to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on 8 December to try and arrange a meeting to discuss the campaign, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told him that he would see him the next morning, 9 December at Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s house, and that meeting duly occurred.   vii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich also gave evidence that he attended and voted in the Duma on 8 December 2000 [373] , at the vote relating to the new national anthem [374]  and that he had a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Zubarov (the Chairman of the Board of the Pension Fund of the Russian Federation) on 8\xc2\xa0December 2000 prior to their departure to Chukotka [375] , and that he attended a birthday party on the evening of 9 December 2000.  He  accepted in cross-examination that whilst he remembered that he did not leave Russia during the period, most of the rest of his evidence was based on reconstruction. Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz challenged this evidence (which he characterised as "Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s strenuous attempts to provide an alibi for himself") on a number of grounds.  He submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own evidence of his alibi had changed "substantially" over time.  In my judgment this criticism was not well-founded.  As I have already mentioned, I do not accept that he had initially admitted in his defence a meeting in Cap d\'Antibes between 7\xc2\xa0and 25 December 2000.  Such changes as they were to the timing of events in his evidence were explicable in the light of the change of focus in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  Insofar as they were not explicable I have taken such matters into account in my general assessment of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence relating to this period.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz further suggested that the evidence relating to the passport stamps and the border authorities was unreliable, and that  little weight could be attached to it.  That was because, as the FSB Border Guard Service themselves confirmed (and as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich accepted in cross-examination), passport stamps are not always made when the Russian border is crossed.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz pointed to the fact that there was no Russian exit stamp in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s passport on 6 December 2000 (when he left Russia to attend the Le Bourget airport meeting) and that it had not been possible to identify any Russian entry stamp in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s passport on 30 May 2001, when it appears he travelled from London to Moscow following the meeting in Cologne on 29 May 2001.  He also pointed to examples of missing French stamps in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s passports.  But whilst it may be the case, that, where one is travelling by private jet, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich habitually did, passports are not invariably stamped, in fact an analysis of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s passports reveal that they do contain at least one stamp (and in most cases both an entry and exit stamp) for each of the foreign trips that he took in the period October 2000 to May 2001 which involved meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  In  my judgment it would be a surprising coincidence if in relation to this alleged meeting there was no record whatsoever, either of exit from, or of entry to, Russia in the passport itself or in the border agency\'s own records.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s suggestion that the evidence from the FSB Border Guard Service could not be relied upon as "authentic, independent evidence" was somewhat optimistic;  there was no evidence to support any suggestion that it had been improperly tailored to suit Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case or was not authentic.  Whilst I accept that it was not exhaustive or complete, (because it was not clear upon what records it was based), it nonetheless provided some supporting evidence of the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had not left Russia during the relevant period.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that there was no evidence to support the assertion that Rosaviation "maintains complete records of private charter flights leaving from and arriving in Moscow in the December 2000 period" (other than assertions in Skadden\'s letters seeking information from Rosaviation).  He further submitted that, if such complete record were indeed maintained, then Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have sought information from Rosaviation in respect of flights from Russia into Lyons airport or Cannes airport, as well as Paris, Marseilles and Nice, as helicopters could have been chartered to have taken Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich from those airports to Cap d\'Antibes.  Again this criticism was valid so far as it went, but the likelihood was that, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich accepted that Lyons or Marseilles (but not Cannes) were possible airports to fly to, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was flying for a day trip to visit Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at Cap d\'Antibes, he would go to the nearest airport suitable for a jet, namely Nice.  Once again, such available evidence as there was supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account and not Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz made similar criticisms of the Global Jet flight records on the grounds that they were not exhaustive and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had not taken steps or made enquiries to secure every possible piece of documentation to evidence his travel arrangements.  Again there was nothing in this criticism, given the passage of time.  So far as they went, these records clearly supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s criticisms of the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his witnesses included criticisms that:\r   i)\tit was "\xc2\x85 implausible that any witness could recall with certainty the exact date upon which a routine event (meeting, party etc) occurred some 10 years after the relevant event"; ii)\tthat, contrary to the impression which he had given in his witness statements, his evidence had been reconstructed; iii)\tthat such reconstruction was not reliable and indeed was reconstruction of "a dishonest sort". In my judgment these criticisms were not well founded.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s sixth witness statement made it quite clear that he and others had been making enquiries in an attempt to reconstruct what has occurred on the three days of the 7-9 December 2000.  The manner in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich gave his evidence orally in relation to this topic was carefully considered and he made a careful distinction between what he positively remembered and that which he had reconstructed from information obtained from others or from relevant documents.  He, and those witnesses who gave evidence in relation to his movements during this period, were able to reference their direct recollection to events such as Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, or, in the case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Kapkov, his birthday on 10 December and the impressions which he had had, as a 25 year old man, of visiting Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s home at Sareevo for the first time.  I found Mr.\xc2\xa0Kapkov to be a credible witness notwithstanding his association with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s evidence of the meeting in the evening was likewise entirely credible, as were his reasons for remembering the actual date of the meeting, by reference to his secretary\'s reconstruction of the telephone log of his calls with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the date of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, and the concern displayed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Krasnenker, that he too was going to be arrested. Improbability of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on the timing The second reason for concluding that no such meeting took place is the inherent improbability of its timing.  The improbability of timing does not just relate to the unlikelihood that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have flown from Moscow for less than a day\'s visit to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at Cap d\'Antibes during Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s preparations for his campaign in Chukotka.  The improbability also extends to the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appears to have decided to sell all the ORT shares on 7 December, before, realistically, any visit by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could have occurred.\r   The relevant timing of events can be summarised as follows.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky returned from Paris to Cap d\'Antibes on the evening of 6 December 2000, immediately after the meeting at Le Bourget [376] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was arrested at about midday Moscow time (10.00 a.m.  French time) on 7 December 2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was informed of the arrest immediately by Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s lawyers, who were with him [377] .  He then rang Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and they concluded that in the light of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest "we are now in the corner;  we don\'t have any choice" and that accordingly they had to sell the ORT shares.  In his fourth witness statement he put it as follows:\r   "358.\tI gave a telephone interview to the Ekho Moskvy radio station on the day of Nikolay\'s arrest and expressed my view that President Putin was trying to get at me via those closest to me.  However, I announced immediately that I would be giving President Putin what he wanted, namely ORT.  In an interview on 7 December 2000 with NTV (which was reported in Russian newspapers), I announced that I was abandoning my plan to transfer ORT into a trust.  I explained that I was doing this because the trust would have been placed under incredible pressure by the Kremlin.  This was correct, but I also understood that I would have to give up ORT to the State so as to secure Nikolay\'s release." He then originally, before changing his case as to the date of the alleged meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at Cap d\'Antibes went on to say:\r   "359.\tA couple of weeks after Nikolay\'s arrest, towards the end of December 2000 and a day or two before Christmas, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich came to my house in Cap d\'Antibes, where I was then living, and met with Badri and me.  The meeting was arranged through Badri.  My partner, Elena Gorbunova, was also present for the beginning of the meeting. 360\tAt this meeting, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said from the very beginning that he was acting as a messenger in agreeing the terms for the State getting control of ORT.  He did not even try to pretend that there was any other agenda.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told Badri and me that he had come at the specific request of President Putin and Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin and that Badri and I had to sell our interests in ORT to him immediately. 361.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told us that if we did not sell our ORT shares at the price he specified, then Nikolay would be in jail for a very long time.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich knew well that Nikolay was very sick and in need of constant medical treatment.  He added that if Badri and I did not sell the shares, President Putin would seize them in any event and so we might as well sell them.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich assured me that if I agreed to sell, Nikolay would be released from prison.  It was clear to me that we were being threatened.  On this basis, and this basis alone, I agreed to sell my interest in ORT." In an interview with the  Moscow Times  on 20 April 2001 he said:  \r   "Glushkov\'s arrest was a clear signal to me that I have to sell my stake to the state immediately \xc2\x85". and in a statement posted on his personal website in April 2001 he said: "I decided to sell my shares to the state on the day Nikolai Glushkov was arrested". On the evening of 7 December 2000, the day of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky announced his decision to sell his ORT shares in an interview which he gave to the Moscow radio station  Ekho Moskvy  where he said:\r   "\xc2\x85 despite all the talk, all the speculation that I sold the shares, or 49% of the shares today belong to me and my partner [Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili] and in this situation I believe it makes absolutely no sense to struggle against such risks-not risk me personally, but to my friends and family.   Therefore I will decide within the next two days what to do with the share is . Presenter:\tdo you believe at all that you will be able to hold on to them?  No, I simply do not believe that at all.  I think the state will get what it wants."  [Emphasis supplied.] In his evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky confirmed that in this interview he had indeed said that he had decided to sell the stake [378] . When it was put to him in cross-examination that the timing showed that he had already decided to sell, even before any alleged meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, by reference to the two-day period referred to in his interview with  Ekho Moskvy , attempted to draw a distinction between:\r   i)\trealising, as a result of the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, that he would be forced to sell his shares in ORT and that he would have no choice but to do so;  and ii)\tbeing informed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would only be released if he sold the shares, and then, as a result, making the decision to do so. The following two passages in his evidence are examples  which  illustrate this point:   "A.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, I present my position in Ekho Moskvy like it is.  Definitely I already took my decision to sell ORT shares because they put me in the corner, but I said that I need two days more to take a final decision.  It means that I present my position.  My understanding that I am in the corner, I was really shocked, and I present my position.  But I took the final decision, as it\'s correctly I gave in my interview, only after we agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov will be released because I will sell my shares in ORT." [379] "A.\tI just want to say, to tell you, immediately, the same day and so, again, it was so painful for me.  On the one hand, I clear understood, my Lady, that I don\'t have choice after Glushkov was arrested and it\'s position which I presented but I definitely took some -- how to say? -- some break to understand how it could happen.  And only way for me to sell it, even when I said after Glushkov was arrested, "It means that he will be released if I will sell, yes?" This is the point:  that he will be released if I sell.  And the point what I discussed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, "I accept any price you like and for me the importance is only releasing Glushkov", that\'s it.  And I never changed my understanding of that or changed my position on that." [380] But his evidence, as I found it, was extremely confused as to precisely what he was alleging was the real driver for his decision to sell his shares in ORT.  He seemed to accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could not have influenced his decision to sell, as the following passage demonstrates:\r   "Q.\tYes.  Well now, if you decided straight after hearing about Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest that you were going to have to sell out of ORT, unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was already there in Cap d\'Antibes when the news came through, you couldn\'t have been influenced by anything that he said to you, could you? A.\t\tNo.  The point is that, as you remember, our discussion with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in Cap d\'Antibes is the condition to give up is Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov release.  And this is a key point because after that I told that I am not interested more in money at all;  I am interested in just the condition should be Glushkov should be released. Q.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, I don\'t think you\'re really grappling with the point I\'m putting to you.  Your case is that you would never have sold out of ORT if it hadn\'t been for what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said to you on this visit to Cap d\'Antibes.  That\'s your case, isn\'t it? A.\tMy case is absolutely clear:  that I would not sell ORT if Glushkov would not be arrested and I would not sell -- I wouldn\'t sell ORT if Glushkov would not be , and this is the point which I discussed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in Cap d\'Antibes.  As I told you just now, I don\'t remember, happened on the 7th, and it means that I decree -- that I decree my position, present my position, when already Abramovich visited me or it\'s happened later, one day later. Q.\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, is it your case or is it not that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s threats that caused you to decide to sell out of ORT? A.\tDefinitely, but  threat already have done by Putin himself, putting Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in jail . Q.\tNow, the point I\'m putting to you is very simple -  A.\tAbramovich was just messenger of that. Q.\tIf you decided to sell out of ORT as soon as you heard the news from Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s lawyer that he\'d been arrested,  unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was already at Cap d\'Antibes, he couldn\'t possibly have influenced your decision? A.\t Definitely he could not influence to my decision  but I still have in mind my clear understanding that the condition finally will be if Nikolai Glushkov will be released.  I was very emotional, as you understand, that day and I don\'t remember exactly what happened.   But the point is absolutely clear:  that condition was to release Glushkov, in spite of I said I don\'t have choice, but I have arguments to make happen that Glushkov will be released  because I had hope that if he will not be released, I will not accept that" [381] .  [Emphasis supplied.] He gave a similar answer when cross-examined on paragraph 358 of his fourth witness statement quoted above.  He said:\r   "Q.\tNow, my question is this, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky:  you came to that conclusion without needing to have any conversation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich? A.\tDefinitely.  On the one hand conclusion was without any conversation with Abramovich.  On the other hand, I want to understand condition and I want to send clear message that I don\'t worry more about money, I worry just about releasing of Nikolai Glushkov.  And as far as Abramovich already took mission to be messenger between Putin and me, he is absolutely correct person to present my position to Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin" [382] . I was not impressed with the manner in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky gave his evidence on this point.  His pleaded case was very definitely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had threatened him that, unless he agreed to sell his shares in ORT immediately, his interest would be expropriated in any event and Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would remain in prison for a very long time.  His account in cross-examination, however, shifted to one which was more along the lines of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself, in the course of a negotiation through Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, seeking to impose the condition of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release, as a precondition to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s agreement to sell.  What was clear, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself admitted, was that he did not remember exactly what had happened at the alleged meeting.  Even if I were to make the assumption in his favour that, because of the two-day consideration point, his case as to the timing of events was not in any way undermined by this evidence, the general veracity of his case on the ORT intimidation issue was indeed seriously undermined.\r   A further point which went to the inherent improbability of the alleged meeting taking place on 7 December (which was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence as to the probable correct date of the meeting), was that, logistically, it was not possible, or, even if possible, it was logistically extremely difficult, for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to have flown back to France from Moscow on 7 December in time to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that afternoon - after lunchtime as Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova suggested - and to have been back in Moscow that evening when, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich went to Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s house in Moscow together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Krasnenker.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence on this topic was not challenged, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin\'s was.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that there would have been typically a six-hour leadtime from the making of a booking with a jet provider for an unplanned flight until boarding.  No suggestion was put to him in cross-examination as to when the decision was allegedly taken by him to return to France, nor was it suggested to him that he had been given instructions by President Putin or Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin to return to secure Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s agreement to the sale of the ORT shares.  And, on any basis, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had been mandated to communicate threats from the Russian State, it is somewhat surprising that he did not do so at the Le Bourget meeting the day before, since the likelihood of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest would have been known to the State prosecutors on that date, given that the decision to arrest him had already been taken.\r   The evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova, Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud and other witnesses Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud showed that the alleged meeting at Cap d\'Antibes took place after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest.  I disagree.  I did not find the evidence given by these witnesses in relation to the date of the alleged meeting persuasive.  I agree with the analysis in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions that the most plausible reconstruction of events is that these witnesses remembered an occasion after Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s flight from Russia when Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich came to the Chateau de la Garoupe, but that occasion was on 6 November 2000.  Given the nature of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case as to the alleged threats made (threats as to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s  continued  detention), however, it was necessary for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to place the alleged meeting on or after 7 December 2000.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s fourth witness statement attempted to place the meeting after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, on the basis that he said he remembered that the meeting included a discussion about Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s imprisonment.  However, prior to his cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had not previously suggested that the meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich took place on the very same day that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was arrested.  Indeed he had made it clear that he could not remember the precise date.  But if the two events had indeed occurred on the same day, or even on successive days, I find it surprising that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky nor Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova had any recollection of that fact.  Nor was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili recorded in the briefing notes as having said that the two events happened on the same date or successive days.  In his sixth witness statement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that he remembered events of emotional significance to him;  and that the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was one of the most emotional events of his life.  In cross-examination he also described Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s alleged visit as of "much less" emotional significance than the emotional significance of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, "but also emotional strong"  [383] .  If the two events had genuinely occurred on the same day, it is highly probable in my view that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have said so from the start.  The excuse which he gave for failing to do so [384]  - it was all too much for one day - was not convincing.  I quote his answer in full:  \r   "Q.\tNow, if these two events happened on the very same day, I suggest that you would always have remembered it and you wouldn\'t have had to shift about choosing one date after another. A.\t I was waiting this your question.  It\'s good question .  And I tell you I recollect definitely the arrest of Glushkov;  I recollect definitely the meeting with Abramovich in Cap d\'Antibes.  I did not recollect that it\'s happened in the same day and I think, again,  because it\'s so emotional, was Nikolai Glushkov arrest, that I did not coincide those two events, I did not put those two events in one day.  It was too much for one day.  It\'s the reason why initially I didn\'t remember that it could happen at the 7th."  [Emphasis supplied.] Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s belated recollection of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich arriving just after Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on 7 December [385]  also had every appearance of being a late invention, following the rebuttal of his earlier case that the meeting occurred shortly before Christmas.\r   Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova\'s evidence was originally prepared in order to support the case then being made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that the meeting occurred shortly before Christmas.  It then had to be deployed in support of a meeting on 7\xc2\xa0December.  In her first witness statement dated 8 July 2011 she said as follows:\r   "(ix) \tThe Cap d\'Antibes meeting 37\tI understand that Roman now denies that he met with Boris and Badri between 6 December 2000 and Christmas that year. 38\tI am sure that Roman is wrong about this.  Although I do not remember the precise date of the meeting, I can picture it very clearly.  The meeting took place before 24 December 2000.  I am sure of this because at the time, our Christmas tree had not yet gone up;  although I am a Russian Orthodox Christian, and so we celebrate Christmas in January, we put up a Christmas tree in the Chateau de La Garoupe in December in accordance with the French (Catholic) tradition for the staff and other visitors. 39 \tI remember seeing Roman arrived in the entrance hall of the Chateau, after lunchtime.  After Roman arrived, Boris, Badri and I went out with Roman onto the terrace.  We would often sit outside at the Chateau, and even during the winter months we kept the terrace doors open.  I wanted to go indoors as soon as I had gone out onto the terrace, and was on my way inside, when Boris asked me to stay out.  I sat on one corner of the terrace, by the dining table, and the three men sat on the other corner, where there are some chairs.  I went inside after around 10 to 15 minutes, as it was cold.  I do not know whether the men also went inside later, or whether they remained outside for the rest of the meeting. 40 \tI had of course come to know Roman very well by this time.  From what I observed, Roman behaved very differently at this meeting from how I had seen him behave previously.  He used to be respectful towards Boris, almost humble.  However, on this visit Roman seemed to be looking down on Boris, as though he now had all the power in the relationship.  My impression was that Roman was trying to demonstrate that he was doing Boris a huge favour.  I heard the men talking about Boris and Badri\'s interests in ORT.  I recall Roman saying that the government wanted to pay significantly less for the ORT shares than he was going to pay, and that it was only thanks to Roman that they would pay more.  I think Roman also said that he was personally paying some of the sale price as he was fed up with the story with Boris and Badri. 41 \tI remember that after the meeting, Boris was outraged.  He told me that Roman had used Nikolay to blackmail Boris and Badri to give up their interests in ORT, and that he was particularly upset that Nikolay had been used.  I remember Boris saying that Roman was a bastard." Contrary to the submission made on page 30 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s First Schedule, this passage did not include a statement that she had  heard  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich threatening the other two men.  As was clear from paragraph 41 of that witness statement, she recorded that she had been told about the "blackmail" by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky after the meeting.  The suggestion that she herself had heard blackmailing threats, and that she understood "the situation was blackmail" was only made for the first time in cross-examination.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s long-time partner, was, understandably, fiercely loyal to him and had clearly discussed the issues in the case with him at length.  This clearly affected the nature and quality of her evidence.  I was not able to accept her evidence in relation to the issues in dispute.  She gave no satisfactory explanation as to why she had not included such allegations in her two witness statements, nor was she able satisfactorily to explain why she had not addressed the point, in such statements, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had allegedly visited Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s chateau at Cap d\'Antibes either on the day of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest or two days thereafter.  Her description of the meeting was equally consistent with the analysis that it had taken place on 6\xc2\xa0November.  Her evidence that she could "remember" Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich not coming to the house on 6 November was not credible.  I doubt whether she had actually heard what was being discussed by the three men, or, even if she had, that she had any true recollection of what was said.  She gave an unsatisfactory explanation as to the omission from her first statement as to any mention of an alleged trip to the United States referred to in her second witness statement.  I could not rely on her evidence as corroborative of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on the alleged date of the meeting at Cap d\'Antibes.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Richard Giroud was head of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s security team in France in 2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud explained how Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s security team was on high alert when he moved to France, and that the team was on even higher alert following Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest.  He gave evidence to the effect that there was only one meeting at Cap d\'Antibes between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich after his flight from Russia.  He had discussed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s last visit to Cap d\'Antibes with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  Although he said he no longer had any connection with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, I formed the impression that his evidence was shaped by what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had asked him to say.  I did not find his evidence, to the effect that the meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich took place after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, reliable.  Despite the increased security measures, neither before, nor after, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest were any records kept of visits by VIP visitors to the chateau.  At one point he appeared to be suggesting that the meeting took place very shortly before Christmas, which was a previous, but now abandoned, case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s.  His evidence appeared to be based on both a recollection of heightened security at the time of the meeting, and the fact that it was winter, rather than summer.  But as Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud accepted, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s security would have been heightened from the moment he arrived as a fugitive in France in late October 2000.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud said, after Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had fled Russia "We was [sic] on big alert".  Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud also said that he recalled that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky left France shortly after the meeting, but Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s travel records revealed that this was as consistent with a meeting on 6 November as it was with a meeting on or about 7 December.  I therefore could not place any real reliance on Mr.\xc2\xa0Giroud\'s evidence as corroboration of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion as to the date of the Cap d\'Antibes meeting.\r   The evidence of third parties such as Mr.\xc2\xa0Goldfarb, Mr.\xc2\xa0Voronoff, Mr.\xc2\xa0Pompadur and Mr.\xc2\xa0Dubov as to what they had subsequently been told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky about the alleged threats made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not provide any satisfactory supporting evidence of his case as to the date of the Cap d\'Antibes meeting.  Indeed in certain respects passages in their evidence undermined his case on this issue.  Moreover, even to the extent that such evidence corroborated Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, it was not possible to attach any serious weight to it, given that it was wholly derived from what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had allegedly told the witnesses, in some cases some time after the event (and, notably, not immediately), but, invariably, also from his discussions with them about the matter over the years.\r   In this context I should, however, refer to the evidence given by Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova in relation to this topic.  On the evening of 18 October 2011 (the night before she gave her evidence) she produced a fresh witness statement in which she claimed, for the very first time, to "recall" having been told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, between seven and ten days after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest (i.e. between 14 and 16 December 2000 [386] ) over breakfast at the Georges V Hotel in Paris about threats being made at a meeting "in France at Boris\'s place".  Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova had sat in Court throughout Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence and had clearly observed from his cross-examination the difficulties which he faced in attempting to place the Cap d\'Antibes meeting in the timeframe 7-9\xc2\xa0December 2000.  The inference which I drew was that she made up this latest aspect of her evidence, having trawled through her travel records, and the relevant information about her and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s movements, in order to ascertain the earliest date on which she could say that he had told her about the meeting.  It was notable that no such suggestion had been made by her previously at a time when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was claiming that the meeting had happened shortly before Christmas, or possibly between two trips which he had made to the United States between 16 and 26 December (in relation to which her recent statement fixing her alleged conversation at a breakfast meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the timeframe 13-16 December would not have been helpful).  Moreover her recent statement was not consistent with her earlier witness statement, in which she had effectively (by reference to other evidence) said that she was told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about the meeting in January 2001.  Nor was her account consistent with what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had told Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors in June 2005 in her presence, as recorded in the briefing notes;  in those notes he was not recorded as mentioning any threat by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and asserted that it was not within Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s power to procure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release.  She did not dispute that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said what he is recorded as saying in those notes, but she tried to suggest that he was misleading Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors for fear that his words would leak out and become known to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  \r   I have summarised my views as to Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova\'s credibility at section VII above.  In all the circumstances I simply do not accept her evidence as to what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was alleged to have told her over breakfast at the Georges V Hotel.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interviews Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the notes of the interviews with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili also supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that a meeting took place in Cap d\'Antibes between the three men after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest.  In my judgment, on a proper analysis, the notes and draft proofs provided very little support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, and, to the extent to which they did so, they are not reliable.\r   The earlier notes, and draft proof, based on the interview with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili which took place on 29 June 2005, did not support the allegation that a meeting took place at Cap d\'Antibes in the course of which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made threats as to the continued detention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov or the expropriation of the ORT stake.  For example, the final version of the draft proof based on the June interview notes of Mr.\xc2\xa0Lankshear and Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson, stated as follows:\r   "As time passed it was clear that we would not be going back to Moscow.  Many agreements were breached by the government.  We did not trust them anymore.  We needed a trusted man.  We received an invitation from RA to meet.  A meeting took place in Paris between myself, BB and RA.  The meeting in Paris took place at the Le Fouquet restaurant in the Champs Elysees.  I even recall where we sat:  the third table from the left. RA:\t\'For your sake, I will buy your shares and give them to the government.\' He offered $150 million.  Previously we had had an agreement with RA to give $50 million to the election campaign of Putin.  Our share was therefore $25 million to this cause, which RA paid.  Taking into account this $25 million, the price offered for ORT was $175 million. Prior to the Paris meeting with RA, BB and I had decided that we were prepared to give away our shares for nothing in exchange for the release of NG.  His freedom was our overriding concern.  We therefore did not hesitate when RA offered to pay $150 million on the basis that NG would be released.  Evidently it was not within RA\'s power to release NG.  Voloshin himself had promised this to me in a personal conversation I had with him later.  Although I believed them, BB on the other hand took some persuading as he was concerned that he would be deceived.   The release of NG would be arranged through Voloshin.  The basis of the agreement was that RA would buy our shares and give them to the government, and in turn NG would be released on the grounds of his ill health. The price for our ORT shares had come down from $300 million to $150 million.  This was consistent with the practice of the Kremlin.  It was usual for the Kremlin to discount an offer by 300%, if its first offer was refused.  We were treated preferentially as our discount was only 50%!" This account did not mention a meeting at Cap d\'Antibes in the aftermath of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest, nor did it refer to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a person who had made any threats.  But it did make clear that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had already decided to sell their shares, prior to any meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was described as a "trusted man":  not as a threatening blackmailer.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were said not to have hesitated when he offered to pay $150 million, albeit "on the basis that NG would be released".  However the draft proof made it clear that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili thought that it was not within Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s power to secure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release.  It records a statement by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin himself, who in a  later  meeting "\xc2\x85 had promised this to me [i.e. Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili]  in a personal conversation I had with him later " [Emphasis supplied].  I deal with the allegation about a later meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin below, but the point for present purposes is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not apparently suggesting that such a promise had emanated from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   Moreover, the evidence, such as it was, both from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about alleged threats or promises from, or meetings with, Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin about the release of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, was mutually inconsistent and changed over time.
