By way of example:  \r   i)\tIn his first statement in January 2002, made in support of his UK asylum application, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said:   "It was made clear to me by  Russian authorities  that Glushkov would be released in exchange for my stake in ORT.  Indeed, I was promised this - by none other than Voloshin"; "\xc2\x85 this tactic has already been used against [me] by none other than Voloshin, who  personally  told me that my good friend Glushkov would be released if I surrendered my ORT shares." [387]  [Emphasis supplied] [388] The point to be emphasised here is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had conveyed this message, even though in a subsequent paragraph, where Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky referred to an article in  Kommersant , Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was referred to as a "go-between".  On the contrary, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was asserting a personal conversation as between him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin in which the promise had been given.  When Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, in his second statement, made clarifications to his first statement, there was likewise no mention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich having conveyed the message.   ii)\tIt was not until Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky made his witness statement in support of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s asylum application in February 2007 that he said that, although the offer was made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin,  "\xc2\x85 to avoid any misunderstanding I should clarify that Voloshin\'s offer itself was communicated by Roman Abramovich". [389] In this statement Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said "this was at the end of December 2000".  By this time proceedings against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich were in contemplation by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky. iii)\tIn an interview given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, published in  Kommersant  on 4 July 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was reported as saying, in connection with attempts to pressurise Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky: "GEVORKIAN.\tYou mentioned attempts to pressure Berezovsky.  What could the actual motif behind it be? PATARKATSISHVILI.\tBoris Abramovich and I underwent all sorts of pressure, before and after Glushkov\'s arrest.  They tried to bargain the Aeroflot case closure for the shares of ORT television.  We agreed to it when Glushkov was arrested.  We sold our shares.  Alexander Voloshin promised that Glushkov would be released, but he cheated us. GEVORKIAN.\tWhom did he give that promise to? PATARKATSISHVILI.\tTo me. GEVORKIAN.\tIn person or by phone? PATARKATSISHVILI.\tHe related it to me through a person whom both Voloshin and I found trustworthy." iv)\tIt was assumed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin that the reference to "\xc2\x85 a person whom both Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin and I found trustworthy" was in fact Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  This account was quite different from the story given to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors in 2005 when the suggestion was made that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili himself had personally had a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin;   v)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili went on in the  Kommersant  interview to describe negotiations which, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was not released at the end of December, he conducted between January and April 2001 with a number of government officials and emissaries of President Putin, including Mr.\xc2\xa0Sergei Ivanov in order to secure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release.  These negotiations were also referred to by Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in his asylum application and by Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova in the course of her evidence at trial [390] .  There are two points to be made about these negotiations:  first, they did not involve Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in any way whatsoever;  and second, and, interestingly, the terms in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili described them was that, in return for the release of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, the Kremlin insisted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should sell their entire media empire, including all broadcasting and television channels (such as NTV and TV-6) and newspapers, and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should "quit political activity". Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also relied on notes made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors of meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in June and November 2007, respectively in England and Israel.  However, as I have already decided, little weight can be attached to these as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, even when the wording of the notes might appear to do so.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was an active participant at all the meetings and had already started his action against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  His solicitors would no doubt have been looking for evidence which supported his case.  Neither Ms.\xc2\xa0 Duncan nor Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim spoke Russian and there was no independent translator present.  They were therefore unable to verify the accuracy of the apparent translations or explanations given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s statements.  Nor were they in a position to understand what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were saying to each other.\r   Amongst other notes, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz relied upon passages in Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson\'s notes taken on 11 June 2007:  \r   "le Bourget airport/Sibneft Roman last time met in chateau airport in Germany"  and a side note on the previous page, which, next to a reference about the Paris meeting, read:   "Badri, BB, RA. Before Chateau in BB house After Nikolai in prison - 7 December - 25 December"; Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also relied on passages in Ms.\xc2\xa0Duncan\'s note of meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on 29-30 November 2007, which read:   "BB Glushkov arrested Dec. 17/12 RA came to France - arranged by Badri Said sell shares in ORT Said he came on order of Voloshin & Putin -said if we don\'t sell, Putin would take anyway I raised issue of Nikolai, he in jail.  He said if we settle deal Glushkov released Badri settled how much AP BP 1st meeting in France BP called him and arranged meeting We understood we need to meet - both sides. Thought he wld raise Sibneft but he didn\'t .... Antibes House - RA gave us info from Voloshin & Putin.  If you guys don\'t give them the sh\'s NG in jail a long time.  RA said NG v sick, I\'m sorry about this - we decided to give shares. Talked about price - agreed RA said. \xc2\x85 2 meetings with RA - Fouquet + Antibes - threat made Fouquet - also meeting abt ORT, NG Fouquet - BP at George V - met at Fouquet v.  beautiful day. Spring or summer. Antibes - v.  short time after NG arrested (17/12)" Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim, one of the solicitors who attended the meeting in Tel Aviv, recalled that there was disagreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as to whether an alleged meeting took place in Le Fouquet in Paris or at Cap d\'Antibes [391] . I cannot place any real weight on these notes as corroborative evidence supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, such as to persuade me to reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that no meeting took place at Cap d\'Antibes in the period 7-9 December 2000, supported as it was by travel records and other evidence.  Nor, in the light of his evidence and that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin, am I persuaded to attach any weight to the statements in the notes that suggest that threats were made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on the instructions of President Putin and Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin.  Given the circumstances in which the notes were made, and in particular the presence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at the 2007 meetings they are likely to have been self-serving.  Their unreliability is compounded by the successive changes in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on this issue, as well as the different accounts apparently given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of his communications with Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin.\r   The alleged end of the friendship between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich following the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that what he referred to as "the sudden and dramatic end" of the two men\'s friendship at the end of 2000 or early 2001, strongly supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case both in relation to the ORT intimidation issue, and more generally in relation to both Sibneft and RUSAL.  He submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had no coherent explanation for why his friendship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky ended exactly at the time of the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting, which was marked by him not being invited to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s birthday party in January 2001, for the first time since 1996, and by the fact that the men (who had plainly been close) never met again, nor had a proper conversation with each other thereafter.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence was that the Cap d\'Antibes meeting was followed by a complete breakdown of relations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, explicable only by his treacherous behaviour at that meeting.  He described the end of their friendship in the following way:  \r   "In view of our previous friendship and trusted business relationship, I felt hurt and betrayed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  I was sure he had lied to me when he had told me at Le Bourget that he did not expect Nikolay to be arrested, and it was clear to me that in acting as President Putin\'s messenger in the ORT intimidation he was acting for his own benefit - strengthening his own position in the Kremlin, while hurting me, his partner, and at the same time making money out of it.  Over the years, a number of people close to me had warned me not to trust Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich - Badri, Nikolay, Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova, my partner Elena, George Soros (through Alex Goldfarb) - but I had paid no attention to them.  I saw now that I had been wrong to trust Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  At the conclusion of the meeting, I made it clear to him that I knew he was blackmailing me, and that he had betrayed me.  I told him \'It\'s the last time that I will meet you Roma, I never want to see you again\'.  The next time I spoke to him was seven years later, when I personally served these proceedings on him at an Hermes shop in London (and he sought to avoid the service of proceedings)" [392] . Having heard the evidence which both men gave about the end of their friendship, I conclude that such evidence does not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s account of the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting, and that his description was not only exaggerated but also inaccurate.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that their friendship did not stop or cease at any single point of time, but rather gradually declined.  I accept as realistic his cynical comment that his friendship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been based on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s payouts and that, at the point when the final payout had been agreed, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interest in him "was gone".  \r   Thus even before December 2000, the relationship between the two men had cooled.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained, during 2000 Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s influence in Russia declined.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was no longer of active use to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  After the meeting at the Dorchester Hotel in March 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich saw less of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili than he had previously done.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was spending increasing amounts of time out of Russia, even before Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s public dispute with President Putin in relation to various issues including, in particular, the handling of the  Kursk  disaster in August 2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich strongly disapproved of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s response to the disaster, which caused him to question their relationship which thereafter declined further.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described this decline as follows in his 3 rd  witness statement:\r   "202.\tBy way of background, I should explain that my relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky changed after the  Kursk  tragedy of August 2000.  In my view, he took an overtly hostile and one-sided stance against the country\'s leadership as a means of promoting himself.  I believed, and still believe, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was wrong to have used the media, which he controlled, to exploit a public tragedy of that sort to further his own political agenda against the government.  I made clear to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky what my views were.  I did not openly disagree with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky very often and this fact alone caused some disturbance in our relationship.  After that, we almost stopped meeting in person and I increasingly dealt with him through Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili." By late 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had fled Russia and there was even less occasion for the two men to meet.  Thereafter, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky became an increasingly vocal critic of President Putin and the two men grew further apart politically.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Gorbunova\'s evidence, which I have concluded related to a meeting at Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s chateau at Cap d\'Antibes on 6 November 2000, can be accepted insofar as it spoke of her appreciation of a change in the dynamic of the relationship between the two men.  It is not difficult to see why, by November/December 2000, relations between the two men were chilly:  on the one hand, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was frustrated by what he described as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s "irrational behaviour";  as a fugitive from Russia, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was of no use to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich politically, at least for the time being, whilst the present regime remained in power, and indeed had become an expensive liability;  on the other hand, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, as an exile, was no doubt angered or upset by what he would have perceived as the younger man\'s disloyalty and presumption in expressing disapproval of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s public criticism of President Putin.  The appreciation that his prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9 no longer had need of him may have wounded his pride.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described, after the  Kursk  disaster, a number of former acquaintances of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also stopped communicating with him;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would not have been pleased that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had given similar indications of having become disaffected.  These would have been more than sufficient reasons for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s decision not to have invited Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to his birthday party on 23 January 2001.\r   I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, supported by the evidence of his former chef, Mr.\xc2\xa0Christian Sponring, and travel records, that the two men did in fact meet again shortly afterwards, together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, at the M\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa8ve heliport on 10 January 2001.  I deal with the subject matter of the meeting below in the context of the Sibneft intimidation issue.  I accept that it was a meeting conducted on amicable, or reasonably amicable, terms.  \r   The next day, on 11 January 2001 Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky gave an interview in  Kommersant  in which he said:  "I trust Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a business partner":  a surprising description of someone who allegedly only a month earlier had blackmailed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky into selling shares with the threat of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s continued detention.  Interestingly, he also said that, having originally offered to sell the ORT shares to President Putin right after the election, he had returned to the question of the sale of the shares "earlier than \xc2\x85 a month ago", as soon as he had realised that the trust company, which he had proposed to create, would not be able to perform its functions and would not be able to preserve ORT\'s independence.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s explanation in cross-examination that he did not:\r   "\xc2\x85 want to put Abramovich as my enemy publicly because I want to give him space to deliver what we discuss to deliver"  was not convincing;  he could simply have referred to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as his business partner, without expressing the sentiment that he trusted him. The fact that, as I find, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich continued to have a good relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili up until the time of the latter\'s death in February 2008, was also inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the ORT intimidation issue.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was also a friend of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, albeit not such a close friend as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, and one might have expected him to have adopted a similar attitude to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and cut off friendly relations with him, had the latter indeed made the alleged threats in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s continued detention at a Cap d\'Antibes meeting on 7 December 2000.  On the contrary, the two men continued to see each other and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich visited Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Georgia.  For example, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich recounted, having been "stunned" to read disparaging comments made in press interview by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in December 2002, to the effect that he "did not know" Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, he arranged to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Georgia in February 2003.  After the two men had discussed Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich raised the topic of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s disparaging remarks.  I quote the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in his fourth witness statement on this issue in full, because it provides an insight into what was probably the explanation for what became the enmity between the two men.  It is not necessary for me to express any view, and I make no judgment, as to whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was justified in the view that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had betrayed him:\r   "Then I asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about what happened with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and why he suddenly had such a negative reaction to me.  I had been thinking all this time that I had pleased him and had ensured that both he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had enough income to allow them to pursue their various interests outside Russia and enjoy life.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been declared the richest man in Georgia.  Suddenly, when reading the interview in December, the idea presented itself for the first time that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could be unhappy about something, and that made a strong impression on me.  I had been so sure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would think and speak well of me so his interview had shocked me.  I explained my feelings to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and he told me not to worry and pay no attention.  He said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was losing sleep over the capitalisation of Sibneft and was now wishing that he could be part of it.  He just said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was probably just jealous and could not cope with the fact that I might be richer than him.  He assured me that, so far as he was concerned, given the situation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky found themselves at the time, they had made very good money and were therefore very happy.  I felt that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili took my side.  It was our first open conversation after the \'final payment\' deal. We had similar conversations later, including in 2006 when he asked for my help in the \'divorce\' from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  However, this conversation in Georgia was the first time that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was wrong and told that it was \'Boris being Boris\', and \'you can\'t do anything about it\'.  I still felt uncomfortable, as I did not want to believe that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky thought negatively of me;  moreover, it was unjustified.  Because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s obsession with publicity, others might now believe that I had somehow deceived Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  That feeling was particularly unpleasant considering the fact that I had paid him in cash an amount that was absolutely unheard of at the time and had made him apparently happy at the time.  I was the person who had been betrayed." I cannot accept Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova\'s evidence that the continuing contact between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was the result of attempts on Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s part to negotiate some sort of settlement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  She suggested that in 2004 he was conducting negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili with regards to him paying compensation for selling Sibneft at an artificially understated value;  and that in June 2005 and early 2006 the two men were negotiating some sort of settlement in relation to Sibneft and RUSAL.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky made allegations to similar effect and attempted to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was "playing a game" against "the enemy", Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and that, whilst the relations between the two men were outwardly friendly, the reality was that both men were behaving in a "perfectly, perfectly, perfectly hypocritical" manner.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence to the effect that there were no such negotiations and that he maintained a genuinely friendly relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili after the final payment (to which I refer below).  This was supported by the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, who knew Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from 1999, and who said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili "always spoke very nicely, very kindly and favourably about Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich" [393] .\r   The funding of ORT\'s liabilities by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich Another aspect of the evidence which supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, and undermines that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (to the effect that the sale of the ORT stake was only decided upon after the alleged threats made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting on 7 December 2000), was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had started to pay for ORT\'s deficit from as early as October 2000.  Thus the Bolshoi Balance, under Tab "2000 total, cash incl.  monthly" showed a payment of cash out under the heading "ORT CASH" of $1.6 million in October 2000 and $2 million in December 2000.  \r   Alleged control of ORT by the Russian State after the sale of the 49% stake In support of his case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had acted as a tool of the Russian State, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested that, following Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s acquisition of the 49% ORT stake, the State gained full control of ORT.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that at no time had he ceded control over his ORT stake to the Russian government;  he pointed out in his oral evidence that the government had always had a 51% controlling stake in ORT, and that the director general appointed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Ernst, remained at ORT to this day.  It was also suggested to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, by reference to certain press reports in early 2001, that he had not appointed any representatives to the ORT board but had allowed the government to make all the appointments.  However later press reports, to which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not taken, showed that a general shareholders meeting originally scheduled for 29 June 2001 was postponed, because the proposed board, which was being put forward for election, made up entirely of government officials "did not reflect the essence of public television", according to a statement made by Press Minister, Mr.\xc2\xa0Lesin, at the time.  Thereafter, on 7 September 2001, a new Board of Directors was elected which included independent cultural figures, such as the film director Nikita Mikhalkov and the Hermitage Museum director, Mikhail Piotrovsky, in the majority, and with State officials in the minority.  Accordingly, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could place no reliance on this point in support of his case.\r   Conclusion in relation to the ORT intimidation issue I conclude that, whilst Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not sign the share sale agreement transferring his stake to an Abramovich company until 29 December 2000 (and the agreement transferring the LogoVAZ ORT stake was not signed until 28 December 2000), and whilst he may not have been contractually bound until late December, he certainly had in contemplation a sale to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich from October/early November 2000, if not earlier.  Once he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov had been summoned to appear before the public prosecutor in connection with the Aeroflot investigation, it was clear that the writing was on the wall, and that both men faced the overwhelming likelihood of arrest if they remained in Russia.  It may be that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky personally did not make his final decision to sell until he heard of the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov.  It matters not.  But I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he only decided to sell his stake in ORT at the alleged meeting in Cap d\'Antibes on 7, 8 or 9 December as a result of threats made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to the continued detention Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov or the expropriation of the 49% ORT stake, or as a result of any promise by him that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be released.  \r   In reaching this conclusion, and save to the limited extent addressed above in relation to the Kremlin meetings in August 2000, I make no findings as to what pressures, if any, may have been imposed upon Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili by representatives of the Russian State to persuade them to divest themselves of their media interests or to refrain from public criticism of the regime.  All that is necessary for the purposes of this case is my determination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself did not communicate the threats alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.\r   Section XI - Issue A3:  The Sibneft intimidation issue Introduction This section of the judgment addresses Issue A3 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, namely:  \r   "If Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had an interest in Sibneft, did Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich threaten Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that, unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sold that interest to him or his nominee, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would take steps to ensure that: i)\t\this interest in Sibneft would be expropriated by the Russian state;  and/or ii)\t\tMr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be detained in prison for an extended period?" For the sake of brevity I shall refer to this issue as the "Sibneft intimidation issue". In the light of my conclusion in relation to Issue A1, Issue A3 does not strictly arise for determination.  But, although the issue is strictly hypothetical in the light of my decision that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in fact had no interest in Sibneft, which could have been expropriated, it is nonetheless appropriate that I should express my conclusions in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue.  This is because both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich placed considerable weight on such evidence, not only in support of their general submissions as to the credibility of the two men and the various witnesses, but also in support of their respective substantive cases in relation to the existence or otherwise of the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted, if indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had made threats to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft "interests" would be expropriated if they did not sell to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at the price he demanded, that would strongly support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that the latter did indeed have such an interest.  Secondly, if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended, the only explanation for the sum of $1.3 billion paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the circumstances described below was that the sum represented the sale price of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili Sibneft interests, that also would necessarily support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  \r   I also consider that it is appropriate to address the issue because of the very serious nature of the allegations that have been made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  If indeed I were of the view, having read and heard all the evidence, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had intimidated or blackmailed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, whether in the manner alleged or otherwise, it would be right that I should say so, notwithstanding that, theoretically, the issue of intimidation/blackmail might not have been relevant to my ultimate determination of the case.  Conversely, if I were not of that view, it would be fair to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that I should likewise express my conclusion.  \r   The issue This issue, as fully articulated in the Agreed List of Issues, is as follows:\r   "7.\tDid Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich make threats to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (relayed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky), with the intention of causing them to dispose of their interests in Sibneft? In particular:   (1) \tDid Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich threaten in the course of meetings in Moscow with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from about August 2000 to May 2001 that he would use his influence with the Putin regime to seek to cause Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests in Sibneft to be expropriated unless they sold their interests to him?  (2) \tDid Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich threaten in the course of a meeting at Munich or Cologne airport in May 2001 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence within the Putin regime to seek to ensure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would not be released from prison?  8.\t\tIf the threats alleged in paragraph 7 were made, did they in fact coerce Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky into disposing of his alleged rights in relation to Sibneft or did he do so for other reasons?" Executive summary of my conclusions in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue In summary, my conclusion in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not make either express or implied threats to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, with the intention of intimidating them to dispose of their alleged interests in Sibneft.  In particular, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not threaten, in the course of meetings in Moscow with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from about August 2000 to May 2001, that he would use his influence with the Putin regime to seek to cause Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests in Sibneft to be expropriated unless they sold their interests to him;  nor, in the course of meetings at Munich and Cologne airport in May 2001, did Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich threaten that he would use his influence within the Putin regime to seek to ensure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would not be released from prison.  I also conclude that the sum of $1.3 billion paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not represent the sale price of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged Sibneft interest, but rather was a final lump sum payment in order to discharge what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich regarded as his  krysha  obligations.\r   In the circumstances, and given my conclusion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no such interest, the issue articulated in paragraph 8 of the Agreed List of Issues (i.e.  whether the threats made coerced Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky into disposing of his alleged Sibneft interest) does not arise for determination.  \r   Relationship with the ORT intimidation issue As I have already explained, the ORT intimidation issue had implications for the Sibneft intimidation issue, and for that reason was closely connected with it, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case was that "the ORT transaction presaged the  modus operandi  for the Sibneft transaction" [394] .  Specifically, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich deliberately arranged for Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov to remain in prison so that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could use the same alleged threat a second time in relation to Sibneft.  In his fourth witness statement he put it as follows:\r   "365.\tHowever, despite the sale of the ORT shares to entities controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and despite Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich telling us that he was working to make sure that Nikolay would be free, and despite our being told that Nikolay would be released on New Year\'s Eve, Nikolay remained in prison.  I had, and have, no doubt that this was Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s doing:  he wanted Nikolay to stay in prison because he was determined to use the same pressure to which we had submitted in relation to ORT again for his own purposes, in order to take our share of Sibneft." In cross-examination he confirmed that this indeed was his case and emphasised Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s appreciation that, because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s concern about Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s predicament, he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, had strong leverage to force the two men to surrender their Sibneft interests.  The following passage from his cross-examination gives a flavour of his evidence on this topic:\r   "\t\xc2\x85 my clear understanding is that after Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich recognised how important Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov is for us and that we, without any discussion about price or anything, agreed that Glushkov will be released if we will -- if we\'ll sell - return back our shares and not to be keep in jail a long, long time.  Abramovich recognise that it\'s -- this point is very sensitive for us. And just later on, but not too much later because even in autumn 2000, when we have been in Russia, Abramovich already mentioned that Sibneft is under pressure because of my new and -- because of my tension with Putin and he already that time start to, already that time start to present position that we had become more dangerous for the company than even before.  But when he recognised that he has amazing leverage, then he made -- he is progressing in his, I don\'t like to say, violence.  Because initially he put Putin behind - he put Putin in front of him as far as ORT is concerned  saying, \'This is Putin, this is not me, this is Putin asking\'. In Sibneft, position was different, \'Putin is behind of me and you know that he is dangerous, he can do everything and I\'m the person who has special relations with Putin\', and he may influence - \'I may influence to his decision\'. In RusAl case, he even did not put Putin at all as a name because he already was form himself, I\'m sorry to say, as a gangster, yes, because he already knew that it\'s enough him to do any step, we are not able to do anything.  It\'s like evolution of crime of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and in Sibneft it was the same story but it\'s the story of Abramovich with Putin behind of him. Q.\t\tWhat is your evidence, if you have any, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich deliberately kept Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in jail so as to be able to use the threat a second time? If you don\'t have any evidence, fine;  if you do, now is your chance to tell us what it is. A.\t\tIt\'s exactly the point.  The point is that Abramovich has a great influence to Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin.  I don\'t think that Putin point was to seize Sibneft because he got that time what he want to get, ORT under his control, and recognising the importance for us of Glushkov, Abramovich used the same method, the same method, threat, and we didn\'t have choice. We didn\'t have choice for two reasons.  Because, first of all, Abramovich did not deliver on the one hand that Glushkov will be released.  On the other hand, he again said that he -- that Glushkov will be released and we will start negotiations, because it\'s long story, not just for five minutes.  And it is the point that we accept absolutely seriously, serious, that this is threat and [Glushkov] stay in jail long, long time if we will not sell our shares or if we will not sell --" In his evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that he had not previously taken "especially seriously" the "warnings" that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich is alleged to have given to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili after August 2000 about a possible expropriation of Sibneft [395] .  According to him, it was the meeting in December 2000 at Cap d\'Antibes that changed his view:\r   "But with the arrest of Nikolay, the betrayal of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and the realisation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was himself in a position to influence, and might well in fact be influencing, all that was happening, I saw Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s threats for what they were. \xc2\x85 From the time of the Cap d\'Antibes meeting in late December 2000, I believed that the pressure from the Kremlin (if any) was an excuse and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was the person who would make the seizure happen (using his influence with President Putin), or not." [396] In other words, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case was that the inference which he reasonably drew from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s conduct at the Cap d\'Antibes meeting was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was threatening that he himself would use his influence to bring the alleged consequences about.  Thus, on any basis, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Sibneft intimidation allegations were extremely serious ones [397] .  Unlike the ORT intimidation allegation, which involved Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich merely acting as the agent of the Russian State in conveying the State\'s message that it would continue to detain Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov and expropriate the ORT stake, unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky agreed to sell the stake to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the Sibneft intimidation allegations postulated the accusation that  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself , through his influence over President Putin and the then current administration, would bring about not only the expropriation by the State of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged Sibneft interests, but also the continued imprisonment of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov.  In other words, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was accusing Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich not merely of being the messenger of the State\'s blackmail threat, but rather as the enforcer of such threat, if the demands were not met.  It is because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s reliance on what he asserts happened at the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting on 7 December 2000 that my conclusions in relation to the ORT intimidation issue have such significance.\r   Relevant law governing the alleged tort By the time of closing submissions, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case was that the Sibneft intimidation claim was governed by French law, alternatively English law, on the basis that the alleged threats were, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky:\r   "\xc2\x85 largely made in France, entirely received by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in France, and acted upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to his detriment in France and in England". Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case was that the alleged tort was governed by Russian law.  It was common ground that, in all relevant respects relating to be necessary constituent elements of the tort, French law was the same as English law.  \r   As identified in paragraph 5 of the Court of Appeal\'s judgment in respect of the summary judgment application in this case, the essential ingredients of the tort of intimidation as a matter of English law are:\r   "1) \ta threat by the defendant (D) to do something unlawful or "illegitimate"; 2) \tthe threat must be intended to coerce the claimant (C) to take or refrain from taking some course of action; 3) \tthe threat must in fact coerce C to take such action; 4) \tloss or damage must be incurred by C as a result."  Broadly speaking it was agreed that a claim for intimidation in Russian law turned on principles similar, but not identical, to those which would apply at English law.  Broadly speaking, it was agreed that, as a matter of Russian law, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had to establish:\r   i)\tharm (i.e.  loss); ii)\tfault on the part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;   iii)\tunlawful conduct of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  and iv)\ta causal link between the two.   It was also common ground between the parties that both Russian law and English law [398]  recognised a distinction between a (non-actionable) warning by the alleged tortfeasor about something that a third party may do, and an actionable threat by the alleged tortfeasor to do the act himself, or bring it about.  \r   So far as limitation issues were concerned, it was common ground between the parties that:\r   i)\tunder the Foreign Limitation Periods Act 1984, the limitation period to be applied was that of the substantive law governing the alleged tort; ii)\tif the alleged tort were governed by French law, the claim would not be time-barred.   However, there was a dispute between the parties as to whether, if English or Russian law applied, the intimidation claim would be time-barred.   For the purposes of establishing the facts in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue, it was not necessary for me to decide which was the substantive law governing the alleged tort.\r   The evolution of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue Before I turn to consider the evidence relating to the Sibneft intimidation issue, I identify certain background matters which are relevant to my evaluation of that evidence.  \r   In assessing the veracity of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue, it is appropriate to have regard to the change in the nature of his allegations over time.  As I have already said, in a case of this type which relates back to events which occurred many years ago, it may well be that inconsistencies in the pleading or presentation of a party\'s case should not attract criticism or be regarded as undermining the central thrust of the claim or defence put forward.  That is particularly so where, as the trial draws nearer, investigations into the evidentiary background are more focused, and witnesses\' memories may be prompted by their having to concentrate their minds on detail.  But in circumstances where, as here, the court is left with the uneasy suspicion that the changes to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on critical facts (such as what he understood the alleged threats were, and how he assessed them), were tailored to meet legal difficulties raised on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or by the court, during the course of the summary judgment application, they become a necessary part of the evaluation process.\r   The evolution of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on this issue may be summarised as follows:\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s current case on intimidation is pleaded at paragraphs C41 to C46 of the Re-re-re-Amended Particulars of Claim.  It is as follows: a)\tAt meetings in Moscow between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili between August 2000 and May 2001 [399] , Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that there was "increasing pressure from the Kremlin" and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests in Sibneft could [400]  (or would [401] ) be expropriated [402] .  It is not alleged that any threat relating to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was made on these occasions.  It was clear to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from those statements that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili understood (as, it is alleged, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich intended him to) that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should sell their interests in Sibneft to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or "face the consequences". [403] b)\tIn the Voluntary Further Information dated 17 January 2011, served by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky during the hearing in the Court of Appeal, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky pleaded that it was implicit in these statements that "Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence with the Putin regime to seek to cause their interests to be expropriated." [404]   c)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili relayed the content of those conversations to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at his home in France, as a result of which they decided in early 2001 to sell their interests in Sibneft to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and asked for a meeting to discuss the terms. [405]   d)\tThat meeting occurred at Munich airport in early May 2001.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich attended with Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili attended with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not there.  In the absence of Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili raised the question of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release from prison.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that although Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov had not been released in December 2000, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were to sell their interests in Sibneft to him, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would now be released [406] . e)\tIn the Voluntary Further Information served by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky during the hearing in the Court of Appeal, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged that it was implicit in these statements:  (i) that if they did not sell their interest in Sibneft to him, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would not be released;  and (ii) that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence with the "Putin regime" to ensure that he was not released [407] . f)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili told Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky wanted a total of $2.5 billion for their interest in Sibneft shares, even though he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky recognised that this was significantly less than the shares were worth;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich stated that he would only pay $1.3 billion and also refused to pay monies which were allegedly due in connection with their interests in Sibneft and which had not been paid since December 2000 [408] . g)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in private then rang Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky from the Munich meeting.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was at his home at Cap d\'Antibes.  They discussed (i) what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had said to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili since August 2000 about the risk of expropriation;  (ii) the threats that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had made in relation to ORT;  and (iii) the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov had been arrested in December 2000 and detained in very ill health in Lefortovo prison.  They concluded that in these circumstances they had no option but to sell at the $1.3 billion figure which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had offered [409] . h)\tThe result was an agreement to sell the interests of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for the significantly undervalued price of $1.3 billion [410] .  By the Devonia Agreement dated 12 June 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili agreed to sell their interest in Sibneft to Devonia [411] . However, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted in his oral closing submissions, the Sibneft expropriation threat now being alleged was materially different from the one that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was consistently alleging in the period from 2003 up until the first version of his particulars of claim dated 6 September 2007, and indeed thereafter.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not originally suggest that there was a threat to expropriate his interest.  The threat, as allegedly conveyed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was that Sibneft, as a company, would be attacked by agencies of the Russian State if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky continued to be associated with it.  The allegation was couched in these terms, for example, in various press interviews, in Carter Ruck\'s letter before action dated 14 May 2007 and in a witness statement given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky dated 25 September 2007 in the context of litigation between other Russian oligarchs, namely the  Cherney v Deripaska   litigation.  In the letter before action the case alleged, in summary, was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich "advised" Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky continued to be associated with Sibneft,  the company  would come under attack from the Russian Prosecutor\'s office and tax authorities in the same way as had Mr.\xc2\xa0Gusinsky\'s companies.  The claim in the letter was based, not on implicit threats from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, but rather on the proposition that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been induced to part with his interest on the basis of "threats and intimidation" made by the Russian State, of which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had taken "unfair and unconscionable advantage".  It did not allege any threats of action by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  any threats of expropriation by the Russian State of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests;  or indeed any threats at all, even by the Russian government, before the alleged Munich airport meeting.  In cross-examination Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky agreed that letter described "absolutely correctly" what he said was the "reality" [412] .  He claimed that "the facts are the same" but that the "understanding of the lawyers step by step changes" [413] .  I did not find that explanation of the change to his case satisfactory.\r   The first occasion on which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged that there was a threat to expropriate his interest was in the first version of his Particulars of Claim, dated 6 September 2007 (which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich claimed had never been formally served).  This statement of case alleged that at the Munich meeting Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had said that there was both a threat to the company and a threat to expropriate Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests.  It pleaded:\r   "15.\tAt the May 2001 meeting, the Defendant told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili: (1)\tthat so long as the Claimant continued to hold any beneficial interest in Sibneft, Sibneft, its management and its owners would face continued persecution from the Russian Prosecutor\'s Office and the tax authorities; (2)\tthat if the Claimant did not relinquish his  interest in Sibneft, it would come under attack by those in power in Russia in a manner similar to companies controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Gusinsky; (3)\tthat if the Claimant did not relinquish his interest in Sibneft it would simply be seized by the Russian state without compensation.  Accordingly, he had no alternative but to dispose of it to the Defendant."  [414] However, even at this stage, it was not alleged that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would bring this about, rather that the Russian State would do so;  I do not accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that such an allegation was implicit in this pleading.  The subsequent Particulars of Claim (served on 8 January, 2008) did not expressly do so, but they did make sufficiently clear and specific allegations against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that the Court of Appeal was able to conclude that [415] :  \r   "\xc2\x85 any informed and reasonable person would understand that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was alleging that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was threatening (at any rate impliedly, if not expressly) that he would do what he could to bring about the threatened expropriation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Sibneft interests if he was not prepared to sell at an undervalue to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich."  Again, I found Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s attempt in cross-examination to explain this change in his case unconvincing.  He said that:  \r   "But again, I present again \xc2\x85  the same story.  I never change the facts.  The interpretation of the facts is like lawyers\' understanding.  And at the beginning, particularly at the beginning, it was a lot misunderstanding what I presented and what was reality;  what I presented and how they accept it [416] . But the reality here was that the allegation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky understood from his conversation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence at the Kremlin to bring about the expropriation without compensation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft interests, was a critical - and basic - factual element of the story which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself needed to provide to his solicitors;  it was not something that should have only emerged as a result of his lawyers\' changing "interpretation" of the facts.  \r   In a similar way, the allegation relating to the alleged threat about Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov has also changed over time.  Thus, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegation in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was originally that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich assured Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at the meeting at Munich airport in May 2001 that, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s alleged interests in Sibneft were sold, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would be released from prison.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not alleged to have said that he would do anything to  prolong  Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s detention, but only to have assured Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that the government would release Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili sold out of Sibneft.  The allegation appeared in this form in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s witness statement in the  Cherney v Deripaska  litigation in September 2007 [417] ;  and also in his witness statement in response to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s application for summary judgment, where the allegation was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had said that "\xc2\x85 he would see to it that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was now released" [418] .\r   The allegation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky understood that:\r   "\xc2\x85 unless we sold our interests in Sibneft,  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich  would use his influence with President Putin and the Prosecutor-General\'s office to ensure that [Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov] would not be released from prison" and that he had: "\xc2\x85 no doubt that this was what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich intended we understand" emerged for the first time in the Voluntary Further Information served in the course of the hearing in the Court of Appeal [419] , as a result, I was told, of comments made by the Court,  arguendo , to the effect that the only allegation then pleaded, namely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov "would now be released" [420] , was an inducement, not a threat.  The allegation in its revised form then appeared in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s fourth witness statement in the following terms: [421] "384 \tBadri telephoned me from the meeting.  I was at my home in Cap d\'Antibes at the time. 385 \tThe first thing we discussed was the release of Nikolay from prison, which, Badri told me, he had raised.  He said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told him that although Nikolay had not been released in December 2000, if we were to sell our interest in Sibneft to him, he would see to it that Nikolay was now released.  I understood from this that, unless we sold our interests in Sibneft, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence with President Putin and the Prosecutor-General\'s office to ensure that Nikolay would not be released from prison.  I had no doubt that this is what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich intended that we understand, especially as he had made clear at our meeting at Le Bourget how close he was to influential people within the Prosecutor-General\'s office." Although in his written evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested that he had only inferred from what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence to keep Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in jail, in his oral evidence Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky insisted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had actually said to him that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was going to ensure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov stayed in jail [422] .\r   The need to interpret Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s words and conduct in context However, it is important to emphasise that, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted [423] , whilst Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case recognised the distinction between a non-actionable warning and an actual threat, it had always accepted that the words used by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, on their face, did not purport to threaten Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky but rather warned him of adverse State action;  in other words, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted, it had never been Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had said in  express  terms that, unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky handed over Sibneft, then Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself would bring about the expropriation of his interests and cause Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov to remain in prison indefinitely;  rather, it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was more subtle than to put his point expressly - he was playing a game;  but his clear message, which he intended to, and indeed did, deliver and which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili well understood, was a threat;  thus the issue was not whether the express words of threat were used;  rather the issue was whether,  in context , what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said was intended to be, and was properly understood to be, a threat or merely a warning.  \r   I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that context is key, and that it is not appropriate, in evaluating the evidence, merely to look at the actual words used by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Rather the court has to look at the circumstantial context in which the discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili took place and to identify whether, in that context, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could properly have construed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s words and conduct as a threat.\r   Inherent difficulty with the alleged expropriation threat Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted that there was a conceptual difficulty inherent in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the alleged threat that, unless he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili sold their Sibneft interests to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the Russian authorities would expropriate such interests and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would use his influence with President Putin to bring that about;  the difficulty was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case now was that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili simply had personal contractual rights as against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, in relation to their Sibneft and Sibneft-derived interests and not proprietary rights.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted that it was difficult to envisage how the State was going to go about expropriating an undocumented personal contractual right;  the notion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was going to procure the Russian State to require Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to transfer their alleged personal contractual rights against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to the State, thereby substituting itself as the alleged "partner" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had an air of unreality about it.\r   As Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted in response, as a matter of legal technicality it would, of course, be possible for the Russian State to interfere with personal contractual rights and deprive a person of them.  He gave theoretical examples such as the State:  declaring that all of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assets were forfeit to the State, so that any contractual obligations due to him were then due to the State;  or declaring that his contractual rights no longer existed;  or putting pressure on prosecutors and judges to refuse to recognise Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s rights.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz pointed out that in any event, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had never suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich actually used the word "expropriation" in his discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, nor had he alleged that the precise way in which his interests would be taken were spelt out in so many words;  it did not need to be.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz referred to the fact that, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had explained in paragraph 373 of his 4 th  witness statement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no doubt that a range of strategies using criminal investigations, court procedures, insolvency procedures, tax investigations and the like could have been used, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had wanted.  He also submitted that, under whichever was the correct law of the tort, it was irrelevant whether the threat was in fact possible to carry out;  all that mattered was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky believed that such measures could have been adopted and he was not challenged on such belief.\r   Whilst I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz is correct in submitting that, theoretically no doubt, the Russian State might have acted in any of the ways alleged, I am nonetheless left with a sense of unreality in relation to the idea that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have threatened to use his influence with the Putin regime to bring about the expropriation by the State of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s vague and undocumented contractual rights against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Sibneft.  The last thing that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have wanted from a commercial point of view, given the history of the Sibneft privatisation, was the State, in effect, as assignee of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili), having an equal share in Sibneft.  The far more obvious course would have been for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich simply to have threatened that the two men would never be able to prove their undocumented rights against him in a Russian court.  But that was not a suggestion made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in his witness statement - nor was the allegation made that pressure could be exerted by the State on prosecutors and judges to refuse to recognise Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s rights, notwithstanding Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s reference to it in argument.\r   Moreover, the various ways in which it was suggested both in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence and in his written closing submissions [424]  that " de facto  expropriation" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s alleged Sibneft interest could have been achieved, all involved action targeted against Sibneft itself.  It was implausible to suppose that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would seek to procure such damaging action against a company of which, on this hypothesis, he was 50% owner.  The idea, suggested at page 200 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s First Schedule, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could, or would, have procured the placing of Sibneft into bankruptcy, following some spurious tax investigation (also procured by him), so that he could have purchased its assets at an undervalue and thus have become 100% owner of the business, was also fanciful, given Sibneft\'s reliance on Western loan capital and the reputational consequences of such a scheme for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   It is against the above background that I turn to consider the evidence relating to the Sibneft intimidation issue.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s access to and influence with President Putin and the Kremlin It was clear from the evidence that, at the material times, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich enjoyed very good relations with President Putin and others in power at the Kremlin, such as Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin, who was then Head of the Presidential Administration.  It was also clear that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had privileged access to President Putin, in the sense that he could arrange meetings and discuss matters with him, such as the purchase of the ORT shares, the release of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s campaign in respect of the Chukotkan gubernatorial election.  This access also included information being conveyed back to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, by, for example, Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin in relation to discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at the Kremlin.  In his own commentary on the Le Bourget transcript, he referred to the fact that he had stated to the press that he could "\xc2\x85 theoretically act as a trusted intermediary between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and the government".  He clearly acted as a conduit for the relaying of information from President Putin to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as to the latter\'s ability to visit Russia, and no doubt also as to President Putin\'s views on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  The experts on contemporary Russian history agreed that there were widespread reports in the Russian and international press suggesting that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was one of the oligarchs most favoured by President Putin and his administration.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself accepted that he was regarded by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as "close to people in power in Moscow".  But, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin explained, at the time, he was not a member of President Putin\'s "inner circle".\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to rely on this evidence to support his contention that it was entirely credible that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have made the threats in the terms alleged by the former, and likewise entirely credible that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should have believed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to procure that those threats were carried out.  This, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted, was relevant to the context in which what was said by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had to be considered.\r   However the evidence that, as a rich businessman favoured by President Putin, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to exert influence over President Putin, or members of his administration, to persuade him or them,  improperly  to exercise his or their powers to expropriate or otherwise damage Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s commercial interests, or  wrongfully  to detain Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, was tenuous in the extreme.  It consisted of highly conjectural evidence proffered by Professor Fortescue to the effect that he would not find it surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to encourage State agencies, including the Kremlin to "take steps helpful to him" if they were also beneficial to the Kremlin [425] , as amplified in the third scenario referred to in the following passage of his evidence in cross-examination:\r   "Q.  \tLet\'s have a look at your conclusion to this section at paragraph 104 G(B)1/1.01/30.  You say that you would not find it surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to encourage state agencies, including the Kremlin, to "take steps helpful to him" if they were also beneficial to the Kremlin.   Is that a fair summary of what you\'re saying at paragraph 104?  A.  \tYes. Q.  \tWhat steps do you have in mind when you say that?  A.  \tIf I can set up a number of scenarios:  I don\'t think Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could have come to Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin and said, \'Mr.\xc2\xa0X is causing me problems, I know that Mr.\xc2\xa0X is your good friend and a close ally, nevertheless I want you to help me take steps against him, to remove him as a competitor or whatever\', I would find that quite implausible.   If Mr.\xc2\xa0--  Q.  \tAnd -- sorry, forgive me, I didn\'t realise you were continuing.  Please go on.   A.  \tIf Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had come to Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin and said \'There\'s this Mr.\xc2\xa0X, I don\'t think you know Mr.\xc2\xa0X, or you\'re not interested in Mr.\xc2\xa0X, he\'s a problem for me, can we do something about it, would you help me do something about it?\', I think that would be probably unwise, an unwise thing to do in the case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin, but I don\'t find it totally impossible.   Q.  \tRight. A.  \tIf Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich came along to Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin -- put it another -- no, I\'ll start again.   If Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich knew that Mr.\xc2\xa0X was causing Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin considerable frustration and grief he could have two options, he could just say, "Okay, I\'ll leave things to go their own way and hopefully the outcome that I want will just simply happen because Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin will take measures on his own".  The other possibility is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could have gone to Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin and said, \'Look, you know, Mr.\xc2\xa0X is causing us both some grief, let\'s work together to do something about it\', I find that quite plausible." [426] But immediately after the passage quoted above, Professor Fortescue himself acknowledged that he could not say that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to encourage criminal proceedings against Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or people associated with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, and that none of the sources he relied upon in his report supported the proposition that there was a widespread view that that was so.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s submissions to the effect that it was entirely credible that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have made the threat in the terms alleged by the former were also based on a passage in paragraph 52 of the Joint Memorandum in which Professor Fortescue and Professor Service agreed that, from 2000 onwards (and, indeed, before that) there were incidents across Russia in which national and local State agencies used their powers to achieve the  de facto  confiscation or expropriation of private business assets.  The experts also agreed that these incidents would have been known to experienced Russian businessmen like Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Professor Service was initially reluctant to accept that these incidents often occurred at the prompting of, or in collusion with, rival businessmen.  In cross-examination, however, he accepted that he "\xc2\x85 would guess it happened often" and that he would certainly accept that these incidents were sometimes prompted by other private businessmen.  \r   However, in the absence of any direct or specific evidence supporting the proposition that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to influence President Putin or members of his administration improperly to exercise his or their powers, whether in relation to wrongful expropriation or detention, I am not prepared to accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that the context demonstrated that it was highly credible, given his close connection with President Putin and his access to the Kremlin, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have made such a threat, because he was in a position to do so.  Nor do I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence that either he or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili genuinely believed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to procure the continued detention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov or the wrongful expropriation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Sibneft interests.  The evidence which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky gave in relation to this issue was extravagant and unconvincing.  The two men might justifiably have considered that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, because of his connection with President Putin, might have been in a position to make representations to him or to Mr.\xc2\xa0Voloshin, in an attempt to secure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release on humanitarian or similar grounds, but that is a very different matter.  There was no evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich knew, or was a confidant of, the public prosecutor, or that he was in a position to influence the conduct of criminal proceedings.  Contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submissions, there was nothing in the transcripts of the Le Bourget meeting to support this assertion.\r   Finally in this context, I should mention that Professor Fortescue accepted in cross-examination the proposition that President Putin was "very much his own man", who was "not prepared to be pushed around by rich men" and "was anxious to demonstrate" that he was not prepared to be so manipulated.  There was no evidential basis supporting the contention that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to manipulate, or otherwise influence, President Putin, or officers in his administration, to exercise their powers in such a way as to enable Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to achieve his own commercial goals.  At the time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not that type of political animal;  I am prepared to assume that, on occasion, President Putin may have taken his views into account when making decisions, but the suggestion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in a position to pull the presidential strings was simply not borne out by the evidence.\r   The meetings between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in 2001 I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that he met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the Byblos Hotel in Courchevel on or around 4 or 5 January 2001 and that it was on this occasion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili first proposed that the relationship between Messrs Berezovsky, Patarkatsishvili and Abramovich in relation to Sibneft should be ended by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich making a large final payment to them, in order to "set them up for life" (being the effect of the words used by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili).  The date of the meeting was supported by relevant travel and other records, and its purpose by Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s account of what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told him shortly thereafter.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili sought to justify his demand by explaining that, since Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had left Russia, he needed to have financial independence and did not wish to have the uncertainty of irregular payments and the delays associated with negotiating the manner in which he was going to get paid.  \r   I also accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that, on 10 January 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich travelled from Courchevel to Meg\xc3\xa8ve by helicopter on the way to Geneva;  that he met both Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at the Meg\xc3\xa8ve heliport;  and that at this meeting they discussed the final lump sum payment that had been proposed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Courchevel a few days before.  It would appear that no precise figure was agreed at the meeting, but Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said something along the lines that he could pay $1 billion.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described, and as I accept, there was no attempt by either Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to justify the request based on alleged ownership rights;  rather, they tried to justify the amount sought by emphasizing that Sibneft was doing well and consequently that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could afford to pay.\r   As I have already described above, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s recollection that such a meeting took place was supported by his chef at the time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Sponring;  it was also supported by the fact that, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky accepted, he was in Meg\xc3\xa8ve at the time and knew that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was also there, and by the relevant travel and other records.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence also supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account of what was discussed at the meeting;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler had been skiing in Courchevel at the same time as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told him after the Meg\xc3\xa8ve meeting that he was committed to pay at least $1 billion.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that there was no reason whatsoever why, in 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have agreed to make such a substantial payment allegedly to discharge Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s  krysha  obligations at a time when, for the foreseeable future, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could have been of no conceivable political or commercial use to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that this point critically and fundamentally undermined the truth of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case - the only commercial rationale for agreeing to make such a large payment could have been that it was the price for the sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft interests to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   I disagree.  I have little doubt that the first few months after Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezvosky\'s departure from Russia from October to December 2000 were a difficult and uncertain time for him and that he would have been concerned to ensure the certain, and continued, receipt of funds from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  He would have known that, as his conflict with President Putin worsened, the likelihood was that he would be living abroad in the foreseeable future and that he would need substantial funds, freely available in the West, to support his lifestyle.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had already paid $305 million in the last quarter of 2000, as already described  as a "safety cushion" to establish Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky abroad.  But, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described, given the hostility between the Putin administration and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not in a position to continue to provide  krysha  services :   thus he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could not with any confidence rely upon Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich continuing to make payments to them in the long term.  In such circumstances Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had every motivation, at the beginning of 2001, to seek a final, once and for all, lump sum payment from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, whereby he in effect would "buy out" or satisfy, for all-time, his  krysha  obligations.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion that at the time he had plenty of money to finance a future life in exile was not in point, irrespective of the fact that it was unsupported by any evidence to demonstrate availability of sufficient cash funds in the West to finance a lifestyle of the type which he had previously enjoyed.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s previous proposal, made at the Le Bourget meeting, had been that some Sibneft shares should be transferred to him - although, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said, and as I find, he had no entitlement to such transfer.  But he had apparently lost interest in that proposal, perhaps because of the tax consequences, and therefore he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili requested a lump sum payment.\r   On the hypothesis that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s  krysha  case was correct, I find that there was every reason why he should have considered it appropriate and desirable in early 2001 to agree to make such a substantial payment to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Although, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich informed Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler that he had offered around $l billion to end his relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler made his feelings very clear (as did other close associates) that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should not have agreed to pay anything like $1 billion, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself explained in what I found to be credible terms why he made the decision.  First of all, he had been struggling with how he was going to deal with what he regarded as the increasingly unreasonable demands being made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, directly, and via Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  At the Courchevel meeting Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had specifically told him that if he made one substantial payment then thereafter they both would be able to manage for themselves.  He had understood that this would be a final payment.  Thus he described his motives as follows:\r   "274.\tFor my part, however, the decision was both a business and a personal one.  From a business point of view, I needed to ensure that I did not make an enemy of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Although in late 2000 Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky left Russia, at the time I had no way of knowing whether this state of affairs would last.  At the time I met with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, he was still able to travel freely to Moscow and so far as I am aware, still had his direct connections with President Putin.  It was not out of the question that, within a few months, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would be back in Russia.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had a reputation for bouncing back against all odds.  I remember that in 1994 there was an attempt on his life, and he had to move to Switzerland.  Many people I knew at the time thought that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was finished, but he returned to Russia and became more powerful than before.
