Similarly, late in 1997 it became known that President Yeltsin had become tired of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  but then, in April 1998, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky succeeded in getting himself appointed Executive Secretary of the CIS.  Similarly, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky once injured his spinal cord, an injury that would normally leave someone paralyzed for life, but not him.  On another occasion he contracted Hepatitis C which would have been the end of some people, but, after a period of looking a little yellow, he bounced back!  He was quite an extraordinary person and the normal rules seemed not to apply to him. 275.  \tSo, although by the time I met with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Courchevel, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had clearly fallen out of favour with President Putin, I could not be certain that he would not regain influence in Russia.  My only wish was to finalise all relations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and avoid an open conflict since this could have negative repercussions for me and Sibneft at a future date. 276.  \tAs far as I was concerned, by agreeing to make a single last huge payment, I was \'buying myself my freedom\' from any association with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and our krysha relationship.  If, in his own mind, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had by now convinced himself that what I was bullying him out of was his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s \'rights\' to 50% of Sibneft or 50% of \'me\' then I can say without any doubt that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili gave me every reason to believe that they accepted the ultimately agreed price tag of $1.3 billion willingly and gladly. 277.  \tAs I said above, for me this was not only a business decision, but also a personal one since I would have an opportunity to close this particular chapter in my life, and it was very important to put an appropriate full stop at the end of my relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  He had played such a significant role.  The $1.3 billion was an enormous amount of money to pay to someone who had already been well compensated for his services.  Nonetheless, I felt a sense of responsibility for ensuring that he was \'set up for life\';  this payment was therefore also my way of saying to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that, no matter what was happening in Russia, I remained loyal and would always respect what he had done for me.  But that he should now leave me and Sibneft alone. 278.  \tI never thought of getting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to sign any official release.  As I have already explained, krysha is not a legal arrangement or indeed an arrangement which is capable of being reduced to writing or being ended in writing." I accept this explanation.  In early 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s position was by no means as weak as it may seem today.  He had been a fugitive for only three months.  He had been a highly resilient politician in the 1990s.  The criminal charges against him had been made and withdrawn before.  In his time he had been an ally of President Putin.  It was by no means clear that he was finished as a force in Russian politics.  In the light of these factors and the very clear sense of obligation which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich clearly felt that he had towards Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and the considerable contribution which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had made to the success of Sibneft, I do not find it surprising either that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should have sought to negotiate a final payment or that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have considered it in his interests, and indeed, in a personal way, consistent with his  krysha  relationship, incumbent upon him, to do so.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz strongly challenged Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in cross-examination about his reasons for agreeing to make the payment [427] .  In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written [428]  and oral closing submissions there was likewise a meticulous analysis of why it was contended that the reasons Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich put forward for making the payment were not credible and were "constantly moving, and ultimately incoherent";  it was submitted that the only rational explanation for the payment was that it was the purchase price for the sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Sibneft shares.  After a full review of the evidence, however, and despite the force of certain of Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s criticisms of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, I have concluded that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s explanation for the payment is to be accepted.  He described it in the following way in cross-examination [429] :\r   "A.  \tI\'ve described this krysha relationship:  this is a very vague understanding and this is not the numbers, this is the relationship.  To bring that relationship to a close and not to have any problems with regard to payments, with the nonstop stories that I owe them more and more, to bring that to a close, I was ready to make a final payment and bring this to a close. Q.  \tBy this stage you were no longer friends with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  that\'s right, is it not? A.  \tI\'ve explained yesterday, the word "friend", this is a feeling.  Certainly I was very grateful to him for what he\'d done for me.  Certainly I understood and I understand now and moreover I have no regrets because of paying and I would say -- and I wouldn\'t use the word \'pride\', I wouldn\'t say I\'m proud, but I\'m very happy with myself this is the way I\'ve done.  I wouldn\'t have done it in any different way.  I was very grateful to him that he helped me, I myself would never have achieved results such as these, and therefore I thought that I had to pay him. The figure could have been disputed but the fact that I owed him to bring this relationship - our relationship to a close and not ever revisit that matter again, this is what I thought:  yes, that he did have the right to demand. Q.  \tYou suggest you had no obligation at all and that this just was a goodwill payment of $1.3 billion that you were making to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  is that what you suggest? A.  \tI suggest that never ever had any legal obligations and the krysha relationship is not a legal obligation;  this is an understanding.  And once you get under the influence, until the relationship is brought to a close, you will have to pay.  This is what I\'m trying to explain here.   Q.  \tYou see, I suggest to you, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, that the real and only reason that you were paying the $1.3 billion was because you were acquiring from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili their interests in Sibneft, and that is right, is it not? A.  \tI was buying my freedom.  I wasn\'t buying the interest". In the ultimate analysis I found that explanation to be credible.  I accept the Russian historical and other evidence that in the 1990s  krysha -type relationships were a part of the business environment.  Put as its simplest, effectively under the arrangement between the three men, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had "promised" Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili a slice, and certainly a substantial slice, of the "Sibneft" action, in return for their political influence and protection;  it may well be that there were other aspects of the dealings between the three men which the evidence in this trial has not explored.  I do not find it surprising that, for the various reasons which he gave, by early 2001 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was keen to rid himself of that "obligation".  But in order to do so, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was required, by the conventions of  krysha,  to pay a substantial sum.  Despite Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submissions, I do not find it surprising in the least that no assurance was apparently secured by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would not thereafter hold himself out as having any association with Sibneft or with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  as already described at Section VIII above, it was only in June 2001 that for the first time Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky actually claimed to have a shareholding interest in Sibneft;  any such assurance would have been pointless given Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s predilection for engagement with the media, and unenforceable in any event;  even a request for such an assurance would have betrayed a negotiating weakness or vulnerability on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s part.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz challenged Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in cross-examination to the effect that his account of the meeting in Meg\xc3\xa8ve was "just not credible".  In particular, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had changed his case from his original defence so as to allege that there were two meetings (instead of just one with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili alone), that there were certain inconsistencies in his evidence and that it was largely reconstruction.  I do not accept these criticisms, for which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had adequate explanations.  It was not surprising with the passage of time that certain details had not originally been remembered;  obviously to a certain extent his evidence had been reconstructed in the sense of being triggered by reference to the chronology as supported by the travel records and the supporting evidence of other witnesses.  But, at the end of the day, I was satisfied that, in its essentials at least, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s story was truthful and accurately and honestly recollected.  \r   After the meeting at Meg\xc3\xa8ve, the negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich about the amount and the mechanics for the final pay-out were conducted exclusively by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf.  Because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to intimidation, it is relevant to note that, on 11 April 2001, in the intervening period between the Meg\xc3\xa8ve meeting and the subsequent meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was charged with attempting to escape from custody.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich accepted, this charge increased the risk that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would not be released from prison.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asserted that this increased the opportunity for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to exploit the situation, by using Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s freedom as a bargaining chip, the precedent for this, it was said, having been established by the case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Gusinsky in the summer of the previous year.  \r   There were probably three meetings between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in May 2001.  The only direct evidence about them was that given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and members of his staff, but Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, who had not been at any of the meetings, also gave evidence, based on what he asserted Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had told him.  The first meeting was at Munich airport on 10 May 2001;  this was supported by evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s travel documents and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s travel and credit card receipts, which showed that they were both in Munich on that date.  There may have been a second meeting in Paris on 15 May 2001, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in Paris, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s travel and credit card receipts suggest he was also there.  Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko was also in Paris at the time, but she has no recollection of attending such a meeting.  A third meeting occurred at Cologne airport on 29 May 2001, which was also attended by Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko, an executive at Sibneft and financial adviser to and acting for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev who was acting on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  \r   In his fourth witness statement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had referred only to the meeting on 10 May 2001 at Munich, at which he said that the $1.3 billion was mentioned and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich implicitly threatened to prolong Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s detention, and declared that he was not prepared to pay more than $1.3 billion for his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged interests in Sibneft.  This exchange was said to have occurred at a point in the meeting when Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were alone in the room.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed that a report of the threat was relayed to him by telephone by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, apparently from the meeting itself.  In his sixth witness statement, served shortly before the start of the trial, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky acknowledged that it was "possible" that the Paris and Cologne meetings occurred, and that he may have confused the meetings in Munich and Cologne.  I do not draw any inference adverse to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky based on the fact that, in the light of the later production of Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko\'s travel records, he changed his evidence as to the date and location of the meeting in this respect.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself had originally admitted that a meeting between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko had occurred in Munich;  he too changed his case, based on the disclosure of the travel records, to assert that the meeting at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko were present was the Cologne airport meeting.  But, perhaps more surprisingly, for the first time in his oral evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also alleged that, on his return from  Munich , Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said to him, in special and significant terms (using the Russian word "zamochit", meaning "to kill"):\r   "Borya, you don\'t understand, they will waste him they will do him in, they will kill him";  ("him" being Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov). This was colourful evidence, adduced by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky with what can only be described as theatrical emphasis.  If, indeed, such a comment had been made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili after the Munich meeting, as a result of threats made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at such meeting (which was the thrust of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence), I find it surprising that it was not introduced into Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence at an earlier occasion.   I find as facts, based on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko\'s evidence, that:  \r   i)\tat either the Munich or the Paris meetings - it does not matter which -  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, after no doubt some tough negotiation, agreed the amount of the final payment at $1.3 billion; ii)\tthe mechanics, and form, of the payment were agreed at the meeting in Cologne on 29 May 2001;  in particular it was agreed that the method of payment would be cash rather than payment by transfer of securities;  it was also agreed that the first  $500 million would be paid within a month, and the rest in instalments thereafter; iii)\tthat at the end of the Cologne meeting everyone parted on friendly terms. But I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegation, whether it be made in relation to the Munich and/or the Cologne meeting in May 2001, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich expressly or implicitly threatened to prolong Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s detention, or to secure expropriation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged interests in Sibneft, unless the two men agreed to sell their Sibneft interests to him for $1.3 billion.  I have little doubt that there was a negotiation between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili during the course of which the latter demanded a final payment of $2.5 billion to release Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made it clear that he was not prepared to pay more than $1.3 billion, on which figure the parties finally agreed.  It may well have been that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, with some justification, regarded himself and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in a weak negotiating position, given their status as exiles, their urgent need for money [430] , the undocumented nature of their "interest",  and the stance apparently being presented by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that he had no keen desire to buy them out.  This was certainly the impression given in Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s 2005 draft proof of evidence.  \r   But the evidence relating to the meetings themselves, and to the context in which they took place, did not, in my judgment, establish that any express or implied threats were made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, to intimidate Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, against his will, into accepting a payment of the sum of $1.3 billion, either by reference to the continued imprisonment of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov or by reference to the expropriation of the alleged Sibneft "interests".  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence to the effect that no such intimidation took place.  I have no doubt that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich adopted a tough negotiating stance in the discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as to what the final payout figure should be and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich took such commercial advantage as he was able to derive from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s weak bargaining position.  But I do not accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were threatened or blackmailed into accepting the figure of $1.3 billion, irrespective of whether it was the agreed purchase price of their alleged interests in Sibneft, or a buyout of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s  krysha  obligations.\r   For the purposes of my analysis of the evidence relating to the Sibneft intimidation issue, I accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky may have genuinely believed that the value of a 50% share in Sibneft was in excess of $2.5 billion, which, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence was the figure that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had discussed should be put forward to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as the figure which they required to be paid [431] .  In the absence of the valuation evidence, however, I make no finding as to the objective value of either Sibneft, or of a 50% share of its equity capital at the relevant time.  But, even on the assumption that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky held that belief, the evidence does not establish that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili agreed to the figure of $1.3 billion only as a result of blackmailing threats made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   Other evidence in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue Apart from his own evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon the 2007 notes of meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and the draft witness statement subsequently prepared by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors in 2007 based on those meeting notes, but which was never approved by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  I have already explained the circumstances in which the notes, and draft proofs and witness statements were compiled and expressed my views in relation to their relative unreliability.  He also relied upon witness statements that Ms.\xc2\xa0Duncan and Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim (the 2007 interviewing solicitors) gave as to "their understanding" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s position following their interviews with him, as to the circumstances in which the alleged Sibneft interests had been disposed of.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also relied on hearsay evidence given by seven of his friends and associates who gave evidence of what they said Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had said to them in various times about the "threats" which he said caused him to "sell" out of Sibneft.\r   The 2005 Patarkatsishvili proofing materials It is necessary to look not only at the 2007 Patarkatsishvili proofing materials upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied, but also, and significantly, at the 2005 proofing materials, upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich relied in this context - at least to a limited extent.  The 2005 interview notes undoubtedly suggest that, by 2005, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili believed, or at least was asserting, that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did have an interest of some kind in Sibneft, which they had "sold" in 2001.  This was consistent with the position that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had taken since they had begun to move their assets offshore in early 2000.  But, as was submitted in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written and oral closing submissions, and as I conclude, even taken at face value, the 2005 interview notes and draft proofs, are inconsistent with the suggestion that intimidation by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich played any part in the alleged "sale" to which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili alleged that he agreed.  \r   The 2005 draft proofs of evidence for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were prepared shortly after the interviews with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili which took place in Georgia in June and December 2005.  The draft proofs of evidence were based on the contemporaneous notes of those interviews, taken by the two solicitors who had attended those interviews in Georgia, Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson of Carter Ruck and Mr.\xc2\xa0Lankshear of Streathers, both of whom were acting for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at the time. \r   The proof of evidence prepared by the solicitors shortly after the 2005 meeting was in the following terms in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue:\r   "In early 2001 I proposed to BB that we sell our shares in Sibneft.  At this time it was clear that I would not be able to return to Moscow and would be forced to live as a political \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9.  To live in such circumstances without money is difficult.  BB resisted my proposal at first but finally agreed to sell.  I spoke with RA.  A meeting was set up in Munich in April/early May 2001.  RA came to the airport with his wife Irina, and their children.  Ruslan Fomichev also attended the meeting.  We took a small room (approximately 4 square meters) at the airport.  Our asking price for the shares was $2.5 billion, which already represented a discount as the value of the company at that time was at least $6-7 billion.  RA refused to meet our asking price.  This may have been because he did not have the money, or because he simply did not want our shares that much.  It may be that he only wanted to pay out of the dividends! I was aware that our shares were held on behalf of RA and that there was nothing in writing to prove our ownership.  I was therefore concerned that RA could obtain our shares for nothing.   We agreed a price of $1.3 billion.  When negotiating this deal there was no specific mention made of NG but this was not necessary as it was clear that his release was one of the reasons we were prepared to sell. Following the Munich meeting I kept in contact with RA.  He was always complaining that he was experiencing political pressure from the Kremlin.  I initiated the sale against the background of complaints from RA.  I thought that it was a better option to sell and to relieve the pressure on RA.  I believed from what RA said at the time that had we had stayed in the company then there was a risk that the company would have become a target.   Our people were not managing the company.  This was a serious problem for us because there was less and less possibility for us to understand exactly what was happening within the company.  Over time revenue had increased (due to oil price increases) but dividends had decreased.  We should have obtained significantly greater dividends than we did.  Official reports made mention of this.  We did not challenge RA\'s people on this issue as we did not want to cloud the relationship.   The $10 million which is mentioned in the Share Purchase Agreement was paid in Russia.  This was paid by RA.  There is, however, no evidence of payment.  In mid 2001 RA agreed to make an initial payment of $500 million." This account is not consistent with the analysis that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was implicitly threatening either expropriation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged Sibneft interests or the continued detention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, unless Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili agreed to sell at a price of $1.3 billion.  There was no indication that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili perceived any threat of adverse action by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to the alleged Sibneft interests;  on the contrary, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili appeared to be concerned to relieve pressure from the Kremlin on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich so as to ensure that Sibneft itself - the golden goose that was providing the funding for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili - would not become a target.  These exchanges showed that, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili saw it, the concern was not that his own or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interests in Sibneft might be singled out for expropriation by the Russian government, but rather that Sibneft itself would suffer.\r   Critically, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was not even specifically mentioned.  Although the proof goes on to say that it was unnecessary to mention Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, because it was in any event clear that "his release was  one  of the reasons" [emphasis added] that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were prepared to sell, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not recorded as indicating that either Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release or his continued detention was held out as an inducement or threat by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  The fact that one of the reasons why they were prepared "to sell" was said to have been the prospect of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release, was not equivalent to any allegation of a promise of his release, or a threat of his continued detention (whether by the State or by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich), unless a Sibneft related "sale" or payment was agreed.  It was clear from the evidence that in 2001 Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had come under pressure from the State to sell their other media interests and were in negotiation to do so,  inter alia , because of their concerns and fears about Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov.  Such a comment, if truthful, and if relevant to the negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at all, which is questionable, could have equally been explained by the hope or expectation that the State would look more favourably on Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release in circumstances where it was informed that all commercial relationships between the two men and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had terminated.  Moreover there was no suggestion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was coerced into agreeing to anything;  the recognised weakness of his negotiating position was simply a harsh fact of life.  \r   The 2005 notes of interviews also confirmed that the initiative for the "sale" came from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and was motivated by his need for money:\r   "To live in immigration w/o money difficult.  I wanted to sell shares.  BB didn\'t, ultimately said yes.  I spoke with RA." "Conflict with Putin long enough to live abroad without money - talk about sell of shares - after accept - talked to Roman."  The only reference in the notes to what later evolved into the "expropriation" threat was a reference to the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was "under pressure from the Kremlin" and that the company (i.e.  Sibneft itself) could become a target if he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky continued to be associated with it.  The notes recorded:   "Badri:  better option to sell as decrease pressure on RA and allow us to live and oppose regime;   "actually discussing better for Roman - if we stay in company - company a target.  \xe2\x86\x92 Badri kept contact with Roman - Roman always complaining -  experiencing pressure from Kremlin - initiative of Badri - where complaining - better option to sell.  + to stop pressure." Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova was present at the 2005 interviews and acted as the principal translator.  She was also sent a copy of the resulting draft "proofs of evidence" and confirmed in her witness statement that they accurately reflected what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said.  She noted in her witness statement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili frequently required translation and she would also\r   "\xc2\x85 occasionally clarify some of the answers given by Badri where it was clear that he was having difficulty expressing himself". She did not resile from this in cross-examination, but she gave various wholly unconvincing reasons why she said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was being "very very careful, very, very cautious" and "guarded", and was holding back significant material (for example, about the alleged Cap d\'Antibes meeting), when he was giving his answers to the solicitors.  This, she said, was because he was afraid that the answers might "leak out" to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, with whom he was negotiating at the time and he didn\'t want "his negotiating position to be destroyed".  For this reason, she suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had not told the truth to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors [432] .  She also suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili expressed surprise to her that the solicitors were not asking "more probing questions".  I do not accept her evidence in this respect.  It was self-serving, shifting and not credible.  The meetings were being held in private.  They were attended only by Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova herself and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s lawyers.  She was unable to give any satisfactory reason why there was a need for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to be "guarded".  Most importantly, her evidence was contradicted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson\'s evidence, who said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili appeared to respond freely to his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Lankshear\'s questions.\r   The 2007 Patarkatsishvili proofing materials Contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submissions, I cannot place any real reliance upon the 2007 Patarkatsishvili proofing materials as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue.  Even if they could be superficially regarded as doing so, given the circumstances in which they came into existence (which I have already described above), and, in the absence of any cross-examination of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, any weight that could be attached to them would be minimal.  I was not prepared to accept such evidence as rebutting Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account of what was said and what was not said at the May 2001 meetings.  This was not least because of the inherent danger in regarding notes of interviews, and draft proofs or witness statements never approved by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as actually recording his genuine recollections at the time, as opposed to information based on what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself had said at the meetings.\r   A paradigm example of notes or draft proofs being susceptible to multiple interpretation was Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson\'s note of an interview with both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in April 2007.  His notes record:\r   "ORT/Sibneft/RusAl Badri thinks deal fair on Sibneft -  Badri not party - witness"  . Despite what would appear to be the clear meaning of the statement (viz.  that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili thought that the deal was "fair" in relation to Sibneft, which was consistent with his recorded position, in the June 2005 proof of evidence, that he regarded himself as having freely negotiated it, despite the recognition of his weak negotiating position), Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson suggested in his witness statement and oral evidence that it did not refer to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s views.  He said that he believed:\r   "the note \xc2\x85 related to questions Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky put to me as to the possible effect if Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not agree to join in the proceedings as a co-claimant and as to whether he could join later if he so wished". In cross-examination, he accepted that there was nothing in the note specifically recording any discussion of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili joining the proceedings [433] .  However, he continued to maintain the suggestion that the note was a record of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asking whether it would give the impression that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili thought the deal fair on Sibneft, if he were not also a party to these proceedings [434] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson did not suggest that he had a clear recollection of the matter, but, whether he was right or not, which in the ultimate analysis does not matter, his evidence served to show how dangerous it was, given the circumstances in which the notes were compiled, to rely upon what was recorded as an accurate record.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, however, submitted that various notes of the 2007 meetings, contained "a number of illuminating records".  In particular he relied upon:  \r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson\'s note of the meeting at Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s English home in June 2007, which stated: "Sibneft  Roman all the time play  - TV - not able to deliver - not my decision - Putin -  sensitive with Sibneft  - Putin  No choice - believe them all the time  - if not do it take it for nothing, like with Yukos -  RA - he approached us - did not plan to sell - price would go up - understood RA difficult - =Putin press me -why give money to BB -  I don\'t know what to do.   \xc2\x85  Badri - ORT / Sibneft / RusAl  They can take for nothing  - position so -  we will get everything.   \xc2\x85 If sell everything +Putin [don\'t]   push me-  Easy to get NG out ." [Emphasis added by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz]; ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Lindley\'s note of the same meeting, which stated:   "RA -played game etc concerning NG - if don\'t sell  They would take it for nothing  -agreement-  Sale of Sibneft - RA - approached - BP/AP - did not  intend to sell - BUT RA had a difficult position -  PUTIN press him why give money to BB etc  Munich airport - meeting to discuss the sale of Sibneft  \xc2\x85  -$1.3 billion  -not based on numbers/value  -can take these assets for nothing -so should  Get whatever  they  want-  ORT aginst-AP was correct-  Agreement accept-release of-NG  -SIBNEFT-BB not involved in the negotiations  AP-position should get something and in time  \xc2\x85 -if sold shares Glushkov released-all solution  Sell everything would be able to release  NG - less incentive to keep Glushkov in Jail".  [Emphasis added by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz] But as I have already described, these were disparate discussions at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova were also present, as well as the lawyers and Dr.\xc2\xa0Dubov.  The notes do not distinguish clearly whose words were being recorded at any one point.  By this time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had started his proceedings against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and, in the light of his participation in the proof-taking process, the whole thrust of the discussion is likely to have been self-serving and driven by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s agenda.  Moreover, even then the notes do not unambiguously record any clear or specific threat being made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich either in relation to expropriation or in relation to the continued detention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov;  for example, they appear to record Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s perception that the sale of the Sibneft shares would simply give the Russian authorities "less incentive to keep Glushkov in jail".\r   So far as the November 2007 meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Tel Aviv was concerned, it was clear, as Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan described in her oral evidence, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did most of the talking.  The following extract from her cross-examination, together with the quoted extract from Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim\'s witness statement, gives a good flavour of the limited extent to which one can rely upon what was recorded by the solicitors as being Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s own genuine, and un-prompted, recollection:\r   "Q.  \tNow, again, going back to Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim\'s statement, the second sentence of paragraph 23, he says: \'When Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was explaining matters to us it was sometimes difficult to know whether he was explaining his personal knowledge of events, whether he was explaining his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s joint recollection or whether he was translating Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s answers directly.\' Presumably you agree with that? A.  \tWell, not entirely because I think, as I\'ve said, on the whole Badri attempted to answer the questions that - or Badri spoke in English to us directly as regards his recollection.  So there are certain bits of my notes that I quite clearly just remember Badri telling us directly in English;  there are other parts where, yes, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appeared to be translating for him. Q.  \tBut since -- and when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was translating, you weren\'t in a position to know whether the translation was accurate or not? A.  \tNo." Ms.\xc2\xa0Duncan\'s note of the November 2007 meeting, which was the only note of the meeting which survived, did not suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili understood the comments being made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a veiled threat that he would cause the Kremlin to expropriate Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s "interests" in Sibneft.  The thrust of the account was directed at the weakness of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s bargaining position and the pressure allegedly being applied upon Sibneft and upon Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich by President Putin and the Kremlin, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were his partners.\r   Similarly, insofar as her note of the November 2007 meeting referred at all to the alleged threat made at the May 2001 meetings by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s continued detention, it simply read as follows:\r   "NG not ment directly at mtg in Munich b/c others there - oblique ref \'u rem our main pt\'." In the subsequent version of the draft proof prepared by the solicitors, this evolved into the following narrative:  \r   "When negotiating this deal there was no specific mention made of NG but this was not necessary as it was clear that his release was one of the reasons we were prepared to sell.  We did not mention Glushkov by name, due to the presence of Irina and Ruslan Fomichev, but I asked Roman whether he was aware of \'our main issue\' and he confirmed that he knew what I meant."  At this juncture, the impression which was being given was that the reference by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to the "main issue" was being made in the presence of Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  In cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim said that he thought it probable (but not certain) that he was expressly told at the Tel Aviv meeting about the alleged confirmation by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  but he also acknowledged that he was quite sure that he was not told what the form the confirmation took, whether a nod, a wink, a "yes" or some other form [435] .  As was submitted in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions, even on the assumption that there was a confirmation in some unspecified form, it cannot have amounted to more than, at most, an acknowledgment by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s  concerns or hopes or expectations;  a confirmatory wink or nod on the part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, in response to an oblique reference by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, could not possibly have been understood as a "threat" on the part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to procure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s prolonged imprisonment.   Significantly, later drafts of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s "proof", into which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had had no input at all, were in due course amended by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors to insert the following passages:  \r   "65.  \tA meeting was set up in Munich in April/earlyMay 2001 to finalise a deal and agree a price.  Roman came to the airport with his financial manager Irina Panchenko.  Ruslan Fomichev also came with me, although neither he nor Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko were present for the bulk of the discussions between me and Roman." 69.  \tRoman also indicated that, although Glushkov had not been released from prison after the sale of ORT, if we sold our interests in Sibneft then Glushkov would be released.  There was no mention of Glushkov in the presence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko but after they had returned I asked whether he was aware of \'our main issue\' and he confirmed that he knew what I meant."  In other words the revision suggested, for the first time, that there had indeed been an  express  mention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at what was in fact the Cologne meeting in May 2001, in the absence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko, and that an  express inducement  had been made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to his release.  The clear inference I drew was that the revision was made in order to square Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s witness statement with the allegation made in the Particulars of Claim that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had indeed made a direct statement at the meeting in Munich, in the absence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Ms\xc2\xa0Panchenko, that could have been construed as a threat in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov [436] .  It was plain that such revision was inconsistent with what had been actually said by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in 2005 and in the 2007 Tel Aviv interview.  Furthermore, in cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim acknowledged that this different version of events had not arrived from information "directly" [437]  provided by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili but from some other source - in the circumstances that would necessarily have been either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or one of his assistants.  What can only be described as the creative crafting of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s proposed witness statement, leads me to have little confidence in the reliability of the 2007 proofing materials as corroborative evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue.  It was plain that the solicitors had specifically asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili what had been said at the Munich/Cologne meeting about Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said that there had been  no  direct mention at the meeting of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov;  that account had been reflected both in his 2005 draft proof and in Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan\'s note of the 2007 Tel Aviv meeting.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s attempt in cross-examination (when referred to the 2005 draft proof) to explain this away as being:\r   "But again, just note of the solicitors \xc2\x85 who met him and understood in this way, and we had a lot of examples that solicitors understood not correctly". [438] was not impressive. The evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors as to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s recollections Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz additionally sought to rely on the evidence given by Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan and Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim as to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s recollections relevant to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that, whatever were the defects with the notes or the draft proof of evidence, if taken in the abstract, because of their susceptibility to multiple interpretations, the real value of the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors of their meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili lay in the impression which the solicitors gained overall as to his recollections.  He asserted that there had been no specific challenge of certain of the paragraphs of Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan and Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim\'s witness statements where they summarised their impressions of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s recollections.\r   I cannot attach any, or any significant, weight to the evidence of Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan and Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim as to "their understanding" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s position following their interviews with him.  First, whilst Mr.\xc2\xa0Daniel Jowell QC, one of  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s counsel, who cross-examined these witnesses, may not expressly have challenged the specific paragraphs in which they summarised their alleged "understandings", he clearly and thoroughly challenged the basis upon which they felt able to express such views, and the validity of their conclusions.  Second, such evidence, given many years after the event was of very limited value in any event.  Third, some of the answers which they gave about their impressions I found to be unreliable, as I did with certain answers given by other solicitors involved in the Patarkatsishvili proofing exercise.  This itself was not surprising, given the passage of time and the circumstances in which the interviews took place.  Fourth, and most importantly, Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim\'s recollections of the 2007 meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were necessarily informed not just by what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said, but also by what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself had said or had translated as being Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s recollections.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0McKim acknowledged, at the end of the meetings his understanding of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s position on the various factual issues could have been drawn from any combination of what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said, from what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili said and from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s "translations" [439] .\r   The significance of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s position There is a final point to be made at this juncture in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s position.  If Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had believed that the claims made in these proceedings by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were justifiable, he could, at least up until June 2007, when the English limitation period expired, have himself made similar claims.  But, up to the time of his death in 2008, he had never advanced such claim, but, on the contrary, had always given the impression to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler that he was happy with the payments which had been made [440] .  Of course, there might have been all kinds of understandable personal and commercial reasons why Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili might not have wished to have become involved as a co-claimant with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, in what was undoubtedly going to be expensive litigation, notwithstanding that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili might have believed that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had a good claim against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  But there was never any suggestion made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Ms\xc2\xa0Duncan, or to any of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s other solicitors, that he was considering becoming a co-claimant.  \r   Whilst the point is of very limited significance in the overall context, I nonetheless find it somewhat surprising, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to Sibneft (and indeed in relation to RusAl) were evidentially correct, that, prior to his death in 2008, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili does not appear even to have communicated his support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claims to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s hearsay evidence In an attempt to corroborate his account of the events relating to the Sibneft intimidation issue, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon seven witnesses who gave evidence of what they said Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had said to them at various times about the "threats" which he said had caused him to "sell" out of Sibneft.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon this evidence to rebut the suggestion that his case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue was recent fabrication.  I found that the evidence of these witnesses was of very limited assistance in enabling me to reach my final conclusion on this issue.  None of the witnesses were directly involved in the relevant events.  Even where such evidence of recollection was honestly given, I could attach very little weight to it.  Much of the evidence of allegedly previous consistent statements was plainly influenced by the personal loyalties of the particular witness to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  they all gave the impression of being keen to support evidence that had previously been given by him.  Many of such witnesses had been, and continue to be, beneficiaries of his financial largesse.  Their evidence was clearly susceptible to having been influenced, even if only unconsciously, by personal loyalties and wishful thinking, particularly where the witness had had a significant part in the preparation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  Necessarily it was very hard for such witnesses to distinguish, many years after the event, between different occasions on which he or she has discussed the same subject with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.\r   The first of such witnesses was Dr.\xc2\xa0Nosova, one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s most loyal supporters.  As I have already described, she and her husband, Mr.\xc2\xa0Lindley, had a very large financial interest in the outcome of this litigation [441]  under contingency agreements with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, the existence of which she had failed to disclose.  She gave a lengthy account in her witness statement purporting to corroborate Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s account of the alleged intimidation relating to Sibneft.  For example in her second witness statement she said that:\r   "299 \tDuring the first months of 2001, I continued to have frequent discussions with Boris and Badri about Nikolai.  I understood that, even though Nikolai had not been released as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had said he would following the sale of ORT, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was still trying to push Boris and Badri to sell Sibneft to him." She went on to describe how, at a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at Cap d\'Antibes in  April  2001, after Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s arrest for allegedly having attempted to escape jail, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had said to her that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would only be released, if they sold him their interest in Sibneft, and that otherwise he would stay in prison for a very long time.  But, even if I were to accept her as a witness who did her best to give truthful evidence, that account was not consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, which was that the threats relating to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in the context of the disposal of the Sibneft interests, were not made until a meeting between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at a German airport in May 2001, and then were only made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Given my serious doubts as to her credibility, and because of its inconsistency with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, I do not accept her evidence;  if there had been any conversation as between her and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in April 2001, I agree with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s submission that the likelihood was that it only related to the negotiations between the Russian state and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili concerning the disposal of a television station owned by them, TV6, in connection with which there was some evidence to suggest that pressure was being put on the two men by the Russian state to sell their interests.\r   The second witness who gave evidence in relation to this issue was Mr.\xc2\xa0Goldfarb.  His evidence added nothing that was of any assistance to my evaluation of the evidence as given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich respectively.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Goldfarb simply said:\r   "65 \tI was not  involved  in the mechanics of the sale of the shares in Sibneft, however I was aware that it was happening at the time.  I recall that Boris and Badri seemed angry after the deal had been done.  Boris told me that they did not get the price that they should have got for their shares because they had been forced to sell them under pressure." Mr.\xc2\xa0Goldfarb sat through almost the entire trial and, as I have already described, is clearly loyal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.   Mr.\xc2\xa0Gluskhov was the third witness who gave evidence in this context.  In his witness statement he said:\r   " Sibneft 224 \tWhile I was at the Haematological Centre, on some days, one of the people close to me was able to visit me.  He was in contact with Badri, and told me that Badri had told him about the sale of Sibneft, and that everything was being done to secure my release.  My lawyers were also telling me that negotiations were under way with regard to Sibneft and that, no matter what, I would be released. 225 \tAfter Sibneft was sold, and I was still not released, I sent a message with my lawyer, Mr.\xc2\xa0Borovkov, to Boris that he should not sell any more assets to secure my release. 226 \tI am very grateful for Boris and Badri\'s efforts to obtain my release, and sorry that those efforts did not prove to be successful.  I am sure that Boris and Badri would not have wanted to sell ORT and Sibneft.  In particular, they were resources in the fight against President Putin. 227 \tI thought that President Putin was behind the sale of ORT, given the press exchanges and well-publicised meetings between Boris and President Putin in 2000, and ORT\'s enormous political influence.  I did not, and do not, know what degree of influence Roman had in that sale.  However, in relation to Sibneft, I had no doubt that the Sibneft sale (from which Roman stood to benefit financially) was a measure of Roman\'s influence and, at the time, I did not connect it to Putin." [442] Even if I were to accept this hearsay evidence of what Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was apparently being told at the time, it does not assist me.  Again Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, understandably perhaps, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s closest friend, is a very loyal supporter of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s cause.  I have had to approach his evidence with a considerable degree of caution.  Neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, nor his lawyer, Mr.\xc2\xa0Borovkov, made this point in connection with the alleged sale of  Sibneft  interests [443]  in their witness statements in Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s asylum proceedings, although it would certainly have been relevant to the case which Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was then presenting.  This is particularly significant because, in his asylum statements, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov went to great lengths to describe how he was used as a "hostage" in connection with the Russian authorities\' "blackmailing" Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to sell their ORT shares.  If similar tactics had been employed in relation to his continued detention in the context of the alleged sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Sibneft interests, it would have been surprising if that issue had not been deployed in his asylum application.  Perhaps aware of this lacuna, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov attempted to explain in his trial witness statement that, at the time of his detention, he did not connect President Putin to the Sibneft sale.  But that is hard to reconcile with the assertion in that statement that, after the Sibneft sale, he told Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky not to sell any further assets to secure his release.  Moreover, by the time of his asylum application, he would have discussed the matter with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  There were also a number of other anomalies and inconsistencies in Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s evidence which persuaded me that his evidence was not reliable.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Voronoff was the fourth witness who gave hearsay evidence on this topic.  He said that he had spoken to Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili in early 2001 and been aware of the "pressure" being brought to bear on them to sell their alleged interest in Sibneft, and that he had spoken to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about this in June 2001.  He said:\r   "What I do clearly recall is that Badri told me about the Munich airport meeting, and the pressure that Boris and himself were under to sell their shares in Sibneft.  Badri said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told him that there had been some hitch about Nikolay\'s release, and that he was sorry - but that if Boris and Badri sold Sibneft, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would do everything he could to try to get Nikolay released.  Badri said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had also told him that otherwise Sibneft would be taken away from Boris and Badri, and they would be left with nothing." [444] But, for example, the suggestion that at the Munich meeting Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had expressly mentioned Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov, was directly contradicted by the Patarkatsishvili 2005 interview notes.  Moreover, in cross-examination Mr.\xc2\xa0Voronoff accepted that it was hard to distinguish between the various conversations which he had had with Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili about the events in issue over the years.  The following passage gives a flavour of the high water mark of the quality of his evidence about what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had told him over the years about their alleged Sibneft interests: [445]   "Q.  \tDo you mean to indicate by that that you understood that at some point they directly owned 50 per cent of  Sibneft, in the sense of either owning it themselves or through corporate entities that they owned? A.  \tNeither really.  You know, I didn\'t really think of how exactly.  I mean, I was pretty sure -- if I was questioned at that time, I would be pretty sure to say that not directly, but in actual fact, so de facto rather than de jure. Q.  \tAnd are you saying that that is the conclusion you drew from behaviour and meetings you witnessed or are you saying it\'s something you recall specifically being told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili? A.  \tI recall specifically being told by Boris and Badri on many occasions but not like, \'Look, I want you to sit down and listen to this, I\'m going to tell you now\'.  It was really pretty much common knowledge.  It was a fairly close circle of people and certain things were just taken entirely for granted and this one was - was one of them. Q.  \tYou were taking it for granted that they had an interest in Sibneft? A.  \tWell, no, no, not for granted.  I mean, we were told but it\'s not -- like I said, it was mentioned many times in various contexts, in many conversations, you know, so obviously I took it like that. Q.  \tIt must now, in 2011, be very difficult to distinguish any one conversation you had with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili with any other? A.  \tWell, it\'s hard.  But, you know, it was mentioned on numerous occasions because I spent a lot of time with them, you know, and -- with Boris and Badri and we\'d talk about a lot of different things.  Sibneft was definitely one of them, many times, and the general nature of the relationship with Roman was discussed many times.  And so it was really something that was mentioned numerous times." I did not feel able to place any reliance upon Mr.\xc2\xa0Voronoff\'s evidence of what he asserted he had been told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as corroborative of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.\r   Another friend of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Pompadur, also gave evidence to the effect that he had recalled seeing Messrs Berezovsky, Patarkatsishvili and Voronoff in June 2001, and being told that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been "forced to sell out" of Sibneft [446] .  However, he had "quite often" discussed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegations both with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and "more frequently" with Mr.\xc2\xa0Voronoff.  He agreed that it was difficult to remember when he was first told some particular part of the story [447] .  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Nevzlin gave evidence, in his witness statement to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had told him that he had been blackmailed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich [448] :\r   "Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili told me that they had been blackmailed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, with the threat that unless they sold Sibneft then they would have it taken from them in any event and Nikolai Glushkov (who had been imprisoned in late 2000) would not be released. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili told me that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had taken the line of pretending not to be responsible for what he was threatening, suggesting that he was merely a messenger and was neutral, and that if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not do as he suggested then "they\'\' would take Sibneft and keep Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in prison." It was clear from the evidence which he gave in cross-examination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Nevzlin had often discussed the events giving rise to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim with both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili over the years.  But it appeared that it was only in 2004, at a meeting in Israel, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had, for the first time, told him about Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s alleged promise to release Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov [449] .  As a result of his business dealings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, which he described in his witness statement, he did not like him [450] .  I could not place any reliance upon this very general evidence by Mr.\xc2\xa0Nevzlin.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney, a former Ukrainian, and now Israeli, businessman, made a witness statement in support of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  In relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue he said that, at a meeting in England with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in November/December 2007:\r   "\xc2\x85 I also asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili why they had sold their interests in Sibneft and in media concerns (like ORT) so cheaply (which fact Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had previously told me about).  They replied that this had been as a result of threats made to them by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Nikolay Glushkov, their manager who had been imprisoned in Russia (which fact had been widely covered in Russian press at the time).  They told me that the threats had been to the effect that if they did not agree to the sale price, Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov would remain in prison and their interests in Sibneft and the media businesses would anyway be expropriated by the Russian state." Although the Court made an order permitting Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney to provide his evidence by video link, he was not prepared to attend trial and to have his evidence tested by cross-examination.  The reasons for his refusal to do so were set out in a letter from his solicitors to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors dated 18 October 2011.  These included the fact that he was currently engaged in litigation in this court against one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s witnesses, Mr.\xc2\xa0Oleg Deripaska, and did not wish to subject himself to a lengthy cross-examination in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s action, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney\'s solicitors described as being "\xc2\x85 in the nature of a dress rehearsal for his cross-examination at the trial of his own action" against Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney had apparently lent Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky substantial sums of money (although, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, much less than the $50 million figure put to him in cross-examination).  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appeared to have had some financial arrangement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney under which Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney "helps him with my life, not with expenses for litigation" [451] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney did not stand to gain financially from the outcome of the litigation.  However, Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney would necessarily be in a better position to obtain repayment of his loan, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were to win this case.  \r   In addition to the evidence which I have quoted above, Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney also gave evidence to the effect that he had been told by "several reliable sources" that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had "acquired Sibneft" [452] , and that he had also been informed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s "business partner" [453] .  The sources of this information were not identified.  \r   In the absence of cross-examination of Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney, I can attach no weight to his evidence as corroborative of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.  I have no doubt that, had he been cross-examined on his witness statement, he would have been challenged in various respects.  In previous High Court proceedings, in which he appeared as a claimant, the Court considered that his oral evidence was "evasive" and "needs to be treated with very considerable caution" [454] .\r   Absence of any written record of a sale or release of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s obligations Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted that if there had really been a sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft rights and interests under the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements, or a release of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s contractual obligations under such agreements, it was inconceivable that there would have been no document recording the terms on which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was paying over the sum of $1.3 billion.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption further submitted that, from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s perspective, if he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were indeed giving up contractual rights, they would have wanted to ensure that they could enforce the instalment payments against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said, he contemplated from the start that in due course he would bring proceedings against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for compelling him to sell at an undervalue, he needed to have the transaction documented for use in such proceedings;  and the transaction would have had to have been documented in order to satisfy the Western banks to which the proceeds of "sale" were going to be transferred.  He submitted that the absence of any written record was a significant pointer against Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that there was a "sale" of his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s contractual rights and interests to, or in, Sibneft shares, and in favour of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that the payment was to secure Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s release from his non-binding  krysha  obligations.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, on the other hand, submitted that, in circumstances where Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft interests had originally been held under an oral agreement and where the Sibneft shares had been held under Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own control, there was no need for any paper record of the transaction;  from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s point of view, there would have been no need for a receipt as he could have been very confident that he was secure, given the fact that he had paid over $1.3 billion;  it was wholly unrealistic to suppose that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would ever have been able to dispute that he had waived, or agreed a transfer of, his contractual interests in Sibneft, in the light of his receipt of so substantial a payment.  Further Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the point ignored the existence of the "Devonia Agreement", a purported agreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of the first part, Devonia Investments Limited ("Devonia"), a company registered in the British Virgin Islands, of the second part, and Sheikh Sultan Bin Khalifa Bin Zayed Al Nahyan ("the Sheikh") of the third part.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the Devonia Agreement contained a number of recitals and operative clauses which documented the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were giving up their interests in Sibneft.\r   Once again, although the point is not determinative, I conclude that, for the reasons put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption in his oral closing, and in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions, it is surprising, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue were correct, that there was no documentation recording the deal between the parties.\r   By May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky appreciated the importance of recording agreements in writing.  Even before his exile from Russia, he had been trying to transfer his assets into offshore structures in the West.  As he emphasised in both his written and oral evidence, he was by now familiar with the money-laundering regulations in force in most Western jurisdictions, especially those of the European Union where he had been living since October 2000, and appreciated the need to satisfy the money-laundering requirements of Western banks [455] .  In his fourth witness statement, he explained that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili appreciated the importance of obtaining documentary evidence of the sale of any asset, in order to satisfy anti money-laundering enquiries from banks and to make it possible to bring an action for the price in a convenient jurisdiction [456] .\r   "377 \tBefore that meeting [the Munich meeting in May 2001], Badri and I had some discussions about the sale.  We had agreed that if there was to be a sale, it would have to be recorded in writing and subject to English law.  Badri suggested that he would propose on our behalf a price of $2.5 billion.  I didn\'t agree with that as I thought that our share in Sibneft was worth much more.  But Badri was sure that we were in no position to negotiate.  I told Badri that undoubtedly he could judge Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s mood better than I could, and I would support any decision that Badri took regarding the conduct of the negotiations and the final price.  At the same time, it was then that I decided and told Badri that the time would come when we would prove in a court in the West that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had forced us to sell our shares to him for a knockdown price through threats and intimidation, and we would make Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich compensate our losses.  However, at that time we found ourselves locked in a situation where we had no choice as to who the buyer would be and where that buyer in effect held a gun to our heads. \xc2\x85 382 \tWhether the sale was undertaken directly or via the Sheikh Sultan, it was very important for us that the agreement be in writing and subject to English law, and recording the interest in Sibneft which we were giving up.  This was for a number of reasons.  First, we wanted to be sure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would not find a way to avoid making payment.  Secondly, we wanted to ensure that the reason for the payments being made to us were clearly identified, so that there would not be any question that we were entitled to receive the sums, and to avoid any money laundering concerns.  Thirdly, Badri and I were determined to make sure that - one day, when Nikolay was safe - Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would pay for what he had done to us, and so I wanted our interest to be clearly recorded." But there was no evidence that either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili ever asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for a written agreement as, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence, one would have expected him to have done if indeed the two men were selling their Sibneft interests.  In cross-examination [457] , Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky evaded answering the direct question whether he had ever asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to enter into a written agreement by making reference to the "direct agreement" option which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich "refused".  But he was unable to say when, or in what circumstances, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was supposed to have refused this option.  The best he could do was to refer in the vaguest of terms to what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was said to have told him about the option not being available.  \r   But perhaps even more surprising, if the payment had indeed reflected the purchase price that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was paying for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft related interests, was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself did not ask for a written agreement, or even a written receipt simply recording the reason why the sum was being paid.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that he did not remember if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich ever asked for a document recording the transaction [458] ;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that he never thought of getting a release as that was inconsistent with the  krysha  nature of their relationship [459] .  If Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili indeed had had legally enforceable rights in respect of Sibneft, and particularly if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had sought to procure their relinquishment by threats, then a businessman in his position, and with the advisers which he had around him at the time, would, in reality, have been bound to have insisted on a written release, in order to ensure not only that claims to an interest were not raised against him in the future, but also that no claims were raised in relation to the "sale" transaction itself.  In this context, I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s arguments (that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not need a receipt because, given the payment of over $1.3 billion, it was wholly unrealistic to suppose that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would ever have been able to dispute that he had waived, or agreed a transfer of, his contractual interests in Sibneft) as lacking commercial reality - in particular in the light of the respective characters of the two men.  \r   The only document which purports to record any disposition by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of their rights in respect of Sibneft is the Devonia Agreement.  Even if that was a genuine agreement as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Devonia, (and I address the Devonia Agreement in a following section of this judgment), Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not a party to it and had no knowledge of it at the time.\r   Commercial reasons for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have accepted a substantial payment to bring their relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to an end I conclude that by early 2001 there were real commercial imperatives which would have driven Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for a substantial payment to bring their relationship with him to an end.  By May 2001, both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were political exiles from Russia.  They needed money to fund their lifestyles abroad, at least for the duration of President Putin\'s administration, the length of which was uncertain.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s view appears to have been that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were not in a strong bargaining position.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky needed the money to fund his political career and, having left Russia, apparently had no other income.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself admitted that "definitely I need money", before suggesting that that was not his reason to accept the $1.3 billion [460] .  Whatever the nature of their arrangements were with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and whatever they thought that their entitlement was under such arrangements, they were entirely undocumented and would have been difficult, if not impossible, to have enforced.  They would have appreciated that, given their political status as exiles, they were hardly in a position, in the near future at least, to provide any  krysha  or other services to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that would have commanded the quantum of remuneration which they had received from him in the past.  They could hardly be certain in their changed circumstances that he would be willing to continue to finance their expenditures.  Even if they believed that they were entitled to Sibneft shares, or some sort of interest in Sibneft, they would have appreciated that the value of Sibneft would have been in jeopardy if they had called for the registration of Sibneft shares in their own names or in that of their nominees.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was under criminal investigation in relation to alleged embezzlement of Aeroflot funds and was out of favour with the Russian government.  By April 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was also accused of having sought to assist Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov to escape custody.  The $1.3 billion payment had the significant advantage for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that they were able to receive their money in offshore accounts without tax or exchange control problems, and in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, without running the risk that the assets might be frozen by the Russian authorities on account of the criminal investigations against him.\r   These factors support my conclusion that I should accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili who first raised the concept of a final payment with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and that the transaction was one which freely negotiated without the threats or intimidation alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  But I do not go so far as to decide the hypothetical issue raised as Issue 8 of the Agreed List of Issues, namely:\r   "\xc2\x85 if the [alleged] threats \xc2\x85 had been made, did they in fact coerce Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky into disposing of his alleged rights in relation to Sibneft, or did he do so for other reasons?" The factual hypothesis for the resolution of that question would have required a total reassessment of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s credibility on the assumed basis that he had been lying about the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements and/or about what occurred at the May 2001 meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  It is not appropriate for me to embark on that task. Conclusion in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue For all the above reasons I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue.  I conclude that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not make either express or implied threats to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, with the intention of intimidating them to dispose of their alleged interests in Sibneft, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky has alleged.  I also conclude that the sum of $1.3 billion paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not represent the sale price of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged Sibneft interest, but rather was a final lump sum payment in order to discharge what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich regarded as his  krysha  obligations.\r   Section XII - Issue A4:  The Devonia Agreement Introduction Issue A4 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, is:  \r   "If Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had an interest in Sibneft, did he sell it to Devonia Investments Limited under a sale and purchase agreement (\'the Devonia Agreement\') dated 11 /12 June 2001 between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Devonia Investments Limited (\'Devonia\' and Sheikh Sultan (\'the Sheikh\')?" In the Agreed List of Issues, the issue is formulated as follows:\r   "9.\tDid Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili effectively dispose of any of their alleged rights in June 2001 by way of the Devonia Agreement? In particular: (1) \tWas the Devonia Agreement capable in law of disposing of any of the rights under Russian law that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleges he had in respect of Sibneft? (2) \tWas the Devonia Agreement a genuine agreement or a sham?"
