The issues relating to the Devonia Agreement were originally relevant to a number of issues arising in the action:  these included:  \r   i)\tfirst, the issues as to whether the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements were concluded in the terms alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and as to whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich intimidated him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to disposing of such interests (i.e. issues A1 and A3):   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky submitted that the Devonia Agreement demonstrated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did indeed have contractual rights as against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Sibneft, which had effectively been sold, or surrendered, to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, after he had made the alleged threats;  that supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s substantive case in relation to those issues, as well as his submissions in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s credibility;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, on the other hand, submitted that, if the court accepted that the Devonia Agreement was not a genuine transaction, that supported his case on those issues, as well as on the issue of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s credibility;   ii)\tsecond, the issue as to whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had suffered any loss at all, as a result of the alleged intimidation:   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case on loss was posited on the premise that, because of the alleged threats, he had sold his Sibneft interests under the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements at a substantial undervalue pursuant to the terms of the Devonia Agreement, which became effective on 11/12 June 2001, the approximate date on which the agreement appears to have been executed by Sheikh;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, on the other hand, contended that the Devonia Agreement was not effective to deprive Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky of any Russian law rights which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky might have had under the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements, and therefore Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had suffered no loss at all;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s response to this was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was in any event estopped from denying that the Devonia Agreement had any such effect;   iii)\tthird, the issue as to the date on which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had suffered his alleged loss, which was critical for limitation purposes, if the proper law governing the tort was English law:  if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended, the Devonia Agreement was a genuine agreement, the entry into which fixed the date of his loss, then it was common ground that, as a matter of English law, his claim was brought within the six-year limitation period as he had issued his claim form on 1 June 2007;  on the other hand if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich contended, the Devonia Agreement was a sham, brought into existence for money-laundering purposes, then Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich submitted that the relevant date, was not the date of execution of that agreement, but rather the date on which the final agreement had been made at Cologne airport between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on 29 May 2001 when the mode of payment of the $1.3 billion was finally agreed and the transaction went forward, the first instalment of the sum being paid  to Devonia\'s bank account on 31 May 2001;  in which event, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich submitted, the claim would be time barred under English law;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, on the other hand, submitted that even if the Devonia Agreement was not the mechanism by which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suffered loss, the relevant date for limitation purposes would be that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky lost his rights in Sibneft, and thus suffered loss, at the time when he, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, first received payment from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich through the Devonia payment mechanism, namely 12 June 2001, when Devonia first transferred monies to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s bank accounts in the UK; iv)\tfourth, the issue as to what was the relevant substantive law governing the alleged tort:  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky submitted that the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky signed the Devonia Agreement in England supported his secondary case that the substantive law of the tort was England;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich submitted that no assistance in this respect could be derived from the Devonia Agreement, as it was not a genuine transaction. I have only needed to consider the issues relating to the Devonia Agreement for the purpose of determining the issues referred to in subparagraph 829i) above (i.e. issues A1 and A3).  Thus, in arriving at my conclusions that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not have any rights in respect of Sibneft under the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not intimidate or blackmail him into disposing of such rights, I have taken into account, as part of my evaluation of the entirety of the evidence relating to those issues, the evidence relating to the Devonia Agreement.  For this reason, I set out below my findings in relation to the Devonia Agreement, in so far as they are relevant to my determination of those issues.\r   But, given my conclusions in relation to issues A1 and A3, it is not necessary for me to consider the factual issues relating to the Devonia Agreement for the purposes of determining the other issues identified above.  That is because, given that I have decided that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not act in a manner that constituted the tort of intimidation, the issues relating to whether:\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had actually suffered any loss as a result of having entered into the Devonia Agreement; ii)\tthe substantive law governing the alleged tort was French, Russian or English;  and, consequently,  iii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim was time-barred,  simply do not arise for determination.   Executive summary of my conclusions in relation to the Devonia Agreement My conclusions in relation to this issue may be stated as follows.  First, the Devonia Agreement was not a genuine agreement.  It was a sham agreement, entered into for the purposes of generating documentation that would give a false impression that a genuine commercial transaction had been entered into, so as to satisfy the money-laundering requirements of the UK bank, into accounts at which the $1.3 billion paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was, ultimately, going to be paid.  Second, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not involved in, or party to, the Devonia Agreement and was not aware of its terms:  such limited involvement as there was, at a low level, by members of his accounting staff in what might loosely be referred to as the Devonia Agreement transaction was directed at, and limited to, the mechanics for the payment by an Abramovich controlled company of the $1.3 billion to Devonia\'s account.  Third, contrary to the terms of the Devonia Agreement, there was never any genuine intention that Devonia would "transfer the beneficial interests in the Shares being [purportedly] purchased" under the agreement to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or companies or entities controlled by, or associated with, him.  Fourth, Devonia never did transfer such interests to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or any companies associated with him.  Fifth, because it was a sham transaction, the Devonia Agreement did not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements or in relation to the Sibneft intimidation issue.  Sixth, on the contrary, the evidence relating to the issue, and the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky chose to assert that the Devonia Agreement was a genuine agreement, did not reflect well on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s credibility.\r   The terms of the Devonia Agreement As I have already described above, the Devonia Agreement was an agreement dated on or about 11 or 12 June 2001 (being the date on which the Sheikh apparently signed the agreement) between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, described as "the Vendors", of the first part, Devonia, described as "the Purchaser", of the second part and the Sheikh described as "the Guarantor", of the third part, whereby Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili purported to transfer to Devonia their beneficial interests in specified numbers of shares in Sibneft arising under an express oral trust constituted under English law.  The Devonia Agreement was entitled:  \r   "SALE AND PURCHASE AGREEMENT \xc2\x85  AGREEMENT for the sale and purchase of beneficial interests in part of the issued share capital of OAO SIBNEFT" The recitals were as follows:\r   " RECITALS (A)\t OAO SIBNEFT (\'the Company\')  is a company limited by shares incorporated in the Russian Federation with an allotted and issued share capital as at the date hereof of 4,741,000,000 shares. (B)\tThe Company was originally incorporated by the Vendors and Mr.\xc2\xa0Roman Abramovich and the entire issued share capital thereof was jointly held between the Vendors and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (C)\tThe Vendors are now the beneficial owners of 2,062,335,000 shares in the issued and allotted share capital of the Company (\'the Shares\'). (D)\tAt the request of the Vendors, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich procured that the registration of the Shares were legal entities which are directly or indirectly wholly owned and/or controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (\'the Registered Entities\'). (E)\tThe Vendors have agreed to sell and the Purchaser has agreed to purchase all or part of their beneficial interests in the Shares for the consideration and upon the terms and conditions set out in this Agreement. (F)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich holds the Shares and/or controls the Registered Entities and through them the Shares as nominee in trust for and on behalf of the Vendors absolutely on verbal arrangements. (G)\tThe Vendors confirm and are aware that the Purchaser intends hereafter to transfer the beneficial interests in the Shares being purchased hereunder to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or companies or entities controlled or associated with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich. (H)\tIn consideration of the Vendors entering into this Agreement the Guarantor has agreed to guarantee the obligations of the Purchaser under this Agreement." Clause 2A of the operative part of the agreement provided for the sale by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of:\r   "all of their beneficial interests \xc2\x85  together with all beneficial rights of any nature which are now or which may at any time become attached to them or accrue in respect of them" in an initial tranche of 79,320,577 Sibneft shares for $100 million.  It then went on to grant separate and successive options to Devonia to purchase the Vendors\' "beneficial interest" in 12 further tranches of 79,320,577 Sibneft shares for $100 million each.  Each successive option only arose, and was conditional upon, the exercise and completion of the option to purchase the prior tranche.   Under Clause 4 and Schedule 2 of the Devonia Agreement, each of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were required, upon completion of the sale of the first tranche of beneficial interests, to execute and deliver to Devonia "a certificate of transfer of beneficial ownership for 79,320,577 of the Shares", and "such documents as the Purchaser may require to enable the full beneficial ownership of the Shares to vest in the Purchaser." The form of "Vendors Certificate" was provided in Schedule 3 and included the statement by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that they:\r   "\xc2\x85 irrevocably and unconditionally transfer and assign all of my interest, right and title in [   ] shares in the issued and allotted share capital of the Company"  and that, upon receipt of the consideration: "\xc2\x85 the beneficial interests in those shares detailed in the certificate are the absolute property of the Purchaser and may be freely transferred or assigned to any third party whatsoever without any further consent from myself or any third party". Under Clause 5.1 and Schedule 1 of the Devonia Agreement, each of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili jointly and severally warranted, represented and undertook to Devonia,  inter alia , that \r   i)\tthey were entitled to sell and transfer "the full beneficial ownership in the Shares with full title guarantee to the Purchaser";  and  ii)\tSibneft had not exercised or purported to exercise or claim any lien "over the beneficial interest of the Vendors in the shares".   Summary of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Devonia Agreement Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, both in closing, as well as in opening, was that the Devonia Agreement was a genuine transaction which supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case as to the existence of the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements.  The terms of the Devonia Agreement, including in particular its recitals, were relied upon as a written or paper record not only of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests in Sibneft, but also as a record of their effective sale or surrender of such interests to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (notwithstanding that the direct sale was to Devonia).  It was contended that, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not a party to the Devonia Agreement, and did not need to see it, he must have known that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were selling their Sibneft interests to a non-Russian entity controlled by the Sheikh under the terms of an English law/jurisdiction agreement.  It was further contended that the involvement of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s staff in the transaction, such as Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk, and her communications with Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson of Curtis & Co underlined the genuine nature of the transaction, as did the due diligence conducted by Curtis & Co, Clydesdale Bank ("Clydesdale") and Denton Wilde Sapte in relation to it;  in particular it was submitted that it was inconceivable that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis would have acted in the way which he did, if he had known or believed the Devonia transaction to be a sham.  It was also asserted that there was indeed an on-sale by Devonia of the Sibneft interests sold by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   The purported subject matter of the Devonia Agreement The first curious feature of the Devonia Agreement is that it purported to be a sale by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of their beneficial interests in a specific number of Sibneft shares.  But it is no longer Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he had any "beneficial interest" in any shares in Sibneft.  His claim to have a beneficial interest in such shares was deleted from his particulars of claim by amendment in 2009.  As I have already described, his case is that what he acquired under the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements were personal and contractual rights against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Sibneft, including profits generated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s trading companies, as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s acquisition and control of Sibneft, and, as a result, "common" property rights in any property created or acquired by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a result of the "joint activity" between the three men.\r   In my judgment, it is impossible to construe, interpret or characterise the Devonia Agreement as an agreement under which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were assigning all their personal contractual rights against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, not only in relation to Sibneft, but also in relation to the profits generated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s trading companies, to the Sheikh\'s company, Devonia, or as an agreement under which they were assigning "common property" in any property created or acquired by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a result of the joint activity.  The express subject matter of the Devonia Agreement was (purportedly) Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s beneficial (i.e. proprietary) interests in a specified number of shares in the issued share capital of Sibneft.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that:\r   i)\tThe commercial purpose of the Devonia Agreement was plainly for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to give up all the rights he had against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in respect of Sibneft;  business common sense would thus dictate that the Devonia Agreement be construed so as to achieve this purpose.   ii)\tThis was a case where the contract was open to more than one interpretation;  in such circumstances the interpretation to be adopted was one which was most consistent with business common sense;  see per Lord Clarke in  Rainy Sky SA v Kookmin Bank   [2011] UKSC 50  at paragraph 30,  "where a term of a contract is open to more than one interpretation, it is generally appropriate to adopt the interpretation which is most consistent with business common sense".   iii)\tInfelicitous drafting did not prevent the Devonia Agreement having its intended meaning.  Lord Hoffmann\'s well-known injunction in  Chartbrook Ltd v Persimmon Homes Ltd   [2009] UKHL 38 ,  [2009] AC 1101 , at paragraph 21, was to disregard the use of legally inaccurate, and to set no limits to the "\xc2\x85 \'verbal rearrangement or correction\' which is permitted, so long as it is \'clear that something has gone wrong with the language and \xc2\x85 [clear] what a reasonable person would have understood the parties to have meant\'" (at paragraph 25). iv)\tIn any event, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was wrong to describe Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s rights as merely being personal contractual rights:  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili also had common property in any property (including income, fruits and revenues) created or acquired by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a result of the joint activity.   v)\tThe effect, therefore, of the Devonia Agreement was to transfer all of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s rights against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and/or in relation to Sibneft to Devonia.   I do not accept these arguments.  In my judgment it is impossible, even approaching the interpretation of the agreement in the most generous way to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, to construe the Devonia agreement, which by its express terms was an agreement to sell beneficial/equitable ownership in specific quantities of Sibneft shares, as an agreement to assign the personal contractual Russian law rights which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, or any "common property rights" in any property created or acquired by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as a result of the alleged joint activity agreement.\r   Moreover, as pointed out in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions:  \r   i)\tThe alleged 1995/1996 agreements provided, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, for the  common  ownership by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of a bundle of contractual partnership rights to  all  shares in Sibneft.  It would therefore be necessary to read each reference to beneficial ownership of a tranche of 79,320,577 Sibneft shares as a reference to the undivided 50% share held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in twice that many shares. ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was said to be the legal owner, and trustee, of the Sibneft shares which were the subject matter of the Devonia Agreement.  But Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich never himself directly owned any material number of shares in Sibneft.  They were held by companies which he controlled or by banks acting as his nominee.  In consequence, in Russian law, the "common property" in relation to which any rights of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili arose could not have been the shares in Sibneft.  As Dr.\xc2\xa0Rachkov appeared to concede, it would have to have been some interest in the holding companies or possibly in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s right of control over them. Thus, even without consideration of any further factors, the purported subject matter of the Devonia Agreement raised an immediate question over the genuine nature of the transaction which it was purporting to document.  Any transaction that purports to reflect the sale of non-existent rights necessarily calls into question its purpose and its authenticity.  An agreement which purports to record the sale of rights which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky now no longer asserts that he had ever held, must raise even the most indulgent of judicial eyebrows.  \r   The circumstances surrounding the making of the Devonia Agreement But, far more importantly, and leaving completely to one side what might be regarded as legal arguments as to the subject matter or wording of the Devonia Agreement, and as to what, if any, rights or interests it might effectively have disposed of, the circumstances surrounding the making of the Devonia Agreement demonstrated that it was a wholly bogus transaction, entered into for the purposes of providing Western banks with spurious evidence as to the legitimacy of the provenance of the funds being paid to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  It is against that background that one has to evaluate any reliance upon the recitals contained in the Devonia Agreement as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.\r   It was common ground between the parties that by 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were well aware of the potential problems posed by the money-laundering regulations in force in most Western countries, in particular the EU and the United States.  Large cash transfers were likely to provoke enquiries about the source of the funds.  These enquiries would have been difficult to answer satisfactorily, unless it could have been demonstrated that the funds represented the proceeds of an identifiable asset to which the fundholder was entitled, or monies to which they were genuinely entitled under a written commercial contract.  It was clear that this was a serious problem for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, once they left Russia.  A substantial amount of the funds which they had hitherto utilised to fund their living expenses and their other activities had ultimately been derived from undocumented Russian sources.  In the future, the funds which were going to provide for their future livelihood, including the proceeds of the ORT sale and the $1.3 billion which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was going to pay, had to be available to the two men outside Russia, and at least, so far as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was concerned, had to be available in a Western bank, in a country where he could safely live as a political refugee, free from the risk of extradition.  As the evidence showed, in 2000 and 2001 the anti money-laundering procedures adopted by Western banks were becoming ever more rigorous, especially where the funds concerned derived from Russia.  Satisfying, or circumventing, these procedures was an important and necessary feature of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s business arrangements.  It necessarily affected Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s dealings with banks and professional intermediaries.  This was common ground on the evidence between the parties.  It was also clear from the evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich appreciated Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s concerns in this respect and, so far as he was able, was prepared to assist them in their efforts to ensure that any payments made by him or his companies would be accepted on a "legalised" basis by the relevant payee bank outside Russia;  in other words, that the receipt by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of such payments would be in a manner that was regarded as compliant by such bank with its anti-money-laundering enquiries and requirements.\r   The Spectrum transaction There had been a previous transaction, referred to as the Spectrum transaction, which had many similar features to the Devonia transaction.  The Spectrum transaction had been used by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to generate documentation to meet the money-laundering enquiries of Western banks in relation to the receipt, outside Russia, by the two men of $140 million in relation to the sale of their interests in ORT to companies controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  As already described, the true sale price was $150 million, but the price expressly recorded in the formal sale agreements was merely $10 million, the balance of $140 million being paid offshore, not merely because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was by this time an exile, and had concerns about the Russian State freezing the proceeds, but also because he was concerned about whether he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would get exchange control from the Russian Central Bank to export the funds from Russia.  For this reason, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wanted the amount paid in Russia for the ORT shares to be an absolute minimum.  The structure of the transaction was a matter that was discussed at the Le Bourget meeting.  It was apparently Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Gorodilov who suggested a proposal whereby Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would sell a call option to one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s offshore companies to satisfy the foreign banks\' money laundering requirements.  Another simpler proposal was discussed, whereby Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies would simply make a straight payment to offshore accounts designated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  the latter would make the necessary arrangements for what was euphemistically referred to at trial as "legalising" the funds (i.e. to represent them as deriving from a legitimate source so as to satisfy the legal money-laundering requirements of the ultimate recipient bank into which the monies were paid);  and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would agree to pay all or some part of the costs and commission which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have to pay in order to "legalise" the funds.  In the end, as I find, the latter, more simple, course was adopted so far as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was concerned.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was told that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have to pay 20% "commission" in order to "legalise" the $140 million which was going to be paid abroad;  and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to pay 10% of this sum, amounting to some $14 million.  Therefore a total of $154 million was going to be paid abroad.\r   The sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s ORT stake was structured as follows:  there were three contracts of sale;  one between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Akmos Trade Limited Liability Company ("Akmos"), an Abramovich company, for 49.95% of ORT-KB (which itself owned 38% of ORT);  a second between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Akmos for 49.95% of ORT-KB;  and a third between LogoVAZ and OOO Betas ("Betas") (another Abramovich company) for the remaining 11% of ORT.  These contracts were dated 25 December 2000 but were executed by LogoVAZ on 28 December 2000 and by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on 29 December 2000.  The shares were registered in the names of Akmos and Betas at the Moscow Companies Registry on 29 December 2000.  Betas paid LogoVAZ a nominal price for its holding, while the price recorded in the sale agreements with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was $10 million ($5 million each).  However, as described above, the true price was $150 million, and therefore the rationale for the receipt into a Western bank account of $140 million by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili required to be documented.\r   Of the total of $154 million to be paid abroad, $136.3 million was paid  - at Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev\'s direction - into an account in the name of Spectrum General Trading Establishment ("Spectrum") between 8 and 25 January 2001.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Gorodilov, who arranged for the payments to be made, knew nothing about this company.  He simply acted on Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev\'s directions.\r   Although not known to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or his advisers at the time, Spectrum was in fact a company owned by the Sheikh.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephen Curtis, the principal of Curtis & Co, was a solicitor with offices off Park Lane who specialised in the creation of complex corporate and trust structures to hold assets for "super-affluent" individuals, generally from Russia or the Middle East.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis had briefly assisted Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in the  Forbes  litigation in 1998.  In late 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had apparently been re-introduced to him by Mr.\xc2\xa0Samuelson of Valmet.  The Sheikh had become a client of Curtis & Co in late 1999/2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis died in a helicopter crash in March 2004.  \r   Curtis & Co were retained by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at some stage in late 2000 to assist with the receipt, and subsequent holding outside Russia, of the proceeds of the ORT sale.  In December 2000, Curtis & Co put in hand the arrangements for the opening in the name of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of accounts at Clydesdale.  Curtis & Co were then instructed, probably by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, but otherwise by someone else on behalf of Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili, to draft two documents:  \r   i)\ta call option agreement between Spectrum and Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili, granting a call option to Spectrum exercisable within 12 months to purchase their respective ORT-KB shares;  the price for the grant of the option itself was $140 million payable within 14 days, and a further $10 million was payable on the actual exercise of the option;  and  ii)\ta deed of assignment between Spectrum and Akmos, which purported to assign to Akmos the call option rights contained in the call option agreement entered into by Spectrum with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  the amount of the consideration for such assignment being left a blank.  Mr.\xc2\xa0James Jacobson gave evidence about this transaction.  He was a solicitor working at Curtis & Co at the time [461] .  Although Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson had suggested in his witness statement that the firm was acting for Spectrum, "with hindsight" he acknowledged in cross-examination that it was also acting for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.   Both documents were drafted by Curtis & Co in mid-January 2001, shortly after the first payments to Spectrum were made.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili executed the call option agreement sometime after 9\xc2\xa0February 2001, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis wrote to Mr.\xc2\xa0Ivlev, who was acting on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in relation to the transaction, to remind him that it was necessary for their clients to execute the option agreement.  Spectrum executed both the call option agreement and the deed of assignment on about 11 June 2001, when signed copies of both instruments were faxed to Curtis & Co\'s office.  At some stage after this date and before August 2002, a signature was purportedly added to the deed of assignment on behalf of Akmos.  As at June 2001, Curtis & Co only had a copy of the assignment agreement signed by the Sheikh.  On 6 August 2002 a deed of assignment signed by the Sheikh and purportedly signed by Akmos was sent by Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson to Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay\'s office, Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay being at that time aide and advisor to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson said in cross-examination that he had "no idea" how the signature came to be on the copy of the document which Curtis & Co had held since June 2001.  He agreed that the document which he had sent to Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay had been in the files of Curtis & Co since June without Akmos\' signature on it.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson confirmed that there was no other documentary record in the Curtis & Co file of any other agreement as executed by the Sheikh, apart from the copy faxed on 11 June, nor any record of the firm itself having arranged for an Akmos signature to be appended to the assignment.\r   As submitted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, I conclude that the Spectrum agreements were a sham.  They were not seen by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at the time, nor by anybody acting on his behalf in relation to the ORT transaction, including, in particular, Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko and Ms.\xc2\xa0Popenkova.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Gorodilov and Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko gave evidence to the effect that the purported execution of the assignment on behalf of Akmos was a forgery, which I accept and which, in any event, was not challenged.  The arrangements could never have been intended, or effective, to confer call options on Spectrum, because the ORT-KB shares had already been transferred to Akmos by 29 December 2000 and indeed it had been registered as an ORT-KB shareholder by that date.  Therefore, by the time that the call option agreement was drafted, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had no shares over which they could grant a call option, and Akmos was already the owner of the shares which were the subject of the deed of assignment.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was well aware of the date of registration of the transfer, at any rate by 5 February 2001 when he was told about it by Mr.\xc2\xa0Ivlev.  Further, the $140 million had been paid into Spectrum\'s account by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies by 25 January 2001, and by Spectrum to the Clydesdale accounts of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on 13 February 2001, in each case before the call option agreement or assignment were executed by all parties.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was likely to have been aware of the date of the payments into the Clydesdale accounts on about 13 February 2001, since Curtis & Co had access to the Clydesdale statements.  Perhaps not surprisingly, there was no evidence of the option ever having been exercised or of the agreements having been used for any other purpose.\r   In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s First Schedule, at page 212, it was conceded:\r   "\xc2\x85 that the Spectrum option agreement was not genuine.  That is why no reliance is placed upon it." In my judgment, the evidence clearly demonstrated that the Spectrum scheme had no purpose other than to generate documentation which purported to explain that the origin of the $140 million paid into Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Clydesdale accounts, was legitimate in terms of compliance with the bank\'s anti-money-laundering procedures.  Thus the Spectrum documentation purported to show that money had been received from an "acceptable" person or source, so far as the bank\'s anti-money laundering requirements were concerned (i.e. the Sheikh), and represented payment by his company, Spectrum, of the price for the grant of a call option to Spectrum, under the terms of an English law option agreement, rather than the funds representing the sale price of shares in a Russian registered company, paid by an unknown vendor in circumstances where the bank would have had difficulty in checking whether, for example, Russian exchange control or other legal requirements had been complied with in relation to the sale of such shares.\r   According to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, the Sheikh appears to have charged the same, or almost the same, 15% commission for his "assistance" in connection with the Spectrum transaction as he subsequently did in relation to the Devonia transaction.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis agreed at some point with the Sheikh that he would receive a personal commission of $600,000 related to the Sheikh\'s profit on the Spectrum transaction.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not mention anything about Spectrum in his witness statements.  In cross-examination he said that he could not remember anything about Spectrum, and did not remember its name, and that the various arrangements to use the Spectrum mechanism would have been decided upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and implemented by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  However I conclude, based on his evidence and:\r   i)\this signature on the Clydesdale account opening form; ii)\this letter before action, (which referred to the option agreement and that "Our client understands that Spectrum in turn transferred the shareholdings to [Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich], or to [his] nominees");  and  iii)\tinformation which he was recorded as having supplied for the summary judgment hearing in a witness statement used on that occasion, that, even if he could not remember Spectrum\'s name, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have known at the time, at least in very general terms, of the role played by the Sheikh and Spectrum in laundering the proceeds of the ORT sale. I was not impressed by his attempts to distance himself from any knowledge of, or participation in, these arrangements. The reason why the evidence relating to the Spectrum transaction is relevant, and why I have summarised it notwithstanding Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s acceptance of the fact that the Spectrum option agreement was not a genuine agreement, is that the Spectrum transaction sheds light on the nature, function and purpose of the subsequent Devonia Agreement, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky maintains was a genuine agreement evidencing the sale or surrender of his Sibneft interests to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  In a sense the Spectrum transaction served as a dress-rehearsal for the far more substantial Devonia transaction.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s asserted purpose for entering into the Devonia Agreement As I have already described, it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence that it was very important for him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that the agreement which they had reached for the disposal of their interests be in writing, and that it should record the interest in Sibneft which they were giving up.  Various reasons were put forward for their concern.  \r   First, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged that they wanted to be sure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would not find a way to avoid making payment.  I do not accept this asserted purpose.  The Devonia Agreement did not purport to be made with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would not have been able to have ensured Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s compliance with his outstanding instalment obligations, simply by recourse to the Devonia Agreement.  \r   Second, it was said that they wanted to ensure that the  reason  for the payments being made to them was clearly identified, so that there would not be any question that they were entitled to receive the sums, and to avoid any money laundering concerns.  It was common ground between the parties that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a real need to document transactions in relation to their receipt of funds outside Russia, so that the anti- money-laundering requirements and procedures of Western banks could be satisfied and that that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich knew of the importance to the two men of this requirement.  To that extent, I accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a real need to produce documentation justifying their receipt of funds outside Russia, so as to ensure that they were in a position to comply with any anti-money-laundering requirements or procedures of Western banks;  but I do not accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had any wish that the genuine reason for such payments should be specified in the documents.  \r   Third, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asserted that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were determined to make sure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would one day pay for his intimidation, although they knew that this would not be possible until Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov was safely out of Russia.  I do not accept this asserted purpose as a reason for their entry into the Devonia Agreement.  Given that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not a party to the Devonia Agreement, and, as I find below, was not involved in the transaction, the Devonia Agreement did not provide them with an additional weapon to assist them in any future claim against him, based on intimidation.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in this respect was tantamount to saying that he wanted to make sure that there was brought into existence an evidential record of:\r   i)\tbeneficial interests held by him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in a specific number of Sibneft shares under alleged oral trusts; ii)\tthe sale or disposition of such interests at this particular point in time;  and  iii)\tan alleged on-sale to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich. I deal below with what I regard as the most likely explanation for the presence of these matters in the Devonia Agreement. Analysis of the evidence relating to the making of the Devonia Agreement In about April 2001, Curtis & Co appear to have received instructions to handle a transaction similar to Spectrum, but this time said to involve the proceeds of a sale of Sibneft shares.  According to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, he thought that the Devonia structure had been originally proposed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis in order to protect Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assets from the Russian authorities.  On 20 April 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis gave a dinner at Mosimann\'s dining club in Belgravia  which was attended by (among others) the Sheikh, the director of the Sheikh\'s Private Management Office, Dr.\xc2\xa0Eyhab Jumean ("Dr.\xc2\xa0Jumean"), and three representatives of Clydesdale, its Chairman, the Chief Executive and the Head of Compliance.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s attendance note shows that the potential involvement of the Sheikh and Clydesdale had been discussed at the dinner, and probably before.\r   On 10 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at Munich airport, when, as I have already described, the question of a substantial payment to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was discussed.  On Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, the topic had first been raised at the meetings in Courchevel and then M\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa8ve in early 2001.\r   At about this time, Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk, one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s accounts staff, who reported directly to Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler being her ultimate supervisor, became involved.  She was asked by Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko to liaise with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, who was identified to her as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s representative, in relation to the administrative steps and documentation required to set up the arrangements for a payment of approximately $1 billion, subject to the supervision of Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko.  Various options for doing so were considered, which were reflected in a document created by Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk called "Payment Schemes".  At some point in May 2001, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko suggested that the Latvian Trade Bank ("LTB") should be used to receive the funds on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s behalf, as it was a bank used by a number of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies and they had a good relationship with it.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk was thus also instructed to assist Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev to open an account with LTB.  One proposal, put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev to Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk, was that the transfer of the agreed sum to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should be effected by means of a transfer of securities to the two men;  the proposal was that one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies would declare advance distribution of profit to an entity, or entities, specified by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev;  at the same time the entity/entities specified by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev would instruct Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s company to pay the dividends in the form of securities specified by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s company would then acquire in the market through its broker and take them to a custodian where the entity/entities specified by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had accounts.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk described how during a certain period it was unclear which of the two possible options (securities or cash) was going to be utilised to make the payment and therefore the two options were developed concurrently, although it appeared that the dividend mechanism was going to be utilised in any event, irrespective of whether the dividend was paid in cash or in specie (i.e. by transfer of securities).\r   On 14 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson telephoned Clydesdale\'s European compliance officer, Ms.\xc2\xa0Hilton, in order, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson\'s attendance note of the conversation, to provide "some information relating to the proposed transaction concerning the sale of shares in Sibneft".  As recorded in the note, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis said that Sibneft was owned 50% by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and 50% by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili jointly, but that, notwithstanding, the company\'s shares were registered 100% in the name of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  He said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and the Sheikh were "rival bidders" for the 50% owned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  The note recorded:\r   "\xc2\x85 even though the Sheikh may initially purchase the shares, it was understood that he would be more than happy to pass on the shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich while keeping a small stake for himself.  In addition, in order for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to do the deal, it is obviously a pre-requisite that he was happy with the commercial element and negotiations were continuing in this regard."  The note went on to record that, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich bought the shares, he would be paying from funds in Latvia;  if it was the Sheikh, the funds would be coming from Abu Dhabi.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Hilton, however, was unwilling to accept payments from Latvia because EU money-laundering regulations did not apply there.  But she was willing to accept them from the Sheikh, since the bank had done due diligence on him already and he was known to be a member of one of the richest families in the world.  The note recorded Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis as saying that: "\xc2\x85 the new deal would be more along the lines of the Option scenario previously used in the ORT deal \xc2\x85 as in the previous deal the Sheikh would ultimately sell on the shares to [Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich] under this Option scheme." Ms Hilton was recorded as acknowledging this but as saying that "\xc2\x85 the bank were only required to look at transactions which were passing through their bank accounts only";  i.e. the bank would not be required to examine any on-sale to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  She also commented that if the transaction went the same way as the previous one (i.e. the Spectrum transaction) then there would be less work to do for the bank.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis went on to inform her that there would be an initial transfer of $700 million, followed by the balance of $800 million being paid over the next year.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and Ms.\xc2\xa0Hilton then went on to discuss a topic which was clearly intended to be the "sweetener" for the bank, namely the Sheikh\'s conversation at the dinner, where he had intimated that he wished to establish a banking connection with Clydesdale.  \r   I comment that there was nothing in the evidence at trial to suggest that any of the information being conveyed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis in this conversation had come from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or his employees, or that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis had been in communication with any of them (and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson confirmed this) for the purposes of the transaction (other than the limited communication with Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk which I describe below);  nor was there any anything in such evidence to support his assertions that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and the Sheikh were "rival bidders" in the proposed purchase of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged beneficial interests, or that there was any intention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich subsequently purchasing such interests from the Sheikh.  Likewise Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\' description of the Spectrum transaction as a deal in which the Sheikh had ultimately sold on the shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich under an option scheme was also clearly incorrect.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson acknowledged, there was no evidence in the Curtis files to support the proposition that either Akmos, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or any of his companies had ever exercised the call option over the ORT-KB shares, purportedly assigned by Spectrum, or had by that method purchased the shares from the Sheikh.\r   On 15 May 2001 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich may have met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Paris.  In her oral evidence, Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk said that she was told about the $1.3 billion figure after 14 May 2001 which might suggest that the figure was agreed in Paris.  It does not make any difference whether the final figure was agreed in Munich or Paris.  \r   Two days later, on 17 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis visited Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s villa at Cap d\'Antibes to take instructions from his clients, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev was also present.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson faxed to the meeting a preliminary discussion draft of a share sale and purchase agreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on the one hand and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on the other hand.  There appeared to be various long form and short form drafts in contemplation.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis appears to have advised that there should be a direct agreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili so as to:\r   i)\tenable payment to be enforced in the English courts if necessary (there was an English jurisdiction clause in the draft); ii)\t"try and create evidence" of the trust "scenario" which was said to be "currently in oral form"; iii)\tprovide for a release of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s obligations as "trustee" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s stake upon the money being paid. They discussed a proposal under which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would agree in writing to buy Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s "interest" in Sibneft, thereby acknowledging its existence, while the money would be channelled to Clydesdale via the Sheikh so as to satisfy the bank.  In addition to the draft form of sale agreement, a draft form of release under which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili released any claim which they might have against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to the shares, once they had been paid the sums due to them for transferring their beneficial interest in the shares,  was also considered.   The decision was taken that the direct agreement should be in the shorter version, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson, who was tasked with the drafting, was instructed by notes from Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis that the clients "\xc2\x85 want new short form with confirmation of trust arrangements please" and that it was important to "particularly ensure that the trust clause is inserted".  A draft of a direct agreement was faxed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev on 19 May 2001.  This referred to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (confusingly defined as "the Transferees") as the beneficial owners of approximately 44% of the issued and allotted share capital of Sibneft (defined as "the Shares") and contained confirmation by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that "at the Transferees\' request" he had procured that "the registered holders of the Shares were legal entities directly or indirectly wholly owned and/or controlled by him";  and that he held the shares and/or controlled the registered holders "and through them the Shares as nominee in trust for and on behalf of the Transferees absolutely".  The draft form of release was "abandoned" on 18 May 2001, the day after it had been drafted.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson could not assist in his oral evidence as to why the release was abandoned.  The clear inference which I draw is that the release, like the proposal to have a direct sale agreement as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of their alleged beneficial interests, was abandoned because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili knew well that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would not have been prepared, even in order to assist them with their money-laundering objectives, to have signed an agreement purporting to purchase interests which they did not own.\r   The contemporaneous Curtis & Co draft documentation and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson\'s evidence also showed that at one stage, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev were apparently also envisaging that, in addition to these agreements between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, there would be a parallel set of documents recording certain arrangements between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and the Sheikh.  These would be designed to explain to the Russian authorities why such a large payment was being made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to the Sheikh.  The idea appears to have been that the Sheikh would grant Sibneft an oil concession on land known to have no oil under it, to which the payment could be related.  To this end, Curtis & Co drafted two licence agreements each recording the grant of an oil concession to Sibneft for $550 million.  These documents were discussed by Curtis & Co with Dr.\xc2\xa0Jumean of the Sheikh\'s Private Management Office, and e-mailed by Curtis & Co to Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev on 20 May 2001.  In fact the proposal was abandoned shortly thereafter;  as Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson observed in his witness statement, the suggestion that the Sheikh should grant an oil licence for land with no oil would have raised some eyebrows.  There was no evidence that they were ever discussed with anyone on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side, which clearly they would have had to have been, if Sibneft was to be granted an "oil concession".\r   The various contemporaneous drafts and notes, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s description of the proposed transactions, as well as Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson\'s evidence, demonstrated the sham and wholly bogus nature of the proposed arrangements.  A solicitor, Mr.\xc2\xa0Nicholas Keeling [462]  of Denton Wilde Sapte, Gibraltar, was retained to set up any offshore vehicles that might be required.  In a telephone conversation on 21 May 2001 with Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis explained to Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling the nature of the transaction.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis told Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling that it was proposed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should buy the interests of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili for $1.3 billion, of which $500 million would be paid up front and the rest in eight monthly instalments of $100 million each.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling\'s note of the telephone conversation recorded that he was told:  \r   "[Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis] has been brokering a deal whereby Abromovich [sic] will buy out the shares of Berezovsky and Badre [Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili]". But the statement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis had been "brokering a deal" was rubbish;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson\'s evidence was that his understanding at the time was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was not in contact with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and that he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson, had not been told of any such contact by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis.  He also confirmed that, apart from Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk, there was no evidence in the Curtis & Co file of any contact between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s staff and Curtis & Co.   In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions the suggestion was made that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s denial of Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s statement to Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling - that he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, had been "brokering" the deal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich  - should  not be  accepted.  It was said:\r   "in this regard, the disclosure by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, mid-trial, of Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s files of his dealings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in the mid-1990s was of some significance." The fact that the documents were disclosed "mid-trial" had no significance whatsoever;  they were only supplied to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich midtrial by Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own witness, and were thereafter disclosed in their entirety.  The documents did not provide any support for a suggested relationship between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis in 2001, such as to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was "brokering" any deal between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  The evidence showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had met Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis once in 1994 and once again in 1995, and that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler had had discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis at that time about possible commercial transactions, and about the possibility of Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis arranging a Gibraltar passport for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  but in fact Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler had not conducted any business with Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis either then or thereafter at any relevant time.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested that an article in the Guardian newspaper on 1 December 2003 which referred to \r   "talks, which took place in London,  between Stephen Curtis, the British lawyer recently made managing director of Yukos\'s main shareholder, Menatep, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  They are understood to have centred  on calls for more Sibneft control of any combined group\xc2\x85." showed that there had been direct negotiations between Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to the Yukos-Sibneft merger attempt in 2003.  But such talks as there may have been in relation to a merger that did not proceed, did not demonstrate any relationship as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis in May/June 2001 from which it can be inferred that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich knew or had been informed about the terms of the Devonia Agreement. I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence in this respect.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\' statement was untrue;  he was not brokering any deal between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  in making the statement to Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was no doubt trying to persuade Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling of the genuine commercial nature of the arrangements underlining the proposed Devonia transaction and perhaps also trying to talk up his own role.\r   In the telephone conversation on 21 May 2001, recorded in Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling\'s note, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis went on to say that he was drafting agreements between them which would record Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s "trusteeship" of the interest of Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili, of which there was otherwise no written record.  However, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, a parallel set of documents would be required in order to enable the funds to be "extracted" from Russia without identifying Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as the vendor, since Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had always denied in public that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had any interest in Sibneft, information which Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson thought had come from Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling\'s note recorded:  \r   "The plan therefore is that His Highness Sheikh Sultan bin Khalifa Al Nahyan of Abu Dhabi (the head of the Crown Prince\'s office in Abu Dhabi) will arrange for an oil concession to be granted to Sibneft over a large tract of land in Abu Dhabi.  It is anticipated that, in fact, this land will not actually have any oil.  That will enable Sibneft to make a payment to Sheikh Sultan and Sheikh Sultan will then pay Berezovsky and Badre.  There will be formal agreements reflecting this \'reality\', although in fact this is merely a structure to enable the funds for Berezovsky and Badre\'s interests to be extricated from Russia.  It is likely that Sheikh Sultan will in turn, as part of the structure, acquire a 10% interest in Sibneft." Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling was accordingly asked to advise on the establishment of two Gibraltar trusts, the Itchen Trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and the Test Trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and to open accounts on their behalf with Clydesdale to receive the funds.  A BVI shelf company, to be owned by the Sheikh (in the event, Devonia) was to be obtained in order to receive the payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and pass them on to the Clydesdale accounts.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s description of the proposed transaction clearly demonstrated that he was planning a sham transaction which was designed to provide a misleading explanation of the origin of the payments expected to be made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson agreed in cross-examination that this proposal was obviously a sham, "pretty much" designed to generate documents to explain the payments.  However, Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson did in fact draft two licence agreements which he sent to Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev on 20 May 2001.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson later rang Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling back to ask him to reserve a BVI company Devonia Investments Ltd, whose registered and beneficial owner was to be the Sheikh.  It was intended that Devonia would be the recipient of the payment to be made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (whether in cash or by means of a transfer of securities.) On or about 22 May 2001, the Sheikh became the owner of Devonia\'s share capital and one of his employees, Matar Mohamed Saeed Ali Al Neyadi, was appointed as its sole director.\r   It also appeared from Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling\'s attendance note of 21 May 2001 that the figure of $1.3 billion must have been agreed between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at the Munich or Paris meetings in May 2001 and communicated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis.  But, as I have already described, until the end of May 2001, no final agreement was reached between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili about the manner in which the $1.3 billion would be paid.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had given Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk the details of Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson as the contact person to whom she should send documents;  and, at some time towards the end of May, she was told by Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko that Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko had been informed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev that the particular company which was going to be the recipient of the payment would be Devonia.  On 23 May 2001 Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk faxed Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson what she referred to as draft board minutes of a meeting of the board of directors [463]  of the Abramovich controlled company (eventually a Panamanian company, Pex Trade Corporation SA ("Pex")), which included a resolution for the declaration and distribution of dividends which were going to be paid to the Berezovsky/Patarkatsishvili vehicle.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk believed that she sent the minutes at the request of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  This was confirmed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson who could not remember any conversation with her and assumed that she had obtained his details from Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  On the same day, Clydesdale sent account opening forms for the Itchen and Test trusts to Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson.  Curtis & Co.  also sought advice from counsel, Mr.\xc2\xa0Jonathan Fisher, on money laundering issues relating to previous transactions with which they had been involved (including the Spectrum transaction) and sent instructions to him.\r   On 25 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson sent Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling the account opening forms for the accounts of the Test and Itchen Trusts with Clydesdale.  On the same day Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk sent to Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson a list of the documents required by the Latvian Trade Bank to open a safe custody account for Devonia.  \r   On 29 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis had a conference call with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fisher.  The attendance note records:\r   "SLC then raised the new Sibneft share deal and confirmed that BB/AP beneficially owned 50% of the shares in Sibneft.  He said however that the shares were registered 100% in the name of RA.  Effectively BB/AP had approached Sheikh Sultan to buy BB/AP\'s interest in the shares.  SLC had set up a meeting with Sheikh Sultan and Clydesdale Bank as he wanted Clydesdale Bank to discuss the transaction.  The effect of the agreement would be that Sheikh Sultan would purchase BB/AP interest at a discount and then sell on the shares to RA while retaining a minor interest.  The reason behind the Sheikh being involved with the transaction was quite obviously his interest in the oil business and it would also benefit him to have a stake in that particular Russian oil company as he was expanding his oil business assets worldwide.  He would also make a substantial profit on the transaction. "SLC said therefore the agreement at the moment would be that the Sheikh would pay BB/AP between US$500 million and US$1.5 billion for the shares and in response BB/AP would release their beneficial interest in those shares.  The Sheikh would then pass on the beneficial interest to a third party (and it is likely this would be companies controlled by RA) but would retain a small interest and would also take a profit on the resale.  It was also agreed that the Sheikh would provide his own cash to pay for the shares.  SLC expected to receive a substantial amount of money in relation to this transaction as it related to the original introduction.  As he was not involved on the sale on to RA, he would have no way of calculating the fee but was happy for the Sheikh to designate a figure.  RA was expected to use profits from one of his aluminium operations in Russia to pay for the shares.  SLC confirmed that RA was in control of 90% of the Russian aluminium industry.  SLC explained that the reason why it had been structured this way was that RA was the 100% registered owner and had made representations in Russia that he was the beneficial owner.  Therefore, it was difficult to justify any payment by RA for purchasing these shares.  RA was also not prepared to acknowledge the trust arrangement." At this stage Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev was still pressing for payment in a form which would avoid the money-laundering enquiries of Clydesdale when the money was remitted from Latvia to London.  He wanted discharge of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s payment obligation of $1.3 billion to be made by means of transfers of securities of equivalent value to a custody account with a depositary bank in Abu Dhabi.  This would have enabled Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev to have transferred the securities in specie to the West or to describe any cash receipt as representing the proceeds of their sale.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko was resisting the idea of payment in securities on the ground of impracticality.  \r   On 29 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Cologne.  As I have already described, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko were also present at the meeting and its purpose was to finalise the method and timing of the payment of the $1.3 billion.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko described, and I accept, it was agreed at the meeting that payment would be made in cash, not by means of a transfer of securities as Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev proposed;  that $500 million would be paid within a month;  and that the balance would be paid in instalments over a period of time.  As Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk described, whereas the "basic idea" remained unchanged, namely that of an Abramovich controlled company (as mentioned above, Pex) declaring a dividend in the sum of $1.3 billion, it was the method of payment that remained under discussion until the meeting at Cologne.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich gave evidence to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had requested his assistance with the production of documents necessary to enable Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and him to receive the money in London.  In those circumstances I do not find it surprising that Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk was asked to assist Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev with the arrangements for the opening of an account with LTB  and the receipt of the payment from Pex.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko had suggested the opening of Devonia\'s bank account with LTB for convenience, i.e. to minimise the risk of money transfer problems.  \r   In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written  closing submissions the assertion is made that the contemporaneous documents suggest that the plan to structure the sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s Sibneft interests as a direct sale from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich "was rejected by (or on behalf of) Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on some date between 21 and 25 May 2001".  I reject that assertion.  There was no evidence whatsoever to support the contention that any draft agreements relating to a proposed direct sale to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged beneficial interests in Sibneft shares, were ever sent or otherwise communicated to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or his staff, or that he or anyone on his side were ever asked to, or ever did, consider or negotiate such a proposal;  likewise, there was no evidence to support the contention that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or one of his staff rejected the plan originally proposed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis that there should be a direct sale of such interests to him.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own evidence, which I accept, was that there was neither a request for, nor rejection of, a direct sale.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson, as I have already said, confirmed that there was no evidence of any contact between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s staff and Curtis & Co (other than the limited contact with Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk in respect of the payment arrangements and setting up the bank account for Devonia) and could not assist on when or why there had been a change in plan resulting in the proposal for a direct contract between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili being dropped and replaced by a proposal for a purported sale of such interests to Devonia.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence in his witness statement was to the effect that he knew from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was refusing to make payment directly to them because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was concerned that he should not be seen to be paying money to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as this would be harmful to him;  he suggested in effect that it was because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s insistence that there should be no direct payment that it was necessary to effect payment via the Sheikh.  In cross-examination, however, he said that he did not remember discussing any document and did not know whether there had ever been a request for a direct contract.  I hold that no proposal was ever made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, whether by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or anyone else, for a direct contract of sale between himself and the two men of the latter\'s alleged beneficial interest in Sibneft shares, and that there was no rejection on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s part of any such proposal.  I conclude that the overwhelming likelihood is that, whatever Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s advice, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili appreciated that there was no way in which they would ever persuade Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, even solely for the purpose of helping them with the "legalisation" of their receipt of funds, to sign up to an agreement reflecting the purported sale of non-existent ownership interests in Sibneft shares, which they must have known that at least he did not consider that they owned.  \r   Whatever the reason for the change in Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s proposals, following the meeting at Cologne airport on 29 May there was a need to justify to Clydesdale the receipt in London of the $1.3 billion which was going to be paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Devonia\'s account at LTB in Latvia.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\' revised proposal was that, instead of a direct contract with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the documents would now record an agreement by which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili sold their alleged beneficial interests in Sibneft shares to Devonia, purportedly on the basis that Devonia would sell those interests on to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, with the Sheikh taking a turn on the transaction.  The structure of the sale was to be an outright sale of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s alleged interest in one thirteenth of their holding, and the grant of a series of twelve options, exercisable over a period of eight months, to purchase further thirteenths.  Each of the thirteen tranches would be sold for $100 million.  \r   The new arrangements were initially described to Clydesdale on the telephone on 25 May 2001, and then in two draft letters of Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis dated 29 May 2001, one to Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay and the other to  Dr.\xc2\xa0Jumean, Director of Finance and Administration for the Sheikh\'s Private Office.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis copied both drafts to Ms.\xc2\xa0Hilton at Clydesdale.  The draft letter to Dr.\xc2\xa0Jumean set out the new proposal to sell the stake to the Sheikh, and described the stages in which payment would be made, starting with the initial payment of $500 million.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis explained in the draft that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would not enter into a direct agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili because he would not be willing to recognise that they had any interest in Sibneft.  He referred to the "nebulous" character of the interest which in these circumstances the Sheikh would be buying, but observed that this was likely to be a "sticking point" for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson said in his oral evidence, the interest was nebulous because it was undocumented and unacknowledged.  He confirmed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis knew, probably (Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson guessed) from Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, that at this time Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would not acknowledge any interest.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis said that the sale by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would be matched by an on-sale by the Sheikh to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, but that he would not be instructed in relation to that.  He also explained that the new arrangements meant that, owing to his pre-existing relationship with the Sheikh, his firm could no longer act for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili but would henceforth act only for the Sheikh.  All of this was said to reflect "ongoing discussions" with Dr.\xc2\xa0Jumean.  However no explanation was given as to why Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was not going to be instructed in relation to the on sale by the Sheikh to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   The first draft of what became the Devonia Agreement between Devonia and Messrs Berezovsky and Patarkatsishvili was prepared on the following day, 30\xc2\xa0May 2001.  The bank responded to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\'s oral and written report of the change of plan by expressing concern that the Sheikh appeared to be exposing himself to a remarkable risk.  The bank was concerned that the Sheikh might simply be passing money received from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich through to the trusts of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and the bank asked for assurances on this point.  Apparently the bank was not prepared to receive Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s funds.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson agreed in cross-examination, on its face, this was an extraordinary transaction in which the Sheikh was going to buy for $1.3 billion an undocumented equitable interest in a Russian oil company in circumstances in which the registered owner of the shares was not prepared to acknowledge the existence of the interest.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis wrote to them on 31\xc2\xa0May 2001 assuring them that there was no intention simply to recycle Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s funds;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would be depositing funds with the Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank in advance in order to secure the payment of the price which would become due from him if, and when, the Sheikh acquired Messrs Berezovsky\'s and Patarkatsishvili\'s interest in each successive tranche of shares and sold it on to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  But, he said, the Sheikh would not be drawing on these deposits to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  he would be using his personal funds.  He told Clydesdale that the Sheikh would be writing to them directly to confirm this, which the Sheikh duly did on 5 June 2001.  However the evidence showed that not only did Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich never make any such deposits with the Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank, but also that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis had no basis upon which to give the assurance to the Clydesdale that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was going to do so;  the Curtis & Co files and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson\'s evidence confirmed that there was no communication with anyone on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side that would justify any such assertion;  nor was there even any confirmation from the Sheikh that such deposits were going to be, or had been, made.\r   Also on 30 May 2001 Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson sent the corporate documents for Devonia to a Dr.\xc2\xa0Paie in the Sheikh\'s office.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk sent to Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson copies of the documents required by the Latvian Trade Bank to open an account.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson sent these on to Dr.\xc2\xa0Jumean by cover of a fax.  Ms.\xc2\xa0Hilton sent to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis a mapping document to show Clydesdale\'s understanding of the transaction.  \r   By a letter dated 30 May 2001, Devonia, acting by its director, Mr.\xc2\xa0Al Neyadi also provided LTB with standing instructions to transfer the full balance of its account with that bank to its account with the Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank, via Chase Manhattan Bank New York.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis informed Ms.\xc2\xa0Hilton on the next day, 31 May 2001 that the Clydesdale\'s "mapping document" "perfectly" reflected the deal, save that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would not be trustees of their own trusts.  He also said:\r   "While we are not acting for the Sheikh in connection with the sale of his interest to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, I am advised that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich will be making separate deposits with Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank." Around 31 May 2001, Mr.\xc2\xa0Jacobson produced a document entitled \'List of matters for Eyhab Jumean\' as an aide-memoire of what was required to complete the agreement.  This included the following:\r   "His Highness to provide written confirmation directly to Clydesdale that all sums forwarded to the accounts of BB or AP or to their respective trust company accounts in relation to the purchase of the Sibneft shares are the sole property of an are beneficially owned by His Highness.  In order to provide confirmation that he is using his own money in relation to the transaction, this could be done by way of obtaining separate receipts from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and ensuring that His Highness uses independent funds to purchase the shares." None of the actions required any involvement from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, other than the suggestion that "separate receipts should be obtained" from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.
