Having considered very carefully the position I can confirm that the paragraphs above are accurate. 254 \tLater in 1999, Dmitry Bosov (a Russian businessman and Manager of the Transworld Group) approached me with the proposal that my group purchase various aluminium interests in Bratsk and Krasnoyarsk.  Badri also had extensive discussions with David Reuben, on behalf of the Reuben brothers from January 2000 onwards.  We had not previously considered investing in the aluminium industry, although of course I was aware that it was a very important industry in Russia and a very profitable business.  I discussed the possibility with Badri and we decided that a buy-out of the existing owners of these aluminium assets was worthwhile. 255 \tBadri informed me that Oleg Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fridman were also interested in acquiring those aluminium assets for their respective groups (Sibal and Alfa). 256 \tBadri and I raised the Bosov proposal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, as we considered we were obliged to do in accordance with our 1995 agreement with him.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that he would need to discuss it with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and made the point that he was not knowledgeable about the aluminium sector.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich ultimately agreed to the proposal.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich asked that my name should not appear as an interested party in the new aluminium venture because of my political exposure, just as he had requested with Sibneft. 257 \tI should say that although I have mentioned Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov, it was Badri who was the deal-maker with regard to the purchase of the Bratsk and Krasnoyarsk assets.  When Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov tried to present himself to us as being the party who should lead the negotiations and make the deal, I recall Badri saying to me that this should be his, Badri\'s, role as it was he that had good relations with key participants in the aluminium industry, such as Lev Cherney, Vasily Anisimov and the Reuben brothers.  Badri also had extensive discussions with David Reuben, on behalf of the Reuben brothers from January 2000 onwards. 258 \tAs far as I was aware, throughout this period, Badri remained totally loyal to me and supported me in my political struggle.  It was important to Badri and to me, particularly in view of my tension with the Russian authorities, that the aluminium assets were, insofar as possible, kept out of reach from politically motivated attacks.  As I have set out above, by this point I had already come under attack from Prime Minister Primakov, there had been raids on my businesses and I had been indicted on baseless charges (which were later dropped) relating to what was alleged to be an unlawful business activity in connection with Aeroflot.  For this reason, we agreed at Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s request that Badri\'s and my interest in the aluminium assets subsequently acquired on behalf of the three of us would not be made visible and would instead be held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich through offshore corporate vehicles. 259 \tIndeed, when Badri and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich were negotiating the acquisition of these aluminium interests, they told me that they were making the arrangements through offshore structures and subject to Western law to provide us with greater protection against abusive interference by the Russian authorities.  The interests acquired comprised interests in factories and related businesses at Bratsk, Krasnoyarsk and Achinsk, including interests in OJSC Krasnoyarsk Aluminium Plant, OJSC Krasnoyarsk Hydro-Electric Power Station, OJSC Achinsk Alumina Complex, and OJSC Bratsk Aluminium Plant.  (I visited the Krasnoyarsk aluminium plant, and the Krasnoyarsk hydro-electric power station myself in the summer of 1999 or 2000, to familiarise myself with my investments.  I met there with the General Director of the Krasnoyarsk Aluminium Plant, Alexey Barantsev). 260 \tWe agreed that the purchase price of the aluminium assets would be paid for from our entitlement of Sibneft profits.  As with Sibneft, the Abramovich/Berezovsky/Patarkatsishvili interest in the aluminium assets were subject to a 50:50 split between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on the one hand, and Badri and me on the other, in accordance with the agreement made regarding future business interests and in accordance with the use of Sibneft profits to acquire the assets.  Badri\'s and my share was the subject of our own Joint Venture agreement referred to above (i.e.  that, being a commercial venture, our interest in the aluminium business would be shared 50:50). 261 \tThere was some disagreement during the discussions as to who would manage the aluminium business.  Badri wanted to manage the aluminium business himself, whereas I preferred that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have this responsibility as it was important that Badri should continue concentrating on managing ORT.  Owing to the scale of the aluminium business we were setting up, I was concerned that if Badri were to manage it he would have to stop managing ORT.  ORT was the priority for me at the time, particularly in view of the forthcoming Presidential elections in Russia in 2000.  Just as he had in 1995 when I asked him to concentrate on managing in ORT, at this time too Badri agreed to do as I has requested. 262 \tI was not involved in the detailed discussions leading up to the purchase of the aluminium assets.  I have been shown a copy of the contract (which is dated 10 February 2000 and is for the sale and purchase of various aluminium assets comprising shares in OJSC Krasnoyarsk Aluminium Factory, shares in OJSC Krasnoyarsk Hydro-Electric Power Station, shares in OJSC Bratsk Aluminium Plant, the business of Bratsk and the shares in and business of a group of assets defined in the contract as "the Siberian Complex" (which included Achinsky Integrated Aluminium Works).  The purchasers under the agreement are said to be Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Badri (all three are signatories to the contract and enter into it on their behalf and on behalf of companies represented by them).  US$550 million was to be paid as the purchase price for the assets.  Although I was not a signatory to the agreement, I consider that I acquired interests under it as a result of the agreements with Badri and with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that I have discussed above.  Another formal reason for not signing this personally was that I was a member of the Duma at this time, and I was aware that under Russian law I was not allowed to be directly involved in business and could not put my signature on this agreement.  I am surprised that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich signed it personally despite being a member of the Duma as well.  It was reflected in the contemporary press (both Russian and Western) which reported that I was one of the purchasers of the aluminium assets. 263 \tAlthough I was not involved in deciding on or in implementing the structures for the vehicles used to receive the acquired aluminium interests that I have just discussed, my understanding was that the vehicles used would be Western entities, contracting under a non-Russian system of law (probably English - what we often called "British" law - or similar) in order to protect the aluminium interests against the kind of attacks I had experienced on my businesses in 1999, as well as to make them more tax efficient." As a result, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Particulars of Claim were re-amended shortly, before trial, to plead the alleged 1999 Agreement.   Although Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich submitted that the new method of formulation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim to an entitlement to the pre-merger assets was dependent upon there having been a valid agreement in 1995 in relation to Sibneft (on the basis that there were otherwise theoretically no terms which could be applied to the acquisition of the aluminium assets [473] ), I prefer to approach my consideration of the evidence relating to the alleged 1999 Agreement, on a favourable basis to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, that it was a freestanding agreement, independent of the alleged 1995 Agreement, although the terms of the alleged 1999 Agreement might have been similar, or agreed by reference, to the terms of the alleged 1995 Agreement.  What was clear was that the alleged 1999 Agreement sought to avoid the problem about the uncertainty of the alleged provision about future business contained in the alleged 1995 Agreement, by positing a specific agreement to apply the same terms to the acquisition of the aluminium assets.  \r   In approaching the evidence in relation to the alleged 1999 Agreement on a freestanding basis, I have therefore disregarded Russian law technicalities about whether the alleged 1999 Agreement could have been valid, if there had been no earlier concluded or valid 1995 Agreement.  I have assumed, in favour of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, that the later agreement could have been valid, as a matter of Russian law, irrespective of the existence, or validity, of the earlier 1995 Agreement.\r   However, notwithstanding the court\'s approach, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own direct evidence, both in his written evidence, and in cross-examination, was extremely weak when it came to attempting to establish the existence of a new oral agreement in 1999 whereby he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were to have a 50% interest in the relevant aluminium assets.  The evidence in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s fourth witness statement, quoted above, hardly supported such an agreement.  It did not refer to any new agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  The only express reference to the alleged 1995 Agreement was in paragraph 256, which itself only alleged that, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich with Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposal, they thought that they were obliged to do so under the term of the alleged 1995 Agreement relating to future business.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not say in those paragraphs that the 1995 agreement was ever mentioned to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, in connection with the proposal;  nor did he say that any new agreement was made by reference to what was supposed to have been agreed in 1995;  nor did he suggest that, irrespective of any reference to the alleged 1995 Agreement, the three men agreed that the new aluminium interests would be held as to 50% by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and as to 50% by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz sought to rely on paragraph 260 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s fourth witness statement and suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had not been cross-examined on that paragraph.  However that paragraph, apart from the statement that "We agreed that the purchase price of the aluminium assets would be paid for from our entitlement of Sibneft profits" did not deal with any new agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  the reference to the interests in the aluminium assets being subject to a 50:50 split between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on the one hand, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky on the other, "in accordance with the agreement made regarding future business interests and in accordance with the use of Sibneft profits to acquire the assets [i.e. the alleged 1995 Agreement]", again did not refer to any new agreement, or suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had mentioned the alleged 1995 agreement, or its terms, when negotiating with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in 1999 or had expressly agreed, even without any reference to any earlier agreement, that their respective interests in the relevant aluminium assets were to be held 50:50.  Moreover I reject the suggestion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not cross-examined on paragraph 260 of his fourth witness statement.  Although the specific paragraph was not put to him expressly, he was challenged on his evidence in relation to the alleged 1999 Agreement, at Day 9, pages 6-12, and was given every opportunity to explain what he said had been agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  All he in fact claimed in cross-examination was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov had proposed to him that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should acquire assets in the aluminium sector, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov did not actually identify at the time, but which turned out later to be the four businesses constituting the pre-merger aluminium assets [474] ; that he had discussed Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposal with  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who had said that he had received the same proposal from Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov "and from people who are involved in that business" and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had overplayed his role by suggesting that he had initiated the deal;  that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had then met Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and they proposed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and possibly also Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should follow up Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposal;  and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that he would think about it, and later agreed to do so. [475]  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not suggest that the 1995 agreement was mentioned, nor that any reference was made to the rights and obligations said to have been assumed in 1995.  There was no suggestion that anyone thought that a fresh agreement was being made.  The discussion, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky described it, was even vaguer than the alleged agreement about future business in 1995.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich denied that he had ever agreed in 1999, or at any other time, to participate with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the acquisition of the aluminium assets on the same terms as the alleged 1995 Agreement.  His fourth witness statement set out his evidence on this issue as follows: [476]     "138.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleges that, prior to the Agreement dated 10 February 2000 for the purchase of aluminium assets, he and I had a discussion (during which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was also present), which mentioned a proposal of Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov to acquire interests in these assets.  In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s version, initially I had said that I would have to discuss the proposal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler.  In the end, I allegedly agreed to the proposal, provided however that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would not be mentioned as an interested party.  Then we allegedly agreed that the acquisition of the aluminium assets would be carried out through offshore entities pursuant to Western law and we also agreed that the purchase price was to be paid from the proceeds of Sibneft (Berezovsky 4, paragraphs 256-262).  None of this is true.  Mr. Berezovsky had nothing to do with the deal for acquisition of aluminium assets and so all of the matters we allegedly discussed are a fiction.  I do not recall any such discussions about or with Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov before the negotiations on acquiring the aluminium assets at the beginning of 2000.  So far as my role was concerned, the introduction to buy the assets came only from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  I do recall that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili subsequently mentioned to me Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov claimed a share of his commission but that was not a concern of mine (as I explain further in paragraphs 155 and 158-161 below). 139.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also alleges that he had decided that I was going to manage the aluminium assets, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wanted to do that himself.  In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s version, he preferred Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to focus on ORT (Berezovsky 4, paragraph 261).  As I already stated, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no involvement in the management of the aluminium assets and for this reason he simply could not have expressed any such wishes.  As I recall, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did want the enhanced status of CEO or similar position.  His main role at that time was to represent and look after Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interests in ORT.  However, I had no direct discussion with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on the subject of a management position." Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence on this point was not challenged during the course of his cross-examination.  However since Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon numerous other evidential matters, apart from his own direct evidence, to support his contention that there was an agreement concluded in 1999 in relation to his agreed participation in the acquisition of aluminium assets, and that this supported his prior case as to the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements, it is not appropriate that I should simply rely on the technical point that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account was not directly challenged in cross-examination, and, on that basis, accept the latter\'s evidence.  \r   The third basis - interest in pre-acquisition assets paid for out of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s share of Sibneft profits The third basis put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to support his case that he had an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets was that his interest was paid for from his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s share of Sibneft profits.  I address the evidence relating to this topic below.\r   The evidence relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as supporting his case that he acquired an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets Apart from his own direct evidence of the alleged 1999 Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon a number of evidential matters to support his case that he had acquired an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets pursuant to the alleged 1999 Agreement and consistently with what he alleged had been agreed in 1995 and 1996.  Basically his thesis was that the evidence demonstrated the critical role which he had played in the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets and in putting the deal together.  This, he contended, not merely supported his account of the alleged 1999 Agreement, but more than amply justified his claimed entitlement thereunder.  First of all he sought to suggest that he was the recipient of the initial proposal from Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov in late 1999 and that this proposal had originated as a result of the key contacts which he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had cultivated in the aluminium industry in 1998-1999.  In particular, he suggested that his close links with General Lebed had been critical to the successful acquisition of the Krasnoyarsk assets.  Second, he sought to suggest that it was not only Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, but he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, as well, who was involved in bringing Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and persuading Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to proceed with the transaction.  Third, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed that he had been "the key person who had made this deal happen" and suggested that he had had many meetings with the sellers, in particular Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, at which key aspects of the acquisition had been discussed.  Fourth, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested that the terms of the Master Agreement showed that he was, although not expressly identified as a purchaser under the Master Agreement, in fact such a purchaser.  Fifth, he said that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili also agreed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s request that their interests in the aluminium assets subsequently acquired would not be made visible and would instead be held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, because of the danger of politically motivated attacks.  Sixth, he relied upon what he said were the views of the sellers and purchasers under the Master Agreement which he said demonstrated that they thought he was indeed a purchaser of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  Seventh, he relied upon certain press reports to support his assertion that he was, and that everybody thought he was, a purchaser, of the assets.  Eighth, he relied upon comments made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili prior to his death which he said "consistently acknowledged to third parties that both himself and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had acquired an interest in the aluminium assets in February 2000" [477] .   \r   I analyse this evidence below.  I conclude that, contrary to his contention, it does not establish that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had any interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets.\r   The state of the Russian aluminium industry in the 1990s and the events leading up to the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets In order to evaluate Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s respective cases relating to the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets, and to place the Master Agreement in its proper context, one has to look at the turbulent background to the Russian aluminium industry in 1999-2000.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov (who was one of the sellers of the KrAZ aluminium assets) gave a vivid description in his oral evidence as to what he referred to as "the aluminium wars", during which "unbridled criminality reigned from 1994 to 1997".  He described how these difficult conditions meant that those involved in the aluminium business were subject to threats to their personal safety and how there was routine and unwarranted interference with their commercial interests by various regional authorities.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov gave two examples of the problems which he and his staff at plants in the Krasnoyarsk region faced at the time.  The first example he gave was the threats experienced by his staff, who were, on one occasion, met at the airport by a criminal gang and driven to a cemetery;  there the staff were shown graves and told that, if they continued working in Krasnoyarsk, the same fate would await them.  The second example related to the involvement of law enforcement agencies, who raided the plants and intercepted supplies of raw materials.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov referred to the fact that 70 people had been murdered in Krasnoyarsk and how no one trusted anyone else at the time. [478]     In 1999 Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, whom Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov regarded as a high profile and well-connected individual within Russia at that time.  They became very close friends.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili for his help in alleviating the pressure.  Thereafter, however (and even though Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov understood that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was trying to assist him), the situation did not improve.  By the end of 1999 the aluminium plant at Krasnoyarsk was in a desperate situation, and coupled with concerns about his personal safety, and that of his employees, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov was effectively forced out of business and decided to sell his share of the aluminium assets as quickly as possible.\r   In addition to speaking to his fellow shareholders, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov contacted Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov approach Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov contacted Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and thereafter (according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov) Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili played a leading role in orchestrating the negotiations between the sellers and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich concerning the sale.  He also described how, at the same time, negotiations were also ongoing in parallel with the members of TWG, who were conducting separate, private negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in respect of some of their aluminium assets (known as the "Bratsk assets").  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence as summarised above.\r   A further good description of the background to the Russian aluminium industry (which was not disputed), together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence of the role played by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and the absence of any participation by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (both of which were disputed), is found in extracts from paragraphs 144-154 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s third witness statement, which, because of its importance, I quote in some length:\r   " Background 144.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had absolutely nothing to do with any part of my involvement in the aluminium industry and in particular had nothing to do with either the formation of RusAl or the sale of my interests in it.   145.  \tPrior to 2000, the Russian aluminium industry was disorganised, its assets were split between a number of different owners, and some of the players in the industry resorted to forceful methods and violence to protect their interests.  There had been many reports of killings that reached Moscow (the violence was so intense that back then they used to refer to it as "aluminium wars"), so the state of the industry had become publicly known.  The major aluminium smelting plant in Krasnoyarsk had been virtually starved of resources and was scarcely able to operate;  there were many other problems as well.  In the late 1990s, I did not know much about the aluminium industry, although people around me and myself realised that coupled with my ability for successfully building relationships and meeting others halfway on reasonable terms, my experience working in the oil industry would help me sort out the aluminium industry as well.  I knew well the benefits that could come from, for example, combining production and marketing companies in an efficient way and installing capable management.  There were also safety benefits in bringing under centralised corporate management the assets and cash flows of an individual plant.   To put it simply, local gangsters\' ability to extort money could be undermined in circumstances where local plant managers no longer had the power and control over the cash in the business.  It is much harder to target or intimidate a faceless large corporation than it is a local businessman. 146.  \tBy late 1999 I knew most, if not all, the major players in the aluminium industry, and that a number of them wanted to get out.  Notwithstanding that I could see the potential for bringing the businesses together, I still was not keen to get involved in the industry, given its violent and unstable history.  Criminal groups were fighting fierce battles for control of the profits generated by the aluminium industry and dozens of business men (most famously, Mr.\xc2\xa0Vadis Yafyasov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Oleg Kantor and Mr.\xc2\xa0Felix Lvov) had been killed in this struggle for control.  Whilst the level of violence in the industry had diminished somewhat by the late 1990s, it was still a potentially dangerous business and there was a real need for anyone wishing to get involved in it to have physical  krysha  to ensure control and stability. 147.  \tTowards the end of 1999, I had further approaches about getting involved with this industry.  By this time, it was not unusual for different people to bring me various business ideas and ask me to invest in a particular sector.  Among them were some of those whom had acquired shares in the aluminium businesses during the privatisation period. 148.  \tOne person in particular that promoted the idea of involvement in the aluminium business with considerable force was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  In late 1999 or January 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili proposed that I should buy out the aluminium assets of Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, the Reuben brothers and Mr.\xc2\xa0Vasily Anisimov.  It sounded as if he had been trying to achieve something with some of the owners himself but did not have the ability to get anything off the ground.  I have no idea if he was seeking to do this on his behalf or whether he told any of them that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was involved.  When he approached me, however, it was on the basis that he was prepared to act as an intermediary so that I could acquire the shares.  There was absolutely no discussion or mention of a joint ownership and no mention at all to me of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky being involved. 149.  \tAs I said above, anyone seeking to get involved in this industry needed serious  krysha  (the physical protection).  I realised that, with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s assistance as an intermediary, it might well be possible to acquire these assets at a competitive price and try to replicate some of my oil industry success in the aluminium industry.  I discussed this idea with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and he began negotiating with Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, who became the representative of that group for this purpose, to see what might be possible. Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s role in my acquisition of aluminium assets 150.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili worked with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and myself to try to reach a deal for the acquisition of the assets.  At first, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and I did not discuss expressly what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s remuneration or fee would be for the \'intermediary\' work he would perform.  At that stage it was not clear what could be acquired since there were plenty of minority shareholders divided against each other.  Nor was it clear how much these businesses might cost, considering that the state of the various plants and other assets was unclear due to the difficult financial circumstances and lack of investment in the industry for a number of years.  The industry was in heavy debt to energy suppliers (which meant that the supply of electricity could be cut at any moment, which could cause serious problems since aluminium is produced in a continuous cycle) and also to its employees for back wages.  For example the workers at the Krasnoyarsk plant had not been paid for some time and the plant could easily have come to a permanent halt.  There were many risks and uncertainties at this stage.  Consistent with  krysha  principles, there was initially just an understanding between us that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would work with me and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler to see if a suitable deal could be done, and if he were successful, I would pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili an appropriate fee for his efforts.  This understanding was subsequently confirmed in writing between us (as described further below).  We definitely did not discuss or agree that he would receive a percentage of the ownership of the assets or any shares or any rights to shares.  The essence of our understanding was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would only provide important services to help me acquire the assets. 151.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili indeed performed a vital role in my acquisition of these assets.  He seemed to have a good rapport with two of the owners of the aluminium-related businesses from whom I was proposing to acquire shares, Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov.  I was aware from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, in particular, was eager to get out of the industry as he was tired of the violence and extortion.  At some of the early meetings, I was not full of enthusiasm for this deal, still having concerns about gangster elements that continued to plague the industry.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was very keen that the deal should proceed.  At the negotiation meetings, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not discuss price or other terms;  his physical presence, however, reinforced that I had a strong  krysha  and was someone to be taken very seriously.  I do not remember anyone asking me if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was involved in the purchase of aluminium assets and whether there was any kind of arrangement with him.  I am well aware that many people thought we were close because of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s public association with Sibneft and the fact that it was widely known that I was essentially financing his lifestyle.  It is possible, therefore, that the sellers might have made assumptions but none of them shared those assumptions with me. 152.  \tDuring the negotiations and the period immediately afterwards, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili also played an important role in resolving problems on the ground in the Krasnoyarsk region.  The aluminium plants were located in what were regarded as comparatively lawless regions and various criminal groups still had a strong local influence.  At my request, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili went to the Krasnoyarsk region to gather support for a move to consolidate the business of KrAZ where he talked to General Alexander Lebed, the then Governor of the Krasnoyarsk region, who was one of the most powerful and influential figures in the region where the aluminium enterprises were located.  It was important that General Lebed did not oppose our purchase of KrAZ since it would have been extremely difficult to establish and maintain control of the assets we purchased without local political support. 153.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili put out various other \'fires\' that arose from time to time during the process of consolidating control over the aluminium assets I purchased.  (Once I had merged my interests with those of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, however, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s  krysha  soon became less important, as I explain further in paragraphs 177-180 below). 154.  \tI recall that I personally met with Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Yury Schleifstein (a shareholder in the BrAZ who initially refused to sell).  However, it was mainly Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler who handled the negotiations on my behalf.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s contribution was critical and I would not have attempted this transaction without his involvement on my side.  He did not, however, engage in or negotiate the business side of the deal.  It simply was not part of what I needed him for.  I certainly took every opportunity to emphasise to everyone that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and I were on the same team, and it was therefore important for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to sign the 10 February agreement (\' 10 February Agreement \') together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and me (see the SPA of 10 February 2000).   Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not an actual owner or shareholder of any kind in the business (and nor was Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler who also signed the agreement). Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich also explained in cross-examination how disputes in "the aluminium wars" had involved a confrontation between TWG on the one hand and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska on the other, mainly relating to the Krasnoyarsk smelter;  in this context Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had offered to help Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, who, in return for his help, had made a loan to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and provided some funding for ORT;  sometime thereafter, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had supported TWG against Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, and, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had not repaid his loan, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska became extremely angry, because he considered that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were playing a duplicitous game to "cheat him".  I do not need to make findings about these matters, but Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s dislike of both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s appreciation of that dislike, becomes relevant at the time of the Dorchester Hotel meeting.\r   The initial proposal from Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov in late 1999 Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence in his witness statement was that he was approached by the manager of TWG, Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov, who proposed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s "group" purchase interests in the pre-merger aluminium assets.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to characterise Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s approach as a critical factor in the initiation of the negotiations for the sale of the aluminium assets, which would not have occurred, had it not been for his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s previously acquired contacts in the region.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov gave a witness statement on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich although, in the event, he was unwilling to attend the trial.  His statement was served in order to deal with a specific disclosure issue raised by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky which, as matters transpired, did not arise for consideration at trial.  In paragraph 8 of that statement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov said that, at a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in March 2011, he told Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that he was going to file a claim against Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in relation to the commission due to him, as a result of an agreement which he had reached with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in respect of his (Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s) involvement in the negotiations for the sale of TWG\'s, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s and other shareholders\' KrAZ and Bratsk aluminium assets.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended that the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov claimed to be entitled to the payment of the commission from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky showed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov at least understood Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to be involved as a principal in the aluminium acquisition deal.  \r   However, in my judgment, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky can derive only slender assistance from such a statement;  the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov may have thought that he was entitled to sue Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in respect of an agreement which he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov, had with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili does not, even if proved, establish that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (or even Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili) was a buyer of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  The reference in paragraph 13 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s statement to a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in April 2011, where Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov apparently reminded Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that the promise that he would receive money for his role in setting up the aluminium deal had been confirmed at a meeting at Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s office, likewise took the matter no further.  Thus the statement did not suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s agreement was with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  the most that it suggested was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov may have thought that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were partners in the venture.\r   During the course of cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky developed his evidence to contend that he was the "key person" who made the sale of the aluminium assets happen, because he was the person to whom the idea of the sale was initially brought:\r   "I was the key person and it\'s clear why:  because the initial point was people came to me asking -- proposing to sell.  If they will not come to me, it means that it\'s no deal at all in the beginning.  It\'s in completion, I mean in negotiation later on how to structurise, how to -- and so-so, definitely Badri and Roman, they play amazing role in that.  But as far as their generation of -- not generation -- as far as the beginning of everything, without being impossible to move forward, definitely I was the key person and everybody understood that. [479] \xc2\x85 But again, if you ask me why I think that I\'m key person, it\'s not because I talk with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or with Mr.\xc2\xa0Badri.  It\'s not so.  I key person just because people who propose that, they propose it to me;  not even to Badri, I would like to say.  Because they understood that we -- they did not maybe believe so much like we believe that we\'ll create political stability in Russia,  we\'ll win elections" [480] This statement was inconsistent with his earlier witness statement that "it was Badri who was the deal-maker" and who led the negotiations, and inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s oral evidence given earlier the same day that by the time he (Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) allegedly mentioned Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s approach to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had already been approached by Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and discussions were already underway.  \r   Even on the assumption that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov brought a proposal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleges, the role of the Bosov proposal in the initiation of the sale of the aluminium assets was of limited importance.  I do not regard it as supporting his claim to an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets.  The evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, which I accept, was that by late 1999 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich already knew many of the major players in the aluminium industry and had been approached by a number of people about becoming involved in it [481] .  One of those persons who approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who proposed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should buy out the aluminium assets of the leading players in the industry, TWG (led by Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, the Reuben brothers and managed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov) and Mr.\xc2\xa0Vasily Anisimov.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov also described in his evidence how, at Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s suggestion, he had got in touch with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to discuss the possibility of a sale of his aluminium interests.   Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili offered to act as an intermediary.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or agree anything with him.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not involved at all.  Thereafter, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili worked with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler on a plan for acquiring the assets.  It may well be, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov was instrumental in securing the sale of the Bratsk assets as part of the overall deal, but he was certainly not the principal introducer so far as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was concerned.  That was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s third witness statement also provided an instructive account of the background to, and origin of the negotiations, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s role.  I accept his evidence.\r   "Aluminium Assets Acquisition 151.  \tIn contrast to the Russian oil industry at the time, the Russian aluminium industry in the mid- to late-1990s was still extremely fragmented.  It resembled an organised crime racket, with in-fighting and interventions by local officials.  The management of the aluminium assets was concentrated locally which meant that the managers in the plants and factories had control of cash but were in turn vulnerable to having that cash taken from them by force.  The conditions were favourable for gangster style crime to flourish.  It is reported that the so-called "Aluminium Wars" of the late 1990s claimed over 100 lives.  This might sound like journalist exaggeration but there genuinely was a lot of danger associated with this industry.  The amounts of money involved were substantial.  Eventually the killing spread to the streets of Moscow and therefore became a matter of greater public awareness.   152.  \tI recall that towards the end of 1999, Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney approached us several times directly to see if we might be interested in getting involved in the industry (we were not).  I then heard from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney had also approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wanting to make some kind of a deal with respect to several aluminium entities located in Russia because of a squeeze by other competitors in the market.  The plants Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney had an interest in were being starved of raw materials.  There was a particular problem at Krasnoyarsk in the latter part of 1999;  the company was on the verge of bankruptcy and about to stop production.  I believe that Mr.\xc2\xa0Vasiliy Anisimov also approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  It seemed that they all felt that they were in danger of losing their assets altogether and wanted someone to buy them first, while they still had something of value to sell. 153.  \tI believe that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili then approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to see if he would be interested in buying the aluminium assets of Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, the Reuben brothers and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was initially reluctant to get involved with the aluminium industry at all, but he and I discussed it at some length.  We thought that, as we had directly experienced in the oil industry, there was scope in the aluminium industry for vertical integration in order to achieve greater efficiency and thereby extract the full value from the enterprises.  However, the risk was huge - both that the assets would turn out to be worthless and that we too would be victims of gangsterism. 154.  \tIn terms of addressing the gangsterism element, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s role was critical.  He had been in discussions with people in the industry for a while.  He knew the main players and they knew him.  We all believed that he was uniquely placed to provide enough protection ( krysha ) given his reputation in the market at that time.  Based on my discussions with him at the time, I do not believe that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have gone into the aluminium industry at all without Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s protection.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in turn wanted to be seen as having had an important role but he also knew that without Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, there was no deal.  At the time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was one of the few people prepared to pay for shares in these aluminium assets and who people trusted to \'play it straight\' and do things properly. 155.  \tAfter serious internal discussions, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich decided to go ahead with negotiations which I undertook on his behalf.  I negotiated mainly with Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney (he was acting on his own behalf and on behalf of the Reuben brothers) and also Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov - one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney\'s associates - was sometimes at the meetings.  \xc2\x85" Nor am I persuaded that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s previous contacts with General Lebed, the provincial governor, were in any way contributory to, or significant in, the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  I am also sceptical that a single visit by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to Krasnoyarsk during the course of 1999 would have resulted in what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky described as the cultivation of "key contacts in the Russian aluminium sector".  I accept that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky may well have had contacts in the aluminium industry - but in my judgment the key contacts are likely to have been those between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and businessmen in the aluminium sector.  \r   On his own evidence Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s meetings with General Lebed had had nothing to do with the sale of the aluminium assets.  According to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky:-\r   i)\the had close connections with General Lebed and had supported him in his election campaign for the position of Governor of the Krasnoyarsk region in 1998;  and  ii)\the had met with General Lebed early in 1999 to mediate ongoing aluminium disputes in the region. However, whilst I accept that evidence, it was not Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he spoke to (or otherwise influenced) General Lebed in relation to the sale of the aluminium assets, whether in late 1999, when negotiations were ongoing, or at all.  There was no evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been instrumental in late 1999 in securing General Lebed\'s support for the deal.  According to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili who travelled to Krasnoyarsk to secure General Lebed\'s support.  Moreover although General Lebed\'s co-operation was very important in order to ensure that operations at the plants ran smoothly at the local level, his authorisation was not necessary for the sale itself.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had himself described in his third witness statement, it was important that General Lebed did not oppose the purchase of the KrAZ assets, .since it would have been extremely difficult to establish and maintain control of those assets without local political support.   In cross-examination, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described the situation as follows :\r   "General Lebed had nothing to do with the acquisition of assets and who acquired them and he actually did not say whether he was for or against that;  that\'s not part of his authority.  It\'s difficult for you to -- for me to explain, but local authorities had nothing to do with share acquisition process.  However, the situation prevailing, prevailing with the workforce, with the trade unions, when everybody came out into the streets and started protesting, that really was very relevant to the local authority and he was very keen for this matter to be resolved" Evidence to similar effect was given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Mark Buzuk, an adviser to Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, who represented the KrAZ sellers in the negotiation of the sale of the pre-merger aluminium assets in 2000.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk\'s evidence in this respect.  \r   Moreover, in a press interview given on 23 February 2000 General Lebed was reported in the following terms:  \r   "In conclusion, the governor refuted the information that Boris Berezovsky is going to buy some of the shares of the Krasnoyarsk companies.  \'In this transaction Boris Berezovsky is a middleman.  The main purchaser is Roman Abramovich\', Alexander Lebed declared." Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought, in this context and also in order to explain his absence as a designated party to the Master Agreement, to suggest that his political position required him to be discreet about his interest, which was why he was not referred to as a purchaser by General Lebed, and why he was not expressly named as a party in any of the acquisition documentation.  He also attempted to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had requested that his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interest in the aluminium assets should "not be made visible" because of his political position.  But the reasons which he put forward to support these assertions I found specious.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself acknowledged, he was almost at the height of his political power and influence in late 1999; [482]  Mr.\xc2\xa0Putin\'s election victory in March 2000 was generally regarded as inevitable, as Professor Fortescue, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own expert (and, indeed, on occasions Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself) described.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s protestations about "invisibility" were also belied by an interview which he gave to  Vedomosti  in March 2000 when he publicly suggested that he was involved in the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  Although Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky attempted to suggest that President Putin\'s election had made all the difference to his ability publicly to associate himself with the acquisition, there was no satisfactory evidential basis for that assertion.\r   On the evidence, therefore, I find that, even if Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov had initially brought a proposal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, rather than to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, its role in the initiation of the sale negotiations for the KrAZ assets was minimal.  It did not support or justify Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim to an entitlement to a share in the pre-merger aluminium assets.\r   The presentation of Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence was that it was not just Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, but also he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, who was involved in bringing Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and persuading Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to proceed with the transaction.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence on the other hand was very clear that it was just Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili who brought the proposal to him and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had nothing to do with the acquisition.\r   It was suggested in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions [483]  that it was not necessary for the court to resolve what was referred to as:\r   "\xc2\x85 a tangential dispute about whether or not Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was present at the meeting when the Bosov proposal was originally raised with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich"; that the additional evidence relied upon, and the presence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at the Dorchester Hotel meeting, made it clear that he was involved with the proposal.  It was further submitted that, nonetheless: "\xc2\x85 given the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili tended to operate in partnership in all the other business transactions they engaged in (LogoVAZ;  ORT;  Sibneft), and the fact that both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been involved the previous year in Krasnoyarsk, the strong likelihood is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was also involved in the original proposal alongside Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili." But the weakness of this submission was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, supported by that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no involvement whatsoever in the discussions between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in relation to the proposal for the acquisition of the KrAZ and Bratsk assets, or in relation to the implementation of such proposal.  Whether or not there was any sort of bilateral partnership between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in relation to the aluminium assets is not a matter which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky is entitled to raise as against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in this action.  Accordingly I make no finding in relation to any such bilateral partnership allegation.\r   But for the purposes of the Commercial Court action and the Overlap Issues, I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky played no part in presenting Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov\'s proposals to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or in the subsequent discussions about the transaction as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler on the one hand and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on the other.\r   I accept their evidence that, by late 1999:\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich already knew many of the major players in the aluminium industry and had been approached by a number of people about becoming involved in it; ii)\tthat one of those who approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who proposed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should buy out the aluminium assets of the leading players in the industry, the Transworld Group (led by Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, the Reuben brothers and managed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov) and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov;   iii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili offered to act as an intermediary;   iv)\tthat, prior to the making of the Master Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not agree anything with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in relation to the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets;   v)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not involved in discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler in connection with the proposed acquisition;  and  vi)\tthat, thereafter, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili alone, worked with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler on a plan for acquiring the assets. That evidence was also supported by the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov to which I have already referred above. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that he had been "the key person who had made this deal happen" and had been involved in discussions with the sellers During the course of the trial, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky not only claimed that he had been "the key person who had made this deal happen", but also suggested that he had had significant dealings and numerous informal meetings with the sellers, in particular Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, Mr.\xc2\xa0David Reuben and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, at which key aspects of the acquisition had been discussed.  He claimed that it was important to the sellers of both the Bratsk and the KrAZ assets that he was not only involved, but also seen to be involved.  In cross-examination he put it as follows:\r   "A.  \xc2\x85 people want to see me that I\'m really real, I\'m sorry to say that, and this was - definitely they want to understand that it\'s really me who is part of this deal.  I think particularly it was important for David Reuben because he was foreigner, he was not so hard involved in that.  But on the other  hand, as I told you, that time I had good relations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and who else who I mentioned." [484] A strange feature of this allegation was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had not previously suggested, prior to the start of the trial, that he had had any meetings with the sellers of the aluminium assets during the course of the negotiations for their sale.  On the contrary, the picture he had painted was that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili who was the deal-maker with regard to the purchase of the KrAZ and Bratsk assets and who had been involved in "extensive discussions" with the sellers and that he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, had not been involved in the detailed discussions leading up to the purchase [485] .  The new allegation was also inconsistent with his pleadings in the Metalloinvest action where, despite having had every opportunity to advance such a case, he admitted in paragraph 10 of his Reply to the Defence of the Anisimov defendants:\r   "(1) \t...   (a) \tIt is admitted, subject to paragraph 9(1) of this Reply, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not participate in the negotiations in person.  As set out above, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had conduct of the negotiations on behalf of the purchasers;". Similarly, no assertion of meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov or with the other vendors of the KrAZ or Bratsk assets was made in any of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s replies to requests for further information as to his allegation that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov knew that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was the purchaser of the aluminium assets.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was unable to give any kind of satisfactory explanation for the inconsistency between his new assertion at trial that he had been heavily involved in meetings, and his previous statements in his witness statement and pleadings that he had not been so involved.  The Anisimov Defendants\' pleaded case (that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not present at any "\xc2\x85 meetings at which the sale of the KrAZ Assets was discussed") was put to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in cross-examination.  His response was that this was "absolutely not true" as "definitely [he] had a lot of meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov"  [486] .  His attempt at an explanation came down to:\r   i)\tabrogating any responsibility for his pleadings, by blaming his lawyer, Mr.\xc2\xa0Marino, for failing to understand him;  and  ii)\tsuggesting that in his previous statements and pleadings in the Metalloinvest action he had been using the word "meetings" in a special sense, as only referring to formal meetings with an agenda and written minutes.  I did not find Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s attempt to reconcile these inconsistencies impressive.   But apart from the inconsistencies of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum and the sellers, or other parties involved in the negotiations, namely Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky (who were assisting and representing Mr.\xc2\xa0Animisov), and Mr.\xc2\xa0David Reuben gave evidence at trial which directly contradicted Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence that he had been involved in the negotiations or participated in meetings in relation to the proposed sale of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  \r   Thus Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained in his third witness statement:\r   "158.  \tAs for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, he had no role at all in the above process.  I never discussed anything relating to the acquisition of the Aluminium Assets with him, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky certainly did not originate the proposal to acquire these assets.  If there was any agreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili relating to the Aluminium Assets, this was not something I knew about." To similar effect was Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s account in his third witness statement: "159.  \tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, however, was never in the picture.  He had no involvement in the acquisition of any of the aluminium interests of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, nor was there any agreement that he would acquire any such assets either jointly, or at all, nor that anything was owed to him in respect of the role played by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili." Likewise Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum also attended some parts of certain meetings between Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney and Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s unchallenged evidence was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not present at any of these meetings.  He said that he had never seen or heard anything which would have supported the assertion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky played any part in the acquisition of aluminium shares or aluminium assets in 1999 and 2000.  Similar evidence was given by Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, who was part of the working party set up by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to assist with the deal;  she gave evidence that she did not believe Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to have had any interest in it.\r    Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov likewise said that he had:\r   "\xc2\x85 never seen or heard him [Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky] to take part in any negotiations, he was never at any meetings, and these things were never discussed" [487] . Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov was not in fact challenged on this statement in cross-examination.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk said that he had never spoken with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky about the sale of the KrAZ assets;  that, as far as he was aware, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not involved in the sale of the KrAZ assets;  that his name was not mentioned at any time during the sale process and that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, nor anyone who presented themselves as his representative, was present either at any of the meetings regarding the sale or during the preparation of the sale documentation [488] .   Although both Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk confirmed in cross-examination that they did not attend all meetings, and, in particular that they were not present at the meetings relating to the negotiations for the sale of the Bratsk assets, there was no evidence (apart from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s vague assertions that he had had meetings with the sellers) to show that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had attended any meetings with the sellers of the Bratsk assets, such as Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Chernoy.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky, who also worked for Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and acted on his behalf in the negotiations, likewise said that, so far as he was aware, neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, nor any person claiming to represent Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, was involved in the purchase of the KrAZ assets.  It was suggested on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf that several of these witnesses had a motive for concealing his true involvement in the deal.  However, irrespective of the position of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, his staff and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, it is difficult to see why Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinksy or Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk would have had the slightest interest in telling lies on the point;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk ceased to be employed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s companies in 2002;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky stopped working for Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov in 2009 and ceased to be a director of any of his companies earlier this year.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0David Reuben gave evidence on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky under a witness summons;  he provided no witness statement.  But Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben\'s evidence did not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been involved in the negotiations or had been present at any meetings, and contradicted his assertion that it was important to the prospective sellers that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky should be seen to be involved [489] .  As was pointed out in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions, Mr.\xc2\xa0David Reuben is a billionaire in his own right and had no obvious axe to grind against any participant in the present litigation.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben explained that it was the other sellers (Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov), and not he, who had carried out the principal discussions and negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in relation to the sale of the pre-merger aluminium assets;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben had been in discussions with another group of potential purchasers.  However he had met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on a flight to Moscow, a few months before the Master Agreement was concluded;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov was also on the flight and he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were discussing the proposed sale.  From time to time Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would translate for Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben.  In the course of this conversation, Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben asked whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was behind Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the transaction;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili  denied  this suggestion, and said effectively that he was going to do the deal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not involved, "they" were  not going to do the deal at all.  When specifically asked the question by Mr.\xc2\xa0Gillis QC, counsel on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, whether, in his conversations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about who the purchasers were,  any mention had been made of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben replied "no, just -- and even if it is, I can\'t remember."  Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben made no mention in his evidence of any meetings with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky prior to the signing of the Master Agreement, at which the proposed sale of the aluminium assets was referred to or discussed.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben had apparently met Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky before the contract was concluded, but he did not suggest that this had been in connection with the transaction.  He had met Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky once, on a subsequent occasion, after the deal had been concluded, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been quoted in the press as involved in the deal.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben congratulated Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky on "a good buy".  But Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben could not recall whether the meeting had been in London or in Moscow, saying:\r   "But I can\'t recall because this is very significant to you in this case;  to me its just another man that I met.  It\'s not something that I would remember or was not of any importance to me."  I accept the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk that no such informal meetings as alleged by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky took place.  Their account was supported by the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s new "recollections" of these "informal meetings" were also inconsistent with statements he made to  Vedomosti  in March 2000, in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that he was out of Russia during the period in which the sale was agreed.  In cross-examination Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky dismissed this as (yet another) example of a "hypocritical answer" that he had given to the media, but which was not true.\r   Accordingly, I cannot accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that he had had significant dealings and numerous informal meetings with the sellers of the Bratsk and KrAZ assets.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that the terms of the Master Agreement showed that, although he was not expressly identified as a purchaser under the Master Agreement, he was in fact a purchaser Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asserted that the Master Agreement was inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that he was the sole purchaser of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had two arguments under this head to demonstrate that he was an undisclosed party to the Master Agreement:  first, he claimed that the description of Party 1 made it clear that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was a buyer of the aluminium assets and that, accordingly, it should be inferred that he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, was also a buyer;  second, he claimed that, irrespective of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s designation as a buyer, the Master Agreement defined the Party 1 purchasers, not just as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, but also as including the four Offshore Companies which they represented, and which actually became the legal owners of the aluminium assets;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asserted that he had an interest in these companies - and therefore was in fact present, within the definition of Party 1 purchasers.  \r   Apart from the fact that he was not identified in the Master Agreement as a purchaser, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky faced a number of problems about his claim that he was in reality a party to the Master Agreement.  Despite his claim to have been the key person responsible for bringing them about, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky acknowledged that he never saw the Master Agreement, or the ten subsidiary asset sale agreements by which the aluminium assets were acquired, prior to the current proceedings.  He was unable to recall what was discussed at the meetings which he claimed to have had with Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov or Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben or any one else, and, as he accepted, was not involved in the negotiation of the documents.  He had no idea what company or entity had owned the KraZ assets.  He only the vaguest idea of the terms of the deal and could not remember key details, such as the price paid for the assets.  Nor could he identify what obligations he assumed under the Master Agreement.  He had no idea what interests were acquired pursuant to the relevant agreements, how those interests were structured, what the nature of his alleged interest or right to those interests was, nor could he identify how his claimed interest in the aluminium assets was held.\r   But even leaving these issues aside, I cannot accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s arguments, deployed extensively in his oral and written closing submissions, that he was, or should be treated as, a buyer of the Bratsk and KrAZ assets, either because of the inclusion of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the designation of Party 1, or because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had "an interest" in the four Offshore Companies.  The evidence did not establish either proposition.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that he had interest based on the capacity in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili signed the Master Agreement Irrespective of whether the Master Agreement had, or was intended to have legal effect, the evidence showed that it was hastily made by non-lawyers and was clearly a preliminary agreement.  The interests of the sellers in the various shares and businesses were only roughly defined in the recitals to the agreement.  The transfer itself was effected by the underlying share purchase agreements between the selling and purchasing companies.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov described it as "like a protocol of intent, that people would like to sell their assets, nothing more than that." The signatories were the people who had negotiated it (or served as the "enabler" in the case of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili) and who were present at its conclusion.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence was that if any of them had failed to sign the document, it would have been "bad" and given a signal to their counterparties that they were not committed to the deal. [490]  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence confirmed this.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence, which I accept (despite the extensive critique contained in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions), described the respective roles of Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and the respective capacities in which they were signing.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described how all three men were:\r   "part of party 1 and each played our own specific role.   As a group we were party number 1, but that doesn\'t mean that as a group we\'re all acquiring the assets."  Both he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler explained that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were acquiring any interest in the pre-aluminium assets.\r   In cross-examination Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested to Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler that he had signed the agreement as a principal, and had acquired an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets.  The surprising aspect of this allegation (apart from the fact that had never previously been raised by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in his pleadings or evidence) was that it was wholly inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that the pre-merger aluminium assets were acquired on the same basis as the alleged 1995 Agreement, to which he had never suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler was a party.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler rejected that suggestion and explained that his name was there because he was a "representative" of the side that purchased the assets and had been the principal negotiator of the deal, and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler all "represented the purchasing side".   But, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler pointed out, neither he, nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, had paid anything for the assets or had taken any personal risks by becoming the owners of the assets.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained in both his witness statements and in his oral evidence how Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s affiliation to the deal brought with it protection;  he described the essential role which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had played in the transaction and how his physical presence "reinforced that I had a strong  krysha  and was someone to be taken very seriously." Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili knew Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov well, and had an intimidatory reputation which was important in an industry rife with violence.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said:\r   "Without Badri, I would not have poked my nose in there.  Every three days somebody was murdered in that business"  [491] .    It was also clear from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s assistance and protection, i.e.   krysha,  was going to be needed in the future, even once the business had been acquired.\r   I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence that, despite the critical importance of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s role in the transaction, he was only an intermediary and facilitator, and not a co-purchaser of any of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  \r   In particular, I accept that their account was supported by four Protocol agreements purportedly dated 3 February 2000 (but in fact signed later in February 2000) ("the Commission Agreements") made between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (stated to have been acting for and behalf of a service company whom he represented, defined as "the Intermediary") and the Offshore Companies acquiring the pre-merger aluminium assets.  I arrive at this conclusion notwithstanding some of the bogus features of the Commission Agreements.  \r   These agreements provided for the payment of a fee totalling $115 million to a service company represented by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, in respect of, effectively, his role as facilitator and intermediary in the sale of the Bratsk and KrAZ assets to the Offshore Companies.  The Commission Agreements were backdated and thus purported to speak prospectively about a transaction, namely the acquisition, which had in fact already happened at the time the documents were drafted - a point that had always been accepted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  They also contained provisions, such as clause 5 [492] , which were clearly fictitious in the sense that, at the time the agreement was drawn up, the final share price had been fixed and the Intermediary was therefore never at any risk of having to make an indemnifying payment.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that, after the Master Agreement had been signed, probably on 15 February, 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had made it clear that he wanted formally to document his entitlement to a fee;  he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had a meeting in the latter\'s office at which they agreed the figure;  and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich called Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko in and asked her to draft and process the relevant documents.  The Commission Agreements were then prepared by Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, who satisfactorily explained how she had been able to reconstruct the date on which she had prepared them - 15 February  2000.  She also explained that there was a need, so as to "justify a bank transfer on that commission agreement" for the Commission Agreements to demonstrate what was a genuine commercial transaction, which is why she and her subordinate, Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk, drafted the agreements in a way which they did, so as to achieve the objective that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could indeed be paid, into a Western bank account, the commission which was due to him.  However, the fact that the Commission Agreements contained certain bogus provisions to convey to a bank that they genuinely reflected commercial transactions, did not mean that they did not do so, even if they were backdated.  In my judgment, on a full analysis of the evidence, the Commission  Agreements accurately recorded the nature of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s role as an intermediary and the bogus features did not establish, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested that they did, that the Commission Agreements were mis-stating the position when they provided that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (or his service companies) were entitled to be paid $115 million by way of commission in respect of his services in connection with the acquisition.\r   It was common ground that the fee of $115 million was not paid.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence, which I accept, was that, with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s consent, he did not pay the fee because they both agreed shortly afterwards that they should wait and see how the aluminium venture developed and then reassess the fee;  there was still a risk that something could go wrong, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich believed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili probably thought (correctly as it turned out) that he might be able to do a lot better than $l15 million later if the business turned out to be successful.  I deal with the evidence relating to the actual fee paid to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili below.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili presented the signed versions of the Commission Agreements to a notary in Moscow on 16 March 2000 to have them formally notarised.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence was that he believed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili may have had the protocols notarised shortly after the meeting at the Dorchester Hotel on 13 March 2000, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili distrusted Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and was concerned that, as and when Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska became a co-controller of the Offshore Companies, as a result of the proposed RusAl merger, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich might be squeezed out.  It was clear from Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s own evidence and that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that there was no love lost as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had, apparently, taken a dim view of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s conduct in the so-called aluminium wars, because of the latter\'s support of the TWG group.  It is also likely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have wanted to ensure that, if payment of his commission was indeed going to be deferred, as he had agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, there was nonetheless an unimpeachable record of what had been agreed under the terms of the Commission Agreements, so that, if, and when, he returned to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to renegotiate the $115 million, there was no question but that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would receive that minimum sum.
