But if Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in such circumstances had genuinely believed that he, or he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, were contractually entitled to a 50% share in the pre-merger aluminium assets, or, more to the point, a 50% participation interest in the shares of the Offshore Companies, which by then had acquired the assets, it appears highly unlikely that he would have taken steps formally to notarise a document which did not correctly record his actual (and, by 16 March 2000, because of the merger with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s interests, potentially far more valuable) share participation entitlement, but which, on the contrary, incorrectly recorded a capped fee entitlement.  Moreover, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was on good terms with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at the time, and it is likewise difficult to see why, if indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a share participation entitlement, he would have not asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for some document recording that interest, however informal such a document had to be.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s explanation for the Commission Agreements, as it emerged during the course of the trial, was to suggest that they were shams, produced for the purposes of being shown to a Western bank, Kathrein & Co, so that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could open an account into which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would be making payments for the acquisition of an aircraft which, at the Dorchester Hotel meeting in March 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili should receive by way of commission;  therefore, it was said, the Commission Agreements could not be prayed in aid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to support the role played by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in connection with the position of the pre-merger aluminium assets as merely an intermediary, as opposed to someone, who together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, had a 50% participation interest in the shares in the Offshore Companies.  Thus Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in cross-examination that the Commission Agreements were produced:\r   "\xc2\x85 only after the Dorchester Hotel meeting and \xc2\x85 knowing that that they were false agreements and that they were never intended by either side to have any legal effect at all". Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich rejected that suggestion.  His evidence was that the agreement to provide Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili with an aeroplane was only made at the Dorchester Hotel meeting in March 2000, a month or so after the Commission Agreements had been concluded on about 15 February 2000.  His evidence was supported by Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko\'s evidence, both of which I accept.    Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions contained an extensive analysis [493]  of the evidence in an attempt to support his contention, which I have fully considered, although I do not rehearse it here.  The documents that have survived in relation to the aircraft purchase show that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich contributed $25 million to the cost of the purchase of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s plane, which was eventually bought in June/July 2000 for $23.5 million and also contributed substantial sums to the cost of its maintenance and operating costs.   As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained "$115 million could buy you four planes, I think".  He also explained that the deal in relation to the aeroplane was in addition to the commission which he had agreed to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of $115 million.   Having reviewed the evidence relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, I reject his assertion that the Commission Agreements did not accurately reflect Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s entitlement to commission in respect of his services in connection with the  pre-merger aluminium assets.  The evidence upon which he relied to support the suggestion that the Commission Agreements were drawn up "simply in order to allow Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to open an Austrian bank account with Kathrein & Co and to receive money then used to purchase, fit out and maintain his aeroplane" and that, accordingly, the Commission Agreements were shams, was tenuous in the extreme.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Adkin, counsel for the Family defendants, realistically pointed out in the Family defendants\' written closing submissions, if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili required some form of documented basis for receiving money into the West, the simplest solution would have been to document his alleged interest in the aluminium business, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili acquired;  that could have been easily achieved, for example, by granting and documenting a participation interest, whether directly or under a trust, in 50% of the shares in the four Offshore Companies.  No reason was put forward as to why such a simple course was not adopted, if indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case were correct;  even if "visibility" had been a concern, which I doubt, offshore structures could easily have concealed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interest in shares in the Offshore Companies.\r   Accordingly I conclude that, despite his inclusion in the description of Party 1, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not a buyer of the Bratsk and KrAZ assets and had no interest in such assets.  He was a facilitator and intermediary for whose services in connection with the acquisition Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to pay a fee.\r   Moreover, even if, contrary to my conclusion, the premise were correct, it would not follow that it should be inferred that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was also acquiring an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets as it were, as a co-owner with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, pursuant to an agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  There was no evidence to support such a conclusion.  Again, I make it clear that I am not deciding whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had a bilateral partnership agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that would have justified such a claim, had I found that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili indeed acquired an ownership interest in the Bratsk and KrAZ assets pursuant to the Master Agreement.  The existence of such a bilateral partnership agreement is a matter for determination in the Chancery proceedings.\r   The second limb of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument - that it should be inferred from the description of Party 1 in the Master Agreement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was also acquiring an interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument under this head, as formulated in paragraph 1114 of his written closing submissions was that:\r   "\xc2\x85 although he [Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky] was not expressly identified as one of the purchasers on the face of the 10 February 2000 Master Agreement, the definition of Party 1 was carefully not limited to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, but extended to and included the 4 offshore companies which they purported to represent (namely Runicom Fort, Galinton, Dilcor, and Palmtex).  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case is that  he was one of the owners of those 4 offshore companies , and therefore also one of the purchasers. 519 519\t\t See Answer 27 of the Response to Part 18 Request for Further Information dated 24 March 2011."  [Emphasis supplied]   Request 27 and Answer 27 were in the following terms:  \r   "27.  \tIn relation to any such assets that it is alleged were \'beneficially owned\' by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky please identify under which law and by virtue of what rights such beneficial ownership interests are alleged to have arisen." "27.  \tThe system of law most closely connected to the acquisition of the aluminium assets was English law (as the law expressly chosen in all the purchase contracts entered into by the Offshore Companies).  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s rights or interests in the Offshore Companies arose (under Russian and/or English law): (1) \tPursuant to the 1995 Agreement; \xc2\x85 (3) \tBy reason of the fact that payment for these assets came from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s share of profits derived from their interest in Sibneft.   Those rights or interests in the Offshore Companies are evidenced in writing by (i) the fact that pursuant to the Share Purchase and Sale Agreement dated 15th March 2000, and the Amended and Restated Share Purchase and Sale Agreement dated 15th May 2000, in each case between Runicom Limited and GSA (Cyprus) Limited and in each case governed by English law, Runicom Limited represented that others apart from Runicom Limited (described variously as the Other Selling Shareholders" and the "P1 Shareholders") were legally and/or beneficially interested in the Offshore Companies;  and/or (ii) the fact that the 10 February 2000 agreement by which the aluminium assets were acquired identifies Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (along with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler) as one of the purchasers of the assets." Thus Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s pleaded claim to support the contention that "he was one of  the owners  of those four offshore  companies ", as set out in Answer 27 above, appeared to be wholly reliant upon:\r   i)\tthe assertion that payment for the pre-merger aluminium assets had derived from Sibneft profits (an allegation that was subsequently withdrawn, in the light of the clear evidence that the acquisition had been financed by a bank loan and funds from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies, and subsequently recouped out of the proceeds of an equalisation payment made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska at the time of the merger);   ii)\tthe inclusion of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the description of "Party 1" in the Master Agreement (an argument which I have held fails);  and  iii)\tthe terms of the subsequent Share Purchase and Sale Agreement dated 15 March 2000, and the Amended and Restated Share Purchase and Sale Agreement of 15 May 2000, to which I refer later in this judgment. But none of these provided any evidentiary basis for ownership of an interest in the Offshore Companies;  the argument at i), if factually supported, at most could have provided a claim against the relevant company as a beneficiary under a resulting or constructive trust of the acquired aluminium assets;  and it was difficult to see how the assertions at ii) and iii), even if well founded, which I hold they were not, supported some sort of beneficial interest held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in the Offshore Companies.   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself, as I have already described, was not able to give any evidence as to how his alleged interests in the Offshore Companies were held, arose or were structured.  His claim as formulated in Answer 27, quoted above, was inherently circular and vague.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk gave evidence in their witness statements to the effect that the Offshore Companies were offshore companies of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and were not challenged on this aspect.  For example, it was not suggested to either of them that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told them, or that there was any other basis upon which they should have known, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had some sort of beneficial interest in the shares in the Offshore Companies.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was cross-examined on the basis that the Offshore Companies (for example, Palmtex) were his companies, but it was not suggested to him either that he had ever told Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that he, or anyone else, was holding 50% of shares in the Offshore Companies for their benefit, or that he had any obligation to do so.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum gave evidence that the shares in the Offshore Companies were bearer shares, and, although he was cross-examined about the terms of the subsequent Share Purchase and Sale Agreement dated 15 March 2000, and the Amended and Restated Share Purchase and Sale Agreement of 15 May 2000, it was not suggested to him that any of those bearer shares were held, or should have been held, by, or on trust for, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or that he knew that they were, or should have been, so held.  At page 37 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s First Schedule, with reference to 407 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions, the statement is made that:  \r   "The Master Contract defined the Party 1 purchasers, not just as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili - but also the 4 offshore companies which they represented, and which actually became the legal owners of the aluminium assets.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky has always asserted that he had an interest in these companies - and therefore was in fact present, within the definition of Party 1 purchasers.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich has not been able to refute that, by showing that the 4 offshore companies belonged solely to him." But the onus was not on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to refute Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion that the latter "\xc2\x85 was one of the owners of those 4 offshore companies, and therefore also one of the purchasers" of the pre-merger aluminium assets [494] ;  the onus was on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to establish that he was such an owner whether legally, as holder of the bearer shares, or beneficially under the terms of a trust, declared, for example, by the nominee holders of the shares.  He failed to do either.  Thus the claim by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to be the beneficial owner of the shares in the Offshore Companies, apart from being inconsistent with his pleaded case at paragraphs C59 - C59B (in which he claimed that "\xc2\x85 the aluminium assets [were] beneficially owned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich"), provided him with no additional route to becoming a party to the Master Agreement.  The reality was that any claim to be entitled to a beneficial interest in 50% of the shares of the Offshore Companies depended on the enforcement of his alleged rights under the alleged 1999 Agreement.\r   The assertion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s interests in the pre-aluminium merger assets needed to be hidden I have already dealt with this claim to a certain extent.  It was not borne out by the evidence.  The principal reason proffered by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as to why his interest in the aluminium assets needed to be concealed, and why he was not to be named a party to the Master Agreement, was an asserted concern about the risk of politically motivated attacks on his assets having regard, in particular, to the problems he is said to have experienced with Prime Minister Primakov.  But, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky accepted in evidence, by late 1999 his dispute with Mr.\xc2\xa0Primakov was long since over, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had won that battle and was at the height of his powers.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Primakov had been dismissed from his office as Prime Minister in May 1999.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also suggested he did not sign the Master Agreement because he was a member of the Duma.  No evidence was adduced to suggest that there was any legal difficulty in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s participating in the ownership of assets because of his elected position, as opposed to the management of assets, and the suggestion was contradicted by his own evidence elsewhere and by the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (also a member of the Duma at the time) signed the Master Agreement.  But even if one were to accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s explanations as to the reason why he was not expressly referred to in the Master Agreement, they simply do not shed any light on why no steps were taken to document his claimed ultimate ownership interest in a confidential agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, or to structure the ownership of his interests through a confidential shareholding or other vehicle structure outside Russia.  Moreover his stated desire for invisibility hardly sat well with an interview which he gave to  Vedomosti  in March 2000, in which he boasted publicly of his supposed involvement in the aluminium business.\r   The views of the sellers under the Master Agreement which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said demonstrated that they thought he was indeed a purchaser of the pre-merger aluminium assets Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to place strong reliance on what he asserted were the views of these sellers of the pre-merger aluminium assets, and their representatives (Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben, Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk, Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney), that he was indeed a purchaser under the terms of the Master Agreement;  thus, in his written closing submissions, it was submitted that:\r   "the evidence strongly suggests that this was also the understanding of all of the 4 sellers of the aluminium assets and their representatives". That was not my impression of the relevant evidence.  If, and to the extent that, any of the sellers were under that impression, given what, as was apparent from their evidence, was their limited knowledge, their belief can have very little weight in an evaluation of what was actually the case.\r   The high watermark of Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben\'s evidence was that he assumed that the buyers were Sibneft shareholders or "like the Sibneft people \xc2\x85 who were buying it" (this description also apparently including Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler) and he assumed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was one of the "Sibneft people" because his understanding was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky "was involved" with Sibneft along with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich [495] .  Such evidence hardly supported the earlier assertion made in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written opening submissions that Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben would give evidence that the sellers of the aluminium assets understood the purchasers to be "the Berezovsky group".  Moreover Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili never mentioned Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s name in this connection:  \r   "Q\tAnd in your conversations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about the purchasers and the purchaser not being Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, was mention made of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky? A.\t\tNo, just -- and even if it is, I can\'t remember. Q.\t\tYou said earlier that reference was made to Sibneft. A.\t\tYes. Q.\t\tIs that something that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili himself said? A.\t\tNo, my own partners were talking as well, they were discussing this.   You see, we never specifically mentioned who one person is or one company is.   So when we talk about the sale, we are talking about Badri and his partners.   It was common knowledge Mr.\xc2\xa0Badri was a partner of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  he said so, it was a known factor, so I assumed it to be that way.   I have never seen any documents or papers.   I was not a friend of either of them to say.   I was not the enemy either.   But I really had no idea what or where or how.   That was how we assumed it to be [496] ." But Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben\'s evidence, based on assumption, was very weak support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he was a purchaser.  His other evidence, to which I have already referred, that he himself never came across Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in connection with the transaction at the time undermined Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertions of his own centrality to the deal.\r   I have already addressed part of the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov above.  I attach little weight to the self-serving press interview which he gave subsequently to  Vedomosti  in January 2008, stating that the "shares" in the aluminium factories were "sold to Abramovich and Berezovsky (signed on their behalf by Patarkatsishvili), at a time when he was seeking to claim commission from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and possibly also from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky submitted that the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, and his representatives, Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky, to the effect that they thought both Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler were co-purchasers of the pre-aluminium assets along with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich also strongly supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case and undermined that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as being inconsistent with it.  I do not accept that analysis.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence was that he did not know what arrangements had been reached between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  At the time, he assumed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had some interest in the transaction given his involvement in the negotiations and the fact that he was named as a purchaser in the Master Agreement.  But he said that he:\r   "\xc2\x85 didn\'t quite know what kind of arrangements might have existed between Abramovich, Shvidler and Badri \xc2\x85 and wasn\'t all that bothered at that time [497] ."  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence in this respect was supported by Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky.  Their evidence was also that, based on the Master Agreement, they assumed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili acquired an interest in, or right to, the aluminium assets, but did not know what that interest was.  And none of Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Buzuk understood Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to have acquired an interest in the aluminium assets.  \r   In my judgment, however, there was no inconsistency between this evidence and the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.   At the time of the Master Agreement they simply did not know what the true position was, and, like Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben, they did not need to know for the purposes of the transaction.\r   But in his written closing submission Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky invited the court to reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s "self-serving assertion that he was not aware of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky having an interest in the aluminium assets" [498] , although, somewhat confusingly, this was also accompanied, both in the written and Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s oral closing submissions, by the suggestion that it was not necessary for the court to make a determination in relation to any issues about Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s knowledge.  I deal with this point further below, in the context of the second RusAl sale and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s knowledge at that time.  \r   For the purposes of Issue B1, however, I am satisfied that, at the time of the acquisition of the pre-merger assets, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov did not know that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was in any way involved in the transaction or understand that he had any interest in it.  In this context Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to rely on:\r   i)\ta formal declaration made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov in support of his application for a visit to the United States in October 2001 in which he stated that he had sold his shares in the KrAZ assets in February 2002 to "shareholders of Sibneft"; ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Moss\' notes of the meeting in Baden-Baden with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov was present;  and  iii)\ta fax dated 27 March 2007 sent to Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky from Syndikus Treuhandstalt. None of this documentation took Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case any further nor did it establish that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov had any knowledge of, or thought that, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was involved in the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets as a purchaser. Accordingly I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence can be relied upon to support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.\r   A witness statement of Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney was also relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky this context, in relation to what was said to be the understanding of his brother, Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, Mr.\xc2\xa0Reuben\'s partner in TWG, as to the identity of the purchasers of the Bratsk and KrAZ assets.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney was not a seller of such assets.  It contained the following passage:\r   "In 1999, a number of aluminium assets owned by me, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and our partners were merged to form a new company, Sibal.  Also in 1999 I had heard that Lev and [the TransWorld Group] were seeking to sell all their aluminium assets.  I wanted to buy them out and I spoke to Lev at some point in 1999 to try to secure the deal.  Unfortunately, my business relations with my brother were not particularly good at this time and he would not give me a final answer. Later in 1999, Mr.\xc2\xa0Nekrich and another former business partner of mine, Mr.\xc2\xa0Iskander Makhmudov called me from Moscow and told me that Lev and [the TransWorld Group] had sold all their aluminium assets in Russia  to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and his partners in Sibneft.  Lev also confirmed to me that this was the case .  I was not pleased with this development, as I had also been interested in buying those assets. "  [Emphasis added]. I have already described the circumstances in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney declined to give evidence, even by way of video link.  In the absence of cross-examination, I am not prepared to attach any weight to this untested statement which not only has a reference to the wrong date but also was wholly dependent upon what his brother had told him.  But even if the statement truly reflected the belief of Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney, it would have provided minimal support to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case.   Various press reports relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon certain reports in the media at the time of the sale to support his assertion that he was, and that everybody thought he was, a purchaser of the pre-merger aluminium assets.   These included three reports in  The Moscow Times ,  American Metal Market  and  Metals Week  in February 2000, in which "a spokesman" for Mr.\xc2\xa0Lev Cherney (apparently Mr.\xc2\xa0Bosov) was reported as confirming that TWG\'s controlling stakes in the Bratsk and KrAZ aluminium assets had been transferred to "Sibneft shareholders".  In addition, the reports in  The Moscow Times  and  American Metal Market  respectively suggested that the purchasers were "companies with firm ties to tycoon Boris Berezovsky" and that the assets had been:\r   "bought up \xc2\x85 in what looks like another major power play involving two of the country\'s most powerful businessmen - oil tycoon Boris Berezovsky and \xc2\x85 Roman Abramovich" In addition, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon a number of interviews given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler well after the event, in July 2000, November 2000 and May 2001, which were all subsequently published on the Sibneft website.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to rely on the following emphasised passages:  \r   i)\tan interview given to  Vedomosti  on 11 July 2000, in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler was asked: " And is your [aluminium] transaction complete ? Almost.  The shares have been transferred to the  new owners  and Russian Aluminium is practically functioning as one company.  But it may take a year for the paperwork to be completed and for the transaction to be approved by various committees. \xc2\x85 But what funds were used to buy aluminium plants? It is rumored that Sibneft\'s money was used. Sibneft\'s money was not used in the aluminium deal.  And it is easy to determine by looking at our GAAP accounts.   Our shareholders  obtained funds in particular from Western investment funds." [Emphasis added] ii)\tan interview given on 13 November 2000, published in  Petroleum Intelligence Weekly  in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler was asked: " Unclear shareholding structures remain a worrying aspect of many Russian oil companies.  Can you reveal who the principal shareholders are in Sibneft ? First, I would like to say that Sibneft is a separate oil company not mixed up with the aluminium interests of  our shareholders .  As for the list of shareholders,  Roman Abramovich controls about a 40% stake, a similar amount is controlled by the company\'s top management , while the rest is in free float.  I would also like to underline that the Chorny [sic] brothers (metals magnates who handed over their aluminium assets to  Sibneft shareholders  at the beginning of the year) have never been and are not represented in Sibneft" [Emphasis added] iii)\tan interview given to  Vremya Novostei  on 14 May 2001 in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler was asked: " About a year ago, Sibneft shareholders said they had acquired a group of aluminium plants.  Now they have purchased GAZ and are creating the RusPromAvto company.  This gives one the impression that there is some kind of financial-industrial group.  Can it be described ? No it can\'t.  Sibneft and the aluminium smelters have  common shareholders , of course.  But this does not change anything." [Emphasis added]" In addition to the references to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz sought to rely on the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler referred to "Sibneft shareholders" in the plural, and also on the fact that the public statements referred to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as only having a 40% interest in Sibneft.\r   In my judgment this was flimsy evidential material upon which to base a case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was either a shareholder in Sibneft or had become a shareholder in companies which controlled the aluminium assets.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich accepted, the Russian press associated Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky with Sibneft - something which, certainly before Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s departure from Russia, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich found useful.  But that association, as I have already explained, was also consistent with a relationship of  krysha .  And both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler gave entirely credible explanations as to why, in the media at least, Sibneft deployed a deliberate policy of not referring to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as the sole ultimate beneficial owner of Sibneft, but rather presenting the profile of the Sibneft shareholding structure as being 40% controlled by "Sibneft management".  The reality, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum and Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko described, was that there was a trust structure above the registered holders of the Sibneft shares which were controlled by management, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his family, were the sole beneficiaries of those trusts and therefore effectively in control of 80% of Sibneft.  I found Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s explanation as to why, in the circumstances prevailing in Russia at the time, one would not wish to portray oneself as the sole owner of a majority interest in Sibneft, because of assassination or kidnap risks, entirely credible.  The practice of distancing oneself from controlling ownership was one which was supported by Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov in his evidence.\r   Comments made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili prior to his death which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged "consistently acknowledged to third parties that both himself and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had acquired an interest in the aluminium assets in February 2000" [499]   The briefing notes taken by Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson in June 2005 and by Mr.\xc2\xa0Stephenson and Mr.\xc2\xa0Lankshear in December 2005, at interviews with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, provided some evidential support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as "core shareholders" in Sibneft, together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, acquired the pre-merger aluminium interests.  But the weight which I attach to this evidence is not great.  The comments which the solicitors have noted are brief and vague and do not descend into detail.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption suggested, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili may have wrongly believed by this date that he had acquired such an interest, or, in my view more likely, his statements may have been simply self-serving so as to assist Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in the prosecution of his case against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  In the absence of cross-examination of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, I am not prepared to find that these statements outweigh the other evidence and, in particular, the documentary evidence.  Moreover, the notes appeared to suggest that the money used to acquire the pre-merger aluminium assets were Sibneft resources;  that was clearly incorrect and raised a fundamental question as to the reliability of what Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was telling Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors.\r   I can place no reliance upon the 2007 proofing materials, not only for the reasons I have already given, but also because the particular statements relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were in fact attributed by Ms.\xc2\xa0Duncan to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky himself and not to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  In any event, the accuracy of these notes is dubious.\r   The third basis for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim to an interest in the assets - the allegation that it was agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that the cost of acquiring the Bratsk and KrAZ assets would come out of their respective profit shares in Sibneft It was common ground that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili made any financial contribution to the cost of acquiring the pre-merger aluminium assets.  The Master Agreement and the ten acquisition contracts provided for the payment by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies (i.e.  the Offshore Companies) of $575 million, of which $175 million was due within a week of the agreements, a further $125 million over the rest of 2000, and $275 million on 10 June 2001.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, in his sixth witness statement, set out full details of the payments required and how they were financed;  in summary, $100 million was funded by a loan from MDM Bank, which contributed to the March and April instalments, and the balance was funded from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies and, subsequently, from Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s equalisation payments.  No payments were made out of Sibneft itself.  \r   It was also common ground that, as matters subsequently turned out, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich recouped the whole of the $575 million which he had paid for the Bratsk and KrAZ assets from the equalisation payments subsequently made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  But that was not something that was foreseen, and certainly not guaranteed, at the time that the assets were acquired under the terms of the Master Agreement.  That was particularly so, given that:\r   i)\tthe equalisation payment to be made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was originally agreed at $400 million at a time when the Bratsk assets were not included in the merger deal; ii)\tthe Bratsk assets were subsequently included in the deal in April and May 2000 and the agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska restated on 15 May to incorporate them when the equalisation payment was increased to $575 million; iii)\tthat figure exactly matched what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had paid for the entirety of the pre-merger aluminium assets. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument, however, was that it was irrelevant that, in the event, the transaction was self-financing and that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were not called upon to pay anything.  In paragraph 260 of his fourth witness statement, he said that he had agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (presumably in early 2000) that the purchase price of the pre-merger aluminium assets would be paid for from his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s entitlement to Sibneft profits.  In his written closing submissions [500] , it was argued that the evidence showed that in 2000 it would have been perfectly feasible for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have funded their half share of the purchase price of the pre-merger aluminium assets ($287.5 million) out of the profits which they were expecting to receive during the course of 2000;  which, it was said, supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s account of the agreement.   In addition it was submitted that \r   "\xc2\x85 in order to see who contributed to the financial cost of the aluminium acquisitions, one has first to investigate who was entitled to the $575 million sum that was due to be paid and was paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case is that he was one of the people who was entitled to benefit from that payment, being one of the partners in the aluminium acquisition itself.  Moreover, \xc2\x85 the contemporaneous contracts make it clear that this sum was due to be apportioned between the " Other Selling Shareholders " and the " Other P1 Shareholders ", rather than being payable solely to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich which is what one would, on his case, have expected." [501] I deal with those three arguments in turn.  First, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertion in his witness statement that he had agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that the funding for the acquisition would come out of his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s share of "Sibneft profits" was undermined in cross-examination [502] .  His repeated restatement of the alleged agreement was not convincing;  he had only the vaguest idea of what the cost of acquiring the Bratsk and KrAZ assets was;  and he had no idea as to the quantum of Sibneft profits to which he was, or was prospectively, entitled in that year.  \r   Second, the evidence relating to the available "Sibneft profits" did not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s allegation that he had agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich that his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s contribution would be funded from this source.  Sibneft\'s own profits in 2000 could not possibly have supported such a burden;  they were ultimately shown in the Consolidated Financial Statements, signed off by Arthur Andersen ZAO on 30 April 2001, at a figure of $674.845 million, of which only $50.683 million was distributed by way of dividend.  Even approaching the matter on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that "Sibneft profits" should be widely defined as extending to any profits made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s Trading Companies as a result of the acquisition of Sibneft, his case was not made out.  Whilst it was true that the payments received by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies during the course of 2000 totalled some $490.2 million, which would, theoretically, have been sufficient to have paid for  their alleged 50% share of the cost of acquiring the pre-merger aluminium assets, namely a figure of $287.5 million [503] , the evidence did not support the proposition that any part of the payments actually made to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were ever applied, or intended to be applied, in such a way or that they had otherwise contributed to the cost.  The year 2000 was the one year in which a comprehensive spreadsheet (the FOM spreadsheet) recording payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili survived.  This spreadsheet recorded no entry representing payment of their share of the cost of acquiring the pre-merger aluminium assets, or setting off their liability to contribute to the cost of such acquisition against payments that would have otherwise been due to them, or applying payments made to them for such purpose.   Moreover, on the footing of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own case that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a 50% interest in the acquisitions, $87.5 million of their contribution to the cost would have been due almost immediately, in February and March 2000, and, so far as the February instalment was concerned, prior to the receipt of any funds from Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  There was no evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had ever paid anything, or had asked, or been asked, to pay anything.  Nor (apart from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence about the original agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich) was there any evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had ever raised the question as to how or when their contribution to the acquisition costs had been, or was going to be, funded out of "Sibneft profits";  or that that point had ever been the subject matter of discussion with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Nor was there any evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been told that they need not worry about making any contribution because, in the event, the equalisation payment from Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was going to fund the transaction.\r   Third, the argument that one needed to look at who was entitled to the $575 million sum that was due to be paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, to ascertain who actually contributed to the financial cost of the aluminium acquisition did not logically advance the argument that the evidence supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case as to his agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  I deal with the terms of the "contemporaneous contracts" upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied in the next section of this judgment.\r   Accordingly, in my judgment, the third basis put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to support his interest in the pre-acquisition aluminium assets does not assist his case.\r   Conclusion on Issue B1 Accordingly I conclude that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili acquired any interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets prior to the Dorchester Hotel meeting, whether by virtue of the alleged 1995 or 1999 Agreements or otherwise by virtue of any agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  I conclude that, in the events which happened, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not acquire any such interest pursuant to, or by virtue of, the Master Agreement.  Subject to these points, I make no determination in relation to any claim by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that he acquired such an interest as a result of the alleged joint venture agreement asserted by him in the main Chancery action, which is not for determination in these proceedings.  However, in the Chancery proceedings, he will be bound by my conclusion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did not acquire such interest as a result of any agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich prior to the Dorchester Hotel meeting or pursuant to the terms of the Master Agreement.\r   Section XV - Issue B2:  Was it agreed at the Dorchester Hotel on 13 March 2000 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have a share of the aluminium business created by the merger of those assets with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests? Introduction Issue B2 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, is:  \r   "Issue B2:  Was it agreed at the Dorchester Hotel on 13 March 2000 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have a share of the aluminium business created by the merger with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests?" Issue B2 addresses Issues 17 and 18 in the Agreed List of Issues, which are in the following terms: "17.\tAt the Dorchester Hotel meeting, did Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deri-paska agree to pool their assets in the Russian aluminium industry? 18.\tWas it expressly agreed and/or understood at the Dorchester meeting: (1) \tThat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would, as trustee, hold half of his 50% interest on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as beneficiaries;  and/or (2) \tThat none of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would sell his interest in RusAl without the agreement of the others;  and/or (3) \tThat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would assume fiduciary obligations in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili?" Issue B2 also corresponds with Overlap Issue 2 and 3(a).   In the light of my previous conclusion in relation to Issue B1, it might have appeared logical to have approached this issue against the background that if, as I have found, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no interest in the pre-aluminium assets that were contributed to the merger, it would be objectively somewhat unlikely that he would have obtained a share of the merged business without contributing either cash or assets to it.  However, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz relied upon much of the evidence relating to Issue B2 as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to Issue B1, I have approached the evidence relating to this issue on a notionally freestanding basis, and have, during the course of my evaluation of it, considered whether such evidence indeed supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to Issue B1.  I have also considered such evidence in the wider spectrum as to whether any aspect of it could be relied upon to support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to Sibneft and the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements.\r   Executive summary in relation to Issue B2 No agreement was made at the Dorchester Hotel meeting on 13 March 2000 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have a share of the aluminium business created by the merger of the pre-merger aluminium assets with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests.  There was no agreement made at that meeting to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would pool the pre-merger aluminium assets acquired in February 2000 with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had no interest in the pre-merger aluminium assets and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had already agreed to pool such assets as between themselves.  In particular, no agreement was made at that meeting by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, or by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili:\r   i)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would hold 50% of his interest in the merged business on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili; ii)\tthat none of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili  would sell his interest in RusAl without the prior agreement of the others;  or iii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would assume fiduciary obligations in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili. The evidence relating to this issue supports my conclusion that the relationship between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was based upon a protection, or  krysha , type relationship and not on any contractually binding agreement between the two men.\r   The merger negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska prior to the Dorchester Hotel meeting Certain aspects of the evidence relating to the events leading up to the Dorchester Hotel meeting were effectively common ground.  In summary, these events were as follows (and, to the extent that they were not common ground, I find the following as facts):\r   i)\tThe merger agreement, by which the pre-merger aluminium assets were combined with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests, originated in an encounter between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska at the White House in Moscow in late February 2000 during which the possibility of a merger of their aluminium businesses was discussed.  Negotiations were subsequently conducted in early March between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, on the one hand, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Bulygin [504]  (an associate of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska) on the other hand.  The negotiations started late one evening in early March 2000, and continued late into the night at the Baltschug Kempinski Hotel in Moscow, and, on the following day, at Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s house in Sareevo village near Moscow.  They culminated in the drafting and signing on that day of a preliminary agreement ("the Preliminary Agreement") as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of the one part (referred to as "Party 1") and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska of the other part (referred to as "Party 2") to merge the respective aluminium interests of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in a single company, in the event RusAl.  At the time a number of the aluminium assets in question were on the brink of bankruptcy and so swift agreement was required.  The negotiations were also conducted in great secrecy because all the participants were concerned about the potential problem that TWG, or other competitors in the aluminium market, might attempt to cut off the merged company\'s access to supplies of raw materials, if the merger became known prematurely. ii)\tThe Preliminary Agreement set out the basic features of the proposed merger.  It was drafted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Bulygin on his laptop without the input of any lawyers.  It was signed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and by Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  The Preliminary Agreement was undated, but the evidence was that it was signed at Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s house following the meetings at the Baltschug Kempinski Hotel.  It provided, in summary as follows: a)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska would buy from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich 50% of the aluminium assets identified in the agreement (which at that stage did not include the Bratsk assets) for $400 million. [505] b)\tTheir combined aluminium assets would be transferred into their joint ownership and management. c)\tFor a two year period, the joint business would comprise the production of bauxites, alumina, raw materials for primary aluminium manufacturing and primary aluminium.  Any new acquisitions falling within these categories were to be made by the parties together (clause 4.6). d)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska would enter into a further agreement by 20 March 2000 at the latest (clause 5).  In addition to the standard terms, clause 4 of the Preliminary Agreement provided that this further agreement would include certain terms specified in the Preliminary Agreement.  Clause 4 provided that the following terms were to be included: "4.\tThe Parties agree that in addition to the standard terms the Agreement shall by all means include the following terms: 4.1\tParties 1 and 2 warrant that, together with their partners (not including TWG or any companies and/or individuals related thereto or affiliated therewith), they own the assets and that the stated assets have not been pledged as security for the obligations of Parties 1 and 2 and are not subject to any third party rights, disputes or attachments. 4.2\tParty 1 warrants its and its partners\' concerted will to sign the Agreement on the terms determined herein, and shall be fully liable to Party 2 for any action (omission) by its partners associated with the performance hereof. 4.5\tTo jointly manage the assets owned by the Parties, the Parties shall establish joint ventures before 01.04.00 to hold the property and to conduct joint business. 4.6\tThe Parties hereby define the framework for the conduct of joint business for a two year perspective as comprising the production of bauxites, production of alumina, production of raw materials for primary aluminum manufacturing, and production of primary aluminum.  Any new property acquisitions falling within the interests of the joint business shall be carried out by the Parties together." e)\tThe parties were required within three days to appoint their respective representatives responsible for the preparation of the further agreement (clause 5).   f)\tBy 15 March 2000 the parties would agree upon (i) a joint management team for the venture, with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich proposing "CFO nominees [506] " and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska proposing "CEO nominees [507] " (clause 6);  and (ii) the composition of the Board of Directors of the joint venture, to be formed on a parity basis.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich undertook to procure the inclusion of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s representatives on a parity basis into all relevant management bodies, including the Board of Directors (clause 7). g)\tClause 8 provided that joint business would start on 1 March 2000, i.e. immediately, and that profit sharing would also begin from that date.   h)\tClause 13 contained confidentiality provisions so as to avoid alerting the market to the deal prior to the merger taking effect in order to avoid a possible risk of disruption to the supply of raw materials.  It was in the following terms: "13 \tThe Parties undertake to hold confidential the terms of this Preliminary Agreement and any subsequent agreements.  Information concerning this Preliminary Agreement and other agreements on the basis thereof may be communicated to third parties only subject to the Parties\' consent." i)\tClause 14 contained an English governing law provision for the anticipated further agreement and a dispute resolution provision providing for any disputes arising thereunder to be referred to "the Court of Arbitration of the UK Chamber of Commerce and Industry, London". Shortly after the signing of the Preliminary Agreement, a working group was established to prepare the final agreement.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side was represented by Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum and Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko (as well as by Mr.\xc2\xa0Andrei Osipov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Kenneth Schneider).  Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s side was represented by Mr.\xc2\xa0Stalbek Mishakov (at the time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s in-house Russian lawyer), Mr.\xc2\xa0Alexander Bulygin (a business associate of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska) and Mr.\xc2\xa0Paul Hauser (an external lawyer from Bryan Cave, acting for Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, who remained a client at the time of trial).  The first meetings took place in London between 7 and 12 March 2000.  In the course of the working group\'s discussions, it was agreed that six offshore companies would become the initial shareholders of RusAl.  Each would be owned on a 50:50 basis by Runicom Limited (subsequently replaced by Madison Equities Corp ("Madison")) and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s company, GSA (Cyprus) Limited ("GSA") (later replaced by Baufinanz Ltd ("Baufinanz")), which was itself ultimately renamed Eagle Capital Group Ltd ("Eagle")).\r   The working group met again on 14 March 2000 and into the early hours of 15 March 2000 at Sibneft\'s offices in Moscow.  The meeting was attended by Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, Mr.\xc2\xa0Osipov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Schneider (for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich) and by Mr.\xc2\xa0Mishakov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser (for Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska).  As points arose for determination, they were taken upstairs to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler to reach a final agreement.  \r   These meetings of the working group culminated in a Share Purchase and Sale Agreement dated 15 March 2000 ("the 15 March SPSA") between Runicom, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s company, (as "Vendor") and GSA, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s company, (as "Purchaser").  The 15 March SPSA contained the following material terms [508] :\r   i)\tthere were the following definitions: "Companies" was defined as the four Offshore Companies which had purchased the pre-merger aluminium assets; "Other Selling Shareholders" was defined as "\xc2\x85 those other persons who together with the Vendor are the legal and beneficial owners and holders of 100 per cent of the shares (both in registered and bearer form) of the Companies as at the Completion Date" however the "Parties" to the agreement were defined as only including Runicom and GSA; ii)\tby 15 March 2000 SPSA Runicom, as Vendor, agreed to sell to GSA 50% of the shares in the Offshore Companies (i.e. Runicom Fort, Galinton, Palmtex and Dilcor, being the four companies which had purchased the pre-merger aluminium assets under the ten sale and purchase contracts dated 10 February 2000);  Runicom agreed to do so "on its behalf and on behalf of the Other Selling Shareholders with full title guarantee";  the price for the sale of 50% of the shares in the Offshore Companies was $400 million (payable in instalments);   iii)\tGSA (Cyprus) agreed to transfer to Runicom Ltd the ownership of half of the shares in the Deripaska aluminium assets (identified in the agreement) being contributed to the deal;  the $400 million payable by GSA to Runicom was, in essence, an equalisation payment to compensate for the fact that the assets contributed by Runicom were more valuable than those contributed by GSA (Cyprus); iv)\tthe agreement contained various representations, warranties and other provisions addressing the position of the Other Selling Shareholders;  by way of example, I refer to the following:   "5.1\tThe Vendor shall procure that neither it, the Other Selling Shareholders, nor any of their respective transferees, successors or assigns, shall transfer to any third person any of the shares in the Companies which such entity owns or controls for a period of two years from the Completion Date without obtaining the prior, written consent of the Purchaser. \xc2\x85 6.1\tThe Vendor represents and warrants to the Purchaser that as at the Completion Date: 6.1.1\tthe Vendor and Other Selling Shareholders are together the legal and beneficial owners of 100 per cent of the shares of the Companies, which shares are owned free from all encumbrances, charges and liens; \xc2\x85 6.1.3\tthe Vendor has the power and authority to act in the name of and to represent the Other Selling Shareholders in respect of the sale of the Shares, and to receive the Transfer Price on their behalf; \xc2\x85 6.1.5\tneither the Vendor nor any of the Other Selling Shareholders shall have any claims of any nature against the Companies whatsoever, including but not limited to any actual or contingent charges, encumbrances, pledges or liens;" v)\tClause 8 contained a provision referring any disputes under the agreement to the London Court of International Arbitration, with a seat in London;  it also contained an English governing law provision; vi)\tclause 18 provided: " Rights of Third Parties Except as expressly provided in this Agreement, nothing in this Agreement will create or confer any rights or other benefits on or in favour of any person who is not a party to this Agreement whether pursuant to the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 or otherwise.  For [the] purposes hereof, the Parties hereby expressly provide that the Other Selling Shareholders are to be considered for all purposes \'intended third party beneficiaries\' to this Agreement with respect to the obligations of the Purchaser and, as such, shall be entitled (without limitation) to damages in the event of any breach by the Purchaser of its obligations pursuant hereto;  provided, however, that in the event of any disputes hereunder any claims of the Other Selling Shareholders for damages from the Purchaser shall be made and enforced by the Vendor, acting as agent and/or attorney for such purposes on behalf of the Other Selling Shareholders." vii)\tRunicom and GSA agreed to employ all reasonable endeavours to negotiate in good faith and enter into a shareholders\' agreement regulating the management and business of the Offshore Companies by the Transfer Date (a date not later than 30 days after the Completion Date), upon which the shares in those companies were to be transferred to GSA;  and viii)\tby virtue of clause 4.5 and schedule II part 3, the Bratsk assets were expressly excluded from the merger deal. On 15 May 2000, the 15 March SPSA was amended and restated to reflect changes in the deal since 15 March ("the 15 May Restated SPSA").  The main changes were the addition of the Bratsk assets (which had been excluded from the previous agreements) to the assets to be contributed by the Runicom side and the contribution of the Sayansky plant from Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s side [509] , the resultant revaluation of the equalisation payment (which involved a calculation of the value attributed to the Bratsk assets, less the value attributed to Sayansky plant ) gave rise to an increase in the equalisation payment to be paid to Runicom of $175 million, bringing the total sum up to $575 million.\r   RusAl itself was ultimately registered in Moscow in December 2000.  Its initial shareholders were six companies registered in the BVI, including two of the four Offshore Companies who had been purchasers of the pre-merger aluminium assets under the ten contracts dated 10 February 2000;  these were:  Galinton, Dilcor (two of the Offshore Companies), David Worldwide Corp., Kadex Metals Ltd., Valeford Trading Ltd.  and Foreshore Ventures Ltd.  ("the Initial RusAl Shareholders").  It was agreed between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska that the shares of the Initial RusAl Shareholders (which were in bearer form) would be distributed 50/50 as between Runicom (although subsequently ownership was exercised through Madison) and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s company GSA, and that the share certificates would be kept by the authorised representatives of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to Issue B2 Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed that, very shortly after the pre-merger aluminum assets were acquired, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich informed him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and his Sibal group were interested in integrating their respective aluminium assets into a new company;  and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that it was preferable not to compete with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, who had many years of experience in the aluminium sector, but rather to work with him in partnership.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should negotiate with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to see what merger terms might be available.  He further said that, in the course of several private discussions between the three men in Moscow about a week, or perhaps a bit more, before the Dorchester Hotel meeting on 13 March 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and he discussed the principal terms on which they would be prepared to merge;  and that they agreed that:  \r   i)\tthe "confirmation" of their obligations under the alleged 1995 and 1996 Agreements;   ii)\tno one should be able to "leave the business" (i.e. sell his interests in the new entity) without the consent of the other parties to the agreement;   iii)\tif a merger could be agreed, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would hold their shares for the three of them on trust;  and  iv)\tthat the agreements they made regarding their aluminium assets, including the trust, would be subject to English law.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky said that a meeting was arranged a week or two in advance to take place at the Dorchester Hotel in London on 13 or 14 March 2000 between the principals to the merger deal (i.e. himself, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska) "to finalise the key details of the deal to be made" [510] . Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case was that he intervened at the decisive point of the merger negotiations, by presiding over the meeting at the Dorchester Hotel on the afternoon of 13 March 2000, between himself, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska which marked the point when the final agreement was reached which was subsequently embodied in the 15 March SPSA executed two days later.  His evidence was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili led the negotiations, but "everybody understood that I am key person, not anybody more" [511] .  He claimed that the merger was indeed agreed at this meeting, and that, in particular, it was agreed that no party could sell their interest without the agreement of the others, and that the arrangements, both internally as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and their agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, would be governed by "British law" [512] .\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case in relation to issue B2 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich denied that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had any involvement in the merger of the pre-merger aluminium assets with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests.  He denied that he had any discussions with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky about the proposed merger prior to the Dorchester Hotel meeting.  He said that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was also not party to the merger discussions, but that he informed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili of the merger agreement after he returned to Moscow from London on 12 March 2000.  He claimed that the meeting at the Dorchester Hotel was arranged at the last moment, at Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s insistence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky having been told about the merger by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and having summoned Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich so that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky could be told about it directly.\r   Analysis of the direct evidence relating to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s alleged involvement in the merger and the Dorchester Hotel meeting itself I address first the direct evidence relating to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s alleged involvement in the merger and to the Dorchester Hotel meeting itself.  I then turn to deal with the various aspects of circumstantial and collateral evidence relied upon by him to support his case.  In coming to my conclusion in relation to the direct evidence, I have also taken into account the points made on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf in relation to the circumstantial evidence.  \r   The events leading up to the Dorchester Hotel meeting My findings of fact in relation to the direct evidence relating to the events leading up to the Dorchester Hotel meeting are as follows:\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no involvement in any of the merger negotiations, as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, including those which led to the Preliminary Agreement and those of the working party set up under it;  thus he was not expressly named as a party to the Preliminary Agreement, or any of the subsequent agreements by which the merger was effected, namely the 15 March SPSA and the Restated 15 May SPSA;  he had no documented interest in the merged business, and did not seek to obtain any documentary record of his interest;  and he had no involvement in the formation of RusAl or the operation of any part of the merged business.   ii)\tBetween 7 and 12 March 2000 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and their respective teams were in London where they met on several occasions to conduct the merger negotiations.  They also resolved the issue of securing arrangements for the supply of raw materials to the aluminium plants, which had been the concern which the confidentiality provisions of the Preliminary Agreement had been intended to address.  By this time, the merger had already started, from a practical point of view, to have been put into effect and the aluminium operations had already started to be combined. iii)\tContrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence, there were no private discussions or meetings between him, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in Moscow in the week or so before the Dorchester Hotel meeting in relation to the proposed merger and no discussion about its terms.  The first that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky heard about the merger was as a result of the telephone call made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, referred to in the next paragraph. iv)\tOn Sunday 12 March 2000 [513] , Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, who had returned to Moscow from London that afternoon, telephoned Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and told him for the first time about the deal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich thought it necessary and appropriate to do so, notwithstanding the fact that the merger was not going to be announced until later, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had an outstanding financial obligation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in relation to the fees for the work which the latter had done in connection with the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich thought it would not be appropriate to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to hear about the merger from the newspapers.  The confidentiality concerns, which had related to the possibility of attempts by competitors such as TGW to disrupt supplies of raw material to the aluminium plants, had been resolved by this stage.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s explanation as to why he informed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was entirely credible;  I do not deduce from the fact that he did so, without the prior consent of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was, or was regarded by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as being, a "partner" and therefore not a "third party" within the meaning of clause 13 of the Preliminary Agreement. v)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s immediate response was that he was not happy about the proposed merger and warned Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich about Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Shortly after the discussion, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili rang Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich back and told him that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would like to meet with him straight away, because, or so Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich understood, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky wanted to hear from him directly about the merger.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was in London because Monday 13 March was the first day of the House of Lords\' hearing of his case against  Forbes Magazine.   So Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich arranged to fly back to London (from where he had just come) on the next day, 13 March 2000, with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, in order to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.   vi)\tContrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that, approximately a week or ten days before the Dorchester Hotel meeting, he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had agreed  in advance  to set up a meeting  in London [514] ,  as a summit of principals to agree the terms of the merger, it was clear from the evidence (including flight and travel records) that the meeting was arranged, on 12 March, as a result of the last-minute "summons" from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  If the meeting had indeed been arranged in advance it is inconceivable that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, and possibly also Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, would have returned to Moscow on the Sunday afternoon from London, only to have turned round and flown back again to London the next day.  In a clear shift in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, his written closing submissions appeared to accept the fact that the meeting was arranged at the last moment, although a faint attempt was made to suggest that it was only the venue that was arranged at the last moment [515] . Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested that there was no comprehensible reason why Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, facing an important week of discussions to finalise the merger agreement (which had to be signed by 20 March at the latest pursuant to clause 5 of the Preliminary Agreement), would have embarked on a day trip from Moscow to London and back, simply to inform Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky directly of the terms of the merger, merely because of an alleged  krysha  relationship relating to Sibneft.  He suggested that the only comprehensible raison d\'\xc3\xaatre for the meeting was:\r   "\xc2\x85 because Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s partners, and he needed their consent to [the] RusAl merger.  Indeed just a few days earlier, he had warranted in the Preliminary Agreement that they would consent [as per clause 4.2]." [516] This, he submitted, was only consistent with a partnership agreement between the three men, under the terms of the alleged 1995, 1996 and/or 1999  Agreements.  I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s analysis of the purpose of the Dorchester Hotel meeting as set out above.  It did not reflect the evidence and also was inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own case and evidence that the purpose of the meeting was to discuss and finalise the terms of the merger as opposed to agreeing a deal that had already been concluded.  Furthermore, if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz suggested, the true purpose of the Dorchester Hotel meeting was to obtain Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s consent to the Preliminary Agreement, it was surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no knowledge of the Preliminary Agreement and no recollection of it being produced at the Dorchester Hotel meeting, as he admitted in his evidence.  Indeed he did not see the Preliminary Agreement until after the Commercial Court proceedings were instituted.  His evidence demonstrated that he was entirely ignorant of its terms at the time of the Dorchester Hotel meeting.\r   I conclude that there was every reason at the time why Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have obeyed Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s peremptory summons.  The Russian presidential election had occurred on 7 March, only a few days earlier, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, who believed himself at that time to be an ally and patron of President Putin, and who had contributed substantially to his election campaign, was, the evidence suggested, at the zenith of his political influence.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz described it in his oral opening, this was a time when Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was "basking in the glory of having been involved in President Putin\'s election victory".  I found Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s explanations convincing, notwithstanding the heavy challenge to which they were subjected in cross-examination.  In his oral evidence Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that:\r   "For me, meeting with Berezovsky was always important.  Some of them were more important, other meetings were less important.  If he had asked me to fly to New York, I would have probably flown to New York if I had that possibility to do so [517] . \xc2\x85 At that point in time Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was one of the most influential people in Russia and if he asked me to come and tell him about something I usually did that immediately, without delay [518] .  \xc2\x85 To me personally, there was no benefit that accrued to me personally from this.  I usually complied, if I could, with [Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s] requests." [519] I did not find that explanation for the Dorchester Hotel meeting at all surprising.  It was entirely consistent with the relationship between the two men at the time, under which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich regarded Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, an ally of President Putin, as his influential political protector, and provider of  krysha.   At that stage in their relationship it was unlikely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have risked offending Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, or the loss of the elder man\'s future political influence.  Indeed, the nature of the relationship between Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and his prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9 involved Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky asserting his importance precisely by way of these unforeseen commands at short notice.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account was also supported by that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler.  He explained that:\r   "It will sound strange, but he [Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich] always did [respond to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s requests to see him], and Badri insisted that Boris wanted to see him.  \xc2\x85 When Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky heard about this merger from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, who was told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, he decided that the meeting was necessary and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich went along.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky liked to be associated with big deals and small deals as well.  So what was the motive from his side? I guess that nothing" [520] . Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler gave two other examples he could immediately recall of occasions on which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had commanded his attendance for no obvious or useful purpose.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler commented that:  "that\'s just the kind of relationship we had" [521] .  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler conceded, this looks strange to external observers but\r   "it was [an] extraordinary time, [involving] extraordinary people. [522] " Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also submitted that there was no credible reason for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to have required such a meeting, simply so that he could be informed of the merger deal, and that the only sensible rationale for his presence, and that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, was that the time had arrived when negotiations had advanced to the point where a deal could be agreed, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were needed to agree to the final terms of the agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska pursuant to clause 4.2 of the Preliminary Agreement.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption, on the other hand, whilst accepting that it had never been entirely clear what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky expected out of the meeting, suggested that:\r   "\xc2\x85 he was certainly a man with a rich sense of his own importance and a taste for grandstanding may well be a sufficient explanation of why he wanted to have it." I conclude, contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission, that it was entirely understandable why Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have wanted such a meeting, and that the fact that he required Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to attend was entirely consistent with the  krysha  relationship between the two men.  Thus whilst, perhaps, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption suggested, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky wanted to figure as the great man involved in one of the important events of the Russian business world, and to highlight his own importance, he would also have seen the RusAl merger, and the profits it might generate, as an opportunity for increasing the quantum of his financial demands on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s perception, and possibly also that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as I have already held, was that they considered themselves entitled, under their  krysha  relationship, to a "slice" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s "action".  In those circumstances, I do not find it at all surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have wished to have demonstrated his hold over Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and required his presence at the meeting;  nor do I find it surprising that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich felt it necessary to comply with the wishes of his protector.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to accompany him on the trip to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich gave a number of reasons why he did so.  First, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich felt that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska realised that "to achieve peace it was necessary to get together, meet and put an end to this" [523] ;   I have already described above the background to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s dislike of both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Second, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich wanted Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to accompany him to London because he saw it as a useful occasion on which to discuss the numerous issues which had arisen from a hastily constructed merger that had created the second largest aluminium company in the world.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described how the luxurious and quiet environment of his private jet was a convenient place in which to do business.  Third, he explained that such a meeting was a means of demonstrating to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska that he had powerful friends and associates in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  I accept those reasons.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, in his witness statement, gave the following evidence as to why he accompanied Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich:\r   "In March 2000, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich asked me to accompany him to London to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  I was keen to build a good relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as my new business partner.
