In addition, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky still owed me the abovementioned money and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler assured me that the repayment of this long-standing debt would be resolved at the meeting.  As a favour to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and in the hope of recovering the money Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky owed me, I agreed to travel to London to meet him.  The three or four hour plane journey was nothing out of the ordinary for me since I often had to travel long distances for business - the aluminium plants which I controlled were located in Eastern Siberia, over 3,000 kilometres from Moscow.  I recall thinking that the flight would be a good opportunity to get to know Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler better.  Whilst all the key terms of the combining of various of our businesses had already been agreed and documented in the Preliminary Agreement, there were a number of ongoing issues to discuss in relation to the new business." He supported that account in cross-examination.  The integration of the two groups of businesses had been in progress ever since the execution of the Preliminary Agreement and clearly there were many practical issues to discuss.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s explanation that he also saw the meeting as an opportunity for him to confront Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky about his unpaid and long overdue loan was also entirely credible.  It was clear from his oral evidence that he had been genuinely irritated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s failure to repay the loan of $16 million which Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had made to him.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s evidence as to his reasons for attending the meeting. In both Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s oral and written [524]  closing submissions, there was an extensive critique of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s stated reasons for the meeting.  Taken individually, in an evidential vacuum, some of the arguments might have had some force.  But against a background where Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was asserting that the meeting had been agreed in advance - an allegation which had no evidential foundation, and which, from a practical point of view, was highly unlikely [525]  - and where he had had no other involvement whatsoever in the negotiations, I had little hesitation in preferring the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska on this point.  In this context I should say that I have taken into account Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s argument that clause 4.2 of the Preliminary Agreement was consistent with, and explained the need for, the Dorchester Hotel meeting, and that "because of his warranty, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had to ensure that his partners really did consent to the merger with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska" [526] .  The argument provided little assistance to me in deciding whose evidence to accept.  That clause was merely a warranty of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s "partners\' concerted will to sign" what, in the event, was the 15 March SPSA.  There was no practical or legal requirement, under that clause, to wheel Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to demonstrate their consent.  Moreover, if, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s hypothesis, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had needed to ensure that he had, in truth, obtained Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s consent or "will to sign" the 15 March SPSA, it was surprising, to say the least, that they were not provided, in advance, with a draft of the SPSA for their approval, and were not required to sign it.  Still more surprising is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not provided with, and did not see a copy of, either the Preliminary Agreement or the 15 March SPSA until they were disclosed during the course of this litigation.\r   The Dorchester Hotel meeting Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler all gave broadly consistent accounts of what occurred at the Dorchester Hotel meeting.  I prefer their evidence to that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  My findings of fact in relation to the direct evidence relating to the Dorchester Hotel meeting can be summarised as follows:\r   i)\tThe meeting was scheduled to take place in the early afternoon.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler turned up about 1pm at the Dorchester Hotel and went to the sitting room in Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s suite.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had not been warned to expect Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and was clearly irritated by his presence.  There was an uncomfortable hour or so during which the four men hung around waiting for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, who had been at the House of Lords all morning in connection with the  Forbes  litigation, finally turned up sometime after 2pm.  He appeared from another room in the suite informally dressed in a dressing gown [527] , which hardly suggested that the meeting was one at which critical business decisions had to be taken.   ii)\tThereafter the meeting was awkward and brief.  It lasted no more than an hour.  There were no negotiations about the terms of the merger.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed in cross-examination that there were five key terms finalised at the Dorchester Hotel meeting, namely: a)\tthe proportions of the business to be owned by the Deripaska side and the Abramovich side; b)\tthe role of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in the merged business and the management arrangements; c)\tthe governing law; d)\tthe price (i.e. the equalisation payment); and  e)\tthe provision that none of the participants (including Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska) would be entitled to sell out without the consent of the others. But all these key points (except for the last) had in fact been agreed under the terms of the Preliminary Agreement and there was no need for any further negotiation.  By the time of this meeting, the merger was a done deal.  So far as the last provision was concerned, I find it was never raised or agreed at all, whether with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, or simply as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  If such a term had indeed been agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged, it is inconceivable, given its critical importance, that it would not have found its way into the 15 March SPSA or the later 15 May Restated SPSA.  Apart from the high degree of commercial improbability that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska would ever have agreed to such a term, given his dislike of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence in cross-examination on this aspect was particularly unconvincing. iii)\tThe one term which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed he was able specifically to recall was that all participants at the Dorchester Hotel meeting agreed an equalisation payment of $575 million.  This assertion had appeared in his witness statement at paragraph 278.  He repeated it in cross-examination before being taken to the terms of the Preliminary Agreement and the 15 March SPSA which referred to a figure of only $400 million, when he attempted to backtrack.  However the figure of $575 million clearly could not have been agreed on that occasion.  As I have described above, the equalisation payment fixed in the Preliminary Agreement and referred to again in the 15 March SPSA was $400 million:  the $575 million figure was not introduced until the 15 May Restated SPSA, when the Bratsk assets and the Sayansky plant were introduced into the merger for the first time.  I infer that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky (or more probably someone on his behalf) had picked up this figure when looking at the 15 May Restated SPSA in the course of the litigation and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had crafted his evidence accordingly. iv)\tIn particular, and contrary to the assertion made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, but which was not put to any relevant witness, I find that there was no discussion at the Dorchester Hotel meeting about the inclusion of the Bratsk assets in the merger in return for increasing the equalisation payment due from Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska from $400 million to $575 million.  The suggestion that it had been discussed was put forward in argument as a reason why Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have remembered the figure of $575 million;  it was also suggested that the reason why the provision was omitted from the 15 March SPSA was lack of time.  But there was no evidence whatsoever to suggest that the additional contribution of the Bratsk assets on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side, and of the Sayansky plant on Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s side had been agreed at the time of the 15 March SPSA, with a resultant increase in the equalisation payment to $575 million.  Nor did Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggest in cross-examination that there had been any agreement at the Dorchester Hotel meeting about the value at which the Bratsk assets and the Sayansky plant would be contributed to the deal, with a consequent increase in equalisation payment.   v)\tI find that the RusAl merger was indeed discussed at the Dorchester Hotel meeting, despite Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s failure to remember that fact.  But the discussion would have been superficial.  The rest of the talk was about the aluminium wars, the current state of Russian politics, the repayment of a debt which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky owed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, but which had not been paid back for several years and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s request to be provided with an aircraft.  It was agreed that an aircraft would be purchased for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as part of his fee for the assistance which he had provided Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in connection with the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets.  It was also agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would discharge Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s debt to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska by means of a set-off against the sums owed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich under the terms of the Preliminary Agreement.  But I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that the critical terms of the merger were negotiated or agreed at the Dorchester Hotel meeting;  his evidence in cross-examination came nowhere near to supporting such a suggestion. vi)\tApart from the fact that all of the key terms of the merger had already been agreed and contained in the Preliminary Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence about the Dorchester meeting was undermined by the fact that all the members of the working party who gave evidence (Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko and Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser) denied any knowledge of the Dorchester Hotel meeting and that any mention was made at any stage of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili having any underlying interest in the merger.  Moreover they were never given to understand that they should wait for instructions from their principals as to the outcome of such meeting.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence was likewise undermined by his absence of knowledge of the Preliminary Agreement and of any of the subsequent agreements by which the merger was effected. vii)\tContrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence, there was no discussion or agreement reached at the Dorchester meeting, whether express or implied, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would, as trustee, hold half of his 50% interest in RusAl on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, as beneficiaries;  or that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would assume fiduciary obligations in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  It follows that there was also no discussion or agreement that such alleged trust arrangements would be governed by English law. It follows that I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence in relation to the Dorchester Hotel meeting.  In reaching this conclusion, I have taken into account all the circumstantial evidence relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, the principal aspects of which I address specifically below.\r   The circumstantial evidence relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in support of his claim to have acquired an interest in the merged entity I turn now to consider the circumstantial evidence, largely relating to the period after the date of the Dorchester Hotel meeting, which was relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as strongly supporting his claim that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had an interest in the merged RusAl business.  Again I emphasise, that, in evaluating the direct evidence, and arriving at the conclusion which I have set out above, I have also taken into account this circumstantial evidence in order to test whether my preliminary conclusions on the former should be varied, or, at the least, further informed, by my views on the latter.  I also repeat, that in evaluating Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to the Sibneft issues, and in particular Issue A1, I have taken into account those aspects of the RusAl circumstantial evidence that were relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky as supporting his case that he had an interest in Sibneft shares and Sibneft related profits or generally as going to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s credibility. \r   There is, however, a preliminary point to be made in relation to the circumstantial evidence relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Adkin submitted in his written closing submissions [528] , one has to assess Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s points on the circumstantial evidence against the background of what, in relation to that period, the logic of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case entailed:\r   i)\tAt the centre of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in the Commercial Court Action was the claim that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich fell out spectacularly, very shortly after the arrest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov in early December 2000;  as already described, this involved the allegation that, using Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov as a hostage, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had been instrumental in forcing Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to sell, for a fraction of their true value, first his interests in ORT, and then in Sibneft, and that, in doing so, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had betrayed his promise to procure Mr.\xc2\xa0Glushkov\'s release, not once but twice. ii)\tAgainst that background, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to RusAl required one to accept that, notwithstanding what had allegedly happened in relation to ORT and Sibneft, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was content, after December 2000 and May 2001, to leave his interest in the aluminium business in the hands of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and took no steps to record or document that interest in any way. iii)\tThat case also required one to believe that, whilst asserting an interest in the profits generated by RusAl, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky took no steps to establish what those profits might have been, or what he was entitled to from them, or indeed whether he was being paid any such profits at all (save to say that he assumed Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would have told him if he was not). iv)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case also assumed that, whilst Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was prepared to betray Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in relation to ORT and Sibneft, it was safe for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to assume that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would not do so in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s wholly undocumented interest in RusAl, and indeed would continue to pay him very large sums in respect of such interest for years afterwards. v)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case also required one to accept that, notwithstanding his claimed half share in the $585 million payment made following the sale of the RusAl shares in July 2004, he had no idea what happened to those millions, save for an investment of a portion of them, which he claimed, he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili made in MGOK/Metalloinvest.  As to that investment, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case also required one to believe that, notwithstanding their previous experiences, neither he nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili troubled to document their interest in it. The principal circumstantial evidence relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky related to the following topics:\r   i)\tthe terms of the merger agreements in 2000; ii)\tthe Le Bourget transcript; iii)\tplanning documents of his staff and advisers treating RusAl as his asset; iv)\tthe "Curtis notes"; v)\tthe alleged distribution to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky of RusAl profits;   vi)\tthe sale in 2003 of the first 25% tranche of RusAl shares held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska;   vii)\tthe sale in 2004 of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska via Cliren;  and  viii)\tthe interviews with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili. The terms of the merger agreements Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied on the references to the "partners" of Party 1 (Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich) in the Preliminary Agreement at clauses 4.1 and 4.2 (quoted above) to support his claim to have been an undisclosed party to the Preliminary Agreement.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that, if clauses 4.1 and 4.2 were taken at their face value and given their ordinary and natural meaning, it demonstrated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did indeed have partners who, together with him, were entering into the merger with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  He further submitted that, if it had been the case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich really had had no partners, as the latter contended, then the obvious warranty for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to have given to address Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s concerns would have been a warranty that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had no partners and was acting solely on his own behalf.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also submitted that clause 4.2 was consistent with, and explained the need for, the Dorchester Hotel meeting.  I have already addressed this second point above.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not claim to have been involved in any way in the drafting of the Preliminary Agreement and did not see it at the time.  Indeed, as I have already mentioned, he did not see it until disclosure in these proceedings.  There was no evidence to suggest that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had had anything to do with the drafting of the agreement or had seen it either.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assumption that "partners" referred to him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not supported by the evidence.  There was no evidence to suggest that any of the participants had Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in mind.  The background to the inclusion of the "partner" provisions was the aluminium industry where rivalries and mutual distrust were rife.\r   Four of the individuals who were present at the negotiations leading up to the Preliminary Agreement gave evidence in relation to this point.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that their evidence was mutually inconsistent and incoherent.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions subjected it to a detailed and semantic critique [529] .  However, such inconsistencies as there were, were minor and no more than matters of emphasis.  It was not surprising, in the circumstances, that some of the participants had different motivations for requiring warranties.  The evidence showed that there were a number of underlying concerns which resulted in the use of the term "partners":  first, there was a concern on the Deripaska side, that no part of TWG should be included in the deal;  second, not all of the aluminium assets which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was bringing to the merger were at that time within his control;  it was therefore necessary to provide that he had responsibility for ensuring that the third parties who controlled those assets did what was necessary to enable the merger to take place.\r    Mr.\xc2\xa0Bulygin, the draftsman of the agreement, who, because he was ill, could not attend the trial, described the matter as follows in his witness statement:\r   "13.\tI also recall well the discussion which lay behind the provisions of Clause 4.1 which refers to the principals and their partners warranting that they own the assets.  The reference to partners in Clause 4.1 expressly excludes anyone from TWG.  This was significant.  At the beginning of the discussions, neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska nor I believed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could have purchased the Aluminium Assets and that he had paid such a large sum.  The TWG shareholders had spent so long aggressively acquiring and building up the Aluminium Assets that we could not quite believe that they had relinquished them to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or that they were now out of the industry.  We suspected that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could be a nominal owner only and that we might find ourselves having to deal with our rivals again.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich convinced us, however, that he really had purchased the Aluminium Assets and that he intended to retain them.  I believe there was the same suspicion on the other side about TWG, so the parties included a mutual warranty by which each side expressly disclaimed that anyone from TWG was a partner.  Given the focus of the discussion about TWG, I do not recall any discussion about who, if anyone was a partner of each principal.  For my part I assumed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler was Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s partner.  I am certain that there was no discussion by telephone with, or mention of, either Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky throughout the entire meeting. \xc2\x85 26.\tI never saw Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at any stage of the merger, nor did I ever hear from anyone at that time of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky having an interest in any of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s assets that went into the merger.  I also do not recall any mention of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili having an interest in any of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s assets that went into the merger.  I have never been involved in any business with either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Indeed, I never met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and I have never formally met Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\xc2\x85." In his oral evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich confirmed that he did not have any "partners" in the transaction.  He said that the contract was written precisely to make sure that neither side needed other people\'s warranties and referred to the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had other partners in relation to various plants that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was contributing to the merger.  His evidence was that, by the time that the Preliminary Agreement was signed, at his home later the next day, he was so exhausted that he did not read the document and left it to Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler to read through.  In cross-examination, he said that he believed that it reflected Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s concern to ensure that TWG did not feature in the transaction as undisclosed parties.  He explained that some of the assets which he was contributing to the merger did not belong to him, but to others, and therefore it was necessary for there to be a provision that he was responsible that they would deliver;  in the eyes of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, such people were indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s partners.  He explained that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s concern about the silent involvement of TWG was underlined by the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had not yet fully consolidated ownership of the assets which he was contributing to the merger.  The fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had agreed to sell aluminium assets, to which he yet had to obtain title, was borne out by the evidence.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s evidence was to similar effect.  He was cross-examined on the basis that the reference to "partners" included him, as well as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili;  he denied such suggestion and explained that he was not a partner of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or his companies;  he said that he had understood the reference to partners was simply a reference to third parties (such as owners of other aluminium plants, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had agreed to contribute to the merger) upon whose conduct the practical fulfilment of the merger was dependent.  The reference to the "partners" of the parties (i.e. Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska) was intended as an indication that the parties would take responsibility for ensuring that those stakeholders did what was necessary to ensure that the merger was effective.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz sought to make capital out of the fact that clause 4.2 envisaged such parties actually signing the agreement, and the sellers of the various aluminium plants would not be actually signing up to the merger agreement.  But I did not find that argument persuasive;  apart from the fact that the agreement was a hastily drawn one, the logic would demand that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were intended to sign the agreement - something which was never suggested.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s evidence about the reference to "partners" was to the same effect.  He observed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Bulygin had drafted the document in a hurry and that it would have been much more appropriate to say "interested parties or stakeholders" rather than "partners" [530] .  He explained the commercial context very clearly in his oral evidence:\r   "You see, the assets that Abramovich had acquired at that time were in a rather complex -- complicated condition.  All those factories were on the brink of bankruptcy, including the Achinsk plant, which had already been put under external management, was in administration.  And unless swift action had been started, almost immediately, in order to achieve a recovery from the crisis -- and this is a production that cannot be stopped, this is a continuous production -- even if for one day they had fallen short of feedstock the assets would have been greatly damaged and harmed.  I was interested, I had a vested interest in making sure that everything that we had agreed upon be implemented very, very accurately and clearly in order to save those plants.  Now, for that, all the interested persons had to act together, and that means the suppliers, the managers of those plants, those people who had trade relations with those plants.  And this is exactly what I asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to ensure that it happened, to the extent that that was under his influence  [531] ." Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky put forward similar arguments in relation to the use of the phrase "Other Selling Shareholders" in the 15 March 2000 SPSA and the phrase "Other P1 Shareholders" in the 15 May Restated SPSA.  Again Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky suggested that these phrases clearly reflected the understanding of the parties thereto that there were shareholders other than Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in his companies, and that, in fact, these shareholders were Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser, who was a principal draftsman of the documents, explained that the parties had little time to conduct the ordinary due diligence that would be expected on a transaction of this type, and that there were essentially four reasons why he used the term "Other Selling Shareholders".  In summary, these were:  first, to cater for the possibility that certain of the companies in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was acquiring an interest were held by Abramovich entities other than Runicom;  second, because it was unclear whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies had completed the acquisition of all of the shares in the underlying companies which were to be sold to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska;  third, because of a suspicion on Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s side that TWG still had some kind of an interest in the assets that were being sold, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser was concerned to ensure that the agreement was enforceable even if it transpired that TWG did still have such an interest;  fourth, there was a possibility that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had partners himself - although the person that Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser and Mr.\xc2\xa0Schneider focused on in this regard was Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler (who was running the deal negotiations), and no other names were mentioned in this connection.  More generally, Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser said that there was no mention of either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the negotiations for this agreement [532] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser\'s recollection was that in the course of the negotiations there was no sensitivity or issue raised on either side regarding naming other partners and that formed no part of the motivation for the inclusion of the somewhat ambiguous phrase "Other Selling Shareholders".  He also referred to the fact that the companies owning the underlying assets were bearer share companies, which meant that the language had to ensure that what they understood to be the position remained the position [533] ;  the phrase was therefore drafted in the broadest possible way.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum (who was also involved in the negotiations from the Abramovich side) gave a similar explanation to that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser.  It was for essentially the same reasons that a similar phrase ("Other P1 Shareholders") was used in the 15 May Restated SPSA.  Again, neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s names were mentioned in this connection.\r   Once again, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions contained an extensive and detailed analysis as to why it was said that the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum was unsatisfactory;  and why Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum could not have offered the warranty which, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, he should have been offering (namely a warranty that he was the sole beneficial owner of the four Offshore Companies), "because both Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (and indeed Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska) knew that it would have been untrue" [534] . I do not accept that criticism.  I can see every reason why, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum explained, it would have been undesirable and unnecessary for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself to have given a personal warranty or guarantee that Runicom was the sole beneficial owner of the shares in the Offshore Companies;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not even a party to the 15 March SPSA, and it would not have been appropriate for him to have become a party in a personal capacity;  and there was simply no need to investigate, or reveal, the corporate or trust structures under which the Offshore Companies were held or had been acquired.\r   In the light of all the evidence which I heard from those who were concerned with the drafting of these documents, and which I accept, I cannot attach the significance that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s submissions seek to place on these words.\r   The Le Bourget transcript Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended that the Le Bourget transcript was "compelling evidence" that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had an interest in RusAl.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument based on the Le Bourget transcript depended on the use by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of the word "we" when referring to his holding in the merged aluminium business - RusAl.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the use by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of the plural "we" was an admission that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich held the RusAl shares together with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  The relevant Boxes relied upon were Boxes 497 - 514 which read as follows:\r   497 B: The same will have to be done with Aluminium. 498 A. What do you mean by \'the same\'? 499 B: With Aluminium, need (to do the same) 500 A. You cannot do anything with Aluminium, that\'s for sure. 501 B: Why not? 502 A. We only hold 50 per cent there, so the other party has to agree. 503 B: (So what)?... 504 A. And they will demand the same, will demand the same.  Tax affairs haven\'t been regulated yet for Aluminium, so there is no point in applying this [scheme] there.  It would significantly reduce income.  Besides, you will have to wait in line to receive dividends. 505 B: Fine, what I\'m saying is\xc2\x85 in any case, the time will come, finally\xc2\x85 nnn\xc2\x85 506 A. Nnn\xc2\x85 with Aluminium it is very simple.  If we go legal, they would have to do the same.  They can\'t have one half legalised, and the other half - not. 507 B: I agree, so\xc2\x85 This 508 A. (Then they) will all appear:  Bykov, Misha, Anton and Aksyon, and Oleg Deripaska and (his)\xc2\x85 nnn\xc2\x85 companies nobody would even talk [to them / to it / to us / about it].  You don\'t agree with this, do you? 509 B: Nnn\xc2\x85 I have a different view (all the time). 510 A. Well then, now I have a different one.  (Perhaps we are) in such a situation, that (they)\xc2\x85 511 B: Nnn...a completely different view.  You know, they all understand everything already.  It will never ever be possible to prove to anyone or anybody that I (haven\'t moved residence).  This, nobody is prepared to believe it.  You can (say) whatever you like.  Let\'s believe it is not so. 512 A. They don\'t think it\'s wrong.  The only thing which stops them from talking to us seriously, is just a feeling, a hunch that you might be there.  This is the only thing which is stopping them. 513 B: Roma, but I can tell you (that we have now), we\'ve spent a lot of time (for the West)... 514 A. I\'ve understood all your arguments...I know you, you said...nnn...spent a lot of time (but not on this subject).... [Emphasis as supplied in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s closing submissions] Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz also submitted that this passage demonstrated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was refusing to allow Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to formalise their interests in Sibneft and RusAl not because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich rejected any suggestion that those ownership interests existed, but rather because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that he was not prepared officially to document his relationship with either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   I do not accept those submissions.  This section of the transcript quoted above followed immediately upon a passage in which the three men were discussing the means by which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could continue to pay Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the light of the re-organisation of his trading companies.  As I have already described, the subject of the discussion at the Le Bourget meeting was what should be done to "legalise" Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s receipts, i.e. to ensure that the money that was paid to him would be received in a way that would satisfy Western banks\' money laundering rules.  Again as I have already described, up to this date, whenever Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had wanted money, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had simply been able to draw on funds from his trading companies.  However, from the end of 2000, the trading operations of those companies were being integrated into Sibneft, with the result that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s main source of cash would become Sibneft dividends, which were only payable on a six monthly basis.  One proposal (which I have already referred to above) was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili might become registered shareholders in Sibneft for the purpose of receiving their payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich from an apparently legitimate source (Boxes 451 to 496).  \r   At Box 497, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky started the discussion about aluminium by saying that "the same will have to be done with Aluminium".  In his written commentary on the transcript, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that this appeared to be a suggestion that he (Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) should become a registered shareholder in RusAl.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument was based on the use of the word "we" in the response "We only hold 50 per cent there" in Box 502.  In context, and given the evidence which I heard from both men in relation to the Le Bourget meeting, and RusAl generally, I do not consider that the word "we" has got to be read in the way contended for by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, i.e. as referring to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as, effectively, a partnership unit.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that he used the word "we" to mean his side as opposed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s side.  As was submitted in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s written closing submissions [535] , not only were there other places in the recording where Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich commonly used "we" to refer to things which he or his businesses had done, but Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich also emphasised that he generally used the term "we" rather than "I" when referring to his companies.  Had I been more impressed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence in relation to the RusAl and other issues, I might have been able to place some weight on this passage in the transcript as supporting his case;  as it was, it was no more than a lightweight semantic point.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also sought to rely on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s statement that "you will have to wait in line to receive dividends" at Box 504.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that there was no reason why Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have had any interest in dividends from RusAl, if, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich contended, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had nothing whatever to do with the aluminium interests;  there would had been no basis for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to have waited in line at all.  But, taken in context, one can see, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s comment was a response to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s suggestion that he should become a shareholder in RusAl in order to receive payments in the future, rather than any recognition of an existing interest. \r   Planning documents of his staff and advisers treating RusAl as his asset Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky next sought to rely on various materials, all of which were generated after March 2000 and were internal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and their staff and professional advisers, such as Valmet/MTM.  I have already considered these documents to a certain extent above in the context of my determination of the Sibneft issues.  They were:\r   i)\tan undated "Explanatory Note" referring to the payment of $100 million commission to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili; ii)\ta brief biography of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili; iii)\ta structure chart apparently accompanying it, said to date from before 21 April 2000; iv)\tthe list of documents; v)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Samuelson\'s Inter-Office Memorandum, dated 5 September 2000;  and  vi)\tan email from Mr.\xc2\xa0Samuelson to a Mr.\xc2\xa0Maillard attaching structure charts for the Hotspur and Octopus trusts. In the RusAl context, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz relied on the fact that some of these documents appeared to have been based on the premise, or assumption, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had an interest in the merged aluminium business, i.e. RusAl.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not call any witnesses to explain the circumstances in which these documents were drafted, by whom, or for what purpose or otherwise to explain their content.  He himself was not able to give any such evidence, as, by his own admission, he had not been involved, and indeed was never involved, in the detailed arrangements of his own financial affairs.  However, what was clear from the evidence, and as I find, was that they were produced without any input from, or knowledge on the part of, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich or any of his staff or advisers.  Moreover, by this time (2000 and thereafter), as I have already explained when dealing with these documents earlier, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili recognised the need appropriately to document the provenance of their funds in order to comply with Western anti-money-laundering procedures.  Many of the documents appear to have been designed for the purpose of showing Western bankers or professional advisers or trustees (such as Mr.\xc2\xa0Samuelson) so as to enable arrangements to be made for the receipt of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s funds in the West, in what might be referred to as a "legitimate" way.  It is against that background that the weight of such evidence falls to be evaluated.\r   It is likely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, at one time Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s financial adviser, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay, at one time Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s financial adviser, might have been able to have given relevant evidence about these matters, and indeed various other matters.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did not choose to call either of these men, having apparently fallen out with both of them [536] .  At various stages in argument [537] , it was submitted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should have called Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as a witness and indeed that it was an "oddity" that he had not done so.  Furthermore Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz invited the court to draw various adverse inferences from what was characterised as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s "failure" to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  I address this particular issue below in the context of the Curtis notes, where I explain why I disagree with the submission.  For present purposes it is enough to say that, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky chose to rely on various internal financial memoranda as supporting his case on this issue, but did not want to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, or Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay, that was a matter for him;  but, in those circumstances, he had to bear the consequence that, necessarily, the court would attach limited weight to such material.\r   The Explanatory Note, which referred to a payment of $100 million commission to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, was relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to support his case not only that the Patarkatsishvili commission agreements were shams, but also to support the case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had ownership interests in relation to both Sibneft and the aluminium assets.  The memorandum, which was undated and anonymous, spoke of a stage in an envisaged process whereby "the assets belonging to the partners [i.e. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili] in the main business projects" would be distributed;  the listed assets included interests in LogoVAZ, "the aluminium complex", Sibneft, ORT and Aeroflot.  It appeared that the Explanatory Note had been prepared for the purposes of presentation to Valmet, or Mr.\xc2\xa0Jenni, or other professional advisers of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, probably sometime in or about April 2000.  It, together with the second, third and fourth documents mentioned above, appeared to have been part of a package of documents which was intended to be sent, but which was never in fact sent, to Mr.\xc2\xa0Jenni, who denied in his evidence receiving it.  The overwhelming likelihood is that the Explanatory Note was prepared in connection with the "legalisation" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s funds outside Russia - in other words to present the picture that the two men had ownership in various assets that would explain their income streams.\r   The Explanatory Note was subjected to an extensive evidential analysis in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions to support the propositions,  inter alia  that it was authored by Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov advised Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky about structuring his arrangements in relation to RusAl subject to "British law", and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov had knowledge of its contents.  These submissions were amplified in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s Second Schedule at pages 256-257 by a new linguistic analysis of the Russian text, to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky\'s authorship of the Explanatory Note was apparent from a comparison of the language, syntax and layout of the Note with three other Russian language documents that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged were authored by Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky.  This in turn gave rise to supplementary written closing submissions from the Anisimov defendants served on 6 March 2012 and yet further written response submissions served by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky on 13 March 2012.  This linguistic analysis was not put to Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky in cross-examination, although he was cross examined on the Explanatory Note at length.  Nor was it supported by the evidence of a Russian linguistic expert.  In those circumstances I am not prepared to attach any weight to the new linguistic analysis.\r   I reject the three contentions put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to the effect that the Explanatory Note was authored by Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov advised Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky about structuring his arrangements in relation to RusAl subject to "British law", and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov had knowledge of its contents;  the evidence did not support these contentions.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky convincingly denied authorship of the memorandum in cross-examination and there was no sensible reason why he should have prepared it;  in particular, it is highly unlikely that he would have referred to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as "the clients".  I also accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence that he gave no such advice to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Thus I accept the analysis put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Malek in his oral closing and supplemental submissions in relation to these four documents, as well as that put forward on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in his written and oral closing submissions.  I conclude that the most likely author of the document was Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay, although that point is immaterial to my conclusion that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov had any knowledge of its contents.  The document wrongly asserts that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had ownership interests in Aeroflot.  Moreover, contrary to the submissions put forward on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, the detailed information relating, for example, to the vendors of the pre-merger aluminium assets contained in the structure chart, that was apparently intended to be part of the package of documents, and the other three documents referred to above, would all have been available to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as a party to the Preliminary Agreement, and the commission agreements, and as somebody involved, in his capacity as intermediary, in the facilitation of the ten individual sale and purchase contracts referred to above.  \r   Likewise, for similar reasons little reliance can be placed on the Samuelson material, namely his Inter-Office memorandum and the e-mail attaching structure charts for the Hotspur and Octopus trusts.  I have already addressed these documents in the context of the Sibneft issues.  The information contained therein would have been derived from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Kay.  Moreover none of the steps which the Samuelson material contemplated being taken - namely the placing of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interests in Sibneft or RusAl into trusts - was ever put into effect.  Thus whilst Mr.\xc2\xa0Samuelson may have been told that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili owned such assets in order to reassure him as to the source of the funds which he was going to receive (which were said to be derived from their assets), such assets were in fact never placed, or purportedly placed, into any structures set up by him.\r   Accordingly I do not place any weight on these materials as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he had an ownership interest in RusAl.  Once again, if I had been more convinced by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own direct evidence about the RusAl issues, I might have considered attaching some weight to what professional advisers such as Valmet were being told;  but even on that hypothesis, such materials would have carried very little weight, given what little evidence there was about the circumstances in which they were generated and the fact that, certainly in relation to Aeroflot, they misrepresented the position.  \r   The "Curtis Notes" I have already briefly referred to the Curtis notes in the context of the Sibneft issues and referred to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\' role in connection with the Spectrum and Devonia transactions.  The available evidence about the provenance of the notes was that Ms.\xc2\xa0Flynn, a night secretary at Curtis & Co in 2003 and 2004, recalls that the notes were handed to her one evening by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, who told her that they were vitally important.  She noted this fact on a post-it sticker which she placed on the notes when she copied them.  She could not recall when she was handed the notes by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and the notes themselves are undated.  Although they necessarily must have been produced by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis prior to his death in March 2004, there was no evidence as to whether they were made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis actually at the meeting which they purported to record, or sometime thereafter.  They had been written in Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis\' manuscript.\r   The notes purported to record a meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at his house in Georgia in the summer of 2003, attended by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, an unidentified man referred to as "Igor" and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum.  The relevance of the notes, if they were indeed a true record of what was discussed, was that they purport to record discussions, to which Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum was said to have been a party, which assumed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had been shareholders in Sibneft along with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich;  that they had sold those interests via a structure which had been complicated and costly;  and that at the time of the meeting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had a 25% interest in RusAl, as did Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  The notes purported to record discussions concerning (among other things) the means by which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili might sell out of RusAl and sell their stake back to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  \r   In his oral closing submissions, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz in effect submitted that there could be no half-way house so far as the court\'s conclusion in relation to the Curtis notes was concerned;  the court had two choices:  either they were authentic notes accurately recording a discussion to which Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum was party, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky submitted they were;  or they were "a deliberate forgery created by an English solicitor, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, and created for some reason which has never been adequately explained by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich" [538] .  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written [539]  and oral [540]  closing submissions contain a detailed analysis of some of the evidence relating to this issue.  \r   I conclude, on the basis of all the evidence, that the Curtis notes were not a direct or contemporaneous record of anything discussed in the presence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum on the occasion of his one and only visit to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s summer house in Batumi, Georgia, on what, as was common ground, and as supported by the flight records, was 25 August 2003.  It is not necessary for me to decide whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili alone was dishonest in possibly suggesting to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum had indeed had the discussions in Russian, which the notes purport to record (Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis not being able to speak or understand Russian);  or whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, either alone, or together with, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, was dishonest in purporting to record that such discussions had taken place in English in Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s presence, as the notes appear to suggest;  although I consider that the hypothesis that both men were dishonest is the more likely.  If it were necessary to do so, I would not have difficulty in holding that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was indeed dishonest in this respect, despite the fact that he was, to use Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s words, "an English solicitor".  His conduct in relation to the Spectrum and Devonia transactions demonstrated, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s closing submissions somewhat euphemistically put it:\r   "\xc2\x85 a track record of recording meetings so as to create a desirable, rather than necessarily truthful, version of events [541] ." or, in more blunt language, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis was quite prepared to manufacture sham documents where it suited his clients\' purposes and created a significant fee opportunity for himself. In summary, my reasons for this conclusion, and the relevant facts, as I find them, are as follows:\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum was the only witness who gave evidence in relation to this meeting.  Despite the extensive challenge to his evidence in cross-examination, and the lengthy critique in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s closing submissions, I found him to be a patently honest and reliable witness.  Obviously, he was loyal to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  But, although that factor necessarily had to be taken into account in my evaluation, it did not detract from what I regarded as the underlying veracity of his evidence.  In 2003 Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum was the managing director of the company now known as MHC (Services) Limited ("MHC"), based in London, a consultancy service company which provided consulting and administrative support to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  He had previously been the head of corporate finance at Sibneft and had been part of the working group responsible for the implementation of agreements between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to merge their respective aluminium interests into RusAl.  However, his involvement with RusAl had been limited to certain aspects of the shareholders\' agreement between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, as such agreements typically involved concepts with which he was more familiar, given his background in corporate finance and international mergers and acquisitions, when at Salomon Brothers.  He had just been involved in Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s acquisition of Chelsea Football Club, which had completed in July 2003, and it was largely to discuss football that he went to see Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili. ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum explained the reason for his trip to meet Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and the nature of the so-called "meeting", in his witness statement as follows.  : "86.\tI met Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Georgia on one occasion in 2003 (at a meeting at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not present), which I believe to have been in the late summer/early autumn of 2003 because I can recall that I had been heavily engaged in the acquisition of Chelsea Football Club and its aftermath at the time of the visit (that transaction completed in July 2003).  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told me that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had invited him to his seaside home to see the house, which had recently been completed, and to discuss with him the possibility of an investment in a football club.  Because of a Russian arrest warrant issued against Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, he was not able to travel outside Georgia.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich asked me if I could attend in his place as a sign of respect to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  I was in Moscow at the time and had no desire to go but, given my involvement with Chelsea Football Club, I reluctantly agreed.  I travelled to Batumi, Georgia, in a chartered aircraft, and was then transported by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s helicopter to his house. \xc2\x85 89.\tI recall that there were ten or so adults at the beach house and there were wives and children around.  This was not a Western-style sit-down lunch, but rather a very informal gathering with people coming and going throughout the time I was there.  I was taken on a brief tour of the house, but I spent the rest of the time outside, where food was served, with the other guests and family.  In addition to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, I recall that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev was there.  I had met Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev before and knew him slightly.  Additionally, I do recall that there was one gentleman who I took to be English, or perhaps American, who could have been Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, but I had not met him before and I have not seen him since.  I believe I may have spoken with him briefly in English (I do not recall that he spoke any Russian, unlike the other guests), but this would have been nothing more than polite conversation - not about business matters.  I did not take particular notice of this person.   90.\tAll I can remember discussing with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was the recently announced acquisition by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich of Chelsea Football Club, and I recall Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili saying that this had been a great idea and wanting to do the same.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili raised the fact that he had some contacts in Brazilian football and enquired whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had any interest in making an investment along with him.  As I recall, he was hoping that this would enable him to travel to Brazil, despite the arrest warrant.  He felt that he had acquired a negative image and said that he was hoping to get the same kind of positive publicity in Brazil as he saw Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich as having obtained in England.  He was very excited about this idea.  I assured him that I would speak to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich about the proposal.  I have a recollection that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili also mentioned that he had contacts in Georgian football circles and, I believe, he said that he had made an investment in Dynamo Tbilisi (a prominent Georgian football club).  He may also have asked whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would like to be involved in an investment in that club, but I cannot now be sure. 91.\tI stayed at the house for approximately two hours and then left to return to the airport where I took another charter flight, this time to Nice where Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was staying.  I passed the details of my conversation about investing in football clubs on to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich when I met with him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told me that he had no interest in investing, but that he was ready to consider assisting Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in his venture.  I then continued my return flight back to Luton and home in London.  The following year Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili did invest in the Brazilian club Corinthians along with a partner, Kia Joorabchian.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not provide any assistance in relation to the investment." I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence, as set out above, that this was an informal open air meeting as opposed to a commercial meeting.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had held an investment in Dynamo Tbilisi (a prominent Georgian football club) since 2001, and he was interested in generating some positive publicity for himself in order to improve his image in the way in which, in his view, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had done by acquiring Chelsea F.C.  It was common ground that around a year later, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was indeed engaged in negotiations for the purchase of a Brazilian football club.  I reject the assertion, made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz in cross-examination, that, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s negotiations in relation to Brazilian football did not take place until August 2004, the topic of football was unlikely to have been the subject matter of conversation at the meeting in Batumi in 2003.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum described, and as one might expect, the acquisition of Chelsea FC was a, if not the, principal topic of discussion between Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at the luncheon party.  \r   I accept that any conversation between the two men and Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev would have been conducted in Russian.  I accept that, irrespective of the extent of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s grasp of the English language, Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum would not have spoken in any other language than Russian to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Unlike the others present, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis did not speak Russian.  It therefore follows that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis could not have been directly recording in any note what was being said between Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  That was however directly contrary to the impression given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis in his Notes, which suggested that he was recording detailed business discussions in English.  I also accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence that no one was taking a note of what were social conversations at an open-air lunch.  I also accept his evidence that, if he had seen anyone taking a note, he would have asked for a copy of it.  \r   The entirety of Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence was wholly inconsistent with the notion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum had had the detailed discussions purportedly recorded in the Curtis notes.  He had never met Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis before and had never previously done business with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Nor was Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis well-known to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum was adamant that he did not discuss the ownership or sale of RusAl.  He knew little about it and indeed the matters purportedly covered in the notes were outside his knowledge and expertise.  I found his explanation that he had had only a limited role in the acquisition of RusAl, and would not, without specific instructions, have discussed Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s private business affairs in front of the people present, to have been entirely credible.\r   There was an extensive thesis developed on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that only Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum would have known some of the information contained in the Curtis notes.  It is not necessary for me to engage in any detailed analysis of this evidence.  Suffice it to say that a considerable amount of information about the structure of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s ownership interest in RusAl, and, in particular, the use of bearer share companies in the BVI, would have been available to Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s other representatives and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as a result of the $1.3 billion payment to Devonia, which had been structured through dividend payments from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s aluminium interests;  likewise, various details of his ownership interest in RusAl,  the aluminium trading company, had been made available to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s representatives in connection with other payments.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili himself would, as I have already mentioned, have had knowledge of certain of the offshore companies used in the context of his role as an intermediary in the conclusion of the Preliminary Agreement and the ten individual sale and purchase contracts.  Moreover, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own Particulars of Claim expressly recognised, the 50-50 split of ownership between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in respect of RusAl had been publicly announced by as early as 4 April 2001 and had been expressly confirmed in correspondence prior to Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s visit to Georgia in the context of certain commission payments.\r   There was, as I find, every reason why, by the time of the Patarkatsishvili lunch in August 2003, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis might have been keen to have "created evidence" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s asserted interests in aluminium assets.  In February 2003 Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that he was considering ending his joint venture with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in relation to aluminium;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that this would have involved settlement of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s outstanding commission.  This would have raised in Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s mind the problem of "legalising" any funds received in a manner that would have satisfied the anti-money-laundering compliance procedures of Western banks.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had previously suggested in late 2000 that future payments by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could be "legalised" by transferring shares in Sibneft to them so that they could receive payment of dividends and justify their receipts in that manner.  That, as I have already described, was a topic discussed at the Le Bourget meeting.  The evidence suggested that a similar scheme was being considered by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, shortly after the former\'s meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in February 2003, when Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili instructed Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis to prepare a draft memorandum of understanding between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, which would, if executed, have provided for the transfer of the shares in a company owning 25% of RusAl to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (but not to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky) for a nominal amount, following which the shares were to be sold back to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  But the problem which Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis faced, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s legal adviser, as he had pointed out in 2000 in relation to the alleged interest in Sibneft, was the absence of any written record that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had ever had an interest in RusAl.  I conclude that the likelihood is that Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis wrote the Curtis notes in order to generate evidence of such an interest.  As was recorded in the notes themselves, it was important "to create proof of ownership to show where/why proceeds of his own sales are derived".  Whilst I do not need to make any particular finding in this respect, I am unable to attach any evidential weight to these notes as supporting Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to an interest in RusAl.\r   In this context, it would be somewhat surprising, if the Curtis notes indeed recorded a genuine meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili never mentioned to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors, in 2005 or 2007, any meeting in Batumi (or elsewhere) with Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum at which the RusAl assets were discussed.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili appears to have told them that he first heard about Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s sale to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska "through the market", and indicated that he was unhappy to learn of it.  If he had met with a representative of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich a matter of months before the sale and discussed RusAl, it is almost inconceivable that he would not have mentioned it.  Similarly, whereas Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s draft proof indicated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wanted to stay in the aluminium industry, and in particular wanted to stay in business with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the Curtis notes record a suggestion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili wanted to sell to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   I found Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence on this topic cogent and credible.  Contrary to the submissions made in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s closing submissions, I did not find him to be either evasive, discomfited or "forced to admit" significant matters adverse to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case in cross-examination.  He was an impressive witness.  \r   The absence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as a witness There are two subsidiary, but related, points, which I need to mention in the context of the Curtis notes and also in a wider context.  The first addresses certain evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum for the first time in re-examination, and then in further cross-examination, in respect of Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev;  the second relates to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s argument that adverse inferences should be drawn by the court from what was referred to as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s "failure" to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, a topic to which I have already briefly referred above.  \r   In re-examination, in response to the question:  "What enables you to be certain that no note was being taken at the meeting [at Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s house in Georgia]?", Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum for the first time gave double hearsay evidence to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had told Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and others, about six months prior to trial, that the Curtis notes had been compiled after Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum had left the Patarkatsishvili luncheon party and that they had been dictated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis.  That evidence had not appeared in any of Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s or Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler\'s previous witness statements.  In further cross-examination by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz on this issue, Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum gave evidence that, in the context of a discussion as to whether to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as a witness, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev forwarded to Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler a text message said to be from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky which Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev read as a threat from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, which Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev said gave rise to concerns for his safety.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum described the text message as being along the following lines:\r   "A\t\xc2\x85:  \'I know you\'re helping them.  I\'m watching you.  I\'m listening to your phone calls.  I\'m controlling your Skype.\'  And I think he referred to Dr.\xc2\xa0Evil, \'I\'m Dr.\xc2\xa0Evil\', something to that effect. Q.\t\tSo you say Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky signed himself off as \'Dr.\xc2\xa0Evil\' in this? A.\t\tCorrect."   In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions it was submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, "\xc2\x85 in an attempt to discredit Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and dishonestly to promote Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case" had "fabricated a story" about the "Dr.\xc2\xa0Evil" text message, which discredited both Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum as witnesses;  and that it was inconceivable that such a damning text message would have been deleted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler if he had ever received it [542] .\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption explained that he was not prepared to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as a witness, not only because Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had been, throughout the relevant period, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s agent, but also because it was part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had been engaged in the preparation of sham documents for the purposes of laundering Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s money.  For that reason, as well as the one referred to below, he did not rely on the above aspects of Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence (i.e. both relating to the alleged subsequent dictation of the Curtis notes by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and the text message), since he said that he could not properly deploy hearsay evidence derived from Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev, in circumstances where he would not have been willing to call him as a witness in response to a counter-notice.  However Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption rebutted the suggestion that the evidence was fabricated and submitted that there was no evidence to support that proposition.\r   In correspondence between the parties\' respective solicitors following Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence, Skadden, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s solicitors, stated that, in accordance with his usual practice, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler had deleted the message from his BlackBerry smartphone shortly after he had received it;  that the BlackBerry had been forensically tested by IT experts instructed by Skadden "\xc2\x85 on behalf of our client", with a view to establishing whether the message could be retrieved;  but that, as a result of the inherent limitations of the recovery process, and the manner in which messages marked as "deleted" in the memory on the handset were subsequently randomly overwritten by the smartphone\'s operating system, it had not been possible to recover the message;  and, accordingly, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum confirmed the accuracy of the evidence which he had given to the Court, concerning the text message, in view of the fact that it had not been possible to produce the message in question, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not propose to rely on that aspect of Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s testimony.  \r   In the light of the understandable approach adopted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s counsel and solicitors in relation to these two aspects of Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence, I have not relied in any way on such evidence in arriving at my conclusions about what occurred at the Patarkatsishvili luncheon party or about the Curtis notes.  Nor have I relied upon such evidence in any other way, whether as casting light upon the reasons why Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev was not called as a witness, or as adversely reflecting upon Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s or Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, their respective credibility, or otherwise.  However, contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submissions, and consistent with my approach of disregarding this evidence in its entirety, I am not prepared to accept that the evidence was untrue in the sense of having been dishonestly fabricated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and/or by Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted, there was no evidence to support such an allegation.  Whilst not tested by cross-examination, or supported by forensic evidence at trial, the explanation given in correspondence by Skadden as to why the message had been deleted, and why it could not be retrieved was, on its face, reasonable.  If Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had wanted to base allegations of dishonesty against the two men on this material, then an application would have needed to have been made to recall Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler for further cross-examination, and to subject his smart phone, or the findings of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s IT consultants, to further scrutiny.  \r   No adverse inference to be drawn from the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev I turn next to deal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission that the court should draw adverse inferences from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s alleged "failure" to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as a witness.  The thrust of this submission was that, if called, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev would have been unable truthfully to support Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case on Sibneft ownership, on the circumstances of the Sibneft sale, or on the RusAl dealings, and, in particular, would not have supported:\r   i)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that there was no partnership between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on the one hand and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on the other; ii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence as to the \'proposals\' supposedly made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev in advance of the Le Bourget meeting, which I have referred to above;   iii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that the Devonia Agreement was a sham;  or iv)\t Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum\'s evidence that the Georgia meeting with Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, as recorded in the Curtis notes, did not occur.   It was further submitted that these were: "\xc2\x85 all matters of intense dispute between the parties upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev could have given relevant first-hand evidence"; that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his team were on perfectly good terms with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev;  and that the reasons put forward by Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption were not good reasons for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich not having called him. It was indeed the case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev could have given relevant evidence in relation to a number of areas of dispute between the parties.  He was based in London and therefore susceptible to a witness summons.  Both sides had had some contact with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev in relation to these proceedings.  For example, in the course of the summary judgment proceedings, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had relied upon various statements made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s lawyers in 2007, although they had subsequently fallen out;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side had also had some contact with Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev during the course of the proceedings from April 2009 onwards, but the evidence did not demonstrate, contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submission, that such contacts had been extensive or that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev "was willing to assist Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s team on request".  The reasons Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky gave for not wishing to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev were not limited to the fact that the two men had fallen out as a result of the North Shore litigation;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky went on to describe in explicit terms how he now regarded Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as untrustworthy and a liar.\r   The parties agreed that whether or not the court should draw adverse inferences from the fact that one party had not called a particular witness was heavily dependent on the particular circumstances of the case;  one test was whether a party "could not realistically" have been expected to have called the witness in question;  see  Wisniewski v Central Manchester Health Authority  [1998] PIQR 324 .\r   Contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submissions, which, to my mind, had an air of unreality about them in relation to this point, I conclude that no adverse inference could or should be drawn against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for not having called Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  Apart from the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had been Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s financial adviser, confidant and agent in all the relevant matters in relation to which he would have been called to give evidence, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption submitted, it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev had been involved in the generation of sham documents for the purposes of laundering Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s funds.  I see no basis upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich could have "realistically" called Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev as a witness, only for Mr.\xc2\xa0Sumption to have attempted to suggest to him in chief, in effect, that he was a dishonest liar.  Notwithstanding Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s attempt to formulate the matters in respect of which he submitted that adverse inferences should be drawn against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, as ostensibly matters which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had to prove, the reality was that burden of proof, and the evidential onus, in relation to the critical issues in respect of which Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev\'s evidence was relevant (e.g. that, under the terms of the Devonia Agreement, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili sold their interests in Sibneft;  that the Curtis notes demonstrated that the two men had an interest in RusAl), lay fairly and squarely on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  I therefore reject the submission that any adverse inferences should be drawn against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich because, understandably, he chose not to call Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev.  \r   The alleged distribution to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky of RusAl profits The next matter upon which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied to support his allegation that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had an interest in RusAl was the fact that, between 2003 and 2005, two companies associated with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, namely Blue Water Resources Inc and Rich Brown Enterprises Ltd, received $175 million from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s contention was that these sums were payments of RusAl dividends in respect of his and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s ownership interests in RusAl.
