This issue in fact corresponded to Issue 22 in the Agreed List of Issues, which was formulated as follows:\r   "Were payments of $50 million to Blue Water Resources Inc in 2003, and $125 million to Rich Brown Enterprises Limited from 2003 to 2005, payments of RusAl profits;  or were they part of a payment of interest and "commission" in relation to the $1.3 billion?" The underlying facts relating to this issue were complex and extensively rehearsed in the respective parties\' closing submissions.  In summary:\r   i)\tIt appeared not to be in dispute [543]  that sums totalling $377.5 million were paid from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili during the period 2002 to 2004.  The dispute between the parties centred on the nature of these payments and whether the $175 million was part of the larger payment of $377.5 million. ii)\tIt was common ground that, at some stage after the $1.3 billion "pay-off" agreement referred to above was agreed, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili approached Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and asked for some form of further payment to compensate for the commission payments which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been obliged to pay in relation to the $1.3 billion.  The only dispute on this issue was the outcome of that approach. iii)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich gave evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili made his request some time in 2002, when the two men had had a meeting probably in Tbilisi.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili asked him for more money on the basis that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had not received the full benefit of the $1.3 billion pay-off previously agreed since: a)\tit had been paid in a number of instalments over a period of time, with no compensating payment for loss of interest;  and  b)\ta substantial commission had been paid to a Sheikh to "legalise" the transaction. Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that was the first occasion on which he had learnt of the involvement of the Sheikh as the intermediary to transfer the payments made to Western banks.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said that, after some negotiation, he agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to pay a further $377.5 million in total, to be made in instalments, in order to compensate him and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky in relation to the commission payments and loss of interest.  Payments in that total amount were made to companies designated by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and/or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in instalments between mid-2002 and early 2005.  In cross-examination it was suggested that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had made up the meeting and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had never asked him to pay further amounts by way of commission.  That was a somewhat surprising suggestion given that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had spoken to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich about the topic. iv)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence was that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had discussed the question of asking Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to make a payment in compensation for these matters, but that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili subsequently told him that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had refused to make any further payment in relation to the $1.3 billion.  He said that the $175 million received by Blue Water Resources and Rich Brown Enterprises represented dividends or profit shares in respect of their aluminium interests.  He did not appear to have had any explanation in respect of the balance of the $202.5 million which was subsequently paid. v)\tThere was no dispute that the payments were made from Rual Trade Limited ("Rual"), which was an aluminium trading company jointly owned (indirectly) by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, which traded with the RusAl group.  However, I did not accept the inference which Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to draw from this fact, namely that the payments represented RusAl profits.  Funds from Rual were also used to finance the Devonia payments pursuant to the $1.3 billion pay-off arrangement;  but Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky never suggested that the Devonia payments represented profits due to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in respect of their ownership of aluminium assets, simply because Rual was the source of the payment.  As was submitted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, the reality was that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich made his payments to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili from whatever cash funds within his businesses were conveniently available at the time.  The fact that dividend distributions from Rual were the  mechanism  of payment did not reflect the reason for the payment;  such payments from Rual were not equivalent to dividend payments from  RusAl  in respect of any alleged ownership interest. I preferred the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to this issue.  First, Mr.\xc2\xa0 Berezovsky was unable to give any positive evidence to support his case that the $377.5 million represented payments of RusAl profit shares rather than commission-related payments.  He had no knowledge of the profits of RusAl and had made no enquiries about them.  He said in his witness statement that \r   "I believe that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich paid profits to Badri and me from our RusAl interest - and I am sure that Badri would have told me if this had not happened - but I do not know the sums or mechanisms involved [544] ." Second, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky admitted that the suggestion that the $377.5 million were payments in respect of RusAl profits had not come from him but had been derived from his lawyer\'s analysis of the documents.  As regards the $175m payments, he disclaimed any recollection of them, saying:  \r   "I\'m almost sure that this knowledge of Mr.\xc2\xa0Marino got not from myself directly;  maybe he analyse[d the] papers [545] ." Accordingly, Mr, Berezovsky could give no direct evidence on whether or not the payments were indeed commission payments.   Third, it was clear that, on the previous occasion on which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had paid substantial sums to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili which had to be "legalised" in the West, in respect of the purchase of their ORT shares, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had in fact agreed to contribute to the commission costs incurred in the process of "legalisation".\r   Fourth, Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis treated the payments in a manner consistent with their having been related to the Devonia transaction:  he sought to take the balance of his commission on that transaction (some $4.5 million) from one of them.\r   Fifth, the timing of the payments supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account.  The payments did not start until after the time of the meeting between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in 2002.  Had Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky been entitled to receive RusAl profit payments, then, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, such profit payments should also have been made in 2000 and 2001.  There were no such payments during those years;  this was demonstrated by an analysis of the figures in the Bolshoi Balance, and of the evidence of Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko.\r   Sixth, although a point in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s favour in relation to this issue was the absence of any documentation to support Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s explanation of the reasons for the payment, the fact was that it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence that a meeting had taken place at which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had made a specific request for an additional sum to compensate the two men for their additional expenditure in legalising the $1.3 billion.  Thus Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s own evidence supported such a purpose for the payment.  Whilst I have taken the absence of documentation into account in reaching my conclusion, it does not persuade me to reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence.\r   Seventh, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky relied upon various other attendance notes and documents which he submitted supported his case on this issue.  In particular he relied upon communications between Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling of Denton Wilde Sapte, in his capacity as trustee of the Itchen Trust, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Andre De Cort ("Mr.\xc2\xa0De Cort"), who, at the time, was in-house counsel for Millhouse Capital UK Limited (subsequently MHC Services Ltd, one of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies).  Mr.\xc2\xa0Keeling was concerned to receive a letter from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies confirming that the funds which were being paid to Blue Water and Rich Brown were derived from legitimate income, and did not represent the proceeds of crime.  For that purpose, Mr.\xc2\xa0De Cort provided to Curtis & Co a source of funds letter relating to the various dividends which were being paid through the chains of various companies, and ultimately to Blue Water and Rich Brown.  He confirmed that:\r   "\xc2\x85 the source of the funds that will be paid by way of dividends by RuAl Trade Limited are derived from interests it holds in and its involvement in the trading activities of aluminium products." Certain of the attendance notes of discussions between the two men and Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis likewise referred (for example) to the fact that "the funds in question constituted properly earned profits arising from trading activities on behalf of RusAl" (corrected by Mr.\xc2\xa0De Cort in evidence to RusAl Group).  But none of this documentation suggested, and certainly did not unequivocally suggest, that, whatever the source of the payments, the character in which either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili were receiving the funds was as ultimate beneficial shareholders of shareholdings in RusAl.  The letter was directed at demonstrating the legitimate source of the monies paid, not at the capacity in which the ultimate recipients were receiving the funds.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also, in this context, relied upon a letter dated 18 September 2003 from Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev "writing as the authorised representative of Mr.\xc2\xa0Arkady Patarkatsishvili" to Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis and Denton Wilde Sapte.  In this letter, Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev wrote:\r   "\xc2\x85 the agreed ultimate beneficial ownership of (and consequent entitlement to dividends arising from) Rual and the interests it holds in the trading activities of aluminium products are held as to 25% Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and 25% by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich". This letter appears (so far as it was possible to tell in the absence of evidence from Mr.\xc2\xa0Fomichev) to have been occasioned by a proposal, which was ultimately acted upon in July 2004, to vest the second 25% tranche of RusAl in Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in order to enable him to explain the receipt by him of substantial sums by way of commission.  I address this topic further below.  The letter was not copied to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (or any of his representatives), and appeared to have been designed to legitimise the funds for the purpose of money-laundering regulations.  The letter does not, of course, support any beneficial ownership of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  It treats the whole 25% as belonging to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.\r   For the above reasons, I conclude that this aspect of the circumstantial evidence does not provide such sufficient support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, that I should reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s direct evidence in relation to the topic.  \r   The sale in 2003 of the first 25% tranche of RusAl shares held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska In 2003, the RusAl group was restructured.  RusAl shares were transferred from the original six offshore companies to a unified holding company, RusAl Holding Limited.  RusAl Holding Limited was incorporated on 7 May 2003.  It was initially owned on a 50:50 basis by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich through Madison, a BVI company ultimately owned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska through Baufinanz, a BVI company ultimately owned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Save where it is necessary to differentiate, I use the term "RusAl" as referring indiscriminately to the previous RusAl entity and RusAl Holding Limited.\r   As I have previously mentioned, in September 2003, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich (through Madison) sold a 25% tranche of RusAl shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska (the purchaser being Baufinanz).  As a result, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s holding in RusAl increased to 75%.  This was effected by two share purchase agreements dated 17 September 2003, the first between Madison and Baufinanz, and the second between various companies respectively controlled by Messrs Abramovich and Deripaska, pursuant to which Madison and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s other companies sold a total of 25% of RusAl Holding and RusAl (half of its holding), together with certain other assets, to entities ultimately owned and/or controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  The price was $1.825 billion, of which $1.578 billion related to the 25% of RusAl and the balance to other assets.  Completion of both agreements took place on 30 September 2003.  Neither of the two share purchase agreements said anything in relation to the further 25% stake in RusAl.  \r   On the same date, a Deed of Pre-Emption and Option dated 30 September 2003 ("the Deed of Pre-Emption") was executed as between Madison and Baufinanz.  Pursuant to section 2, Madison granted Baufinanz a right of pre-emption in the event of an offer by a third party, and pursuant to section 3, an option to purchase in the event of a change of ownership, in relation to the rest of Madison\'s stake in RusAl Holding.  In the event that a third party made an offer, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska could elect either to match that offer, or propose different terms.  If Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s alternative terms were not acceptable, then he either had to match the third-party offer or let the shares go to the third-party.  In the event that there was a change of ownership or control, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska could propose a price for the shares.  The parties would then negotiate in good faith.  However if, ultimately, the parties could not agree, the matter was to be resolved by expert determination.\r   At or about the same time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to amendments being made to the corporate constitutions of the companies that were holding RusAl, to remove any right of veto which a minority 25% stake in those companies might otherwise enjoy.  At the same time various corporate resolutions were passed, so as to ensure that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s nominees were appointed as directors of those companies.\r   Although Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not involved in any way in the sale of the first 25% tranche of RusAl shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, and none of the documentation mentioned his name, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that a number of features surrounding the sale supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili indeed had an interest in 25% of RusAl.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted as follows [546] :\r   "1380.\tIn short, it is Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that: (1) \tIn the summer of 2003 he reached an agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to sell the entire 50% stake in RusAl to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska at a fixed price ($1.825 billion for the first 25% stake plus 2 other assets;  and $450 million for the second 25% stake); (2) \tHowever, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska did not have sufficient cash to acquire the entire 50% stake in RusAl in one go; (3) \tThe agreement to sell the entire 50% stake was therefore not legally documented at that time;  instead, all that was legally documented was the sale of the first tranche and an option agreement in respect of the second tranche. 1381.\tThere are, yet again, real difficulties with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s explanation which suggest that his evidence on this issue is very unlikely to be the truth.  In particular: (1) \tHis explanation cannot be squared with the evidence Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska previously gave in his litigation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney as to why it was that the RusAl sales were conducted in two stages. (2) His evidence cannot be squared with the contemporaneous contractual documentation, suggesting, as it does, that there had been no agreement reached between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in the summer of 2003, regarding either a sale of the second tranche, or an overall sale price for the entire 50% stake in RusAl. (3) \tThe agreement to sell the entire 50% stake was therefore not legally documented at that time;  instead, all that was legally documented was the sale of the first tranche and an option agreement in respect of the second tranche." Thus, Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that, from a common sense perspective, it was commercially inconceivable that, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich really was entitled to dispose of the whole of the 50% RusAl tranche in 2003, he would only have disposed of half the stake (i.e. 25%), leaving himself as an unprotected minority at the mercy of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, of whom even Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich said in evidence "like to squeeze his partners".  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s story about 2003 was bogus, and the far more credible explanation was that the remaining 25% tranche was not Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s to sell, because it belonged to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  That, said Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz, was consistent with the evidence Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had previously given in his litigation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Michael Cherney as to why it was that the RusAl sales were conducted in two stages, and what had been publicly said in the media "by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s own spokesman";  moreover, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence could not be squared with the contemporaneous contractual documentation, suggesting, as it does, that there had been no agreement reached between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in the summer of 2003, regarding either a sale of the second tranche, or an overall sale price for the entire 50% stake in RusAl.\r   Whilst, arguably, on one analysis, the 2003 sale documentation did not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that, in the summer of 2003, he had agreed to sell to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska the entirety of Madison\'s 50% interest in RusAl, I nevertheless find, based on both the written and oral evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Bulygin, much of which was heavily challenged in cross-examination, that, in commercial terms, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s account of the deal between himself and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was correct.\r   In summary, I find the relevant facts to have been as follows:\r   i)\tIn February 2003, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich visited Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and told him in general terms that he was thinking of terminating all his joint ventures with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and selling out to him.  These included not merely RusAl but also joint ventures in a car manufacturing business and an energy business.  Although Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had not made up his mind at this time as to whether he would actually sell out to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, their respective management teams were clearly finding it difficult to work together.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s reasons for this decision had nothing to do with either Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky or Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Apart from the fact that his team was finding it difficult to work with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s team, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich took the view that his investment in the aluminium business had paid off sufficiently and he was committed to a new project in the oil industry, upon which he wanted to focus.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and he had different understandings about the future development of the business, that he had formed the impression that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was "trying to squeeze us out" and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska preferred to work "solo" in the sense of wanting to make all the decisions on his own.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich appreciated that he would have to settle the outstanding question of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s commission, as he had played a significant role in the original acquisition of aluminium as well as providing  krysha  assistance in relation to the problems in the aluminium industry.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was not happy about Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s intention to leave the aluminium industry as, so Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had various ongoing projects in relation to which he hoped to enter further commission.  But no suggestion was made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at the meeting that he, or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had any interest in RusAl shares. ii)\tThat the settlement of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s outstanding commission was the subject of discussion at this meeting was supported by the fact that in April 2003, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili appears to have instructed Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis to draft a "subject to contract" "Memorandum of Understanding", as between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili providing for the transfer of the shares in a company owning 25% of RusAl to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, for nil consideration.  The prospect of the payment of commission would have been likely to have raised in Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s mind the usual problem of "legalisation" in the face of Western money-laundering regulations, and it is probable that the Memorandum was produced with that aim in mind. iii)\tThe Memorandum recited that: "50% of the registered  and beneficial interest  in the unencumbered issued share capital of [RusAl] is registered in the names of companies or entities controlled by [Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich]" [Emphasis added.] I comment that no reference was made to any beneficial ownership held in such shares by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, which, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case, the two men clearly had at this stage.  The Memorandum went on to provide that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would procure that the entire issued share capital of a company owning the registered and beneficial interest in 25% of the total issued share capital of RusAl, would be transferred for a nominal consideration to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili or such third party as he should nominate;  and that thereafter Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili would procure that such nominee would sell the 25% stake in RusAl to such other company, corporation or entity as Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should nominate for a total aggregate sum in $, the amount of which was left blank;  subject to a condition that the purchaser would simultaneously enter into a share option agreement permitting Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s nominee to re-purchase up to 12.5% (of the issued share capital of RusAl) at the same cost for a period of time expiring on the fifth anniversary of the share option agreement. iv)\tBut whatever the intent of the Memorandum so far as structuring the payment of a fee to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and presenting it as a share sale transaction, was concerned, and insofar as anything can be derived from a draft document that was not shown to, or negotiated with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side, what was of relevance in relation to the document was that: a)\tit did not mention or refer to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  and  b)\tit was inconsistent with either man having any beneficial interest in RusAl shares in April 2003.  That was not merely because of the absence of any reference to such interest in the recital, but also because the operative provision relating to the transfer did not suggest that the transaction was merely vesting legal title in an existing beneficial owner of either the RusAl shares themselves, or of the shares of the Abramovich company holding such shares. v)\tAccording to the evidence of both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, supported by that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Bulygin and Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler, in the summer of 2003 a commercial deal was orally agreed between the two men personally that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska would buy Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich out from all their various joint ventures in a number of businesses for $2.3 billion.  But Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was unable to raise financing from banks in such a large sum at that stage.  He had been able to raise only about $1.9 billion in funds.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich described it as follows in cross-examination: "We agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska that we\'ll finish our relationship because the relationship between our managing teams were very stressed, we knew it wouldn\'t lead to anything good and that would put an end to our joint business.  Our joint business consisted of several assets:   RusAl was one of them, Ruspromavto was another and Irkutskenergo was another.  Oleg initially wanted to acquire RusAl and he wanted to acquire the rest when he would get money.  So he would buy the rest, acquire the rest later. But because these assets, Ruspromavto and Irkutskpromavto (sic), I didn\'t need that at all. Irkutskenergo was acquired for RusAl.  That is the power  station that generates electricity for the aluminium smelter.  Ruspromavto is just a collection of car plants, it was a hobby for Oleg.  You know, it was a hobby for him and, as a mate, I agreed that I would participate in that with him.  It wasn\'t much money, but I never thought that this business would grow into General Motors;  I didn\'t see that future for this business from the very beginning.  But I supported Oleg in the initiative, in this vehicle manufacture, as much as I could. And when the question arose that we would finish our joint activity, he said -- he proposed, "Buy RusAl and let\'s leave the rest".  And I said, "No, no, no, let\'s agree that I would sell everything to you but..." So we agreed that 50 per cent of RusAl would be sold but that we would structure the deal in the following way:  initially he would get 25 per cent of RusAl and all the other stuff we held together, Irkutskenergo, Ruspromavto;  and later, when he raises the funds, he\'d get the second part of RusAl for $150 [547]  million on condition that he manages to pull that deal within a year [548] ." vi)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s evidence on this topic included the following passage:   "A.\tSorry, and the total amount, the total price of the transaction, if I remember correctly, for all the businesses was about US$2.3 billion, a little bit more than that, a little bit more than US$2.3 billion.  And so, therefore, those were difficult negotiations in terms of what assets will be bought out by myself at the initial stage and that\'s why it was structured the way it was done. Q.\t\tMr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, I suggest to you the reason that at that stage you did not acquire a full 50 per cent from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was because you were told that only 25 per cent was available.  Do you dispute that?  A.\tNo, the reason is that I simply did not have sufficient funds available to me, I did not find sufficient funds immediately, and I can say that because I was actually handling that transaction [549] ." vii)\tAs he also explained, the car manufacturing business and the energy business were "highly politically sensitive", which was another reason why Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was concerned to ensure their immediate sale and not leave those assets over to the second stage: "Q.\tHowever full your explanation may be now, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, the reason you didn\'t buy the full 50 per cent was because you were told that only 25 per cent was available.  That is right, is it not? A.\tWell, what I can do is only reiterate that, for me, the negotiations with banks were very difficult and, as a result of that, I was able to raise about 1.9 -- almost $1.9 billion, and Abramovich then asked me to first put an end to our relationship with respect to the power business and the car manufacturing business because they were highly politically sensitive businesses and plants, if I can put it that way.  And when he entered that complex oil-related deal he did not want to have any conflict of interest with the authorities." [550] Given the absence of financing, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not prepared, at that stage, to sell the second 25% of RusAl to him, and leave the purchase price outstanding.  So the two men agreed that the aluminium business RusAl would be divided and sold in two parts instead.  The price for the interests comprising the first part of the sale was agreed at $1.865 billion and the price of the second part (the remaining 25% tranche of RusAl shares) was agreed at $450 million.   It was submitted on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that the account given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was "quite obviously untrue" and that neither of them had any satisfactory explanation in cross-examination for the fact that the Deed of Pre-Emption between Madison and Baufinanz, did not contain a fixed price for the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares and did not give a right to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to purchase the shares at his discretion.  It was also submitted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had no satisfactory explanation for what he had said in his witness statement in the Cherney litigation.  \r   As to the first point, I accept, based on the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser, the solicitor acting for Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska who drafted the Deed of Pre-Emption, that neither Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s nor Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s business representatives conveyed to the lawyers, who documented the arrangement, the essential commercial terms of the deal, namely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had a right to purchase a second 25% tranche at a fixed price of $450 million;  and that if they had done so, the Deed of Pre-Emption would have been drafted very differently.  However, although the point clearly raised serious questions about whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska were indeed telling the truth about their agreement, I am satisfied, having heard both men in the witness box, and notwithstanding the slight inconsistencies in their evidence, and the absence of any written record, that they did indeed reach the commercial deal to which both men referred.  Moreover, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Malek pointed out in his closing submissions, to a certain extent, at least, the documentation reflected the agreed but, staged, sale structure;  it was Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich who wanted to exit his partnership with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, not Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska who wanted to purchase the shares from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  A right of pre-emption given to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in the event that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich found an alternative purchaser (rather than a right to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to control the timing of the sale) was consistent with that.  Moreover Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was protected by the fact that he had 75% control of RusAl, with no minority blocking rights in the various holding companies.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich had been compensated by the substantial control premium paid for the first 25% tranche.\r   I find there to have been nothing surprising or questionable in the fact that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to the alterations to the relevant provisions relating to the exercise of minority rights in the companies owning RusAl shares, once the sale of the first 25% tranche had been agreed.  It was clear from evidence that effective control of RusAl\'s management and business had passed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska at this stage.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich himself described, the two men agreed to terminate a previously existing shareholders\' agreement governing their activities as shareholders in RusAl, at the first stage of the transaction so that Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska would essentially acquire all management rights for RusAl immediately upon the sale of the first 25% tranche.  It was not surprising, in those circumstances, that a substantial control premium was paid by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska for the first 25% tranche.  Indeed, that appeared to me to have been consistent with the commercial deal arrived at between the two principals rather than inconsistent with it.  There was certainly no evidence to support the assertion made in paragraph 1399 of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written closing submissions that:\r   "1399.\tSuch conduct on the part of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich is, however, entirely consistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich seeking to appropriate for himself (and his partner Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler) a substantial control premium for the sale of the first 25% stake in RusAl, whilst leaving his remaining partners - the disgraced oligarchs in exile - in the lurch and at the mercy of Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska." As to the second point, I consider that Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s argument attached too much emphasis to the statement made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska in a witness statement in a jurisdiction dispute with Mr.\xc2\xa0Cherney.  The passage read as follows:\r   "Originally I made an offer in 2003 for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s full 50% interest, but I was told that only 25% was available.  I never heard from Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky at that time or subsequently with any complaint about the transaction." I comment that the witness statement did not refer to the reason for the "unavailability" of the remaining 25% as being the fact that it was owned, or subject to rights claimed over it, by a third party.  As Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska explained, the remaining 25% was not available at that stage, because Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not prepared to sell it on terms that the purchase price was left outstanding, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska did not have the funds to purchase it.  Accordingly I do not consider that this witness statement undermines Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s account. I attach no weight to the press articles relied upon by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.\r   In the circumstances I conclude that the evidence relating to the sale of the first 25% of RusAl shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska does not support Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claim that he had an interest in RusAl.\r   The sale in 2004 of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska via Cliren Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky contended that the sale of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares supported his case that he had an interest in RusAl.  In order to understand Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s arguments in relation to this issue it is necessary to set them out in some detail.  In his written closing submissions, the argument was put as follows [551] :\r   "(1) \tThroughout the second RusAl sale, everyone proceeded on the basis that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not the ultimate beneficial owner of the remaining 25% stake in RusAl.   (2) \tIndeed, throughout the second RusAl sale, everyone involved in the second RusAl sale transaction recognised that there was at least one, if not two, other beneficial owners of the remaining 25% stake in RusAl:  one of whom was certainly Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.   (3) \tMoreover, a number of the participants in the second RusAl sale were clearly of the view that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was either a trustee, or at the very least acting in a fiduciary capacity vis-\xc3\xa0-vis the real beneficial owner or owners.   (4) \tThe only confusion (if there really was any) was as to whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was the other beneficial owner, alongside Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.   (5) \tIn particular: (a)\tMr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s team were of the view that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was also a beneficial owner, alongside Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili:  but were reluctant to do anything further to document Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s ownership, in particular because of representations previously made to banks.  They therefore proposed a more limited acknowledgement from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich:  that whomever Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili said was the beneficial owner was in fact the beneficial owner;  coupled with a warranty from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that he was the sole beneficial owner.  In this way, they hoped to transfer the risk of the warranty being proved false (in the event that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky did raise a successful claim), from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.   (b) \tMr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s team were originally instructed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was also a beneficial owner, alongside Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  However, they were prepared to live with the acknowledgement from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and the warranty from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that he was the sole beneficial owner.  In doing so, however, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s representatives made it quite clear (in e-mails saying as much) that they had not made any enquiries into the matter, that they were assuming that the position with regard to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had been resolved one way or another, and that they would not cap Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s liability in the event that the warranty proved untrue.   (c) \tMr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s team clearly also understood that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was a beneficial owner, alongside Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and entitled to 50% of the RusAl proceeds that would flow through the bank accounts to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  However, in order to get the deal done (and as already had been suggested by Mr.\xc2\xa0Curtis, as recorded in the Curtis Notes of 23 August 2003), they were prepared to structure the transaction so that it appeared that only Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was the beneficial owner if that made it easier for the other parties.  They therefore went along with the proposal from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s representatives (i.e. the acknowledgement and the warranty referred to above).  Because there were clear risks attached to this, however, prior to closing, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s team required Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to sign off on an official release to them, in which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili indicated that he fully understood the risks that he was undertaking in the event that the warranty he was giving (about Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky not being involved) was untrue."  In Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written opening submissions, and in cross-examination of certain witnesses, the suggestion was made that those people who were involved in the sale of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares, deliberately, and dishonestly, tried to "airbrush" Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky out of the documentation relating to the transaction, at the insistence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and his representatives.  What was effectively a conspiracy allegation was not proceeded with in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s closing submissions, where the argument was presented in the somewhat modified form.  This was to the effect that, rather than admit the truth that he was not the beneficial owner of a 25% stake in RusAl, but that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky were the true owners of that stake, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was forced to argue that he was prepared to execute false documents in order to deceive Western banks as part of a money-laundering conspiracy to enable Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to transfer funds into the West [552] .\r   The evidence relating to this issue was comprehensively set out in the parties\' written closing submissions, and in extensive detail.  I should acknowledge, in particular, the assistance provided by a helpful and focused schedule at Annex III to the Family Defendants\' submissions.\r   I now turn to consider that evidence and to set out my findings and conclusions in relation to it.  Before I do so, I make two points.  First, it is important to bear in mind, when considering whether the events relating to the sale of the second tranche indeed supported Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case that he had an interest in RusAl shares, that in these proceedings such an interest could only be demonstrated on the basis of the alleged 1995 Agreement, the alleged 1999 RusAl Agreement, the contribution of his alleged Sibneft profits to the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets, and/or what Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky alleged was agreed at the Dorchester Hotel meeting.  The court in these proceedings is not addressing the issue whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had some interest as a result of, or under, a bilateral partnership agreement or other private arrangements with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili extending to all or some of their business assets.  Second, it is not necessary for me to rehearse every single evidential point raised on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and I do not do so;  however, I have taken them into account in reaching my conclusions as set out below.\r   Findings in respect of the evidence relating to the sale of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares There was no dispute that the contractual documents of transfer, whereby Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska acquired the second 25% tranche of shares in RusAl,  on their face  show that:\r   i)\tthe second 25% tranche was transferred by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s company Madison to a BVI company, ultimately controlled by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, called Cliren Investment Limited ("Cliren"); ii)\tCliren then sold the tranche to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s holding company, Eagle;  and  iii)\tas part of the transaction, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili represented and warranted to RusAl and Eagle that he was the sole and beneficial owner of the RusAl shares transferred.   I now set out my findings as to the facts leading up to the conclusion of the contractual documentation of these arrangements.\r   Following their discussion in February 2003, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich visited Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Georgia in October 2003.  He told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili about the sale of the first 25% tranche of RusAl to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, which had taken place in September 2003.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich explained that, although he had officially sold only 25% of his RusAl shares, he had in reality agreed to sell out everything to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and had essentially now exited the aluminium business.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was upset about this, because he had wanted Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to stay involved in the aluminium business as Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had hoped to act as an "enabler" on a number of other deals, so he saw it as a lost opportunity for future business.  As in February 2003, there was no mention or assertion by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that he owned interests in RusAl or the pre-merger aluminium assets.  There was no issue as between the two men that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had indeed earned his fee for helping Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich acquire the pre-merger aluminium assets and that it would be considerably more than the "floor" price of $115 million which they had previously agreed.  As an opening move in the negotiations, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili asked Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich for $700 million;  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich counter-offered with a figure of $400 million, and ultimately, either at the meeting or thereafter, they compromised on a figure of $540 million for what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich referred to as Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s "cut".  That figure was subsequently increased to $585 million for reasons which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not able to recall.  He explained that it was typical of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that, even in their last transaction, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili managed to get the deal renegotiated so that he ended up receiving more than they had originally agreed.  \r   The reason why Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to pay such a substantial sum to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili reflected the fact that the aluminium holdings had been an extremely successful deal for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had made that possible;  first by bringing about the original acquisition of the assets, and secondly because of the valuable assistance which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had in fact provided in connection with the aluminium business.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich also explained that there was his own reputation to maintain, as a person who kept his end of the bargain and that, given the history of their relationship and the services Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had provided, he wanted to end his  krysha  relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili on a friendly footing.  No mention was made during the course of this discussion about Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky expecting to receive any money for alleged services in relation to RusAl or in relation to the aluminium business in general.  \r   At some subsequent stage, either in late 2003 or early 2004, he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili discussed what Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich referred to as the "legalisation" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s remuneration;  the two men agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would "make [Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili] the owner" of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s remaining 25% tranche of RusAl shares as soon as Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was prepared to purchase the second tranche, with a view to the shares being immediately sold to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was well aware that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was particularly keen to receive the money into Western bank accounts and that, in order to do so, he had to satisfy the anti-money-laundering and other requirements of Western banks.  It is probable that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili suggested the proposal whereby RusAl shares would be transferred into his name.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich appreciated that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could not just receive such a large amount of cash with no lawful explanation for its receipt;  but, although Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich was not certain when it would be possible to close the deal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, he thought that the transaction would present an opportunity to make a large payment to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in a way that would avoid the need to use an intermediary to transfer the funds.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich told Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that it would be necessary to discuss the proposal with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska, who, he anticipated, because of his distrust of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, would not necessarily be keen on participating in such an arrangement.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili could not travel to Russia to conduct the necessary face-to-face negotiations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  In addition, he did not have a sufficiently good relationship with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to negotiate directly with him.  For these reasons, in early 2004, he asked one of his closest friends, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, to participate in the negotiation process with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich on his behalf.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili explained to Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov that he was owed substantial sums by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and that this debt was to be settled from the sale proceeds of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares, which was to be sold to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov had a good relationship with both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili trusted him.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili agreed to remunerate Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov for his services and, at the same time, to fulfil what apparently was an outstanding promise on Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s part to compensate Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov for the low sale price which the latter had received for the transfer of his interests in the pre-merger aluminium assets.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was not entirely happy about the prospect of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili being involved in the transaction.  However, he was prepared to go along with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s proposals for commercial reasons, since, according to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, it was important for Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska to acquire the RusAl shares for $450 million.  On the face of the contractual documents, of course, there might have been an opportunity for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to increase the price.  Unknown to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich at the time, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili apparently was paid an extra $15 million by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  \r   In the following year, a working group was formed on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s side to negotiate the terms of the sale to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska of the second 25% tranche.  It included Mr.\xc2\xa0Tenenbaum, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, Ms.\xc2\xa0Khudyk and (from 8 June 2004) Mr.\xc2\xa0De Cort.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was represented by a Mr.\xc2\xa0Mishakov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser, a solicitor at Bryan Cave.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, acting on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, instructed his then senior adviser, Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky, to oversee the structural and legal aspects of the deal.  At an early stage, Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky instructed a corporate lawyer at Akin Gump, a Mr.\xc2\xa0Faekov, to assist him.  Contrary to the assertion made in Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s written opening submissions, Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov was not also acting on Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s behalf in the transaction.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky\'s evidence, supported in the event by that of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky were only acting on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.\r   The detailed negotiations took place mainly between 9 June 2004 and 20 July 2004.  A number of draft agreements and memoranda were circulated.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, as he accepted in evidence, played no direct part in the negotiations.  He was not shown the transaction documents either in draft or as executed.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and his team took their instructions from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili alone.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky gave no instructions to Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov or his team and had no contact with them.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence that he understood that he was acting solely on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was not involved and did not have any interest in the 25% RusAl stake, or in the proceeds of its sale.  \r   However, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky heard about the proposed sale.  He told  Vedomosti , in an interview on or about 2 June 2004 that he was the beneficial owner of the 25% RusAl stake still held by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s companies, that he disapproved of the sale and would go to court if necessary.  A similar article also appeared in the  Moscow Times  on 3 June 2004.  This public assertion by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky disrupted the negotiations.  It gave rise to the potential problem, so far as Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s advisers were concerned, that, after the sale had taken place, there might be a challenge to the transaction by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky.  That had a significant influence on the form of the contractual documents ultimately agreed.  However, I find, contrary to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s assertions, that the form of the contractual documentation was not the result of the lawyers airbrushing Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky out of the picture;  rather it was the result of the lawyers, having received instructions from both Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had never been in the picture in the first place, needing to address the problem of his public assertion of interest in the 25% RusAl stake.  This they did by including express warranties, representations and indemnities in the sale documentation to protect Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  \r   The contractual documents relating to the sale by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s holding company, Madison, of its stake in RusAl Holding, were all dated or purportedly dated 20 July 2004 and were as follows:\r   i)\tA Deed of Option Waiver was entered into as between Madison and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s holding company, Eagle.  Under this instrument, Eagle consented to the transfer by Madison of 12,500 shares (the second 25% tranche) in RusAl Holding and the business interests represented thereby, to Cliren.  It was agreed that, upon completion of the transfer, the Deed of Pre-Emption dated 30 September 2003 between Madison and Eagle would be terminated.   ii)\tA Deed of Settlement was entered into as between Madison and Cliren.  Under this instrument Madison transferred the 12,500 shares in RusAl Holding to Cliren.  This was said to be in consideration of, inter alia, various representations and warranties for releases in respect of the "participation" in the purchase of the underlying aluminium assets for "facilitating or procuring the contribution of substantial assets and value" to RusAl, its shareholders and predecessors. iii)\tMadison and Cliren entered into a Deed of Accounting and Release (Dividends) pursuant to which Madison agreed to pay Cliren $135 million in instalments, commencing with a payment of $90 million within 90 days.  This was said to be in consideration of certain releases granted by Cliren to Madison. iv)\tA Deed of Release was made between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  Under this instrument, each of them released the other and their respective affiliates and associated persons (as defined) from any and all obligations they might have to each other in respect, inter alia, of any rights, title or interest they might have to, or in respect of, any shares or securities in RusAl Holding or any company in which RusAl Holding had a direct or indirect majority shareholding or equity participation.   v)\tA share purchase and sale agreement was made between Eagle and Cliren.  Under this instrument Eagle agreed to buy from Cliren the 12,500 shares in RusAl Holding for $450 million. vi)\tA Deed of Guarantee was made between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Eagle.  Under this instrument Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili guaranteed the performance by Cliren of its obligations under the share purchase and sale agreement with Eagle.   vii)\tA Beneficial Owner Deed of Release was made between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili (designated as the "Beneficial Owner"), Cliren, RusAl Holding and Eagle.  Under this instrument, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili represented and warranted that he was the sole and beneficial owner of the RusAl shares.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Cliren, and their respective affiliates and associated persons, released RusAl Holding and Eagle and their affiliates and associated persons, inter alia, from any and all claims which they might have in respect of any shares or securities in RusAl Holding or any of its affiliates or other persons connected to RusAl Holding (as defined to include RusAl or any RusAl business), or any claim arising out of or in connection with the purchase by them of the "25% interest in the joint venture" currently represented by the shares in RusAl Holding.   viii)\tA Deed of Acknowledgement was made between Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  Under this instrument Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich acknowledged to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska that in relation to the shares in RusAl Holding and the "Business Interests" represented thereby (as defined in the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release) he had only had discussions, arrangements and understandings with, and he dealt only with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, and no one else.  Accordingly, whoever Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili identified in the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release as the beneficial owner of the shares and the business interests represented thereby, to the best of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s knowledge and belief must be the beneficial owner thereof. The effect of these transactions was that the second 25% RusAl tranche passed to Eagle, via Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s company, Cliren.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili received the $585 million commission agreed with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich:\r   i)\t$450 million derived from the sale to Eagle of the 25% tranche that Madison had transferred to Cliren for that purpose;  and  ii)\tthe balance of $135 million was paid as a purported dividend under the Deed of Accounting and Release.  The $135 million was not in fact a dividend.  It was a balancing figure required to make up the excess of the agreed commission over the amount which Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska was willing to pay for the shares.  It enabled Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to document the full $585 million when it was paid into Cliren\'s account. The contractual documentation on its face was therefore wholly inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky having had any interest in the RusAl shares based on the claims made in this action.  For that reason Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz relied upon correspondence and other documents generated during the early stages of the negotiations for the transaction which, he said, demonstrated that there were two beneficial owners of the RusAl shares, and that those two persons were Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   However before turning to that correspondence, I address a point made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz in relation to the warranties given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release, and the confirmation of those warranties given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in the Deed of Acknowledgement entered into with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  In the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili gave a warranty of historic title in relation to the RusAl shares as from 15 March 2000, to the date of completion, namely July 2004.  The warranty was in the following terms, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili being "the Beneficial Owner", the "Purchaser" being Eagle and "the Company" being RusAl Holding:\r   "The Beneficial Owner represents and warrants to the Purchaser and the Company that as of Completion: 3.1.1\tduring the Period, the Beneficial Owner was the sole and ultimate beneficial owner of the Business Interests;  and 3.1.2\tsuch Business Interests were not held by the Beneficial Owner for the benefit of any other Person and no Encumbrances or Claims were imposed or asserted in respect of any such Business Interests during the Period." In the Deed of Acknowledgement Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich represented to Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska that, in relation to the RusAl Holding shares (including predecessor shares) and Business Interests represented thereby as defined, he had "only had discussions, arrangements and understandings with, and he only interacted and dealt with the Beneficial Owner" (i.e. Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili);  and that, accordingly, whoever Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had said in the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release was the beneficial owner of the RusAl Holding shares, predecessor shares and the Business Interests represented thereby, to the best of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s knowledge and belief "must be the beneficial owner thereof".  Whilst these warranties or representations were clearly inconsistent with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky having had any beneficial interest in the RusAl shares, they were clearly inconsistent on their face with Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had had no interest in the RusAl Holding shares, or the previous RusAl shares, other than that interest which was specifically created under the Deed Of Settlement as between Madison and Cliren, under which Madison transferred the 12,500 shares in RusAl holding to Cliren.  The warranties were also on their face inconsistent with the evidence given by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Shvidler and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska about the Dorchester Hotel meeting and the arrangements that led to the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets. \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz placed great reliance on this point;  he submitted that it was inconceivable that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would have agreed to give what, on Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s case, was clearly an untrue warranty, for the dishonest purpose of assisting Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to persuade Western banks that the substantial commission payments were in fact the proceeds of the sale of RusAl shares owned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz submitted that the reality was consistent with the warranties, namely that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich never was the sole beneficial owner of the 25% stake in RusAl, but rather that he held the stake for and on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  \r   I do not accept that submission.  Whilst I have carefully considered it, in the ultimate analysis the evidence does not provide any sufficient reason why I should not accept the clear evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s participation in the aluminium transactions, and his, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s, evidence in relation to the Dorchester Hotel meeting.  The reason why the warranty was drafted in that way was extensively explored in the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser, a witness who was called on subpoena on behalf of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.  He gave a clear explanation as to why he believed, whether rightly or wrongly matters not, that he needed an historic representation and warranty from Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili as to beneficial ownership going back to 15 March 2000, so as to remove the possibility that some third party:\r   "\xc2\x85 might show up, claim to have had an interest some time during that period, and then had asserted a claim against Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska relating to the management of RusAl at that time [553] ." His evidence made it perfectly clear that his insistence on including such a warranty was not because he believed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had any such interest, but rather because he did not know what the precise position was and wanted watertight contractual protection for his clients.  Further, Mr.\xc2\xa0De Cort explained that these matters were documented in separate agreements between principals solely for the purpose of risk allocation, given the claims had been made publicly by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky;  and it was not anticipated that the Deed of Acknowledgement or the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release would need to be shown to third parties such as banks.  What was required for the purposes of anti-money-laundering compliance requirements would have been the documents showing Cliren\'s entitlement to, and sale of, the RusAl shares. Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky claimed that the warranty in the Beneficial Owner Deed of Release that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was the sole beneficial owner of the RusAl shares was known by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have been untrue at the time it was given.  As I have already quoted above, his case was also that "Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s team were of the view that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was also beneficial owner" of a 25% RusAl stake;  and that Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky knew that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had a beneficial interest in RusAl.  In particular, in relation to the negotiations for sale of the second 25% tranche, it was asserted that, given Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky\'s alleged knowledge of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s beneficial interest, "\xc2\x85 it would have been astonishing if Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov was not aware of the position".  In those circumstances, where Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky has relied upon his allegations about Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s alleged knowledge as part of his case, and where Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky was cross-examined on the topic, it is appropriate, as Mr.\xc2\xa0Malek submitted, that I should make findings as to Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s knowledge, notwithstanding Mr.\xc2\xa0Rabinowitz\'s submissions to the contrary.  It will then be a matter of argument in the Chancery proceedings as to whether, and if so to what extent, possibly based on different evidence, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky can pursue the point.\r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence was to the following effect:  that during the negotiations for this agreement, which he conducted with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska on Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s behalf, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had asked him whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was the only principal involved in the deal and whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had any sort of connection with the transaction;  that question had plainly been provoked by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s recent statements to the press;  when Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov raised this query with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, he was assured by him that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky "was not anywhere near the deal";  Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov said that he told Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska this.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska had no recollection of such a conversation [554] , which was not surprising given the passage of time.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov\'s evidence in this respect.  None of this evidence was expressly challenged, although by implication it was, given the nature of Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky\'s cross-examination.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky, who was also involved in these negotiations on Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s behalf, also gave evidence to the effect that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili specifically confirmed to him the accuracy of the position stated in the warranty, at a meeting between the two men in Georgia between 7 and 9 July 2004.  During this visit, Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky explained the overall structure of the transaction and took Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili through the key draft transaction documents.  He specifically highlighted the representations and warranties that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was being asked to give, and explained to him that he could have a potential liability if Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky brought a claim asserting that the sale of the second RusAl tranche infringed his rights.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili confirmed to Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky that he understood that he was acting alone.  The suggestion was put to Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky in cross-examination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili told Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky that the representation was false, but that he would agree to it if that was what it would take to get the RusAl sale transaction done.  It was asserted that Mr.\xc2\xa0Faekov was not a party to the conversation and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky was challenged that he had not recorded it.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky firmly rejected the suggestion that Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili told him that the representation was incorrect.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky\'s evidence on this aspect.  The fact that he did not document his conversations with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was unsurprising;  he was not a lawyer and it was not his usual practice to draw up attendance notes.  Moreover, he followed up his conversation with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili with a "deal approval document" which was drafted by Mr.\xc2\xa0Faekov and set out the final structure of the transaction including a list of all the potential risks involved.  These risks included the possibility that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky might make a claim, but Mr.\xc2\xa0Faekov noted that "we are unaware of facts upon which [Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky] could rely".  Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili signed the document.  \r   Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky also relied upon various communications between the parties\' representatives leading to the 2004 sale, as well as communications passing between Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s advisers and the lawyers acting for the First Zurich Bank concerning an attempt to open a bank account for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili.  Mr.\xc2\xa0Hauser, Ms.\xc2\xa0Panchenko, Mr.\xc2\xa0De Cort, and Mr.\xc2\xa0Streshinsky were cross-examined at length on this documentation in an attempt to establish one or more of the following propositions:\r   i)\tthat the documents demonstrated that there were two beneficial owners of the RusAl 25% tranche and that those owners were Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili; ii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov, either directly or through their representatives, were aware of that fact;  and  iii)\tthat Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was deliberately airbrushed out of the transaction.   These allegations were disputed by those involved.  In my judgment, the evidence, on a full analysis of the documentation, did not establish any of these propositions.  The initial references to two beneficiaries in some of the documents, and in particular to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, largely came about as a result of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s claims in the media and the fact that the transactional lawyers involved initially prepared draft proposals, without having had complete knowledge of the underlying transaction from their principals.   Accordingly I reject Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s argument that the evidence relating to the negotiation and sale of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares supports his case.\r   The interviews with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky sought to claim support for his case that he had an interest in RusAl from the Patarkatsishvili proofing materials.  The notes of interviews with Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili recorded that he told Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors in 2005 and 2007 that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky each had a 50/50 interest in RusAl (as well as in Sibneft, a topic which I have already addressed).  By the date of their first visit to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors had been told by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky that he alleged that he and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had once held a joint interest in Sibneft and RusAl;  and they had already been instructed by Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky to investigate potential claims against Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to, amongst other matters, RusAl  and Sibneft.  I have described, in an earlier section of this judgment, the circumstances in which the proofing materials were compiled, and that by the time of the interviews, both Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili and Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had made numerous representations to Western professionals which had allowed funds to be received by them in the West and which would have been wholly undermined, if Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili had departed from them.  These representations had been supported by documents produced for the purpose;  for example the fleeting interest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in RusAl had been "documented" in the form of the agreements with Madison, Cliren and Eagle;  and the alleged interest of Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in Sibneft had been "documented" in the form of the Devonia Agreement.  In those circumstances it would have been embarrassing and difficult for Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to have given a different story to Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s solicitors as to the source of the funds;  it would, or could, have harmed both their interests.  It would not have been at all surprising if he had not chosen to explain the true reason for the receipt of such substantial funds from Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich.\r   Accordingly, whilst the Patarkatsishvili proofing materials on their face provide support for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s case in relation to this issue, for reasons similar to those set out in relation to Sibneft, I do not regard them as having sufficient evidential weight to persuade me that I should reject the evidence of Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska and Mr.\xc2\xa0Anisimov in relation to RusAl.\r   Conclusion in relation to Issue B2, Issue 17 in the Agreed List of Issues and Overlap Issue 2 Accordingly, I conclude that there was no agreement made at the Dorchester Hotel meeting (or indeed at any other time) involving Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky, that he, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska would pool their assets in the Russian aluminium industry.\r   Conclusion in relation to Overlap Issue 5 Overlap Issue 5 was defined as follows:\r   "Was the $585 million received by Cliren following the sale of the Second Tranche of RusAl shares (as defined at paragraph 29 of the Abramovich List of Issues): (a) \t\xc2\x85 (i) \t$450 million of sale proceeds and (ii) \t$135 million of outstanding dividend payments from RusAl?;  and/or (b)\tA payment made by Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili at the request of Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili in return for him providing assistance and protection to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s acquisition of assets in the Russian aluminium industry? I have already addressed the facts relating to this issue in the context of my determination of Issue B2 above.  My conclusion in relation to Overlap Issue 5 therefore follows my findings in relation to the former issue.\r   Executive summary and conclusion in relation to Overlap Issue 5 The commercial rationale for the $585 million received by Cliren following the sale of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares was to discharge Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s obligation to pay an agreed commission to Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili for assistance provided by Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili to Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich in relation to the acquisition of the pre-merger aluminium assets and more generally in connection with the aluminium business.  As a mechanism to effect this payment, Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s company, Cliren, became for a very short period of time a shareholder in RusAl Holding and immediately sold those shares on to Eagle, a company owned by Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska.  In that limited sense only, $450 million of the $585 million received by Cliren following the sale of the second 25% tranche of RusAl shares represented proceeds of sale.  The balance of $135 million was paid as a purported dividend under the Deed of Accounting and Release but, although that was the method of payment, in fact none of the money paid to Cliren represented dividends to which Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili was entitled by virtue of any shareholding acquired prior to July 2004.\r   Section XVI - Issue B3:  Was it expressly agreed at the Dorchester Hotel meeting on 13 March 2000 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would hold Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interest in the aluminium business created by the merger of those assets with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili under an English law trust? Introduction Issue B3 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, is: \r   "Was it expressly agreed at the Dorchester Hotel on 30 March, 2000 that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would hold their interest in the aluminium business created by the merger of those assets with Mr.\xc2\xa0Deripaska\'s aluminium interests on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili under an English law trust?" This issue corresponds to the trust element of  Issue 19(1) in the Agreed List of Issues, namely:\r   "If the above agreements were made:  (1) Was it expressly agreed that the trust and/or fiduciary duties ... would be governed by English law?"  It also corresponds to Overlap Issue 3. This issue only arose if I had concluded that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky was intended to have an interest in the merged aluminium business.  I have found that he was not so entitled.  Accordingly, the question of whether Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich agreed to hold that interest on trust, under whatever law, does not strictly arise.  However I can say that, in any event, I did not accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky\'s evidence that there was an express agreement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich should hold any such interest under an English law trust.  I accept Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich\'s evidence that he made no agreement with Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili that he would hold their alleged interest in the merged RusAl business on trust for the two men.\r   Executive summary and conclusion in relation to Issue B3 The issue as to whether there was any express agreement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili\'s interest in the aluminium assets should be held on an English law trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich did not arise, in the light of my previous determination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no such interest.  In any event, the evidence did not support any agreement that Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich would hold any such interest on trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili whether under English law or otherwise.\r   Section XVII - Issue B4:  If it was agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have an interest in the merged business, but there was no express agreement about the law governing the arrangements between him, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili relating to that business, then what law did govern those arrangements? Introduction Issue B4 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, is:\r   " Issue B4 :  If it was agreed that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky would have an interest in the merged business, but there was no express agreement about the law governing the arrangements between him, Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili relating to that business, then what law did govern those arrangements?" This issue corresponds to Issue 19(2) in the Agreed List of Issues, namely:\r   "If [there was no express agreement that the trust and/or fiduciary duties and/or the contract would be governed by English law]:  \xc2\x85 was there an implied choice of English law, or was English law the system of law with which the trust and/or the fiduciary duties and/or the contract were most closely connected?"  It also corresponds to Overlap Issue 3. Executive summary and conclusion in relation to Issue B.4 The issue as to whether there was an implied choice of English law, or whether English law was the system of law with which the alleged trust and/or fiduciary duties and/or the contract were most closely connected, simply did not arise for consideration, in the light of my previous determination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no such interest, and that there was no agreement to hold such interest on trust.  It would be inappropriate to decide such an issue on a wholly hypothetical basis.\r   Section XVIII - Issue B5:  Would the alleged express RusAl trust be good even in English law? Introduction Issue B5 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, is:\r   "Would the alleged express RusAl trust be good even in English law?" This issue corresponds to Issue 20 of the Agreed List of Issues:\r   "If the above agreements in respect of RusAl were made, did they create a valid express trust under English law by which Mr.\xc2\xa0Abramovich, as trustee, held either:  (1) 50% of his rights of ownership and/or control in relation to the RusAl shares;  or (2) his rights of ownership and/or control in relation to 25% of the RusAl shares;  or (3) 50% of the RusAl shares ultimately owned and/or controlled by him on express trust for Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky and Mr.\xc2\xa0Patarkatsishvili?" It also corresponds to Overlap Issue 3. Executive summary and conclusion in relation to Issue B5 The issue as to whether the alleged express RusAl trust would be good even in English law did not arise for consideration, in the light of my previous determination that Mr.\xc2\xa0Berezovsky had no such interest.  It would be inappropriate to decide such an issue on a wholly hypothetical basis.\r   Section XIX - Issue B6:  If there was no valid express trust, was there a resulting or constructive trust governed by English law? Introduction Issue B6 of the liability issues, as I have defined them, is:\r   "\xc2\x85 If there was no valid express trust, was there a resulting or constructive trust governed by English law?"
